DOC.HEAD: Chief Fusion Research Nowhere To Be Found As Critical Review Deadline Nears
DOC.TEXT: The University of Utah has another week to persuade the state that it invested wisely in nuclear fusion but is facing an unexpected snag: Its chief researcher, electrochemist B. Stanley Pons, has vanished. Pons and British colleague Martin Fleischmann announced in March 1989 tat they had achieved a sustained nuclear fusion reaction in a tabletop experiment. The announcement held out the prospect of a cheap, safe and virtually inexhaustible source of energy. Despite extreme scientific skepticism that continues today, the Legislature appropriated $5 million last fall to establish the National Cold Fusion Institute at the school and to protect the state's patent rights. University officials need to persuade the Fusion Energy Advisory Council, which oversees the state's investment, by Nov. 1 that the institute should be allowed to continue operating. Pons, a tenured professor and former chairman of the chemistry department, has put his house in Salt Lake up for sale and his telephone was disconnected Tuesday. The Deseret News quoted an unidentified university source as saying Pons' family has moved out of town. Hugo Rossi, dean of the university's College of Science, said he doesn't know where Pons is, or what his plans are. ``Our understanding is that he has made satisfactory arrangements for his teaching obligation this fall, and he will be here to meet his obligation for winter quarter,'' Rossi said. James Brophy, the university's vice president of research, said officials are expecting a formal letter outlining Pons' plans for winter quarter. Last week, Brophy said Pons was visiting foreign laboratories, a common practice for senior researchers. The state council is meeting Thursday to review the status of the Pons-Fleischmann experiments and fusion patents over the last year. Pons and Fleischmann said their experiments - involving electrically charged platinum coils containing rods of palladium immersed in deuterium-rich heavy water - produced 100 times the energy needed to produce a reaction. ``We want to know where we stand on the program and what we have to do in the future to preserve our position in this science,'' said council chairman Raymond L. Hixson. ``We have gone this far with it. We had better be sure we are protected for future developments.'' Hixson said there is much information Pons and Fleischmann have not released about their experiments, but he is sure they have reasons for doing so. That information, however, will be critical to the scientific review of the fusion institute, which was supposed to get under way in August. Hixson said Pons' disappearance ``kind of muddles everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Bombs Kill Two Children, Wound Two in El Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with victims' relationships, nationalities. Picks up 7th pvs, `The attack ...'
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels on Tuesday killed two children and wounded two other civilians in a botched homemade mortar attack on the Defense Ministry compound. Two powerful mortar-type bombs fell at dusk about 175 yards short of the sprawling military compound on a house in the neighborhood of San Francisco. The bodies of Natalie Salazar, 9, and her brother Gerardo, an adolescent about 16 years old, were found in the rubble of the big house in the affluent neighborhood. Magdalena Salazar, identified by the authorities as the dead children's mother, and Vilma Molina, their aunt, were taken from the home in ambulances. Some neighbors said they believed the children had been visiting from the United States and could have been U.S. citizens, but embassy authorities said both the fatalities were Salvadorans. The attack came six days after similar homemade mortars were used in an attack on the main air force base on the capital's eastern edge. In that attack, rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front hit their target with the powerful homemade artillery dubbed ``tepezcuintles,'' a native wild pig. The bombs are made of refillable propane gas containers filled with explosive. Each one weighs about 40 pounds. Col. Mauricio Vargas, sub-chief of the joint chiefs of staff that shares the compound with the Defense Ministry, was asked if the target of the attack was the ministry. ``What should concern us is not what was the target, but the result, the deaths of these children and the destruction,'' he said. The bombs almost completely destroyed the home where the casualties occurred and damaged the one next to it. Some walls were left standing, but roof was collapsed in a pile of rubble, glass and twisted reinforcement rods.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Aide, Former Aide Indicted; Lawmaker Cleared
DOC.TEXT: The FBI's long-running probe of state Capitol corruption resulted in indictments Tuesday against a legislative aide and a former aide, and prosecutors cleared a lawmaker of any involvement in the case. U.S. Attorney David Levi said no charges would be filed against Assemblywoman Gwen Moore, D-Los Angeles, the author of special-interest bills that figured prominently in the probe. Levi said the evidence, ``when viewed in its entirety,'' didn't warrant any charges against Moore, who chairs the Assembly Utilities and Commerce Committee. So far, eight people, including two former state senators, have been charged in connection with the 5-year-old FBI probe, which Levi said is continuing. In the sting, FBI agents posed as businessmen offering money for legislative favors. A federal grand jury on Tuesday indicted Moore's former top aide, Tyrone Netters, on nine counts, accusing him of racketeering, bribery, extortion, conspiracy, money laundering and filing a false income tax return, prosecutors said. Netters, who now works for the Assembly Rules Committee, was placed on administrative leave Tuesday, said Bob Connelly, the Assembly's chief administrative officer. Darryl Freeman, a former Assembly aide and lobbyist, was indicted on conspiracy and extortion charges. Moore, who has represented a Los Angeles area district since 1978, said Levi's announcement made Tuesday a ``happy day for me and my family.'' ``For more than two years I have fully and completely cooperated with the FBI in its investigations,'' Moore said. ``I knew I had done absolutely nothing wrong and today that was confirmed by the U.S. attorney.'' If convicted, Netters, 36, faces up to 163 years in prison and a $3.2 million fine and Freeman, 43, up to 40 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. The indictment also seeks repayment of nearly $15,000 that Netters received from FBI undercover agents. So far, eight people, including two former state senators, have been charged in connection with the 5-year-old FBI probe, which Levi said is continuing. In the sting, FBI agents posed as businessmen offering money for legislative favors. The investigation was revealed in August 1988 when about 30 FBI agents raided the state Capitol, searching the offices of four lawmakers - including Moore - and their aides. The former senators, Democrats Joseph Montoya of Whittier and Paul Carpenter of Cypress, were convicted of corruption charges earlier this year. Montoya is serving a 6{-year prison sentence. Carpenter, now a member of a state tax board, is awaiting sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Man Kills Three, Turns Gun on Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2 and 5 to CORRECT to Putman sted Putmam.
DOC.TEXT: A convicted murderer apparently killed two people Tuesday before traveling to a park where he fatally shot his former girlfriend and himself over their broken relationship, police said. ``We believe the suicide victim may be responsible for all the deaths,'' Lt. Jack Putman said. ``We're working on tying all these people together.'' Lt. Ray Nelson identified the man who wielded the weapon as Robert Lee Asberry, 39, of Tulsa. Police were investigating separately the park shootings and the stabbing death of Cheryl Ann Butler, 27, when a detective heard one witness describe a car seen at both slayings. Putman said Ms. Butler apparently was a friend of Brenda Joyce Parks, 31, who died at an east Tulsa park of a gunshot wound as her 18-month-old son watched. Police later found Columbus Dumas, 38, the boy's father, slain in his north Tulsa home. Lt. John Bowman said Asberry died of a gunshot wound to the chest. Asberry was out on parole for a 1976 second-degree murder conviction. He was convicted of killing Brenda Joyce Nelson, the sister of the police lieutenant who described Tuesday's killings to reporters. ``The bastard was the one who killed my sister in '75,'' Lt. Nelson said. Ms. Nelson and Ms. Parks, who have the same first and middle names, apparently didn't know each other, police said. At the park, witnesses and police said Ms. Parks and Asberry talked briefly at a picnic table just yards from a nature trail and tennis courts. Asberry then walked to his car and returned with an automatic shotgun. ``I was over here playing tennis. The man just got the gun and started shooting,'' said witness Thomas Park. ``The man shot the lady first. I saw the lady drop onto the table. I just kind of ducked.'' The toddler was taken unharmed to a county shelter. He played with a stuffed bear police provided while detectives investigated the scene.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Dominates the Ratings With World Series
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Baseball made CBS No. 1 in the latest ratings, but the short World Series cost the network millions in lost advertising revenue. The Cincinnati Reds' four-game sweep of the Oakland A's last week captured first, second, fifth and sixth place in television's top 10, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. But the World Series' failure to reach five, six or seven games resulted in a loss that CBS would estimate only as ``less than $100 million.'' CBS' average rating for the week was 15.9. NBC had a 13.9 and ABC a 12.6. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. It was the second time in the 5-week-old season that CBS was in first place. NBC continued to fare well by pitting female-oriented programming against baseball. ``Danielle Steel's `Fine Things' '' missed tying with Tuesday's opening game of the World Series by a little more than two points. During the National League playoffs, NBC's ``Jackie Collins' `Lucky-Chances' '' buried the game between the Reds and the Pittsburgh Pirates on CBS. NBC's ``Cheers,'' which had been the No. 1 show since the season began, fell to third place last week. Fox Broadcasting's ``The Simpsons'' fell 12 percent in its ratings battle against ``The Cosby Show.'' The animated Fox family received a 16.2. ``The Cosby Show'' got an 18.5 and was eighth for the week. In the network news, ABC and Peter Jennings won again with a 9.9. NBC and Tom Brokaw and CBS and Dan Rather tied at 8.7. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``World Series Game 2,'' CBS, 21.8; ``World Series Game 4,'' CBS, 21.4; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 21.1; ``Monday Night Movies, `Danielle Steel's `Kaleidoscope,' '' NBC, 20.3; ``World Series Game 1,'' CBS, 20.2; ``World Series Game 3,'' CBS, 19.4; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 19.3; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC 18.5; ``America's Funniest People,'' ABC, 18.3; ``Movie of the Week, `Danielle Steel's `Fine Things,' '' 18.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Shoots Man, Two Officers in Downtown Office
DOC.TEXT: A man shot and killed a lawyer Tuesday in a downtown office building and wounded two police officers, who then returned fire and killed the gunman, police said. ``He was confronted by officers, who told him to drop the weapon. He returned fire - he elected to do so for some unknown reason - and the officers had no recourse but to return the fire,'' said Police Chief Frank Jordan. The shootings occurred on the sixth and third floors of te James Flood Building on Market Street at about 1 p.m., police said. ``We don't know the motive at this time,'' said Deputy Police Chief Frank Reed. The attorney was shot dead on the sixth floor. The others, all shot on the third floor, were taken to Mission Emergency Hospital, where the gunman died shortly before 2 p.m., Jordan said. The identities of the dead weren't released. Officer Jim Jean was struck in the face by bullet fragments and was expected to be released from the hospital Tuesday. Acting Lt. John Madden was shot in the left knee and will need surgery, police said. Kiersta Burke, who teaches Russian emigres at Jewish Vocational Services on the sixth floor, said she and her students were frightened by the gunfire and locked and then barricaded the door of their office. ``We were very afraid that someone would break in and shoot us. We were thinking about climbing down the fire escape, but most of my students are elderly so I ruled that out,'' Burke said. ``I couldn't believe how many shots were heard.''

DOC.HEAD: Dinner at McDonald's: Pizza and Celery? ^Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Stacy McIntire and her visitors wanted something with cheese and sauce, so they did the obvious thing at a not-so-obvious place. They went out for pizza - at McDonald's. ``We had company over and we fed four people on two pizzas for something like $12,'' she said. ``We went to the drive-through and didn't even have to get out of the car. We got it in five minutes.'' Pizza, in the land of all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions and sesame-seed buns? Is this a fast-food induced nightmare? Not at all. McDonald's, which for years counted its hamburger sales in the billions, may soon be counting pizza, pasta and other non-traditional offerings in an attempt to boost sluggish U.S. dinner sales. Owensboro's four Golden Arches and 10 others across the Ohio River in Evansville, Ind., are among 240 restaurants nationwide which are test-marketing tomato pies. The 12-inch pies also are being tested in Las Vegas; Hartford, Conn.; Fresno, Calif.; and suburbs of Chicago. Fresh carrots and celery sticks are being test marketed in Pennsylvania and California, and McDonald's also is experimenting with fresh fruit and soups. ``Our customers are interested in a little more variety and more choices,'' said Melissa Oakley, spokeswoman at McDonald's Corp.'s Oak Brook, Ill., headquarters. ``But we have to be very careful in what we choose. We're still committed to serving a limited menu.'' McDonald's, held up by many as a model American corporation, has long been committed to test marketing. Salads, the McDLT and Chicken McNuggets made the grade; the Hulaburger, two slices of cheese with a slice of grilled pineapple on a toasted bun, did not. Ms. Oakley noted that McDonald's tested salads for 10 years before introducing them in all of its 8,500 U.S. restaurants. But Michael Mueller, a Montgomery Securities Inc. analyst who specializes in restaurants, says McDonald's has reasons to press ahead with pizza now - investors' complaints about the company's recent U.S. sales growth. A pattern of progressively weaker domestic sales growth began in 1988 after peaking at 11.6 percent in 1987. A selloff of the company's stock followed release of second quarter results showing domestic sales of $6 billion for the first half of 1990, a 3.3-percent increase from the irst half of 1989. ``From their standpoint they have to do something to boost dinner sales,'' Mueller said. ``This (pizza) is better than nothing.'' But is it better than Tony's, or Vito's, or Sal's? ``If you like pizza, it's just not right,'' said Elaine Lillpop of Rockport, Ind. ``It's a hurry-up job.'' She complained that the pepperoni pizza she bought in Owensboro tasted burned and didn't have enough cheese. Her 8-year-old daughter, Kari, said she didn't like it either. Gail Thompson of Owensboro said she won a free pizza and liked it, but wouldn't buy another. ``I love pizza but I don't particularly like eating it in this atmosphere,'' she said between bites of a burger. ``It's not fast food to me.'' That, says Mueller, is the problem. Pizza doesn't follow the rules that helped make McDonald's the world's largest restaurant chain. ``In the past they've been successful introducing products that are cheap, easy to eat, and come with quick service at the drive-through window,'' said the San Francisco-based analyst. ``Pizza is expensive, hard to eat in the car, and takes five minutes or more to get.'' Pizza also requires special ovens and is more difficult to make. And there are lots of competitors already established in the pizza market, Mueller said. Another restaurant analyst, Roy Burry of Kidder Peabody in New York, acknowledged the problems. But he expressed confidence that McDonald's would find a fast-food pizza that works. ``They've been on track for five or six years with this,'' he said. ``It takes a long time to get it right, which of course they will.'' Pizza was a logical choice, Burry said. The demand for more traditional fast food is not keeping pace with the number of new restaurants, he said. ``Pizza is the only fast food product that's growing,'' he said. ``It's a mammoth market. It offers major potential for them.'' Burry predicted the pizza might be ready for a national rollout within two years. The test likely will be expanded to more markets next year, he said. Ms. Oakley said McDonald's has not yet decided the product's fate. She said pizza is doing ``very well,'' although the company won't discuss sales figures. Pizza Hut, the largest pizza chain, maintains that McDonald's holds only 2 percent of sales in the Owensboro-Evansville market. Evansville workers said sales have been sporadic. A cheese pizza recently sold there for $4.99. The Deluxe, with cheese, sausage, pepperoni, green peppers, onion, tomato and mushrooms, sold for $7.99. Some restaurants sell pizza only after 4 p.m.; some offer quarter-pie slices for lunch. The Owensboro restaurants lure pizza buyers with glass windows that allow customer to watch sausage and pepperoni being spread by hand. But they don't see dough lovingly kneaded and tossed. McDonald's sacrificed fresh dough for frozen in its attempt to make pizza a fast food. Some customers say the dough will be the pizza's downfall. ``It tastes like cardboard,'' said 16-year-old Josh Hamburg of Owensboro.

DOC.HEAD: Female Volunteers Graduate in Riyadh
DOC.TEXT: More than 800 Saudi women volunteers have graduated from first aid courses as part of the country's Persian Gulf crisis mobilization. The graduates at Tuesday's ceremony donned the white coat. But many had their heads covered with a veil, according to women reporters who were allowed to attend the women-only ceremony. The course was conducted under a volunteer program, which has drawn thousands of Saudi women since Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. Opening the door to women volunteers was a dramatic event in the conservative Islamic society of Saudi Arabia. Princess Sultana al-Sudairi, the wife of Riyadh Governor Prince Salman, was among those completing the course. The women wore abayas, or long cloaks, and veils over evening dresses. They filed on stage to the tempo of Arabic music and the cheers of relatives and friends.

DOC.HEAD: Liberation Brings Crime Wave; Fear of Police Is Gone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The liberation of Eastern Europe has stripped police of their greatest weapon - fear - and crime is booming. People seldom tested police authority in the old days. They knew every officer was empowered by the Communist authorities to intimidate, beat or arrest anyone. Crime existed, but the streets were generally safe for all except dissidents. When Communist parties fell from power, the prestige and authority of police fell with them. Without the advantage of fear, the forces of law and order seem unequal to high-tech criminals emboldened by the new climate of freedom and the high profits of dishonesty. ``When I started walking a beat a couple of years ago, all I had to do was look hard at any suspicious character,'' said Joska, an officer in his late 20s. ``When I'm off duty and walking around here now, I have be extra sharp to make sure nobody picks my pocket.'' Joska, whose beat is fashionable Vaci Street, would not give his full name. Hungarian police recorded a 38.8 percent increase in crime during the first six months of 1990 compared with the same period last year. In Budapest, 48,279 criminal cases were under investigation, up 79.5 percent from a year earlier. Police in the predominantly rural Slovak republic of Czechoslovakia reported a relatively modest 17 percent increase in crime, but the growth rate was 52 percent among the urbanized Czechs, with muggings up 250 percent in the first half of the year. In Prague, crime went up 138 percent. One reason Bulgaria began rationing some goods was that black marketeers were hijacking 70 percent of the shipments bound for stores, the newspaper Duma reported in September. Poland reported a 69 percent increase in crime during the first half of 1990 and a 12 percent higher murder rate - to 236 killings in a nation of 37 million. In Romania, with a population of 23 million people, 886 murders had been committed by the end of August, nearly double the number in the first eight months of 1989. Both street and white-collar crime have increased in the Soviet Union, where democratic change has been slowest. Embezzlement cases are twice as numerous as last year, said Vyacheslav I. Runyshkov of the Interior Ministry, and investigators found corruption in half the 160,000 state firms checked between January and August. Sometimes, lack of respect leads to the humiliation of police. About 20 pickpockets routed Polish officers at Warsaw's huge main railroad station in August. They sprayed some with a paralyzing gas and attacked others with planks ripped from benches. One patrolman was hospitalized and police managed to arrest only one person. Among recent victims of Bulgaria's brazen pickpockets was a Greek police general relieved of his wallet in a Sofia department store. In Prague, citizens conditioned by the image of police as the enemy ganged up on several pursuing officers when a pickpocket yelled: ``The police are after me.'' The suspect escaped. ``People must realize that, in a democracy, the police force functions as a protective force and not an abuser of its powers,'' Vladimir Nikl, a Prague criminologist, told reporters. ``It must not be treated as an enemy.'' Technology is another problem. Criminals often have better equipment than the police. Old Soviet-made Lada squad cars and walkie-talkies from the early 1960s are no match for Mercedes, BMWs and the latest electronics. Krokodil, the Soviet satirical weekly, devoted a cover page to the unequal contest. It depicted policemen on bicycles, armed with slingshots, pursuing gangsters firing submachine guns from a Mercedes. Lt. Col. Janos Bodracka, head of the criminal investigations unit in Budapest, said police could not expect financial help while East European governments are trying to modernize their economies. ``If I gave you one of our radios, you couldn't talk to someone 10 meters away,'' he said. ``If one cop tries to warn another that the suspect is about to leave, the damn thing is so lod it scares the suspect away. ``I have 20 cars for 100 detectives and most of them cannot do over 120 kilometers (70 miles) an hour. Western criminals can walk in here and get away with murder.'' Low pay exacerbates the grievances of bad image and outdated equipment. Junior police officers in Warsaw are paid the equivalent of about $115 a month, the pay in Hungary is $150 and the rates elsewhere are no better. With inflation rapidly outstripping wages, corruption is growing. Bright young people avoid the profession. In Warsaw, where the police force has 9,500 officers and needs 4,000 more, only about 150 of this summer's 2,000 applicants met the requirements. Bodracka said the Budapest force of approximately 4,000 needs at least 500 more officers, and even that would leave the city of 2 million understaffed by Western standards. ``Our strength is nearing an end, but the criminals are growing more and more active,'' he said. ``Citizens have to realize that the quiet days are over.''

DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins cut his own salary and that of nearly 700 other bureaucrats by 5 percent Monday in a move reflecting the city's tough financial times.
DOC.HEAD: Dinkins also, 2nd graf
Veto Helps Bush With Base of Support, Say Political Operatives
With PM-Civil Rights
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's veto of civil rights legislation hurts him with a constituency he yearns to attract, but it helps him with voters who put him in the White House. That was the assessment Monday of Republican political operatives who emphasized the importance of making it clear that the president's opposition was to quotas, not to civil rights. ``The temptation to support a bill - any bill - simply because its title includes the words `civil rights' is very strong,'' Bush said in his veto message. ``But when our efforts, however well-intentioned, result in quotas, equal opportunity is not advanced but thwarted,'' the president added. ``I don't think it's going to play very well in the black community,'' Republican former Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey said of the quota argument. Kean, who got more than 60 percent of the black vote in his landslide 1985 re-election campaign, said he believed Bush did what he thought was right, ``although I'd like to have seen him sign it.'' The way the legislation was described by its proponents and opponents defined the political issues. To supporters, it was civil rights legislation needed to nullify six Supreme Court decisions that made it more difficult for women and minorities to prove and win job discrimination suits. The measure banned racial harassment in the workplace and allowed punitive damages in the most serious discrimination cases. To opponents, the issue was quotas, not civil rights, and quotas is a potent issue in American politics. ``Republicans are trying not to call it a civil rights bill,'' said Michele Davis, executive director of the Republican Governors' Association. ``We've got to do a lot better job explaining what this legislation does.'' The key for Republicans is convincing people it is quota legislation. The strength of that issue was seen in the race for governor of California, where Republican Pete Wilson succeeded in portraying Democrat Dianne Feinstein as advocating quotas in state hiring. ``It brought some Republicans home,'' said Davis. There were reports that Bush got conflicting advice from White House aides, some arguing he should continue negotiations until he could find a compromise, others urging a quick veto. Kean said he wished the president had found a way to negotiate a compromise. ``What bothers me is, while the disagreements loomed large, they are only over at most 10 to 20 percent of the bill,'' he said. At the same time, Kean said, ``certain people in the political world wanted a presidential veto more than they wanted a civil rights bill.'' Proponents of a veto argued that the president needed to avoid furthering the image of indecisiveness created when he shifted his position on whether he would accept a tax increase to help reduce the federal budget deficit. ``Given where he is on the budget battle, the president is wise to stick to his guns on quotas,'' said Roger Stone, a Republican consultant who has been a strong advocate of the need for the GOP to reach out to black voters. ``It (the veto) will anger a certain constituency,'' said Stone. ``It will also, if Bush continues to push his opposition to quotas, help him with his base constituency.'' Robert Teeter, a Republican pollster and adviser to Bush, said it was essential that the president make it clear ``he's in favor of civil rights.'' Teeter noted that in recent polls Bush has received high marks from more than 40 percent of blacks, a ranking that was far higher than the 10 percent approval ratings President Reagan generally had in the black community. But will a veto of civil rights legislation cause blacks to view Bush as not that much different than Reagan? Teeter insisted that wouldn't happen. ``He is not, has not been, will not be perceived the same as Reagan,'' said the pollster. As part of the Republican outreach effort, the GOP has three blacks running for the House this year, all considered credible candidates and all opposed to the bill on the ground it would encourage establishment of quotas. During a debate Sunday night in Connecticut, Democratic former Rep. Toby Moffett said it was a disgrace that his congressional campaign opponent, Republican Gary Franks, opposed the bill. ``Do not talk to me about civil rights,'' said Franks, who is black. ``I had a cross burned in front of my house'' when he was 9 years old.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Pollution Bill Seen on Track for Enactment
With PM-Clean Air-Glance
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: A tough, new clean air bill is expected to breeze through the House and Senate this week and be signed into law by President Bush. A House-Senate conference committee approved the legislation with only one dissenting voice on Monday. Democratic and Republican leaders expressed confidence the measure will clear Congress, probably Wednesday. The legislation, which is expected to cost the economy more than $22 billion a year when all its provisions are in force, requires new pollution controls on factories, thousands of businesses, automobiles and electric power plants. Bush noted that it has been 13 years since federal air pollution laws were revised and said, ``This Congress, this week, should send me a clean air bill that I can sign.'' White House sources said there did not appear to be anything in the measure that would keep the president from signing it. A provision calling for $250 million in assistance to workers who lose their jobs because of new air pollution controls had been of concern to the administration. But modifications in the plan during final negotiations early Monday appeared to have made the measure acceptable to the White House. ``While we have to take a look at the final language, we are encouraged by the agreement reached on (the jobs assistance) amendment,'' said White House spokesman Steve Hart. The new pollution controls will affect not only huge petrochemical plants, but also smaller businesses such as dry cleaners, paint shops, furniture refinishers and operators of fleets of automobiles. Automakers will have to intensify their push to develop alternative-fuel cars and the oil companies must produce cleaner burning fuels. In some regions, especially the indusrial Midwest, utilities will have to find ways to cut sulfur dioxide emissions, which causes acid rain, and may decide to do so by either switching to low-sulfur coal or installing expensive ``scrubbers.'' Either way, the costs likely will be passed on in form of higher electric rates. As plants turn away from high-sulfur coal to fuel their generators, it is expected that miners in such states as West Virginia will be thrown out of work. That is why Rep. Robert Wise, D-W.Va., pushed for the job-loss assistance provision in the bill. ``This bill touches virtually all Americans from and environmental point of view and from an economic point of view,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the conference that crafted the legislation. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., who headed the House negotiating team, called the new legislation ``fair and reasonable.'' Among the major requirements in the 700-page legislation: -Utilities must cut annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons by the year 2001 to reduce acid rain, which kills trees and aquatic life. -Automakers must slash tailpipe emissions by 30 to 60 percent and provide more alternative-fuel cars for fleet operators and for a limited pilot program for passenger cars in California. -Businesses such as dry cleaners must cut smog-producing emissions. -Cleaner-burning gasoline, including ethanol blends, must be sold in cities with the worst smog problems. -For the first time, industry must install control technology to cut toxic chemical releases by 90 percent. Additional pollution controls may be required to reduce cancer risks near plants in some cases. House and Senate negotiators worked out agreement on the legislation before dawn Monday and the conference committee formally approved the measure in a voice vote later in the day. Only Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., opposed it. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the legislation ``historic in its significance'' and said he expected both the Senate and House to endorse it and Bush to sign it into law. Republican members of the clean air conference, including Rep. Norman Lent of New York and Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, also predicted presidential approval. The White House estimates the legislation will cost the economy $11 billion a year by 1995 and $22 billion to $25 billion annually by 2005, when the bill's provisions take full effect. Industry estimates have put the annual cost in the $30 billion-$50 billion range toward the end of the decade, while environmentalists maintain that any costs would be largely offset by saving $50 billion now spent yearly for health care because of dirty air.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the remaining key issues to be resolved before the 101st Congress adjourns, possibly late this week:

House and Senate budget conferees continue to struggle for agreement on a mix of new taxes and spending cuts aimed at achieving a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction program. Once a reconciliation agreement is reached behind closed doors, it must be approved on the House and Senate floors. A stopgap spending bill, which has kept the government running while work proceeds, expires at 12:01 a.m. EDT Thursday.

The House and Senate must consider a $288 billion package for the Defense Department that slashes President Bush's budget request for Star Wars and barely keeps the B-2 stealth bomber alive. Altogether, 13 appropriations bills financing government agencies through Sept. 30 must be passed before lawmakers go home for the year.

Congressional negotiators approved a clean air bill expected to cost at least $22 billion and affect most of American society, with tougher pollution controls on automobiles, factories, businesses and power plants. The legislation, which toughens federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years, must go back to the House and Senate for endorsement before adjournment.

The Senate continues work on a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill with several controversial provisions, including one that would shift U.S. policy toward El Salvador by cutting military aid. It also includes a proposal to forgive $6.7 billion in past military sales loans to Egypt. When passed, the measure must be reconciled with the House version, which was approved earlier this year.

The Senate has yet to consider House-passed legislation that, among other things, would place some limits on how much mail lawmakers could send to their constituents at taxpayer expense. The mail limits in the House bill would give each member an allowance sufficient to send three first-class mailings to each residential address in their districts, an average of $178,000.

An $11.7 billion appropriations bill that would reinstate strict anti-obscenity restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts is pending in the Senate. The bill would trim the agency's $175 million budget request by $5 million. Opponents favor a House-approved proposal to let the courts decide whether federally subsidized art works are obscene.

Senate leaders and the Bush administration have reached agreement on the broad outlines of legislation providing assistance for low-income families. But major differences with the House remain an obstacle to passage. The latest Senate version is a five-year, $15 billion package. Most of the money would go for an expansion of earned income tax credits for low-income working families with children.

Five members of the Senate - four Democrats and a Republican - are awaiting completion of a Senate Ethics Committee investigation into allegations the lawmakers improperly intervened with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating, owner of the collapsed Lincoln Savings & Loan Association, who gave them substantial campaign contributions. The five under investigation are Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Donald Riegle of Michigan, John Glenn of Ohio and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, also is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Member of 2 Live Crew Admits 1987 Obscenity
DOC.TEXT: A member of 2 Live Crew pleaded guilty in state curt Monday to an obscenity charge involving simulated sex during a performance by the rap group here in 1987. Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross was given a six-month suspended jail sentence, fined $1,000 and placed on six months' unsupervised probation after his local attorney, Mike Dauphine, entered the guilty plea on Ross' behalf. District Attorney Nathan Stansbury said Ross was charged with obscenity after simulating sex on stage during a concert appearance here. Three members of the group, including Ross, were acquitted of misdemeanor obscenity charges Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Near Final Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS top 2 grafs with additional detail on status of unresolved disputes. Stands for AMs
DOC.TEXT: Congressional and White House budget bargainers moved to the verge of a compromise late Monday on a $250-billion deficit-reduction bill raising taxes on the wealthy and cutting Medicare, participants said. Party leaders planned to present rank-and-file members Tuesday with options for resolving remaining disputes over taxing the rich, raising the gasoline tax and constraining Medicare spending, said one Democrat who asked to not be identified. Democratic and Republican congressional leaders met privately with Bush administration officials until after 11 p.m. Monday in the Capitol. Afterward, none would say a bargain had been struck, but many said good progress had been made. Asked if the two sides were on the brink of a budget deal, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said ``I think so.'' ``We're making progress,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Democrats were strongly considering dropping their call for a surtax on millionaires. In the face of adamant opposition by President Bush and Republican senators to a surtax on the rich, Democrats were weighing a GOP alternative that would limit the deductions millionaires can itemize on their income taxes. House Democratic leaders were sounding out their rank and file to see how much support there was for that idea. With the two sides advancing otherwise similar proposals to raise taxes on the wealthy, agreement on this matter would be a major step toward completion of a $250 billion deficit-reduction pact. Leaders would like to bring a compromise bill to the House and Senate floors by midweek. Early in the day, Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee said he believed Republicans and Democrats could work out a plan to raise taxes on the wealthy. Later, he said some House Democrats were against the GOP plan to limit deductions on the rich. Lawmakers from states with high local taxes or where charitable contributions are high - suc as New York and California - fear that the measure would hurt them disproportionately. ``The question is can I pass it,'' Rostenkowski said. ``I don't know. I lose too many (state) delegations.'' On a day in which weary lawmakers spent hours waiting for computers to analyze various tax proposals, gallows humor prevailed. ``So far it's been very productive,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said early. ``We haven't met.'' The legislation is aimed at cutting the federal deficit over five years by taking action on two fronts: -Raising taxes, including levies on tobacco, alcohol, airline tickets and such luxuries as furs and yachts. -Restraining spending, including money for student loans, benefits for veterans and retired civil servants, agricultural programs and dozens of other areas. Both sides have suggested raising the income-tax rate to 31 percent on the richest Americans, up from its current 28 percent. They have also proposed limiting the deductions available to people earning more than $100,000. Democrats want to also impose a 7.5 percent surtax on people earning more than $1 million yearly. ``Ninety-five percent of this package essentially is demanding serious sacrifice from everyone else, veterans, government employees, working families,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``We think it's fair to let millionaires pay their fair share.'' But GOP senators were ardently against the idea, arguing that imposing a surtax on some taxpayers would invite boosts later on for everyone. After days of bargaining, Democrats were considering other plans, which House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., described as ``infinitely changeable.'' The two sides were entertaining similar offers in other unresolved areas. They seemed near agreeing that the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax would increase by a nickel or perhaps slightly more. And while Democrats wanted to reduce the growth of Medicare by about $44 billion over the next five years, Republicans wanted to slash to be about $3 billion deeper. But participants emphasized that nothing had been settled in either of those areas. Democrats were saying the more taxes they could raise from the wealthy, the milder the Medicare reductions would be. ``M and M is still the problem, millionaires and Medicare,'' Panetta said. There were even hints that the gasoline tax might not be raised at all. Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich., said Gephardt told him it would be difficult for Democrats to achieve the 10 percent surtax on the wealthy, but indicated it might be possible to leave the gasoline tax alone. Last year, 65,000 families reported earning more than $1 million on their income-tax returns. Boosting tax rates on the wealthiest people would mean an increase for 600,000 families. Bargaining was also continuing over raising the $51,300 ceiling below which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is deducted from paychecks. Democrats want to boost the cap to $125,000, Republicans to $98,000. The bill, when completed, would be the cornerstone of $500 billion worth of savings over the next five years. The rest of the deficit-cutting would come from restraining the defense budget in a separate bill and from savings from projected payments on the national debt. White House budget chief Richard Darman was in the Capitol Monday participating in the talks. On Sunday, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and other administration officials left the meetings, complaining that Democrats were not responding to GOP offers. The meetings went on without them.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Campaigns for GOP Candidates in New England
DOC.NOTE: EDS: First event at 9 a.m. EDT; GOP breakfast in Burlington, Vt.; will be led
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is escaping the battle of the budget for a day to stump for Republican candidates in New England, one of the most economically hard-pressed regions of the country. Bush planned to speak at fund-raisers for GOP candidates in Burlington, Vt., Manchester, N.H., and in the Connecticut cities of Waterbury and Stamford. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's speeches ``will deal primarily with budgetary matters, but (will be) also heavily aimed toward the local election that the president's working for.'' Bush likes to tell audiences that a good budget deal is the best antidote to a lagging economy. New England's economy has lagged more than most. After being the strongest during the Reagan years, the region's economy is now one of the nation's weakest. Of the six New England states, the Democratic governors of Vermont, Massachusetts and Connecticut all opted not to seek re-election. The Republican governor of Rhode Island was running far behind his Democratic challenger in the polls and the GOP governor of Maine was in a tight race with his predecessor. Some economists have questioned the wisdom of a budget deal that cuts spending and increases taxes - as both House and Senate versions would do - just as the nation seems to be sliding into a recession. Conventional economic wisdom is that the government should stimulate the economy when it's weak. But the administration argues that a sound budget deal will help the economy by driving interest rates down. ``We've got to put this nation back on the path to long-term economic growth. And the way to do that is to get a budget through, and that will bring the interest rates down and that will put more and more Americans back to work where they belong,'' Bush said in a recent political speech. Gone from either version of the $500 billion, five-year deficit cutting package now before a House-Senate conference committee is an earlier proposal that generated strong opposition in New England. That was a 2-cent-a-gallon tax on heating oil that was part of the package negotiated by the White House and congressional leaders but rejected by the House. Bush's New England tour was postponed from two weeks ago, when he canceled it to remain in Washington during an earlier stage of the budget crisis. The president's first stop was a fund-raising breakfast for the state GOP in Burlington, Vt. Former Gov. Richard Snelling is favored to regain the office he gave up six years ago, which would return Vermont to Republican control. Bush also was expected to put in a plug for Rep. Peter Smith, the Republican incumbent, whose re-election bid is being challenged by former Burlington Mayor Bernie Sanders, a Socialist. Bush also planned to speak at a fund-raising lunch for GOP Senate candidate Rep. Robert C. Smith in Manchester, N.H. Smith was heavily favored to capture the Senate seat being vacated by fellow conservative Gordon Humphrey. He is challenged by former Democratic Sen. John Durkin. The president planned two campaign appearances in Connecticut. The first was a reception in Waterbury for GOP House candidate Gary Franks, who is running for the congressional seat being vacated by GOP gubernatorial candidate John Rowland. The Democratic challenger is former Rep. Toby Moffett. Moffett gave up his House seat to run unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1982; he ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1986. Bush also was to speak at a fund-raising dinner for Rowland in Stamford. Rowland is in a three-way race for governor. Former Republican Sen. Lowell Weicker, running as an independent, is leading in the polls while Democratic Rep. Bruce Morrison has been trailing.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Candidates Have Lots of Excuses for Shelving Bush Ads
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of `their'
DOC.TEXT: Droves of Republican candidates are shunning television ads of themselves with President Bush, and they've got their reasons. They couldn't get to the White House for a taping. The quality of the footage is bad. They don't have money to buy the TV time. Endorsements don't work in their race. And, well, maybe it's not such a good idea to latch onto a guy whose ratings are slipping. Who promoted a wildly unpopular budget plan. Who's part of the Washington establishment that this year's candidates love to hate. ``If something is radioactive, your natural inclination is to stay away from it,'' said Craig Tufty, a spokesman for Rep. Fred Grandy, R-Iowa. Is there a Bush endorsement in Grandy's future? ``We don't have one,'' said Tufty, ``and we don't plan on getting one.'' Bush has taped about 100 endorsement spots for Republican House, Senate and gubernatorial candidates. But an Associated Press spot check of campaigns across the country indicates few are finding their way onto the airwaves. Many candidates seem to be taking their cue from freshman Rep. Jim McCrery of Louisiana. He scrapped plans to show his ad with Bush before the state's unique open primary on Oct. 6. Instead, he ran ads against Bush's budget compromise. McCrery coasted to re-election 10 points ahead of a Democrat who had been expected to give him trouble, and a winning strategy was born. Bush has been welcomed and feted all over the country as a cheerleader and fund-raiser for the same candidates who have vetoed his on-air presence. The decision most often is explained diplomatically. ``We've chosen to push John's agenda with our television ads, rather than having the president do it for us,'' said John Truscott, a spokesman for Michigan gubernatorial candidate John Engler. ``We're concentrating on Wyoming issues rather than Washington,'' was a comment typical of many campaigns. ``We'd like to keep our advertising focused on the candidate,'' was another. Some had other reasons. A spokesman for Wisconsin Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said video footage of Bush's June trip there was of such poor quality that it won't be aired. And Michigan state Rep. Dave Camp, trying for an open House seat, couldn't make a taping session. ``They wanted us in Washington the next day,'' said his campaign manager, John Guzik. Several campaigns said they still don't know if they'll play their Bush cards but they denied the president's ratings would influence their decisions. John Hudgens, campaign manager for Arkansas gubernatorial candidate Sheffield Nelson, was more blunt. ``If he's ranking high in the polls and very popular, that's one thing,'' Hudgens said of Bush. ``But if he's dropping in the polls it would be silly for us to throw him up there. His popularity is an issue.'' A couple of politicians have figured out how to exploit Bush's support while at the same declaring their independence from him. Sen. Larry Pressler, for example, ran an ad incorporating film of Bush complimenting the South Dakota senator during a Washington fund-raiser. But the ad also includes Bush's comments that Pressler doesn't always go along with the White House. And Rep. Al McCandless, running against Ralph ``Pa Walton'' Waite near Los Angeles, made an ad that says Bush supports him even though he didn't support the president's budget deal. That's followed by a White House tape of Bush saying nice things about McCandless. That particular ad has not aired yet and may never, but spokesman James Moore said any McCandless TV in the heavily Republican district will include Bush's comments and the same type of disclaimer. ``Unfortunately,'' he said, ``I think we have to.'' Some candidates apparently feel Bush still is popular enough to help them. Senate challenger Allen Kolstad of Montana and Nevada gubernatorial candidate Jim Gallaway are using endorsement spots with no caveats. The president has been on TV in Maine, site of his beloved summer home, for Sen. William Cohen and House hopeful David Emery. He's on the air in Nebraska, too. ``Sen. Jim Exon ... President Bush,'' says the announcer as the screen shows photographs of the two men. ``Putting politics aside and standing together and protecting our national security in the Middle East and at home.'' Exon certainly transcended politics in that ad. He's a Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: Mensa, the IQ Society, Expands Behind the Iron Curtain
DOC.TEXT: The increasing intellectual freedom enjoyed by Eastern Europeans has created a rush to join Mensa International, the high IQ society, according to the group's officials. After years of running into bureaucratic roadblocks, Mensa has made inroads in several communist countries. Yugoslavia now has 950 Mensa members, Poland 900 and Czechoslovakia 750, said Ed Vincent, executive director of Mensa. The group also is evaluating tests taken by 350 Muscovites and plans on testing several hundred people in Bucharest next week. Worldwide, the group has 97,000 members. Only people who test in the top two percent of the population can join the society. Mensa's principles of free thinking and open exchange of ideas, once considered unwelcome behind the Iron Curtain, has received a warm welcome in the past two years, said Vincent, in Philadelphia for Mensa's annual board of directors meeting. ``They examined us carefully,'' he said. ``Once they found we were about intellectual pursuits and we were not politically affiliated, they welcomed us.'' For years, Mensa was unable to break through the many bureaucratic layers set up by communist leaders, Vincent said. ``A lot of correspondence was mostly one way,'' he said. Sometimes it would take six months to get a response from the government in Moscow, and more often than not it was just a referral to another government agency. ``But once the (political) changes began, the new governments found little difficulty with us,'' he said. Most Eastern Europeans interested in joining Mensa are in their 20s, usually working at universities or training academies. ``They are more psychologically capable'' than older eastern Europeans in seeking out Mensa, Vincent said. ``The past three generations have been restricted in making choices all their lives,'' he said. ``A 52-year-old might be interested in joining, but he might find it difficult to express his desires.'' Internationally, membership has grown from 72,000 in 1986 to 97,000 this year.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: George Romero, director of ``Night of the Living Dead'' and other cult classics, has started shooting ``The Dark Half,'' a film adapted from the Stephen King novel of the same name. Shooting began last week at Washington & Jefferson College in western Pennsylvania, an area the director has favored in making low-budget flicks. The $15 million Jekyll-and-Hyde story will be Romero's most expensive film. In ``The Dark Half,'' Oscar-winner Timothy Hutton plays a professor who can't sell his books under his own name but whose horror novels written under a pseudonym become best sellers. The pseudonym becomes a separate personality. The plot was inspired by King's own career. King has had success under the name Richard Bachman, a pseudonym he adopted because his publisher feared a glut of his material on the market would hurt sales. --- LONG BEACH, Calif. (AP) - Dudley Moore had to contend with a piano that went clunk and another that wandered across the stage during a benefit. The concert Sunday at California State University at Long Beach was to help pay for $3,000 in repairs on a Steinway grand piano and replace another valued at $50,000 that was destroyed when a concert hall roof collapsed July 2. ``Hmmm. A broken string. This is actually a true Steinway,'' the comic actor said of the piano borrowed for the benefit. ``I want you all to think about this when you buy that new Steinway.'' The star of such films as ``10'' and ``Arthur'' got another piano from the wings, but it began to glide across the stage as he played. He gazed at the crowd and said, ``I love playing on moments of sheer panic and desperation.'' The concert was expected to raise $15,000. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Athlete Bo Jackson, recording artists Heavy D. and Al B. Sure! and ``Cosby'' star Malcolm-Jamal Warner will make cameo appearances during a fantasy scene in Monday's episode of the NBC series ``Fresh Prince.'' The celebrities will appear at a Halloween party rapper Fresh Prince fantasizes inviting them to. The show's producer, Quincy Jones, and Kadeem Hardison of ``A Different World'' also will appear. Guests on the one-hour special will donate their fees to the dropout prevention program Cities in Schools. --- PADUCAH, Ky. (AP) - Sheriff Howard Walker Jr. could have sworn he marched through Army basic training in 1969 with Vice President Dan Quayle's cousin. But Quayle set the sheriff straight Monday. ``That cousin's me,'' the vice president told Walker at a Republican fund-raiser. Walker said Quayle was a good friend in his platoon at Fort Bragg, N.C., where Quayle trained before serving in the National Guard. Through the years, Walker forgot Quayle's first name. When the politician became famous, Walker assumed the vice president was a relative of the Quayle he knew. ``When I went through the line, he recognized me, and it blew my mind,'' Walker said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - The woman whose voice sent police officers on calls in the Martin Milner-Kent McCord TV series ``Adam-12'' has retired from her job as a real-life dispatcher. Shaaron Cooper, 52, spent her last day at the Los Angeles Police Department on Sunday after 30 years on the force. Ms. Cooper provided the voiceover introduction and radio calls for the police drama during its 1968-75 run. She also worked on ``Dragnet,'' which ran from 1952 to 1970. Both series were created by Jack Webb. Ms. Cooper was one of the best dispatchers in the department, said Officer Don Lawrence. ``Officers were sending her messages all day Sunday,'' he said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Diana Muldaur of ``L.A. Law'' says the wickedly insensitive lawyer she plays draws attention mainly because she's a woman. ``If it were a man doing the same things, no one would blink,'' she said about the character, Rosalind Shays, in a recent interview. ``In fact, it wouldn't even be good copy,'' said Muldaur, who was nominated for an Emmy for best supporting actress. ``It goes on every day.'' Shays was ousted from the ``L.A. Law'' firm at the end of last season. She resurfaced in the NBC series' season opener last week, filing a $500,000 sex discrimination suit.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Puts Strain on Caribbean Islands
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis is putting a severe strain on the tiny nations of the Caribbean, whose frail economies and scant natural resources make them highly vulnerable to higher oil prices. Except for Trinidad and Tobago, which produces just under 1 percent of the world's oil and stands to benefit from higher prices, most of the developing nations of the region are heavily dependent on foreign oil. Suriname and Barbados also produce some oil but not enough for domestic demand. When the price of crude doubled to about $40 a barrel after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the ripple effects in the Caribbean included higher food, utility and transportation costs. Dollars to pay interest on foreign debt also became more scarce. ``The prices have gone up at a time when we are struggling to deal with very difficult economic problems,'' said Frank Abdulah, deputy secretary-general of the 13-nation Caribbean Economic Community, or Caricom. ``It has clearly taken its toll on the Caribbean community.'' Oil prices tumbled Monday below $29, but the long-term direction remains unclear, analysts said. ``The current situation reminds us of how extremely vulnerable our small nation is,'' Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley told reporters recently. ``This has grave implications for the Jamaican economy since we are completely dependent on imported oil.'' Manley said the gulf crisis would affect all Jamaican economic projections, including discussions with the International Monetary Fund on Jamaica's $4.5 billion foreign debt. Another hard-hit country is the Dominican Republic, where consumer prices were sharply raised in August under a government plan to control runaway inflation. The program touched off nationwide strikes and clashes between protesters and security forces in which at least 60 people were killed. Unable to pay higher oil prices, the Dominican government cut imports by 40 percent and introduced rationing, causing long gas lines. The deteriorating situation prompted a flurry of media reports about rumors of a possible coup against President Joaquin Balaguer, the nation's blind, 84-year-old leader. Both the military and Balaguer's Cabinet have strongly denied the existence of any movement to overthrow the government. Balaguer told the nation recently ``there is a delicate situation, not only in the Dominican Republic but all over the world ... The only countries enjoying stability today are oil-producing nations.'' ``None of these mini-countries are politically strong enough ... to weather serious economic adversity without remarkable consequences,'' said Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington-based think tank. ``And these (consequences) could include replacement of governments with opposition parties and, at the very worse, military regimes.'' In Guyana, one of the hemisphere's poorest nations, Prime Minister Hamilton Green said higher fuel prices could exhaust earnings from the country's main exports - sugar, rice and bauxite. ``For the bauxite industry we use a lot of ... fuel and diesel for those huge kilns and this has had a very bad effect on the economy,'' Green said in an interview. ``This whole thing has gone out of kilter.'' Elsewhere, Antigua has raised electricity rates and, according to the monthly news magazine Caribbean Insight, at least one shipping line operating in the British Virgin Islands has raised cargo rates. Concern also has been raised about the possibility of higher air fares, which could hurt tourism, the economic lifeblood of many Caribbean islands. ``One would hope the duration of the Middle East crisis is short-lived,'' said Luther Miller of the Barbados-based Caribbean Tourism Organization. ``But hopefully it will be more expensive to drive than to fly.'' With substantial oil reserves, the twin-island nation of Trinidad and Tobago, could reap a windfall. Industry Minister Bhoe Tewarie said a sustained price increase of just $1 would pump $50 million a year into the treasury. But he said the government wanted to reduce its dependency on oil wealth and had no plan to significantly increase production. Widespread poverty in Trinidad since the collapse of oil prices in the early 1980s was cited by Moslem rebels who stormed Parliament in August and staged an abortive coup and six-day hostage siege. Rafeeuddin Ahmed, the U.N. undersecretary-general for international economic and social affairs, said Monday that higher oil prices ``will be an unbearable additional burden'' for some Third World and Eastern European nations. The IMF is said to be studying ways to help developing nations caught in the gulf squeeze, but is not expected to produce a new round of lending. ``In the 1970s, the energy crisis caused over-borrowing and that resulted in the debt crisis,'' said one financial source in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But borrowing should not be a way out of this crisis. These countries are going to have to bite the bullet and adjust their policies to reflect the high cost of oil.''

DOC.HEAD: Tower's `Boozer' Comment Livens Exon-Daub Race
DOC.TEXT: It took a Texan to spice up Nebraska's lackluster U.S. Senate campaign. The race between two-term Democratic Sen. Jim Exon and Republican Hal Daub came to life when John Tower came to town. Tower, a former Texas senator, arrived to campaign for Daub still nursing a grudge over the Senate's 1989 vote to reject his nomination to be secretary of defense. Exon had opposed Tower's nomination. ``Sen. Exon bore down on me heavily on the drinking thing when he's got the reputation in Washington of being one of the two or three biggest boozers in the Senate,'' Tower said. Exon denied the innuendo that he was a heavy drinker and said it was typical of Daub's ``desperate, dirty tactics.'' But Daub's camp said it had nothing to do with Tower's comments. ``If my opponent continues to harp on this so much I think he'll be making it into an issue when in fact it is not our intention, nor has it ever been our intention, that it be an issue,'' Daub said. Democratic leaders said Tower's comments created a backlash against Daub. And once the rumors about Exon had been raised, Daub's personal life also came under scrutiny. Daub was asked about a 1978 incident in which he suffered a stab wound in his home. Daub had said he fell and stabbed himself in the arm but rumors of a domestic incident persisted. Daub, who served four terms in the U.S. House and ran unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1988, was visibly miffed and walked out of a news conference when the 1978 incident was raised. Exon, who insists he has never been drunk, said medication he had taken years ago for gall bladder problems may have made him appear tipsy. That prompted Daub to call on Exon to release his medical records. Which prompted Exon to suggest that Daub should release his ``family records,'' a veiled reference to the domestic rumors. Democrats see the Tower incident as a sign of desperation on the part of Daub, who trailed Exon in polls published before the Tower remarks. ``Hal Daub is in the tenth round of a fight and he has lost nine rounds, so he decided to bet everything on one of his patented low blows,'' said Democratic State Chairman Mike Dugan. Daub refused to give the apology demanded by Exon, but said he did regret Tower's remarks. If anything, Daub said, Exon should be the one to apologize for his previous treatment of Tower. In opposing Tower's nomination, Exon had cited Tower's past drinking habits. ``Hal Daub didn't initiate this and, in a way, John Tower didn't, either,'' said Daub spokesman Al Meyer. Before the Tower incident,Exon and Daub had campaigned on issues such as agriculture, taxes and defense. Exon cited his congressional seniority and committee assignments, including his chairmanship of an Armed Services subcommittee important to the Bellevue-based Strategic Air Command. He also stressed his role in stopping Denver's Two Forks Dam project, work helping to keep rural air service for Nebraska and a voting record that he said reflected Nebraska's values. Daub said President Bush needs Republican support in the Senate, and Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle have visited Nebraska to campaign for him. He depicts Exon as part of the old politics of the Democratic Party, which Daub blames for the federal deficit and other problems. Daub also has stressed his decision to refuse contributions from political action committees, although he took more than $1 million in PAC money in earlier campaigns. Daub said his brief political layoff after being defeated by Sen. David Karnes in 1988 convinced him that the PAC system was corrupting politics. Exon campaign manager Chuck Pallesen said Daub accepted money from out-of-state Republican organizations that use loopholes to get around the PAC laws while acting as PACs. Daub denied that and said Exon's acceptance of PAC contributions was evidence of his politics-of-the-past mentality. Each candidate's campaign reported spending about $1 million this year as of Oct. 1. However, Daub entered the final weeks of the campaign $32,000 in debt while Exon had $670,000 available.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Investigators Said to Mishandle SexProbes
DOC.TEXT: Navy investigators of rape and sexual assault cases at a naval training center in Florida may have sexually harassed the victims whose allegations they were investigating, according to an internal report. The report by the Navy's inspector general said it appeared that agents of the Naval Investigative Service, or NIS, needed better training in how to interrogate sex crime victims. The NIS said in response that it was arranging more ``sensitivity training.'' The report released Monday by the Department of the Navy said investigations of sex crimes at the Orlando Naval Training Center could be improved if the NIS used more women agents there. NIS said it would do so, despite its fear of ``creating the perception that certain assignments are `women's work.''' Navy inspectors who compiled the report on Orlando said they were told by the company commanders of some rape and sexual assault victims that the women were ``revictimized'' during questioning by NIS agents. It did not elaborate on that point except to say that the agents questioned the veracity of statements made by the victims. ``There is a possibility ... that some victims may have recanted statements to avoid further contact with NIS,'' the report said. Rep. Beverly Byron, D-Md., chairwoman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on military personnel and compensation, said the sheer number of cases at the Orlando center - 13 in a year and a half - reflects a serious problem. ``Eight rape cases and no prosecution, five sexual assaults - there's got to be a breakdown in leadership and oversight,'' she said. ``If you had one case, maybe two - which are intolerable - it wouldn't be as blatant as this many cases.'' The report, written last July, said many company commanders at the Orlando center use sexual harassment to intimidate recruits, a condition that ``sends a strong signal to developing sailors that such behavior is acceptable.'' The Navy, which has come under fire on many fronts recently for its treatment of women recruits and sailors, said it acted swiftly to correct the problems at Orlando. The Navy inspector general's report said that eight rape and five indecent assault cases were ``substantiated or resolved'' at the Orlando training center in the 18 months ended June 30. None of the rape cases was prosecuted. The Navy public affairs office at the Pentagon declined to release an accompanying document explaining how each of the rape and indecent assault cases was concluded. The inspector general's report mentioned the outcome of just four cases: two were dropped because the victims made false statements; one was dropped because the victim refused to be cross-examined in a Navy investigation, and another was dropped because the suspect was transferred from Orlando. The office of Rear Admiral Louise Wilmot, commander of the training center, released a statement saying, ``Every report of an alleged incident is immediately investigated, but if there is insufficient evidence the accused cannot be prosecuted.'' The base statement said no instructors or supervisors were involved in the alleged rape cases. ``In all cases, they were classmates, acquaintances or peers,'' it said. The chief of education and training for the Navy, Vice Adm. John S. Disher, wrote in a letter accompanying the inspector general's report that the Orlando center had managed to cut down on incidents of sexual harassment. ``Nevertheless ... this report indicates that much more must be done in Orlando, within the Naval Education and Training Center, and, presumably, throughout the entire Navy,'' Disher rote. The inspectors said they discovered that NIS agents are given only a one-time training session on conducting interrogations of sex crime victims, although they also receive ``rape awareness training.'' In response to the criticism of his agents, Rear Adm. Thomas Brooks, director of NIS, wrote in a letter to Disher that his office is trying to arrange for additional ``sensitivity training'' for interrogators. He pledged to personally assure that ``the sensitivity issue'' is central to agents' training.

DOC.HEAD: Cannons, Gunfire Music to Marines' Ears
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine with a fondness for rock 'n' roll on the firing line isn't referring to a song. It's the boom-boom-boom of cannon and rat-tat-tat of machine guns that gets things moving. ``This is music to our ears, although other people get very nervous when they hear it,'' said Col. James Fulks, operations and training officer of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. ``Anytime there's live fire, the Marines are going to be excited. These guys are going to be so pumped, it'll take a week for them to come back down,'' said Fulks, 44, peering through his binoculars at targets down range. Marines did their shooting Monday on a practice range cleared on the desolate wasteland in northeastern Saudi Arabia. After bulldozers carved out a line in the sand, Marines shooed away Bedouins, camels and goats from their target zone and fired the 25mm cannon and M-60 machine guns that are mounted on their light armored vehicles. ``This is what we get paid for,'' said Cpl. Hugh Roop, 25. ``If we're just sitting around, it doesn't make us feel that we're earning our money.'' The range this day belonged to Alpha Co. of the 1st Light Infantry Battalion, which is based at Camp Pendleton, Calif. Soldiers let loose barrage after barrage at 55-gallon drums and other targets as far as 3,000 feet away. It was the first live-fire exercise for this company since it arrived in August as part of Operation Desert Shield. The Marines routinely train in the desert back home, but the harshness of Saudi sand takes some getting used to. Whenever possible, soldiers sought shade under their vehicles and drank copious amounts of water. At midday, the temperature hit 106 degrees. Inside the belly of their armored scout vehicles, it was 20-30 degrees hotter for soldiers outfitted with mandatory flak jackets. ``It's like an oven,'' said Cpl. Craig Smith, 22 of Lafayette, Ind. ``But it's a lot better than walking, doing the humping regular grunts do. I'd rather be riding.'' Smith relished the action, even if it was practice. ``It breaks the monotony. We finally got a chance to go out and bust some caps, break the pressure a little bit and release some frustration,'' Smith said. As one way to battle the boredom, Marines with canteen cups captured the little black scorpions that thrive in the Saudi desert. Recently, they've been getting some recreation time at rear areas: movies on VCRs, pool tables, reading material. They're also getting two hot meals a day and plenty of mail. They take about three showers a week, including those jury-rigged from water bottles. One enterprising sergeant even produced a container of Tang to mix drinks for reporters. Marines who have been out in the desert for months had questions of their own for the media: Are there Vietnam-type demonstrations back home? Does the public support them? How long will they be here? What college football team is number one? What are Saudi cities like? (All they see is sand). ``It's important for us to know that people support us. Otherwise, we'd feel like we were all alone,'' Roop said.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Term Gain Outweighs Short-Term Pain, Economists Say
DOC.TEXT: John Maynard Keynes might not approve, but many private economists believe the Bush administration and Congress are right in backing budget cuts and tax increases even in the face of a possible recession. That view flies in the face of a major economic tenet advanced by Keynes, who argued that cutting government spending and increasing taxes is the wrong thing to do in economic hard times. Instead, the late British economist contended the government should run deficits during recessions to prime the pump and encourage a shrinking economy to start growing again. In the emerging budget deal, Congress would cut spending throughout government, raise income taxes on the wealthy and hike the federal gasoline tax - all in the name of shrinking the deficit by $40 billion in the current budget year and by $500 billion over the next five years. Economists who support this shock therapy concede that economic growth, at least in the short-term, will be hurt by the tax hikes and spending cuts, perhaps even making a mild recession slightly worse. But they argue that the long-term benefits outweigh the short-term pain. ``When things are this far out of kilter (with the budget deficit soaring), the benefits of solving the underlying structural problem outweigh the short-term damage,'' said David Wyss, senior financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. However, supply-side critics of the effort charge that George Bush is in danger of becoming a modern-day Herbert Hoover. That Republican president preached the need for budgetary restraint as a response to the worsening economic situation of the early 1930s. ``The deficit-cutters have a simplistic notion that if the medicine doesn't taste good, then just swallow hard and you will feel better in the morning. I don't think that is true,'' said John Makin, an economist with the conservative American Enterprise Institute. Supporters of the deficit package contend that the loss in purchasing power from higher taxes and lower government spending can be offset by lower interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve, whose chairman, Alan Greenspan, has given his blessing to the deficit-cutting deal. In addition, supporters say the deficit deal has been crafted so that the biggest tax and spending changes will occur in later years, presumably when the economy will be better able to withstand the changes. In the current budget year, the administration and Congress are looking for only $40 billion in tax increases and spending cuts. This total likely will reduce economic growth, as measured by the gross national product, by less than one-half percentage point over the next year, analysts said. ``To the extent that it is contractionary, it is fairly easy for the Fed to offset that and the longer term results of the package will be expansionary,'' said Harvard economist Martin Feldstein, who fell out of favor as President Reagan's chief economist when he advocated tax increases to narrow the deficit. With economic growth already slowed to a near-standstill, even analysts who support the deficit package believe it will worsen any recession in the next year. ``There is no question that the deficit-cutting package will slow the economy further, but that is the price we are paying for letting the deficits reach these levels and not dealing with the problem when the economy was stronger,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, president of Radnor Consulting Services, an economic forecasting firm. ``We are risking some economic pain and difficulty in the short run, but our country needs to make the sacrifice in order to get these deficits down,'' added Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer, said he believed it was a mistake to count on the Fed's power to bail out the economy quickly with lower interest rates, given the long lag times between changes in Fed credit policies and their impact on spending and borrowing decisions. Jones said he believed a recession, the first one in eight years, began in August and could end up being fairly severe, lasting until the end of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Welk's Home Town Getting Tourism Money From Farm Spending Bill
DOC.TEXT: The birthplace of retired bandleader Lawrence Welk is getting $500,000 in rural development money for tourism from the $52.2 billion approved by the House for agriculture appropriations this fiscal year. The spending bill, worked out by a House-Senate conference committee and approved by voice vote Monday in the House, covers most of the operations of the Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration. But special attention was given to the appropriation for Welk's birthplace - Strasburg, N.D. - by Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., who opposed the spending. ``That's right, `Ah one, ah two, ah three, ah four, ah half a million dollars,'' said Conte, mimicking the way Welk used to direct his orchestra. ``What will they do for an encore? Earmark funds to renovate Guy Lombardo's speedboat? Or restore Artie Shaw's wedding tuxedo?'' The money was included in the bill by the Senate to help revitalize Strasburg, a 700-person community in south-central North Dakota. But Conte and Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., both conference committee members, went on record as opposing the Strasburg appropriation before signing the compromise bill.
