The money is to be used by Welk Heritage Inc. and the Strasburg Economic Development Corp. to renovate the Welk family home and help build a motel and other facilities to accommodate the tourist trade that is beginning to develop around the bandleader's former residence. Many rural communities where farms have been consolidated over the years, causing a loss of economic base, are looking to the government for help to develop other businesses. About half the money in the bill, $27.6 billion, goes to feeding programs, including $19 billion for food stamps and $2.5 billion for the Women, Infant and Children program. Food donations, the special milk program and child nutrition programs also are covered by the bill. The bill appropriates $5 billion for farm subsidies this year and continues the crop insurance program, which had been stripped from the original House bill. ``Since 1980, the (crop insurance) program has lost over $2.6 billion in indemnity payments,'' said Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. ``The administration in the past 10 years increased over $2 billion, an increase of over 450 percent'' But, at the urging of the Senate, Whitten agreed to allow the program to continue if it is at least 75 percent actuarially sound and if USDA's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service takes control over policy sales and loss adjustments. The ASCS had controlled the program until 1980, when it was expanded to allow private insurance companies to issue policies to farmers. The practice became costly because the private companies were reimbursed by the government for administrative expenses and operating losses. Specific agencies and their appropriations are: -Farmers Home Administration, $11.5 billion -Rural Electrification Administration, $334.6 million. -Soil Conservation Service, $771.3 million. -Agriculture Stabilization and Conservation Service, $1.5 billion. -International programs, including food giveaways, $1.1 billion. -FDA, $824 million. ---

Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of Oct. 1 in the seven major beef states totaled 7.68 million head, up 10 percent from a year ago and 4 percent more than two years ago, according to the Agriculture Department. Marketings of ``fed'' cattle in September totaled 1.45 million head, down 8 percent from a year ago and 14 percent fewer than two years ago, USDA said Monday. The placement of new cattle and calves in fattening pens last month was reported at 2.21 million head, up 13 percent from a year ago and slightly above the same month in 1988, the report said. State feedlot cttle inventories are listed here for the seven states, which account for about three-fourths of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of Oct. 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.
Arizona 180 93 California 460 93 Colorado 795 106 Iowa 775 108 Kansas 1,570 111 Nebraska 1,780 107 Texas 2,120 123 ---

Two House Agriculture subcommittee chairmen are opposing a Chicago Board of Trade plan to double the number of grain and soybean futures contracts available to speculators. Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said Monday that such changes should not be made until the effects of the 1990 farm bill are known. The bill, which establishes new planting options as part of government budget cutting, will dramatically change the commodities market, said Glickman, chairman of the wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee. He and Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., whose subcommittee oversees the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, have asked the CFTC to withhold approval of the Chicago Board of Trade plan until next year. The farm bill has been approved by a House-Senate conference committee, but awaits final votes in both chambers and the president's signature. In a letter to CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm, the chairmen said the Chicago Board of Trade plan appears to be response to pressure from big commodity trading fund managers. The funds ``have little interest in the price discovery or legitimate hedging functions of these markets and view them simply as another speculative venture to market to their customers,'' the lawmakers wrote. ``We do not believe the commission should approve the proposal until its proponents can verify with certainty that it will enhance the performance of these markets and allay fears that it will simply subject grain producers, marketers, and users to unnecessary, damaging price fluctuations,'' they added.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist: Verdict Frees Him to Preach Violence
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist says a $12.5 million verdict against himself and his followers over the slaying of a black man will leave him broke - but free to preach violence without fear of being sued again. A jury Monday found that Tom Metzger, a former grand dragon of the Ku Klux Klan, and his White Aryan Resistance incited the slaying by skinhead toughs. The jury ordered Metzger and his followers to pay the family of Mulugeta Seraw the entire $12.5 million sought on its behalf by the Southern Poverty Law Center of Montgomery, Ala. ``Back home, we say it cleans his plow,'' said Morris Dees, an attorney for the law center. ``The first thing we're going to do is send a moving van to his house so we can take it over.'' Metzger, a 52-year-old TV repairman from Fallbrook, Calif., said those responsible for the wrongful-death lawsuit made a ``fatal mistake.'' ``I'll be broke, and under the Constitution I can advocate violence now and nobody can sue me anymore. So all the things I'm accused of that I didn't do I can do now,'' he said. Seraw, a 27-year-old Ethiopian who planned to attend school in Oregon, was attacked on the street in 1988. His head was split open with a softball bat. The Multnomah County jury deliberated about five hours before reaching the verdict on an 11-1 vote. Ten whites, a Japanese-American and a Hawaiian served on the panel. The jury found that Metzger incited the slaying by sending a follower to Portland to teach skinheads to commit violence against minorities. Metzger, who was in California at the time, faced no criminal charges in the case. Metzger was ordered to pay at least $5 million, his group $3 million, and his son John, 22, $1 million. Two skinheads who pleaded guilty were assessed $500,000 each. It wasn't immediately clear how the remaining $2.5 million was to be apportioned among the defendants. ``This jury, I believe, has said there will be a new season for justice in the Northwest and the hate and violence as preached by Tom Metzger hopefully will be shut down forever,'' said Dees, who had made no secret of his intent to bankrupt Metzger. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million verdict that bankrupted a Klan faction in Alabama. He had sued on behalf of the mother of a 19-year-old black man slain by two Klansmen. Metzger and his son represented themselves in the lawsuit. Dees and Metzger said Metzger doesn't have nearly enough money to pay the judgment. Metzger said earlier that his family lives on $1,200 a month. He said he probably will appeal. ``The white racist movement will not be stopped in a puny town like Portland,'' he said. ``I think they (the plaintiffs) shot themselves in the foot and as conditions change in the country, I think you're going to see it.'' Seraw's father, Seraw Tekuneh, who flew in from Ethiopia for the trial, said through an interpreter, ``This is the happiest I feel since my son died because I know he has not died in vain.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Immigration to Rise from Europe, Africa
DOC.TEXT: Increasing numbers of immigrants from Ireland, Poland and Italy will be among 2.1 million people permitted to enter the United States over the next three years under legislation nearing final approval. Staff members in the Senate and House said Monday there were no further obstacles and the bill was expected to pass in a few days. ``We have reached overall agreement on a substantial increase in employment-sponsored immigration, expanded family-based immigration, including an emphasis on immediate families, and a permanent diversity program,'' said Rep. Bruce A. Morrison, D-Conn., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on immigration. There will be a minimum of 48,000 immigrants from Ireland. An additional 72,000 will come from 33 other countries which have been able to send comparatively few people to the United States in recent years. There were no specific numbers for Poland or Italy. This movement toward diversity will also favor people from southern Asia. Additional immigrants are expected from South Korea and Japan, although these countries are not specifically named in the bill. The new law will also encourage Africans to come to the United States for the first time of their own free will. Some 420,000 workers, professionals and members of their immediate families will be admitted in the next three years because they possess needed skills. Of these, 36,000 will be employees of American companies in Hong Kong. Pressure for emigration is increasing in the British colony as the time nears for it to be turned over to China in 1997. Under present U.S. law, the total admitted on the basis of skills would be only 162,000 for the three years. The increase was due to pressure within the United States to compete with Australia, Canada and other countries that have sought immigrants who would boost their economies. The number of visas for non-refugees would be 700,000 a year for three years. Of these, 465,000 would be relatives of people already in the United States - the basis for nine of every 10 foreigners recently admitted to live here. In 1995 and afterwards there would be 675,000 visas, including 480,000 for relatives. The number admitted to bring in additional skills would continue at 140,000 a year. An annual 55,000 would be allowed in to maintain diversity of origin, with no specific countries named. The new law would keep the present annual limit of 20,000 per country of origin for non-refugees. In recent years China, Mexico, the Philippines and India have regularly reached this limit. Under a different provision, President Bush sets an annual figure for the additional admittance of refugees: 131,000 for the year that began Oct. 1, including 52,000 from East Asia and 50,000 from the Soviet Union. Last year, 1,090,000 foreigners were legally admitted to the United States, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The figure was abnormally large because it included many Mexicans and Central Americans who were already living here illegally and were granted amnesty under a new law.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Money Bill Falls Short of Authorized Amount
DOC.TEXT: The House is backing a spending bill that provides money for new programs to combat AIDS but falls short of the hefty amount approved earlier this year as the deadly disease claimed the life of Ryan White. By a vote of 335-74 Monday, the House approved a $182 billion appropriations bill for the departments of Labor, Education and Health and Human Services for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The measure includes $226 million to partially fund a newly authorized program to help cities and local governments deal with the AIDS epidemic. But that was far less than the $875 million authorized by a separate bill enacted earlier this year. That emergency AIDS treatment bill was dedicated in memory of White, an Indiana teen-ager whose fight against the disease, which he contracted from a blood transfusion, gained national attention. Overall, the bill is the second-largest appropriations measure before Congress, behind only the Defense Department spending bill. It must be approved by the Senate before being sent to President Bush. The bill, $7 billion more than requested by the administration, represents an increase of $22.6 billion in spending for the three departments and related independent agencies. The measure retains the prohibition on the use of federal money for abortions for poor women, except when the mother's life is in danger. Abortion-rights advocates had hoped to add language expanding that exception to include cases of rape and incest - a move that prompted Bush to veto the bill a year ago when it passed the House and Senate. But they were stymied when the Senate added language to that provision that would have required parental notification before a teen-age girl could obtain an abortion at any hospital or clinic receiving federal money. Supporters of legal abortions decided to drop efforts to add the money for rape-and-incest abortions rather than accept the parental notification provision. Both provisions were removed in the conference committee. In other action Monday, the House: -Voted to spend $52.2 billion on farming, nutrition and rural development programs. By voice vote, the House accepted compromises worked out by conferees on the appropriations bill that pays for farm subsidies and most Agriculture Department functions, as well as the Food and Drug Administration. -Approved, 343-67, a bill providing $20.9 billion for the Treasury Department, U.S. Postal Service and offices of the president. The bill provides all federal civilian employees - except members of Congress, federal judges and the highest-ranking officials in the executive branch - with a 4.1 percent pay raise. It also includes an overhaul of the federal pay system, including provisions aimed at adjusting salaries to take into account geographic differences in pay for private employees. In the Senate, meanwhile, a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill became snagged in a dispute over whether the United States should continue a policy that bars aid to international population agencies that offer abortion as an option. Earlier, the Senate voted to give Israel at least $700 million worth of U.S. weaponry. The aid was added to legislation that already includes $3 billion in cash for Israel and several other non-cash benefits worth hundreds of million more. Israel is the largest recipient of U.S. foreign aid.

DOC.HEAD: Chanel, Dior Show Loose Tops Over Clinging Suits
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: In summer ready-to-wear shows by a raft of big names from Chanel to Dior, loose jackets were emphasized over what has become the obligatory tight body stocking. Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel put the house's old image to rest in his show Monday. Except for piping, the quilt bag and pearls, Coco's old standbys are gone. But Lagerfeld's quilted bags are made of flashy leather, and he spruced the pearls up with colored beads. He topped hot pants, minis, bicycle tights and leggings with every imaginable jacket, showing scoop necks or various lapels and making it all work in hot shades and black-and-white. Lagerfeld found a new kind of piping in little squares - very attractive in a cream shade of yellow leather on a jacket worn with a circle-link gold belt and inevitable black stretch suit. Looser jackets almost floated in shades of peach or red over tiny, knife-pleated skirts. And the loosening up was wonderful in silly tucked nightshirt tunics over different-shaded leggings. Jean-Louis Scherrer again proved himself a master of wild-animal prints. His tiny shorts, duster-style coats, lean pants and fitted suits had the African imprint that he dressed up for evening wear in sequins. The well-cut clothes had terrific cachet for all ages. Even the fitted glen plaid jacket with its unmatched black-and-white fish print crepe short skit could be worn around town by anybody. Gianfranco Ferre's collection for Dior looked both body-hugging and loose, with floaty toppers over slim sheaths. Leading off with a line of ochre prints, Ferre put plenty of care into the collection, though it didn't always look quite on the mark. However, his billowy organza blouses were beautiful. And loose silky tunics with split sides in appealing shades of pink and apricot would be easy to wear at home, while the multicolored lame-and-brocade figured silks had a certain Oriental splendor. Hanae Mori won praise for a young and sweet collection, starting with wide trapeze beach coats printed with Japanese motifs. Her leather suits revealing a bit of bosom with no blouse underneath were daring for the Japanese doyenne of French fashion. Scottish-born Alistair Blair's first ready-to-wear collection for the house of Balmain made little splash, though he showed a few good ideas. Blair concentrated on classic casual looks in big pearl-buttoned tunics and shirtwaist-style jackets, sometimes with sleeves buttoned off or on. Sonia Rykiel offered a calm for the stressed-out fashion psyche as she turned out her usual sophisticated line of wonderful knits and sophisticated trouser-suit outfits. The favorite skirt line was a loose pullover and perhaps a tunic, fitted around the little skirts. All were hip-hugging and slightly bunched or draped. Meanwhile, Kenzo celebrated the 20th year of his house Sunday as the first Japanese to set up shop here with a sensational show and party in the School of Fine Arts. About halfway through the show, the stage was set up to look like a Neapolitan street scene - complete with guitarists, an ice-cream stand and cafe drinks for the models. Peppy innovations for women featured swirly, long-skirted outfits worn with easy contrasting shirts, harking back to the late 1950s. A party lasting until the wee hours of Monday morning numbered among its guests Paloma Picasso, model Ines de la Fressange on the arm of Christian Lacroix, Angelo Tarlazzi and Issey Miyake.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Panel Considering Post-Election `Keating Five' Hearing
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee, already under Republican fire for foot-dragging, is considering a mid-November public hearing in the ``Keating Five'' cases that would delay any decision until well after the Nov. 6 elections. If the committee took that course at a meeting today, one Republican and four Democratic senators would remain under investigation at election time for their assistance to savings and loan figure Charles H. Keating Jr. Republicans on Monday demanded a swift, pre-election decision on a special counsel's proposal that two of the five, including lone Republican John McCain of Arizona, be dropped from the investigation. Congressional sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the committee members have discussed the public hearing idea and could decide on that course when the committee deliberates today. It takes four votes to advance the investigation from the current preliminary stage. Special counsel Robert S. Bennett has recommended that the investigation continue against Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan. He proposed that probes of McCain and Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, be dropped. The committee is trying to determine whether there is a connection between the five senators' intervention with banking regulators for Keating, the former owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, and the $1.3 million in political donations they received from him and his associates. The Irvine, Calif.-based thrift was seized by the federal government in April 1989 and it may cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses. One source noted that senators will return in mid-November for party organizational meetings and predicted a hearing would be held at that time without any decision this week to advance or drop the probe among any senator. The investigation took on partisan overtones on the Senate floor Monday. Republicans complained bitterly that there were inexcusable delays. Democrats countered that the GOP was selectively leaking material that damaged Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle. McCain began the round of Republican complaints Monday, contending that ``the process has a credibility problem'' because the special counsel's report has been ``gathering dust ... for six weeks.'' He said there is a ``continued suspicion'' of an intentional failure to act on the recommendation before the election. ``There is far more at stake here than just my reputation; it is the reputation of the United States Senate,'' he said. McCain made clear that he blamed Ethics Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala. and said the panel's vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., has tried unsuccessfully to move the investigation along. But Heflin countered that senators had work conflicts that delayed a ruling last week, and he charged there was ``an organized campaign of leaks'' damaging to three Democratic senators, whom he did not identify. Documents obtained last week by The Associated Press and others showed that Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle had a much closer relationship with Keating than they had previously acknowledged. Heflin said, ``It is interesting to note that the leak of documents has been confined to three senators and that there has been no leak of documents about the two other.'' Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, added, ``It is ... particularly disturbing that the leaks have been limited to accusations against members of the Democratic Party, although the preliminary investigation now under way involves members of both parties.'' But Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas said, ``Here we are the week of adjournment and two of our colleagues (McCain and Glenn) have sort of been hung out to dry. I simply believe that it is time to take action.''

DOC.HEAD: Edgar, Hartigan Neck-and-Neck in Fund Raising
DOC.TEXT: Republican Jim Edgar and Democrat Neil Hartigan were neck and neck in fund-raising over the past three months in their race for Illinois governor. Hartigan raised $2.2 million between July 1 and Oct. 7, according to reports filed Monday with the State Board of Elections by two Hartigan campaign finance committees. Edgar raised $2.3 million during the same period, according to a report filed by his finance committee. Hartigan and Edgar have made this the most expensive Illinois governor's contest. Outgoing Gov. James R. Thompson and his opponent, former U.S. Sen. Adlai Stevenson, raised a total of about $8.8 million in 1986. Hartigan had raised a total of $7.7 million as of Monday, and Edgar had brought in more than $10 million, according to their respective campaigns.
DOC.HEAD: Martinez Criticizes Report on Pollution Suit
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez is calling ``blatantly political'' a report that the Bush administration intervened to delay a court motion on an Everglades pollution suit. Martinez said Monday he did not know of any attempt by the White House to hold back a U.S. Justice Department motion that would ask a federal judge to declare Florida in violation of its own water-quality laws and hold the state responsible for damage to the Everglades. Unidentified sources say the motion has been ready for five weeks but was delayed because it could hurt Martinez's re-election bid, the Orlando Sentinel said in a story published Sunday. ``The fact that nobody wants to step forward and give their name clearly shows it's a political statement by someone who wants to make a living out of lawsuits,'' said Martinez. ``My function as governor is to clean up the Everglades, Okeechobee and Kissimmee. That's what I've been doing,'' said Martinez, who has sought to portray himself as an environmentalist in a tight re-election battle with Democrat Lawton Chiles.
DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Meets Old Friend at Fund-Raiser
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff Howard Walker Jr. could have sworn he marched through basic training in 1969 with Vice President Dan Quayle's cousin. Quayle set him straight Monday. ``That cousin's me,'' the vice president told Walker at a Republican fund-raiser. Walker said Quayle was ``a good friend'' in his platoon at Fort Bragg, N.C., where Quayle trained before serving in the National Guard. Through the years, Walker forgot Quayle's first name. When the politician became famous, Walker assumed he was a relative of the Quayle he knew. ``When I went through the line, he recognized me, and it blew my mind,'' Walker said. Quayle got a laugh when he told the story to workers at the gaseous diffusion plant in Paducah. He said he figured it out after Walker mentioned serving with his cousin. ``I said, `Well when did you serve?''' Quayle said. ``He said `in the summer of 1969. ``I said, `Did you have Sgt. Maj. Davidson as a drill instructor?''' That cinched it. Reporters quickly clamored for details of any Quayle high-jinks during leave from the Army post. According to Walker, he and Quayle used their one weekend pass to go bowling.
DOC.HEAD: Brady Joins Push Behind Amendment For Waiting Period
DOC.TEXT: Handgun control activist Sarah Brady urged Florida voters to approve a constitutional amendment requiring a three-day waiting period for the sale of handguns. Voters will decide on Nov. 6 if they want to add the provision to the state constitution, which would make Florida the first state with a constitutionally mandated waiting period. Mrs. Brady, the wife of former presidential press secretary James Brady, has campaigned nationally for stricter gun control laws since her husband was critically wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan. Supporters of Amendment Two said the provision would block the sale of handguns to angry or depressed people. Coupled with the immediate background check on handgun purchases the Florida Department of Law Enforcement should have in place by early next year, they said the amendment would also help limit the exportation of weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Advanced Fighter Program Restored by Conferees
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators on a military spending bill are at odds with Congress' armed services committees over President Bush's plan for full-scale development of the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Fighter. House and Senate bargainers were still working out final aspects of a $268 billion package for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, with hopes of formally submitting the legislation today. Earlier in the process, negotiators from the congressional appropriations committees adopted several provisions that vastly differ from a separate defense authorization bill worked out last week by members of the Senate and House Armed Services committees. In that bill, lawmakers agreed to Bush's fiscal 1991 budget request for full-scale development of the Advanced Tactical Fighter, the aircraft intended to replace the Air Force's F-15. The administration sought $283 million for full-scale development and $763 million to complete the demonstration and validation phase of the prototype aircraft. The defense blueprint approved by House and Senate negotiators last week provides $964 million for the program but prohibits full-scale development this fiscal year. The bargainers stressed the need for the Air Force to finish demonstrating several technologies before beginning full-scale development. Negotiators on the spending bill agreed to the administration's request for full-scale development, one year after expressing concerns about the program. In his major aircraft review, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced his revised plans for the new fighter, which included delaying purchases from 1994 to 1996. The Pentagon plans to buy 750 of the planes. Among the measures in the spending bill are a troop cut of 78,500 from the 2.1 million men and women in uniform worldwide, just over $900 million for the MILSTAR communications satellite and no restrictive language on the Strategic Defense Initiative program. In the authorization bill that sets ceilings for military spending, conferees last week approved a troop cut of 100,000 and agreed to $600 million for MILSTAR. The negotiators also adopted language that limits spending on accounts within the SDI program, thus delaying early deployment of the antimissile system. Congress is expected to approve the spending and authorization bills this week and send them to Bush. However, the authorization bill faces a veto threat. Shortly after the package was announced, Cheney signaled he would recommend that Bush veto the bill. Pentagon officials complained about the size of the troop cut, the restrictive language on SDI and the wording on a base-closure measure. Congressional aides and Pentagon officials worked throughout the weekend and Monday to modify the provisions to make them more acceptable to the administration. A Defense Department official, who requested anonymity, said that some of the issues ``are moving toward resolution in a ay we would like. We're still leaning out there with a possibility of a veto.''

DOC.HEAD: Killer Bee Invasion Believed Thwarted Until the Spring
DOC.TEXT: Scientists believe they have turned back the first U.S. invasion of killer bees but expect a new offensive in the spring. Authorities Monday had not confirmed any new swarms in the week since they trapped the first of the Africanized killer bees that crossed into the United States from Mexico. ``I'm going on the assumption that we won't find another swarm'' until spring, said Elba Quintero, area honey bee program manager for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. ``The weather is getting colder and bees do not normally move in winter time.'' USDA teams on Friday started a search for bees within two miles of where the first swarm of 3,000 was found and destroyed, near the city of Hidalgo. They are taking samples of all managed and wild bee colonies in the area. U.S. and Mexican officials in the past three years had placed hundreds of traps baited with a sex lure to track the bees, which have been moving slowly north since 1957, when they escaped from a breeding experiment in Brazil. Killer bees earned their nickname because of their habit of attacking intruders in swarms and chasing their prey for long distances. Beekeepers and farmers fear the killer bees will take over domestic hives and reduce honey production and pollination of important crops. The swarm last week prompted a quarantine on movement of bees out of the two-mile radius where the killer variety was found. The quarantine also prohibits movement of bees from Texas' eight southernmost counties. USDA trapped two swarms during the weekend along the Rio Grande less than a mile from where the Africanized swarm was caught, but the bees probably are not Africanized, Ms. Quintero said. Test results were expected today. To the naked eye, Africanized bees are impossible to distinguish from the more docile European bees commonly raised in the Americas.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail Seeks Arbitration in D&H-Conrail Track Dispute
DOC.TEXT:
Conrail has demanded that an arbitrator decide whether the Delaware & Hudson Railway has the right to use its own trains and crews on a brief stretch of Conrail tracks between Buffalo and Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Consolidated Rail Corp. called for binding arbitration in legal papers served late Monday. The action came hours after a special regional rail reorganization court denied Conrail's request to hear the trackage case. In the meantime, the issue will be reviewed by the bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., who has been overseeing the D&H reorganization. The approximately 15-mile stretch is key to a $25 million offer by Canadian Pacific Ltd. to buy the ailing D&H. Without access to the Buffalo-Niagara Gateway, CP would be unable to connect the D&H with its own lines in southern Ontario. Canadian Pacific hopes to use the D&H system to connect the ports of Philadelphia and New York with the Canadian interior. If CP can put the pieces together, it will be compete directly with Conrail for freight in the Northeast.
---
DOC.HEAD: Law Students Support Donated Legal Services
DOC.TEXT:
Law schools should require students to donate their services to people who can't afford legal representation, says a group of law students. ``We find that it is really outrageous that people can go through three years of law school and never be exposed to the legal problems of someone who can't afford a lawyer,'' Harvard law student Steve Donzinger, a member of Law Students for Pro Bono, said Monday. ``We are asking our educators to say ... these problems are important enough to incorporate into our education,'' he said at a news conference here. The group wants each of the nation's 175 accredited law schools to incorporate a pro bono requirement into their traditional courses of legal study by 2000. Lawyers and other professional don't charge for pro bono services. Donzinger said fewer than one in six lawyers or law students performs any pro bono work, even though American Bar Association guidelines say its members should perform 50 hours of such work annually.
---
DOC.HEAD: House Passes College Disclosure Bill
DOC.TEXT:
Congress wants colleges to be required to tell prospective students how many athltes graduate and how much crime there is on campus. The House approved by voice vote Monday a bill that would force colleges and universities that receive federal financial aid and grant athletic scholarships to provide graduation data to the Education Department. Academic institutions receiving federal student aid also would have to disclose to students and employees their campus security policies and crime statistics. The bill approved Monday was a compromise measure produced by a conference committee of the House and Senate that ironed out differences in versions passed by each House. The Senate must approve before the final version before it can go to the president.
---
DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Raise Long-Distance Rates.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph is raising its basic night and weekend long-distance telephone rates by 2.2 percent effective Nov. 2. The company said Monday that the increase will result in about $39.4 million in increased annual revenue - about five cents on an average $16 monthly long-distance bill. AT&T said the increase applies only to out-of-state direct-dialed long distance calls made during night and weekend hours. These are after 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday and all weekend until 5 p.m. Sunday. The company said that overall its out-of-state direct-dialed long-distance rates have gone down about 42 percent since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes $700 Million in New Weaponry for Israel
DOC.TEXT: Israel, already the top recipient of U.S. foreign aid, would be given at least $700 million worth of American arms under an addition approved by the Senate with only a single dissenting vote. The Senate voted 97-1 Monday to add the weaponry to a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill that already includes $3 billion in cash for Israel and several other non-cash benefits worth hundreds of millions more. However, the overall bill is subject to further debate in the Senate and its provisions also would have to be agreed to by the House before going to President Bush. The aid would come primarily from equipment being withdrawn from Europe as East-West tensions ease, and must be committed within nine months unless doing so would jeopardize the readiness of U.S. forces. The sponsors, Sens. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, and Robert Kasten, R-Wis., contended that the help was needed to counter the threat of an attack on Israel by Iraq. ``The best interest of this country is served by assuring the viability of Israel,'' Inouye said, citing that country's free sharing of Middle Eastern intelligence with the United States. ``It is the best ally we have.'' But Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., the only senator to oppose the aid, countered that ``the United States is not a bottomless pit of aid money.'' ``No one can say this amendment should be passed because we have not done enough for Israel,'' said Byrd, who chairs the Senate Appropriations Committee. Byrd criticized what he said was the ``fake psychology'' that any lawmaker who votes against a new benefit for Tel Aviv is an enemy of Israel. ``That attitude has been used to considerable advantage around here for years,'' he complained. The new Israeli aid, which Inouye characterized as a message of support, was an apparent attempt to counterbalance new aid to two Arab countries: $6.7 billion in debt forgiveness for Egypt and a $7.5 billion weapons sale to Saudi Arabia. In addition to Israel's $1.8 billion in military and $1.2 billion in economic aid, the bill earmarks $2.1 billion for Egypt, $72 million for Morocco, $382 million for Greece and $545 million for Turkey. The measure became snagged later Monday in a dispute over whether the United States should continue a policy that bars aid to international population agencies that offer abortion as an option. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., pressed an amendment that would remove the United States from a list of countries that signed the policy in 1984. Sens. William Armstrong, R-Colo., and Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., threatened a filibuster over the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Study Shows Cocaine Increases Growth of AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: Researchers say cocaine has been found to speed the growth of the AIDS virus in the test tube, prompting concern it could do the same in drug users. Researchers with the University of Minnesota Medical School at Minneapolis took peripheral blood mononuclear cells and exposed them to doses of cocaine. The cells are a primary target for the AIDS virus. The virus was found to grow as much as three times faster in the cocaine-laced tests. ``In persons who are infected, if they continue to abuse this drug it may have a significant impact on the development of clinical AIDS,'' said Dr. Ronald Schut. Schut presented the findings at the Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, sponsored by the American Society for Microbiology. While about 150,000 AIDS cases have been reported in the United States, researchers say an additional million or more Americans are infected and at risk of developing AIDS. The question now for researchers is whether drug use somehow modifies the immune system to enhance growth of the AIDS, or HIV, virus. ``The initial in-vitro (test-tube) studies suggest that it's possible,'' Schut said. Dr. James Curran, director of the Division of HIV-AIDS at the Centers for Disease Control, said little if any solid information is available on the risk AIDS poses cocaine users. He said drug users are notoriously difficult to study. However, as far as cocaine is concerned, Curran said, ``I think it's safe to recommend don't do it.'' Further studies are under way using immune cells from drug users in a methadone program, where cocaine use is high, to see if the virus grows more easily, Schut said. Also at the conference, doctors from Los Angeles' Kaiser Permanente Medical Center reported that low doses of a common antibiotic can prevent a life-threatening complication in AIDS patients, pneumocystis pneumonia, at much lower cost than the widely recommended aerosol pentamidine. Thrice weekly tablets of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, which is used frequently for mild bacterial infections, prevented pneumocystis pneumonia in 116 high-risk patients for two years, Dr. Joel Ruskin reported. That drug can cost as little as $12 a year, while aerosol pentamidine can cost hundreds, the doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Sustains Lead Over Karpov
With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: The fifth game of the world championship chess match between Anatoly Karpov and Garry Kasparov ended in a draw, enabling Kasparov to keep his one-point lead in the series. The game ended Monday night with Karpov offering the defending champion a draw after his 36th move. Each player got a half point, leaving the score 3 to 2. Game 6 will be Wednesday. The first player to reach 12{ points in the 24-game series will win the championship. Kasparov, who dethroned Karpov in 1985, got a full point for his victory in the second game. The three other games were draws. On the 10th move, Karpov forced the exchange of his queen for Kasparov's queen, which many grandmasters thought was an attempt by Karpov to play for a draw rather than a win. When queens are traded off early in a game, this often reduces the chances of an overwhelming attack by either player. It also increases the boredom. ``This is the most boring game they ever played,'' said grandmaster Roman Dzindzichashvili of New York City. International master Vitaly Zaltsman of New York City said of Karpov, ``This guy is chicken. He has no fighting spirit.'' The first 12 games are being played in New York and the rest will be played in Lyon, France. The winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Also Gain
DOC.TEXT: - The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen in Tokyo on Tuesday while prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange also closed slightly higher. The dollar closed at 127.13 yen, up 0.88 yen from Monday's close of 126.25 yen. The currency opened at 126.40 yen, and traded between 126.30 yen and 127.37 yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,298.30, up 227.44 points, or 0.91 percent, from Monday's 25,070.86-point close. Trading volume was moderately heavy at 550 million shares after the market opened higher at 25,279.10 points. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 84.92 points from their previous close of 84.75 points on Monday. Their yield dropped to 7.710 percent from 7.750 percent. Tuesday's higher stock market close was the seventh consecutive rise in a recovery that began after an extended bear market. The Nikkei average fell to a two-year low of 20,221.86 points on Oct. 1. The cheaper yen was one strong influence, said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst for Nomura Securities. Traders also said lower interest rates, falling crude oil prices and hope for a negotiated settlement in the Middle East helped buoy stock trading. ``The market has changed in the last two weeks,'' said Hidetada Yoshida, a trader for Kidder Peabody International Corp. ``Japanese investors and foreign investors have found the bottom of the Tokyo market.'' But profit-taking might depress any dramatic market rise, he said. The dollar has been edging up slowly against the yen since Friday. On Monday, the dollar gained 1.0 yen after falling 13.55 yen in the 13 previous trading days. But market observers foresee no radical move toward dollar buying. ``There are very few elements in the market to cause big changes,'' said a dealer at Sanwa Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The dollar has gained back some lost ground partly because its drop had been too rapid, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Parties Claim Gains In Nationwide Vote
DOC.TEXT: The conservatives retained control of Greece's second-largest city in weekend mayoral elections, but a socialist-communist coalition captured major provincial centers. In the northern city of Salonica, Mayor Constantine Cosmopoulos of the conservative New Democracy party edged out Dimitris Fatouros, candidate of the socialists and communist-dominated Coalition of the Left and Progress. Final results released Monday by the Interior Ministry showed that Cosmopoulos received 50.91 percent of the vote to 49.09 percent for Fatouros. The hard-fought race in the key industrial city was considered a gauge of political sentiment for the national New Democracy-led administration, which was buffeted by five nationwide walkouts in September. The strikes were in protest of tough austerity measures implemented by the 6-month-old government to slash state spending and offset $10 billion in debts. The first round of mayoral elections was held on Oct. 14, with 215 towns and cities involved. On Sunday, runoffs were held in 143 municipalties. Final results indicated that many leftist voters failed to toe the party line, especially in Athens, Salonica and in provincial areas considered socialist-leftist strongholds. But candidates supported by the socialist-communist coalition took the next three biggest cities in the country - Piraeus near the capital, Patras in the southwest and Iraklion, on the island of Crete. On Oct. 14, the New Democracy-supported candidate in Athens, former socialist minister Antonis Tritsis, edged out popular socialist parliamentarian Melina Mercouri. Former Premier Andreas Papandreou, who heads the socialist Panhellenic Socialist Movement, claimed the conservatives lost 4 percent of their strength overall and called on his party to prepare for new general elections. Premier Constantine Mitsotakis dismissed the claims. He said New Democracy-backed candidates made major inroads by unseating 20 leftist mayors on Oct. 14 and significant gains in some provincial areas on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Awards Baby to Genetic Parents Over Surrogate Mother
LaserPhotos LA1, LA2
DOC.TEXT: Carrying a child does not make a woman a parent, a judge ruled in awarding a test-tube baby to the boy's genetic parents instead of the surrogate they hired for $10,000. Civil rights advocates and ethicists charged that the ruling Monday by Superior Court Judge Richard Parslow ignores the law and creates a ``breeder class'' of women. ``The judge is saying gestation doesn't count, it counts for nothing, and I think that is a very disturbing outcome,'' said Susan M. Wolf, an associate for law at the Hastings Center, an ethics research institute in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. In giving custody of the 5-week-old boy to Mark and Crispina Calvert instead of surrogate mother Anna Johnson, the judge said, ``A surrogate carrying a genetic child for a couple does not acquire parental rights.'' Parslow said Ms. Johnson made a ``substantial contribution'' in giving birth to the child. But her relationship to the baby was like a foster parent who takes a child in when the parent can't, the judge said. ``I think a three-parent, two-natural mom claim in a situation is ripe for crazy-making,'' he said. ``I decline to split this child emotionally between two mothers.'' The decision upholds a contract under which the Calverts agreed to pay Ms. Johnson to carry an embryo created from the couple's sperm and egg. A hysterectomy prevents Mrs. Calvert, 36, from carrying a baby. ``We are entering into very dangerous times if we allow the creation of a breeder class of women whose parental rights can be signed away in a business deal,'' said Ramona Ripston, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. The ACLU had urged the judge to rule all three adults were legitimate parents. The ruling is a ``radical departure from the pre-existing law,'' said Ms. Wolf said. Attorneys had said the dispute could break legal ground because a genetically unrelated surrogate never had sought custody. New Jersey's Baby M case involved a surrogate who was also the baby's genetic mother. In that case, a New Jersey court awarded custody to the father and his wife but ruled that surrogate mother Mary Beth Whitehead also had parental rights. Ms. Johnson, 29, of Mission Viejo, described herself as ``heartbroken'' over the ruling and said she would appeal to the Supreme Court, if necessary, to gain shared custody. ``I'm in a deep state of mourning for my son. He's going to be very confused. He's going to be looking for me,'' she said. Ms. Johnson was ordered to stop her twice-a-week visits to the baby, who was in the Calverts' care since shortly after his Sept. 19 birth. ``I just held him close to me, let him nuzzle up into my shoulder and whispered in his ear that mommy's trying her hardest to get him back,'' she said. ``This is a glorious day,'' said Calvert, 34. Referring to Ms. Johnson's argument that she had developed a bond with the infant, he said, ``The only bonding Anna Johnson has is with your television cameras.'' Christopher Michael Calvert will be the name entered on the child's birth certificate, which was held up by the dispute, the father said. The judge said that Ms. Johnson signed the $10,000 contract knowing she was to give the child to the Calverts. They have paid her $5,000 so far. He also found that surrogate contracts in in-vitro fertilization cases ``are not void or in violation or public policy,'' and he predicted the ``hunger'' by childless couples for their own children would spur more people to pursue similar arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Lincoln's Cracked Sidewalks - Who Shall Pay?
DOC.TEXT: Across the country, voters are said to be on the brink of revolt over rising taxs, politicians who don't lead, schools that don't teach. Here in Lincoln, it's cracked sidewalks. Residents of this city, which is in the midst of a six-year crackdown on cracks, go to the polls Nov. 6 to consider two proposed city charter amendments dealing with who should pay for city-ordered repairs: the city, or homeowners. One ballot question asks voters whether the city should pay. A second seeks reimbursement to property owners for repairs made since April 10, 1989, when the sidewalk improvement campaign began. The questions got on the ballot after Allen Boettcher, a retired extension agent, and 150 other volunteers collected the 3,000 signatures needed to give voters a say in who pays. ``Everybody uses the sidewalks, but only property owners have to pay for the repairs,'' said Boettcher. ``That's the great injustice.'' Sidewalk inspectors fanned out through the capital city's neighborhoods in April 1989, armed with cans of orange spray paint to circle cracks and raised edges. The goal was to inspect and require repairs on all unsafe and broken sidewalks over a six-year period. To date, the city has ordered repairs on about 7,800 properties and new sidewalks for an additional 300. The City Council hoped to make sidewalks safer for people in wheelchairs, the elderly, children, runners and walkers. But Boettcher said some homeowners have been forced to pay two or three times their city property taxes to have the sidewalks fixed. Refunds could cost the city between $800,000 and $900,000, city engineer Rich Robinson said. He said that the city has to pay $40 to $48 to hire a contractor to build a 4-by-4-foot sidewalk section and that property owners may be able to get the work done cheaper. City Attorney Bill Austin has suggested he will recommend legal challenges if voters approve the measures. Regardless of the outcome at the ballot box, Boettcher has caught the attention of Mayor Bill Harris, who has formed a committee of public officials and residents, including Boettcher, to review the sidewalk repair campaign. The campaign replaced a random program that required the filing of complaints about unsafe sidewalks to the Public Works Department. ``People think we have a new sidewalk policy and they have to pay for their sidewalks,'' said Linda Wilson, a City Council member. ``But that's always been the case.'' Councilman Ken Haar said passage of the measures could force the city to back down on its policy of requiring repairs. Boettcher, who has had to repair one sidewalk section near his home, said he supports repairs, as long as the city pays for them. ``It's the most basic part of the city's transportation system,'' he said, adding that the city pays for streets, trails and parks.

DOC.HEAD: Defection Of Hindu Fundamentalist Party Threatens Singh Government
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing Hindu party withdrew its support for Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government today, threatening to bring down the fragile coalition that has governed India for the past 10 months. Singh refused to resign and said he would take the battle to floor of Parliament, where his centrist National Front government had relied on the votes of the Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party to survive. The crisis was precipitated by the arrest earlier Tuesday of Bharatiya Janata's president, Lal Krishna Advani, as he led a cross-country march to muster support for building a new Hindu temple on the site of a 16th century Moslem mosque. About six hours later, party leaders submitted a letter to Indian President Ramaswamy Venkataraman withdrawing support for Singh's National Front government. The prime minister told reporters at the presidential palace that the loss of Bharatiya Janata support ``doesn't mean that all support is gone.'' However, it was unclear how he could avoid calling new elections. With the defection of the Bharatiya Janata Party, Singh's centrist government loses the fragile majority it cobbled together from across the political spectrum after November general elections. No single party had won enough seats to take power unilaterally. The next steps are up to Singh and the president. Under the constitution, the options include Singh's resignation as prime minister and elections for a new Parliament. President Venkataraman could also ask Singh to try to muster a new majority in Parliament, which appears mathematically and politically improbable. Or, the president can turn to the opposition leader, former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, and ask if Gandhi's Congress Party could form a coalition government. That also appears unlikely. The crisis was precipitated by Advani's determination to go ahead with his march to bolster support for the campaign to replace a Moslem mosque with a temple to the Hindu god Lord Rama. Singh had urged Hindu fundamentalists to postpone the temple plan. At least 80 people died this month in Hindu-Moslem clashes spurred by the dispute. In a nationally televised address Monday night, Singh renewed his appeal and said he was prepared to face the fact that his stand could bring down the government. ``Religious fanaticism is the first step towards the foundation for a theocratic state,'' Singh said in his 20-minute TV speech. ``It will be the death of India as a secular state.'' The prime minister added: ``Hundreds of governments can come and go, but the nation should remain one.'' Advani was arrested about sunrise in a remote part of Bihar state near the village of Samastipur, about 450 miles southeast of New Delhi. He had been leading a caravan of supporters across the Hindu heartland to demonstrate and bolster support for plans to build a temple on a site now occupied by a 16th century mosque in the holy Hindu town of Ayodhya. Ayodhya is in Uttar Pradesh state, which lies between New Delhi and Bihar state. Advani's planned path through Bihar and Uttar Pradesh en route to Ayodhya would have taken him through poor villages populated by both Moslems and Hindus. In Bihar especially, these villages have been recurring flashpoints for Hindu-Moslem violence. Hindu fundamentalists have vowed to start building the temple in one week on the spot where they say the Hindu god Lord Rama was born. Moslem activists and religious leaders have vowed to prevent any encroachment on the mosque. The outcry has torn at the social and political fabric of officially secular India, where 82 percent of the 880 million people are Hindus. Moslems form 12 percent of the population. Singh took office in December after ousting Gandhi and his Congress Party in the November general election. Although the Congress Party and its allies hold 210 of Parliament's 522 seats, it lacked the majority to govern. Singh's National Front coalition holds just 141 seats, but it won the tacit support of the two extremes of India's political spectrum: Advani's right-wing Hindu party and the Left Front alliance of several communist parties. With that support, Singh could draw on enough votes to give him the majority needed to pass legislation and stay in power. Bharatiya Janata has 88 members of Parliament, the Left Front 51.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Release Rare Shark
DOC.TEXT: Scientists set free a rare megamouth shark, only one of five ever seen, after deciding the 15-foot, 2,000-pound behemoth with a gaping, silvery maw could not survive in captivity. Biologists attached a radio transmitter to the shark Monday so they can track it for three days until the device's batteries run out. The shark ``is a fabulous opportunity for us, but the animal comes first,'' said Dennis Kelly, an Orange Coast College marine biologist. ``You hate to see something like this die.'' It was apparently the first member of its species to be brought ashore alive and only the fifth such creature ever seen. ``This is like an alien coming out of the depths. It's one in a million,'' Kelly said. With its large, bulbous snout and mouth that can open as wide as two feet, the plankton-eating megamouth is one of the largest sharks in the world. Its mouth is lined with silvery tissue that scientists believe may generate light to attract plankton in dark ocean water. The shark was accidentally snared in a 1,200-foot-wide drift net Sunday in shallow water offshore, then towed here by a 38-foot commercial fishing boat and tethered by its tail to the vessel. After trying without success to find an aquarium big enough to hold the shark, scientists decided to release it, said Robert Lavenberg, curator of fishes at the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History. The fishing boat towed the shark out of the harbor so scientists could videotape it underwater and attach the transmitter. ``It will show the depth, which is the most significant thing we can find out,'' said Rocky Strong, a researcher for the Cousteau Society. Scientists wondered why the shark was swimming in less than 100 feet of water when caught by the net. The sharks are known to swim at depths of 700 feet to several thousand feet. The Sea Shepherd Conservation Society in Redondo Beach had urged that the shark be released immediately. ``It's as if we found a dinosaur and chained it to a tree until it dies,'' Sea Shepherd president Scott Trimingham said. ``One animal left alive in the wild is worth more than 1,000 dead specimens.'' The first megamouth shark ever discovered was caught off Hawaii in 1976 after it swallowed a Navy anchor. It died before biologists could see it. A megamouth was caught off California's Santa Catalina Island in 1984, but died en route to port. It is on display at Lavenberg's museum. Another washed ashore south of Perth, Australia, and died within hours. The decomposed carcass of a fourth megamouth washed ashore in Japan. All four megamouths seen previously measured about 14{ feet.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral for a Clown: Balloon Animals and a Bright Red Nose
DOC.TEXT: There was a lot of clowning around at the funeral, but everybody knew that's how the departed would have wanted it. In fact, Patches the Clown had insisted on it. Patches, also known as Richard Eugene ``Dick'' Brunner, was buried Monday in his trademark black derby, patched suit and polka-dot tie. His nose was covered with bright red clown paint. Brunner, 69, was laid to rest in a casket festooned with balloon animals. He was carried to his grave in a hearse painted with pictures of clowns and balloons. Brunner, who died Saturday in a Nashville, Tenn., hospital, had told a friend of his funeral plans in June after learning he was dying of leukemia. ``I said, `If that's what you want, have at it,' '' said Marvin Melhiser, a fellow member of the Shriners organization for which Brunner performed as a clown. So Brunner's funeral opened with a recording of ``Send in the Clowns,'' a cue that brought 17 clowns into the chapel. They handed out balloon animals to mourners. ``He always had a joke, always had a smile,'' recalled fellow clown Al Arnold.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Government Won't Acknowledge Military Role in Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-backed drug war in Colombia has diverted attention from unprecendented human rights abuses, including those committed by army-sponsored death squads, a rights group says. The independent group Americas Watch said Monday that disappearances, massacres and assassinations have soared since the government cracked down on the drug trade in August 1989. Americas Watch did not accuse the central government of directly violating human rights but said it had refused to acknowledge the high degree of military involvement, only making matters worse. The report said army troops repeatedly violate the laws of war in trying to eradicate leftist guerrillas and have formed ``unholy'' alliances with drug traffickers and paramilitary death squads. It also documented human rights violations by left-wing rebels and traffickers. Traffickers, who have acquired vast land holdings, often share the fanatical right-wing ideologies of the death squads, the report said. It said the Bush administration did not escape responsibility since it pours in millions of dollars of military aid without demanding human rights safeguards. U.S. anti-drug aid often ends up in the hands of unscrupulous army officers who use the money to terrorize local populations, the report says. The government of President Cesar Gaviria, in office for three months, is preparing an official response to the report. A senior government official, speaking to reporters on condition of anonymity, denied that the government lacks the will to prosecute army officers who violate human rights. ``Between 2,000 and 2,200 members of the armed forces have been removed from their posts for various disciplinary reasons since 1987,'' he said. The former administration of President Virgilio Barco began a major crackdown on drug traffickers after the Medellin cocaine cartel assassinated a leading presidential candidate in August 1989. Since then, the government has blamed most political killings on the cartel, all but ignoring army involvement, Americas Watch said. ``The government's insistence that the Medellin cartel leaders are responsible for all violent abuses has become a serious obstacle to efforts to halt the violence, since it has left other paramilitary groups largely free to assassinate leftist leaders and massacre their perceived supporters,'' the report says. It says political violence claimed the lives of 4,000 people in 1988 and 3,200 in 1989, adding, ``These figures as noted are the highest in the hemisphere during those years.'' Some senior army officers have joined forces with paramilitary death squads and drug traffickers in a common battle to defeat the left at any cost, the study says. While recognizing the ``courageous efforts'' of many officials who tried to curb abuses, Americas Watch said government security personnel have tortured or murdered some suspected drug traffickers. ``Suspects `disappeared' after their arrest, many detainees were tortured and in neighborhoods of Medellin the police arrested young people indiscriminately and at times opened fire in crowded public places,'' the report says. Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, is home to the world's most notorious cocaine cartel. The government official acknowledged that ``problems of this nature'' could exist, but said security forces who commit abuses act on their own. Americas Watch said the Bush administration is expected to send $382 million in military and police aid to Colombia between 1990 and 1994, ``without any effort to ensure that these funds do not reach abusive forces.''

DOC.HEAD: Clark Kent and Lois Lane to Tie the Knot
DOC.TEXT: After a half century of avoiding commitment as if it were kryptonite, Superman has popped the question to Lois Lane, and she said yes. ``They've played games long enough,'' ``Superman'' editor Michael Carlin said Monday. ``This story HAD to happen.'' No wedding date was announced, and complications can be expected: The Man of Steel proposes as mild-mannered Clark Kent, and Miss Lane, who accepts in the Nov. 1 issue of ``Superman'' comics, is unaware of his true identity. Superman asks for Miss Lane's hand after he is exposed to red kryptonite, loses his super powers and becomes convinced he can finally lead a normal life. ``It's not a gag, not a one-issue trick story,'' according to an announcement from DC Comics. ``This time, for the first time since the characters were created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster, it's for real.'' A fist-size, plastic engagement ring came in the announcement, along with a newspaper-style notification that gives the lovebirds' backgrounds. For example, Kent, a native of Smallville, Kan., and Miss Lane of Queensland Park, Metropolis, are both Pulitzer Prize winners and published novelists. Kent writes a syndicated column. Miss Lane, who for years barely tolerated Clark and had a crush on Superman, has recently come to see that he is the one ``who is always there when she needs him,'' DC Comics said. Not every proposal becomes a wedding, of course, and when Superman regains his super powers he must again decide whether to reveal his secret identity to Miss Lane. To be continued, as they say.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Film Producer Dies at 83
DOC.TEXT: Lester Cowan, an independent producer whose credits include the W.C. Fields comedies ``You Can't Cheat an Honest Man'' and ``My Little Chickadee,'' died of an apparent heart attack at 83. Cowan, who died at his home on Sunday, was production supervisor of John Ford's 1935 film ``The Whole Town's Talking,'' starring Edward G. Robinson and Jean Arthur. Four years later he produced the first of his own films, ``You Can't Cheat an Honest Man,'' and in 1940 made ``My Little Chickadee,'' which also starred Mae West. In the 1940s, he produced ``Commandos Strike at Dawn,'' ``Tomorrow the World'' and ``The Story of G.I. Joe.'' Cowan originated the first college course in film studies in 1929 at the University of Southern California. Cowan is survived by his wife, Ann Ronell; two brothers, and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: Roy Rogers Undergoes Surgery For Aneurysm
DOC.TEXT: Singing cowboy star Roy Rogers was in good condition after surgery to repair his aorta, his son said. Rogers, 79, underwent four hours of surgery Monday at St. Mary Desert Valley Hospital, said Roy ``Dusty'' Rogers Jr. ``He came through it very well,'' the actor's son said. ``He's off the respirator. The nurse kept telling him to open his eyes, and he kept saying no. He's getting his orneriness back, and that's a good sign.'' Rogers starred in 87 Westerns, including 35 with his wife, Dale Evans, who wrote their theme song, ``Happy Trails.'' His horse, Trigger, is on display at the Roy Rogers-Dale Evans Museum in Victorville. Rogers checked into the hospital Sunday after complaining of stomach pain during church services in this town about 75 miles from Los Angeles. His wife drove him to the hospital. Doctors had monitored an aneurysm, or weak spot, in his aorta for several months, and found that it had bled in one spot, his son said. The aorta is the body's main artery. Rogers underwent open heart surgery in 1978. Earlier this month, he joined Randy Travis at the Country Music Awards in Nashville, Tenn., to sing Travis' ``Heroes and Friends,'' a tribute to Western movie stars. Born Leonard Slye in Cincinnati, Rogers came to California in 1929 as a migrant fruit picker. He appeared as a singer on a Los Angeles radio show called ``Midnight Frolic'' in the early 1930s, and his first bit film role came in 1935. He launched several business ventures, including the Roy Rogers chain of fast food restaurants.

DOC.HEAD: Cleveland Mayor Accepts Apology for Joke
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `The joke ...' to FIX typo in `mad.'
DOC.TEXT: Jerry Van Dyke, in his role as dimwitted Luther Van Dam from ``Coach,'' apologized on the air for having knocked Cleveland two weeks ago in an promotional spot for the ABC comedy, and the mayor accepted. The apology came in a promo as well. It was aired during the Monday night football game between the Cleveland Browns and the Cincinnati Bengals. ``I just want to say that I'm sorry, Cleveland, and I love Cleveland and I love the people in it,'' Van Dam said. Mayor Michael R. White replied: ``The Cleveland of today and the Cleveland of 15 years ago are vastly different places. I think the apology frankly recognizes that there has been a major improvement.'' The joke that got Cleveland so mad was broadcast Oct. 8 during a Monday night football game between Cleveland and Denver. Van Dam, a football coach in ``Coach,'' said in the promo, ``I think the problem with Cleveland is, even if you win, you lose. You still got to go home to Cleveland.'' Dale R. Finley, president of the Cleveland Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the joke reflected an image created when the city's oil-slicked Cuyahoga River caught fire 20 years ago and the city went into default in 1978. The city has since changed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Koreans Cheer Soccer Teams From North and South
DOC.TEXT: The two Koreas met on the soccer field at Olympic Stadium today before more than 80,000 South Koreans, who cheered for both teams and roared approval for unification. South Korea's national team won 1-0, but the score was insignificant beside the diplomatic coup in having two enemy nations share a playing field for only the second time since World War II. The first time was two weeks ago in North Korea, when the northern team beat the south 2-1. Today's crowd was the largest to see a South Korean sports event since the 1988 Olympic Games. At the end of the game, spectators rose for a standing ovation as the athletes jogged around the stadium holding hands and waving. The teams exchanged shirts and waved them in the air. ``Our wish is unification,'' blared a unification song over the loudspeakers. The game, called North-South Unification Soccer, is the high point of a five-day visit by a 78-member North Korean sports delegation, the first from the Communist north to visit the south since the 1945 division of the peninsula. South Korean soccer players visited the north earlier this month. That visit was only the second civilian exchange between the countries in more than four decades. The soccer delegation returns to North Korea on Friday after rounds of sightseeing, dinners and talks on future sports exchanges. South Korean Sports Minister Chung Dong Sung and his North Korean counterpart, Kim Yu Sun, agreed in principle to form a joint single team for the 1992 Olympic Games and other international sports events at talks in Pyongyang. They said further discussions would be held in Seoul. About 5,000 plainclothes police were positioned inside and outside the stadium. Spectators were searched twice and passed through metal detectors to get to their seats. Scalpers were asking $140 for tickets, 10 times the highest face value price. The teams of the rival Koreas entered the stadium side by side, holding hands and waving to thunderous applause. ``This is not purely sports festival,'' Kim said before the match began. ``It should lead to a unification festival.'' ``I hope this soccer match will be a spring board for national unification,'' Chung. Thousands roared in approval and waved colorful pompons. Spectators had been asked not to bring national flags, decorative placards or other paraphernalia which would be identified only with South Korea. A drum and bugle corps played and a gigantic electric signboard flashed the pictures of the ministers. The North Korean team threw half a dozen soccer balls signed with their signatures into the grandstand and screaming spectators raced to retrieve them. During the game, the South Korean crowd cheered wildly for plays by both teams. Radical students, who had said they would root for the North Korean visitors, were not visible. News reports said tickets were sold on an individual basis apparently to avoid large radical or dissident groups sitting together. The sports exchange comes at a time when South Korea and North Korea are seeking to find ways to ease tensions and work together for unification. The prime ministers of both Koreas met for the second time last week in Pyongyang, the north's capital, and have agreed to meet again in Seoul in December. A South Korean musicians' delegation returns Wednesday from a 10-day visit to the north. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945 at the end of the World War II. The two nations fought a war in the early 1950s and a peace treaty was never signed. The border between the Koreas remains tightly sealed and is one of the most heavily fortified demarcations in the world with more than 1.5 million troops on either side.

DOC.HEAD: Two Women Soldiers Stabbed in Northern Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT age of slain youth to 14, SUB graf 8, `One of ... army said.' Picks up 9th pvs, `The first ...' ^By ALLYN FISHER
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian truck driver stabbed two women soldiers in northern Israel today in a third straight day of Arab knifing attacks in the country, Arab reports and Israel radio said. The wounded soldiers were rushed to Rambam Hospital in the port city of Haifa, the radio said. Their condition was not immediately known. The attack occurred as the soldiers waited for a ride to their base at a hitchhiking post at a major intersection, the radio and Arab reports said. A truck with blue license plates, indicating ownership by a Palestinian from the occupied West Bank, stopped and the driver got out, the radio said. ``He took out a knife and started to stab the soldiers,'' the radio said. Other soldiers at the site fired on the assailant as he fled, it said. Police said the man later was captured. Israel radio said the man was from Jenin in the West Bank. The town of about 20,000 people and surrounding camps were torn by anti-Israeli protests on Monday. At least nine Palestinians were shot and wounded by Israeli troops in the clashes, Arab hospitals reported. One of the Palestinian youths, 14-year-old Mahmoud Lahlouh, died of his wounds on Monday. He had been hit in the chest by a bullet, the army said. The first knife attack occurred on Sunday morning in Jerusalem, when a Palestinian killed three people in a quiet neighborhood. Seeking to prevent further violence, security forces closed Jerusalem to Arabs from the occupied territories on Monday and thousands of extra police patrolled its streets. Nevertheless, a Palestinian stabbed a Jew in the city, slightly injuring him. Police searched a nearby village for the assailant. After Monday's violence, national police headquarters announced the ban on Palestinians entering Jerusalem would continue for at least a second day ``in view of the present tension in the city.'' Serious clashes in Jerusalem began on Oct. 8, when police fired on Moslems on the Temple Mount after they stoned Jewish worshipers at the nearby Western Wall. At least 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded. On Sunday, a knife-wielding Palestinian apparently sought to avenge the killings on the Temple Mount. The motive in Monday's knife attack was not clear. The death of Lahlouh raised to 763 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 34-month uprising against Israeli occupation. An additional 28 were slain by fellow Arabs, most for allegedly collaborating with Israel. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Finder of Lyme Disease Says it's Overdiagnosed Now
DOC.TEXT: The doctor who first identified Lyme disease 15 years ago says doctors are overdiagnosing the tick-borne illness. ``It's being used to cause a number of conditions it is not causing,'' Dr. Allen Steere of the Tufts University School of Medicine said Monday. The bacterial disease, which causes a distinctive bulls-eye rash, fever and arthritis and is carried by tiny ticks that are often found on deer, is being blamed for conditions ranging from chronic fatigue to stress, Steere said. The danger, he said at the Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, occurs when misdiagnosed patients are put on antibiotics for up to two years and run the risk of complications from the drugs. The national Centers for Disease Control reported 7,402 cases of Lyme disease in the United States in 1989, up from 4,574 in 1988. No one's quite sure exactly how many of the reported cases are not properly diagnosed or how many actual cases never get reported, Steere said. ``But the idea that thousands of cases (misdiagnosed as Lyme disease) are occurring each year - I think that's in the ballpark of what we're dealing with,'' he said. Steere was at Yale University when he identified the first cases of Lyme disease in 1975 in patients from Old Lyme, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Optimisim About Gulf Crisis Boosts Dollar, Stocks Up Again
DOC.TEXT: Optimism about the Persian Gulf crisis boosted the dollar against the Japanese yen today, and prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange gained for the seventh consecutive trading day. ``People think the situation has eased, so that is why the dollar is going up,'' said Masahiro Ishikawa, assistant manager of the treasury department for Deutsche Bank's Tokyo office. The dollar closed at 127.13 yen, up 0.88 yen from Monday's close of 126.25 yen. It opened at 126.40 yen, and traded between 126.30 yen and 127.37 yen. The dollar now has climbed 2.73 yen in three trading days, after a 13-day slide that totaled 13.55 yen. Some traders feel that the market has hit bottom, ``and if the (gulf) war finishes, the dollar will go up,'' Ishikawa said. The dollar's rise forced investors who last week thought the dollar would slide further to cover their short dollar positions this week, said Masakazu Kimura, a manager in the foreign exchange group of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a meeting of central bank branch managers that he welcomed the yen's strengthening because it would offset the inflationary effect of higher crude oil prices. But he warned against a plunge in the dollar's value, and urged cuts in the U.S. fiscal deficit to help keep up confidence in the markets and support the dollar. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,298.30, up 227.44 points, or 0.91 percent, from Monday's close. Trading volume was down from Monday's 600 million shares, but still moderately heavy at 550 million. Rumors that Saudi Arabian monetary authorities were unloading Japanese bonds dampened a strong early morning rally, traders said. The more comprehensive TOPIX index of all issues listed on the first section rose only to 1,859.56 points from Monday's close of 1,858.30, said Pelham Smithers, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Asia Ltd. ``On Friday, we downweighted our portfolios to 40 percent stocks from 45 percent, reflecting (our feeling that) the stock market was out of line with other financial instruments,'' he said. Including today's gains, the Nikkei index has advanced 2,908.14 points, or 13 percent, over the last seven trading days. The index is up 25.1 percent from its low for the year - 20,221.86 on Oct. 1. ``Japanese equities seem to be developing a powerful upside trend,'' Andrzej Tojek, senior international market analyst for Merrill Lynch Japan Inc., said in a newsletter distributed Monday. ``There are a lot of bullish people out there still,'' Smithers said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 84.81 points from their close of 84.75 on Monday. Their yield dropped to 7.735 percent from 7.750 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Transplant Patient Dies After Blood Type Mix-Up
DOC.TEXT: A transplant patient died a week after being given a heart of the wrong blood type, hospital officials say. The 47-year-old man's blood type had been incorrectly listed on a transplant-matching computer, said Dr. Robert Emery, director of heart transplantation for Abbott Northwestern Hospital and the Minneapolis Heart Institute. The unidentified patient, who died after undergoing organ rejection Friday, had type-O blood but received a heart from someone with type A, Emery said. Emery said the hospital and heart institute were investigating how the mistake occurred. He said a check revealed no other errors involving patients on the institute's waiting list. Had the patient been given a matched heart, Emery said, his chances of survival would have been close to 100 percent.
