He said the survival rate for type-O patients receiving transplants from type-A donors is about 60 percent. Shortly after the new heart began functioning in the man's chest, laboratory personnel discovered the mistake. Doctors put out a call for a second, matched heart but none became available. The man had waited about six months for the first heart. It looked like the patient, who was put on anti-rejection drugs, might survive despite the mistake, but his body rejected the organ Friday, Emery said. The patient's own heart was nearly destroyed by cardiomyopathy, a deterioration of the heart muscle. He also suffered from lung problems and kidney failure. Because of his kidney trouble, he was not eligible for an artificial heart to carry him until a matched heart became available.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Member Pleads Guilty to Obscenity
DOC.TEXT: A member of 2 Live Crew pleaded guilty to obscenity and was fined $1,000 for simulating sex during a show by the rap group in 1987. The plea, entered Monday by a lawyer for Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross, came two days after he and two other members of the group were acquitted in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., of obscenity for an adults-only show at a nightclub in June. In addition to fining Ross, State District Judge Byron Hebert placed him on six months' unsupervised probation. District Attorney Nathan Stansbury said Ross simulated sex on stage with a woman from the audience. The group has not been back to Louisiana since but is scheduled for another Lafayette nightclub appearance in late November. ``I heard that the promoter said they have a new show - a PG version. That remains to be seen,'' the district attorney said.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Arrested for Locking Child in Car Trunk While at Work
DOC.TEXT: A woman who said she couldn't find a baby sitter she could trust locked her 5-year-old daughter in the trunk of her car while she worked at a shopping mall, police said. Chante Fernandez, 24, of Elizabeth, was charged with criminal restraint and freed on $5,000 bail. Her daughter, who was not hurt, was placed in protective custody. The woman, who could get up to five years in prison and a $7,500 fine if convicted, was arrested Saturday after shoppers at the Woodbridge Center mall parking lot heard sounds coming from the car trunk. Officers said they found the girl inside with a blanket, a coat, a flashlight, a book, a stuffed animal and a doughnut. Police said Ms. Fernandez told them she had been keeping the child in the car for the past month while she worked weekends as a sales clerk. Ms. Fernandez said she had gone through three baby sitters but fired them because they stole from her, brought boyfriends into her home or left the child alone for long periods. She said a fold-down rear seat allowed the girl to climb out of the trunk if she needed to.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Rise Slightly in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Concern about the cost of German reunification paved the way for a temporary rebound of the dollar against the mark today, but currency traders predicted the downward trend of the dollar would resume soon. Gold rose slightly. On Monday, five respected German think tanks said they foresaw slower than expected growth in the German economy. In addition to the German concerns, the dollar was helped by signs that a negotiated solution might be possible to the confrontation in the Persian Gulf. This triggered a sharp drop in oil prices to under $30 a barrel. Hussam Kharbotli, a vice president of First Chicago in London, said the dollar might continue consolidating today, but that it would resume its downward trend later this week because of the continued lack of any solution to the U.S. budget deficit talks. ``I can understand the dollar having a breather after falling down through 1.50 marks, but there is no fundamental change,'' said Paul Darmody, a senior dealer at Nikko Bank Ltd. in London. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.88 yen to a closing 127.13 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 127.83 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.5225 German marks, up from 1.5135 -1.2845 Swiss francs, up from 1.2800 -5.0960 French francs, up from 5.0662 -1.7150 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7655 -1,139.00 Italian lire, up from 1,134.25 -1.1740 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1725 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9430, compared with $1.9495 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $370.75 per ounce at midmorning, from $367.75 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $370.75, up from $369.00 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 23 cents to close at a bid $371.59. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.23 a troy ounce, from Monday's $4.21.

DOC.HEAD: Baseball Commissioner Favors Move to Santa Clara
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `If you ...' to fix typo in `he.' Also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent has thrown his support behind a plan to move the San Francisco Giants 40 miles south to Silicon Valley. Vincent said Monday the ``Santa Clara Giants'' had a certain ring to it, referring to the name that makes skin crawl in San Francisco, the Giants' home for 33 years. ``If you get the vote, it will be a big-league name. I guarantee it,'' he said. Voters in Santa Clara County will decide next month whether to build a $153 million stadium in Santa Clara. Vincent said the move was the best solution to the ``dire'' situation San Francisco voters created last fall when they narrowly defeated a measure to build a new ballpark to replace aging Candlestick Park. The alternatives are keeping the Giants at Candlestick, famouse for icy wind blasts and fog, or moving out of the San Francisco Bay area, Vincent said. ``I don't think there are many communities in the United States who get a chance at a team and turn it down. San Francisco seems to be the exception,'' he said. Giants owner Bob Lurie wants out of Candlestick, and has cited surveys showing that fans don't support the team enough because they don't like the ballpark.

DOC.HEAD: Court Throws Ethics Amendment Off Ballot
DOC.TEXT: Missouri's Supreme Court threw an initiative off the November ballot that, if approved, would have cut the number of state lawmakers, created an ethics commission and shortened legislative sessions. The court Monday agreed with a lower court that Amendment 5 unconstitutionally dealt with too many subjects. Curtis Wilkerson, a supporter of the measure, charged that legislative leaders, by sitting up front at the hearing on the issue, had intimidated the court ``with unspoken threats of no more pay raises'' if they upheld the measure. The measure would have reduced the Statehouse from 160 legislators to 103 in 2003 and would have barred lawmakers from tacking pay raises for themselves onto other bills. The ethics commission would have governed lawmakers and other officials. It would have shortened the legislative session by two weeks. ``It's a shame the court decided to block the people's right to vote on this issue. Never before has the will of hundreds of thousands of Missourians been so plainly disregarded by politicians and the courts,'' said Gov. John Ascroft, a Republican who strongly backed the initiative. The court did not say whether any of the seven judges dissented. The one-paragraph ruling said a written opinion would be issued later.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arraigned in Theft of GM Pictures
DOC.TEXT: A photo technician who had access to confidential photographs of future General Motors Corp. car models was arrested for trying to sell them back to GM for $75,000, the FBI said. Gregory C. Hooper, 36, of Royal Oak was charged with mail fraud at his arraignment Monday in U.S. District Court and released on a $10,000 personal bond. He faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. GM offered a $30,000 reward last November for the arrest of whoever was responsible for leaking pictures, slides and drawings of several future GM products to auto enthusiast magazines. Among them were photos of what was described as the 1991 Saturn model. Hooper allegedly collected $40,000 by selling the material to Autoweek, Automobile, and Car and Driver magazines. ``He stole the photos in 1988 and into last year,'' FBI agent John Anthony said. ``After that, he started selling them to magazines.'' He said Hooper contacted GM after a magazine ran an article about the reward. ``That is also when we got involved.'' The FBI seized the stolen material Friday after identifying Hooper through telephone calls he allegedly made to GM last week. Hooper worked as a photographic technician in a GM department where the photos were stored, Anthony said. U.S. Attorney Stephen Markman said the publication of some of the stolen material, including pictures of clay models, has cost GM millions of dollars. ``Such a crime has a profound impact on GM's future competitive position,'' said GM spokesman Don Postma. He said Monday the $30,000 reward money had not been paid.

DOC.HEAD: Colorado Bar Association, Business Groups Try Resolution Before Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: Too many people who file lawsuits could have talked their differences out and saved money, say lawyers and business people with a plan to promote more talking and less suing. ``Ninety-five percent of cases settle without trial, but often settlement happens on the eve of trial,'' said Colorado Bar Association President Jerry Conover. Lawyers' and business association officials introduced a program Monday called Colorado Pledge, which they believe is the first of its kind. Participating businesses promise not to sue each other until they've tried to resolve disputes through negotiations or other alternatives. The Bar Association will supervise the resolution efforts. ``We hope it will show to you a side of lawyers that is not frequently enough publicized - a side of lawyers that solves problems and helps clients solve problems not in the courtroom arena,'' Conover said. The Bar Association, the Greater Denver Chamber of Commerce, the Colorado Association of Commerce and Industry, and the National Federation of Independent Business are participating. But absent from Monday's news conference announcing Colorado Pledge was a representative of another lawyers' group, the Colorado Trial Lawyers Association. Companies that have signed the pledge so far include Adolph Coors Co., Pepsi Cola Bottling Co. of Colorado Springs and United Banks of Colorado Inc. Staying out of court will save businesses money and avoiding litigation will save their executives time, said those putting the program together. Art Shenkin, whose accounting company signed the pledge, said he once served as an expert witness in a case ``where the legal fees on both sides turned out to be more than the total amount being sued for.'' ``Had the parties been able to get together for a solution amicable to both sides, it would have saved a lot of money and a lot of time and both businesses would have been better off,'' Shenkin said.

DOC.HEAD: Fahd Says Saddam Won't Lose Face if He Pulls Out of Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd today urged Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait and said the Iraqi president would not lose face if he did, according to news reports. The statement appeared to be Saudi Arabia's most conciliatory message yet to the Iraqi leader since his forces seized Kuwait on Aug. 2 and subsequently massed on the Saudi border. ``It would be nothing to cause anxiety or pain,'' Fahd told the Saudi Press Agency. ``But to the contrary if President Saddam thought seriously about the matter, he will find that it is in the interest of Iraq, in his interest, and in the interest of the Arab nation, that he pull out from Kuwait.'' ``If a blunder was committed, there is no reason to follow the mistake with another mistake. The correct reply is to remedy the mistake.'' The Saudi Press Agency distributed Fahd's statements hours after a meeting with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. The two also met Monday to discuss the nearly 3-month-old gulf crisis. Fahd made the statements to the reporters accompanying the Egyptian leader, the agency said. If Saddam acted on this advice, ``we would be thankful,'' Fahd said. ``If he thinks he will get another reaction, I think he will get thanks.'' Egypt has 14,000 troops deployed in the mostly U.S. multinational force of 300,000 men and women that was rushed to the region to confront Saddam. At the start of his Saudi visit Monday, Mubarak met with his troops deployed at the northeastern region of Hafr al-Batin and told them their presence was meant to ``force him who lost his reason to return to it.'' He also expressed Egypt's hope that the gulf crisis will ``end without bloodshed.'' Mubarak departed today for the United Arab Emirates, another gulf ally of Kuwait where Egyptian forces are also deployed. Diplomatic sources said Monday that Fahd and Mubarak agreed the Iraqi withdrawal and the restoration of the al-Sabah family to the rule in Kuwait could be followed by negotiations on disputes that caused the invasion. On Sunday, Saudi Defense Minister Prince Sultan, third in the leadership after Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah, said ``rights, whether valid or doubtful'' could always be discussed, but only after a Iraqi withdrawal. Some quarters took the prince's remarks as a sign that the Saudis were ready to agree to territorial concessions by Kuwait. This was a factor in oil prices plunging $5.14 a barrel in New York and closing at $28.38. The Saudi defense minister subsequently issued a statement ``to clarify ... wrong interpretations'' of his words and reaffirmed that ``the kingdom categorically rejects the Iraqi aggression on sister Kuwait.'' The statement distributed today by the Saudi Press Agency said the kingdom ``reaffirms its full committment to all Arab and international resolutions demanding Iraq unconditionally withdraw...from Kuwait, and the restoration of legitimacy to Kuwait under the leadership of the Emir.''

DOC.HEAD: Arbitrator Upholds Non-Alcoholic Lunch for Water and Sewer Workers
DOC.TEXT: An arbitrator has upheld a Water and Sewer Commission edict that prohibits workers from having lunchtime cocktails, but says workers accustomed to the practice should be given time to adapt. Arbitrator Timothy J. Buckalew agreed with commission director Robert Ciolek's no-alcohol rule, which was imposed last January. Union officials contended workers have the right to do whatever they please during their unpaid lunch breaks. The union said it would accept the ban only if workers got a raise or a shorter work day. In his decision released Monday, Buckalew said the commission had the right to impose the ban for safety. ``The commission clearly has an interest in insuring not only that the employee reports to work sober, but that he maintains sobriety throughout his work day,'' he wrote. Buckalew added, however, that workers who do drink at lunch be given ``ample grace time'' to change their habits. As a footnote to the decision, Buckalew quoted from the Bible: ``Go, eat your bread with enjoyment, and drink your wine with a merry heart; for God has already approved of what you do.'' Ciolek said drinking at lunch was dangerous for the workers, who sometimes must drive and operate jackhammers on the job. ``There is no constitutional right to have a few pops at lunch,'' Ciolek said.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Announces Formation of U.S.-Soviet TV Commission
DOC.TEXT: Soviet and U.S. television executives will examine coverage of politics and government in both countries in a commission established at The Carter Center of Emory University. Former President Carter announced the formation of the U.S.-U.S.S.R Commission on Television Policy. He said he will be the host at the group's first meeting, scheduled for February 1991. ``The impact of television in both the Soviet Union and in the United States cannot be overestimated, and the commission will focus on concrete policy issues of importance to both countries,'' Carter said Monday in a written statement. The U.S. membership on the commission will include the presidents of the three major networks and Ted Turner, chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System. Government officials, educators and public opinion experts from both countries also will serve on the commission. The group will study policies and regulations relating to televised coverage of elections and electoral campaigns, referenda, and the activities of legislatures. About 97 percent of the Soviet population watches TV across 11 time zones and the average prime time audience consists of 150 million viewers, based on estimates from The Carter Center's Soviet Media and International Communications Program. ``There, as here, the era of television politics has arrived,'' said Ellen Mickiewicz, director of the Soviet Media Program. Eduard Sagalaev, director of News Broadcasting for Soviet National Television, said the creation of the commission is more than another sign of cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union. ``Our commission can in many ways support a permanent space bridge between different continents, countries and peoples,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Northern Delaware
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook up parts of northern Delaware, but was not strong enough to cause major damage, officials said. Dr. Robert Jordan, director of the Delaware Geological Survey, said the Monday night quake lasted about 20 seconds. It measured between 3.3 and 3.4 on the Richter scale, a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. The U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo., put the magnitude at 2.9, said spokeswoman Pat Jorgenson. The quake was centered 15 miles south of Wilmington in the Delaware River Valley and was felt in that area and in southern New Jersey, she said. Jordan said the earthquake was just about strong enough to cause minor damage, such as cracked plaster. Since 1972, the state has recorded 40 earthquakes, all minor, Jordan said. The worst occurred on Feb. 28, 1973, measuring 3.8 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald Sent to Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `MacDonald was...' to add that sentence of labor could be fulfilled by community service.
DOC.TEXT: Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald drew nearly six years in a tribal jail and an $11,000 fine for taking cash, loans, plane rides and use of an car from businessmen trying to curry favor with him. ``You have not admitted to any wrongdoing and shown no remorse,'' Judge Robert Yazzie told him Monday. But he added, ``I truly say you were a great leader and made valuable contributions to the Navajo people.'' The 61-year-old MacDonald, who was suspended from office last year during his fourth term as leader of the 180,000-member tribe in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah, was convicted Wednesday of bribery, conspiracy and ethics charges. His son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., 36, was convicted of similar charges and drew a 1{-year jail term and a $2,500 fine Monday. MacDonald was sentenced to five years, 11 months in jail followed by nearly five years of labor, which could be fulfilled by community service. His son was sentenced to a year of labor. MacDonald was seeking election to the new position of tribal president, but election law says no person convicted of ethics violations may hold tribal office for four years. The tribal council Friday authorized the election board to postpone the Nov. 6 election for two months. MacDonald's second trial was postponed from today until Nov. 27. That case involves conspiracy charges stemming from the tribe's purchase of a ranch for $33.4 million from a company that paid $26.2 million for the property five minutes earlier. MacDonald also awaits trial on 93 fraud counts stemming from the tribe's 1986 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-liners Say Won't Let Up on Spiritual Pollution, Crime
DOC.TEXT: China's guardians of Marxist ideology announced a new campaign today against pornography and Western liberalism and said they would press on with an anti-crime drive in which hundreds have been executed. The announcements, made in headlines in the Communist Party newspaper, the People's Daily, contradicted widespread expectations that the party would relax its tight social controls after the Asian Games ended Oct. 7 in Beijing. Hong Kong newspapers, many of which have close ties to Chinese officials, had predicted that more participants in last year's failed democracy movement would be released from jail if the games went off smoothly. But Zhou Chengkui, spokesman for the National People's Congress, said on Monday he had no word of forthcoming releases. Today's announcements further indicated the hard-liners who have dominated Chinese politics since June 1989 have no intention of relaxing their hold. Their speeches said that China's current stability is fragile and called for vigilence against alleged anti-party forces. ``At present, our country is politically, economically and socially stable,'' Qiao Shi, the party official in charge of police matters, said in giving the order to continue China's 6-month-old crackdown on crime. ``But we must see clearly that the relatively smooth public order of these few months was achieved through the might of the (crackdown on crime),'' he said. ``In ideology and in work, we cannot relax one whit.'' The international human rights group Amnesty International said last month that more than 720 people were given death sentences in China from January through mid-August, including more than 350 in June and July alone. Official newspapers have reported thousands of arrests since the anti-crime campaign began in May, causing cities to expand their police forces and in some cases form civilian patrols. The party also held an anti-pornography campaign for about six months beginning in June 1989, when the army crushed a student-led movement for democratic reforms. Not only pornographic but pro-democratic publications were seized and burned. Liu Zhongde, who headed that drive, said a new campaign to last through next spring will clean up remaining ``spiritual pollution and cultural garbage.'' The People's Daily quoted him as saying that 12 percent of the country's newspapers, 13 percent of its social science periodicals and more than 7 percent of its publishing houses had been closed since June 1989. He said 32 million books and magazines were destroyed and nearly 80,000 people were convicted for involvement in illegal publising activity. ``This is still just a good beginning,'' he said. ``Some obscene publications that have been explicitly banned have reappeared in new form. Illegal publishing activities have reared their heads.'' He blamed this on ``the bourgeois liberal tide,'' the party's phrase for Western-style democratic ideas such as free speech and multiparty rule. ``People who support bourgeois liberalism ... advocate complete Westernization,'' he said. ``But complete Westernization necessarily opens the door to corrupt and degenerate capitalist things, and thus obscene things are spread.''

DOC.HEAD: Seven Years After Beirut Bombing, Marines Apply Lessons
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to remove reference to political interference. Pickup 6th graf, `Since deploying...'
DOC.TEXT: James Tucker was just dozing off after a hard night of Marine guard duty in Beirut seven years ago when a bomb blast demolished a nearby barracks and jolted him from bed. The Oct. 23, 1983, truck bombing killed 241 Americans, mostly Marines. Tucker, now 26 years old and a sergeant, is dug into another defensive position in Saudi Arabia today, but his Marine outfit is far more cautious. ``We're more terrorist-oriented, we are more terrorist-aware,'' said Capt. John Gauthier, 30, of Caldwell, N.J., a company commander with the 1st Battalion, 6th Marine Regiment. In the aftermath of the truck bombing by a Shiite Moslem suicide driver opposed to the U.S. involvement in Lebanon, the Marines changed everything about the way they defend themselves. Since deploying in Saudi Arabia in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, these Marines have had at least four heightened security alerts for terrorist attacks. Most of these Marines were in high school at the time of the Beirut bombing and have little memory of it. But the threat is emphasized in their training and even the smallest incident can provoke a response. A civilian car flashing its lights near a camp was sufficient to trigger one alert. The threat has also been used to try to cover at least one embarrassing incident - when a soldier with a self-inflicted wound first claimed he was shot during a gunfight with terrorists. Marine officers and enlisted men say the main lessons drawn from Beirut are that they cannot let their guard down, and the United States has to stick to clear-cut policy goals. The approximately 900 Marines sent into Beirut as a peacekeeping force in the aftermath of the Israeli invasion were gradually pulled into a sniping war with the Shiite militias in the neighborhoods around their main airport barracks. But they simultaneously maintained the peacekeeping policy of leaving ammunition clips out of their guns while on regular duty. ``We're all walking around with loaded weapons right now and if the need comes to use them we won't hesitate,'' said Sgt. Richard Hall, 27, of Jacksonville, N.C. Security precautions include not billeting Marines in large buildings, not entering civilian stores, watching out for any speeding vehicles on nearby roads and only stopping on highways for police or other military vehicles. The Marines in Beirut were ``too lax. Their defenses were down,'' said Lance Cpl. Peter Delgado, 27, of Buffalo, N.Y. Soldiers out in the desert are keeping their weapons close by whether in the chow line, showers or on morning exercises. ``It helps you keep your guard up,'' Delgado added. The Marines feel confident that their scattered desert positions have lessened the threat to a great extent. ``I don't think a truck loaded with dynamite could make it out here. We have enough trouble with our own trucks,'' said Lt. David Gurfein, 25, a mortar platoon leader from Great Neck, N.Y. Having Iraq as a clearly defined enemy and the Saudi commitment to their involvement also gives confidence. ``Here you see all Arab countries pulling together to get one person ousted from Kuwait,'' Gauthier said. But the fact that they are dug into defensive positions causes some concern. ``I'm not real happy with static positions,'' Gauthier said. ``I'd rather be moving.'' The actual anniversary of the Marine barracks explosion did not prompt a security alert, Saudi officials and diplomats said. But for Beirut veterans like Sgt. Tucker, the anniversary brings to mind the huge black cloud he saw over the barracks from his billet at a nearby university the day of the attack. ``It makes me feel a little light in the stomach,'' he said, thinking about the friends he lost.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Auditor Jumps into Governor's Race in Minnesota
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Jon sted John. INSERTS one graf after 7th graf, `Perpich, seeking...' to add background.
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota's Republican auditor has jumped into the governor's race, taking advantage of allegations the regular GOP nominee invited teen-age girls to take a nude dip with him nine years ago. Auditor Arne Carlson announced a write-in campaign Monday against Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich and Perpich's embattled Republican challenger, business executive Jon Grunseth. Two women have charged in sworn statements that Grunseth encouraged them to join him in a nude swim in 1981, when they were 13 and 14. Grunseth, 44, denied the allegation but has been under increasing pressure from his party to quit the race. An internal GOP poll last week indicated that five Republicans, including Carlson, could beat Perpich in the Nov. 6 election but that Grunseth could not. Carlson, auditor since 1979, finished second to Grunseth in last month's GOP primary. Grunseth welcomed Carlson's decision to get back in the race, saying Carlson is ``liberal enough'' to pull Democratic votes from Perpich. Grunseth also said he would stay in the race. ``The road to victory over Rudy Perpich has been paved with my reputation and the tears of my family, and I've got a right to drive down that road,'' he said. Perpich, seeking a fourth term, said of the development, ``This has to be solved by the Republicans themselves.'' Republicans began the year with high hopes of unseating Perpich, who had been derided as eccentric and put on the defensive about living in too grand a style, with a luxury car and bodyguard. Carlson acknowledged that a run-in campaign ``has a very slim chance of success.'' But he told supporters, ``I'm convinced that regardless of how difficult the mechanical barriers of a write-in campaign may be, I think with your help all throughout the state of Minnesota, we can do something that is unprecedented. We can win.'' According to the sworn statements by the two women, Grunseth urged them, his 13-year-old daughter and a 16-year-old girl to swim naked with him at a 1981 party at his house. The women said they refused but that Grunseth, his daughter, Nina, and the 16-year-old took off their clothes. One of the women said Grunseth also tried to pull down the strap of her bathing suit and touch her breast. Grunseth's daughter denied the allegations, and Grunseth said that if any skinny-dipping occurred, it was after he went to bed. ``Have I ever been skinny-dipping in my life?'' he said Sunday. ``Yeah. So what?'' Carlson's action ``kind of took the wind out'' of a move by some lawmakers to pressure Grunseth to resign, Senate GOP Minority Leader Duane Benson said. ``A lot of people are kind of comfortable with two (Republican) people in it,'' Benson said. ``But it would have really boiled had Arne waited another day.'' House Republican Leader Bill Schreiber said the Carlson candidacy could boost GOP turnout and help the party capture more seats in the Legislature. Democrats control both houses, but all 201 seats are up for re-election. John Stanoch, Perpich's campaign chairman, said Grunseth's popularity and support have been declining over the past week. ``I would suppose the majority of that support is going to go to Arne Carlson,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Rebels Bomb Headquarters of Two Oil Companies, Bus
DOC.TEXT: Rebels bombed the headquarters of two oil companies today and set fire to a bus near the capital, one day before militant labor unions planned a nationwide general strike. No casualties were reported in any of the attacks, police said. Maj. Gen. Cesar Nazareno, chief of the Philippine Constabulary, blamed the bombings on Communist rebels and leftist labor groups seeking to heighten unrest in advance of Wednesday's planned strike. The first explosion occurred early today at a building housing the power generator of the head office of Caltex Inc. in Manila. The attackers threw a homemade explosive from outside the fence that punctured the roof and a nearby wall with shrapnel, said police Lt. Col. Pacifico Villalino. Ten minutes later, another explosion ripped through the emergency generator building of the head office of Shell Companies of the Philippines, also in the capital, police said. The bomb damaged the roof and shattered glass panels in nearby buildings, said police Lt. Col. Remy Macaspac. Both Shell and Caltex have asked for government approval to raise fuel prices to make up for cost increases brought about in part by the Persian Gulf crisis. The proposed increases have been widely criticized. In the third incident, police said rebels flagged down a bus headed for Manila from Cavite, 15 miles south, and set it on fire after allowing passengers to get off. A motive for the attack was not immediately clear. The 150,000-member military was placed on maximum alert for the walkout, which is open-ended. Unions want a $1.50 per day increase in the minimum wage. In the Manila area alone, trade union officials said strikers will include up to 485 trade unions with more than 322,000 workers, 29 drivers associations with 150,000 members and four unions of government employees. Nick Elman, spokesman for the militant labor alliance, the May First Movement, said protesters will demonstrate in 48 areas in the capital. But the nation's largest labor federation, the Trade Union Congress of the Philippines, said it would not join the strike until the government rules on a wage demand. President Corazon Aquino, in a statement, today urged workers not to support the strike. ``I appeal to labor to settle their demands peacefully at the forum provided for by law - the regional wage boards,'' Mrs. Aquino said. ``All parties - labor, business and government - are duly represented in that body and it has all the facilities and mechanisms for dialogue and give and take.'' In Angeles City, 50 miles north of Manila, the military said Communist rebels threatened to bomb at least 10 gas stations if they opened Wednesday. Angeles is home to the U.S.-run Clark Air Base, one of the largest American military facilities overseas. Additional military checkpoints were set up today in streets near the sprawling American base. ``Information gathered showed that both leftist and rightist rebels are to launch tactical offensives such as bombings, kidnappings, killings,'' said police Lt. Col. Julius Yarcia. Renegade soldiers are believed to have been involved in at least 38 bombing attacks in the Manila area since August.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator in Gas-Price Protest Won't Leave Jail
DOC.TEXT: An 80-year-old state legislator arrested during a protest has pledged to remain behind bars on misdemeanor charges until gasoline prices drop or he's thrown out of jail, activists said. Avery Alexander, a state representative from New Orleans, was one of 16 demonstrators arrested for trespassing Sunday after they linked hands around the gas pumps at an Exxon station. All were booked and told they could go free without bond, but Alexander refused to leave. The charges carry maximum penalties of a $500 fine and six months in jail. Parish jail authorities refused to comment on what they would do about Alexander, a longtime civil rights activist who was arrested in 1960 in New Orleans for sitting at a whites-only lunch counter. Alexander planned to stay in the parish prison ``until there is a change in the situation with the gas prices,'' Pat Bryant, executive director of the Gulf Coast Tenants Organization, said at a Monday news conference. ``Or until they throw him out,'' added John Zippert, head of the Federation of Southern Cooperatives, based in Epps, Alabama. Zippert, Bryant and others have traveled to 30 cities from Huntsville, Ala., to Baton Rouge, trying to drum up support for a national protest including picketing at gasoline pumps just prior to the Nov. 6 elections. ``People are fed up with the gas companies. A lot of folks are fed up with the war. Everybody's fed up with gas prices,'' Bryant said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, world oil prices have fluctuated wildly, soaring at one point to more than $40 a barrel. Crude oil prices Monday plunged $5.41 a barrel to $28.38 in reaction to Middle East peace hopes, but analysts said it may take from three to 14 days for lower prices to show up at the pumps. The price of a gallon of gasoline rose 2{ cents in the past two weeks, reaching a national average of $1.47, according to a survey released Sunday. The biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,500 gas stations indicated prices have risen more than 40 cents a gallon since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Louis Althusser, Marxist Philosopher, Dead At 72
DOC.TEXT: Louis Althusser, one of Europe's most prominent Marxist philosophers, has died, family friends said today. He was 72. Althusser died Monday at La Verriere au Mesnil-Saint-Denis Hospital south of Paris. No cause of death was given. Althusser, who had a history of emotional instability in later years, was the object of sensationalistic news coverage after he strangled his wife in 1980 on the premises of the Ecole Normale Superieur, where he taught. In 1981 he was judged mentally incompetent to stand trial and was hospitalized at a Paris psychiatric facility. He was released in 1984. Althusser was best known for his provocative interpretations of the works of Karl Marx, Sigmund Freud and Mao Tse-tung. He underlined the importance of Marx's view of class struggle as determining the course of history. In ``For Marx,'' published in 1965, he argued that Marx did not become truly revolutionary until later in life. In ``Lenin and Philosophy'' in 1969, Althusser said adopting a philosophical position was never without political repercussions. Philosophy, he once said, was ``the class struggle of the mind.'' Althusser joined the French Communist Party in 1948, and though he never quit, was one of its most outspoken critics. In 1978 he published a series of articles in the newspaper Le Monde outlining the party's failings. He was born Oct. 16, 1918 in Algiers, and went on to earn France's highest degree in philosophy. The funeral was scheduled for Thursday in Viroflay.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Defends Support for Higher Taxes, Spending Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, campaigning for Republican candidates in New England, today defended his support for unpopular higher taxes and spending cuts. He said the days of ``damn the deficit must come to an end.'' ``We're hanging tough for a good agreement,'' Bush said, speaking in one of the most economically hard-pressed regions of the country. He said he hoped a budget package he can support would be crafted by congressional negotiators by Wednesday's midnight deadline. ``We've got a sluggish economy out there nationally,'' Bush said, claiming that a $500-billion, five-year deficit-reduction plan could help the economy by driving down interest rates. He called on Republicans, many of whom oppose his budget stand, to put ``self interest'' aside and stand with him in support of a budget plan. The ``days of tax and spend and damn the deficit must come to an end,'' Bush said at the Vermont fundraising breakfast. He was introduced by Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., who is running for re-election and who is one of the few Republicans in the House to have voiced support for a Democratic-drafted deficit-cutting plan opposed by the administration. For his part, Smith said, ``My differences with the administration are a matter of record.'' He noted his support for the civil rights bill Bush vetoed on Monday as well as their differences on the budget. However, he praised Bush's support for a package combining tax increases with spending cuts and said Vermont voters were willing to pay higher taxes to get the nation out of deficit spending. Smith originally supported the tax-increase and spending-cut plan assembled by the White House and congressional leaders but later repudiated by the House. When the original bill failed, Smith announced support for a Democratic-designed bill, which boosted the tax rate on the highest-income earners and added a surtax for millionaires. That bill was condemned by the White House. ``I wish he'd stop reminding me that we have a few differences out there,'' Bush said, praising Smith for having an ``independent mind.'' Smith's re-election bid is being challenged by former Burlington Mayor Bernie Sanders, a Socialist. Bush claimed Democratic control of both houses of Congress was to blame for the current budget mess. Bush traveled through New England on a small two-engine jet. The runways at some of his stops were too small to accommodate the large jumbo jet that he usually uses as Air Force One. Outside Bush's first stop, several dozen protesters stood in the rain carrying banners and shouted at Bush's motorcade urging him not to go to war over oil in the Persian Gulf. ``I saw some of those signs saying no war for oil,'' Bush noted. He said he could understand the frustrations of the demonstrators. But, Bush said, the ``starving of embassies,'' the holding of hostages and the occupation by Iraq of Kuwait were ``crimes against humanity.'' ``There can never be any compromise against this type of aggression,'' Bush said. He compared Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait to Hitler's occupation of Poland. ``It isn't oil we're concerned about. It's aggression. And this aggression is not going to stand,'' he declared to a sustained round of applause. New England's economy, after being the strongest during the Reagan years, is now one of the nation's weakest. Of the six New England states, the Democratic governors of Vermont, Massachusetts and Connecticut all opted not to seek re-election. The Republican governor of Rhode Island was running far behind his Democratic challenger in the polls and the GOP governor of Maine was in a tight race with his predecessor. The president's first stop was a fund-raising breakfast for the state GOP in Burlington, Vt. Former Gov. Richard Snelling is favored to regain the office he gave up six years ago, which would return Vermont to Republican control. Bush also planned to speak at a fund-raising lunch for GOP Senate candidate Rep. Robert C. Smith in Manchester, N.H. Smith was heavily favored to capture the Senate seat being vacated by fellow conservative Gordon Humphrey. He is challenged by former Democratic Sen. John Durkin. The president planned two campaign appearances in Connecticut. The first was a reception in Waterbury for GOP House candidate Gary Franks, who is running for the congressional seat being vacated by GOP gubernatorial candidate John Rowland. The Democratic challenger is former Rep. Toby Moffett. Moffett gave up his House seat to run unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1982; he ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1986. Bush also was to speak at a fund-raising dinner for Rowland in Stamford. Rowland is in a three-way race for governor. Former Republican Sen. Lowell Weicker, running as an independent, is leading in the polls while Democratic Rep. Bruce Morrison has been trailing.

DOC.HEAD: Accord Hinges on How to Raise Taxes on Richer Americans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators struggled today to resolve their differences over how to raise taxes on the wealthy. President Bush appealed to Republicans to put aside their ``self-interest'' and line up behind the deficit-cutting plan taking shape. After months of effort, lawmakers appeared to be building toward agreement on a plan that would raise the gasoline tax, tax the wealthy and cut programs as diverse as Medicare and farm subsidies. Asked if agreement were near, House Democratic Whip Bill Gray said, ``Who knows, lightning might strike at any moment.'' Bush's top aides were involved in the talks while the president campaigned in New England - both for GOP congressional candidates and for the deficit-cutting deal. Bush called on House Republicans, many of whom opposed his budget stand, to put ``self-interest'' aside and stand with him in support of a plan. ``We're hanging tough for a good agreement,'' Bush said at a Burlington, Vt., fund-raiser for Republican Rep. Peter Smith. At the Capitol, House Democratic leaders met with their rank and file to discuss the proposals to raise taxes on the richest Americans. ``We want to talk to them about how to bring the wealthy in, what the administration says it wants to do,'' Gray said. A dispute over how to raise taxes on Americans with incomes over $100,000 a year is blocking agreement on the $250 billion deficit-reduction plan. After a full day of on-and-off talks, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Monday night that bargainers were on the brink of agreement. ``Not yet,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, replied when asked whether a tentative agreement had been reached. Time is short. The government will run out of money at midnight Wednesday and there are doubts President Bush will sign a third stopgap spending bill unless a deficit agreement is ready. In addition, Congress is eager to adjourn this week for the year. By all accounts, the biggest obstacle to signing a pact was choosing between Democrats' insistence on a surtax on high-income taxpayers and a Republican proposal to limit their itemized deductions. Whatever option is chosen would be added to a plan that tentatively would raise the top tax rate on the nation's wealthiest from the current 28 percent to 31 percent. That would represent a major concession for Bush. Part of the money drawn from the wealthy would be used to scale down the 9{-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase passed by the Senate and to moderate proposed increases in Medicare patient costs. The deficit bill would raise taxes on tobacco, alcoholic beverages and airplane tickets and levy a new luxury tax on part of the price of expensive cars, boats, planes, furs and jewels. The measure would considerably reduce Medicare reimbursement of physicians and hospitals. People whose wages exceed $51,300 a year would pay a higher tax for Medicare. Farm subsidies would be reduced; some fees for federal services would go up. The tax and Medicare package would, when added to spending restraints on most government programs and reduced interest payments, reduce the budget deficit by about $500 billion over the next five years. Both the Senate bill and the House version would require upper-income people to pay a heavy share of the tax increase. The administration is adamantly opposed to the surtax, saying it would amount to another tax-rate increase on those with higher incomes. Bush's negotiators and Senate Republicans say a limitation on deductions would be much fairer. House Democratic leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri said after the session Monday night that the surtax was still on the table. Others involved in the discussions, including Sen. Bob Packwood of Oregon, senior Republican on the Finance Committee, said that option was all but dead. The Democrats' surtax would require the 35,000 people with taxable incomes - after deductions and exemptions - above $1 million a year to pay an additional levy of as much as 10 percent. A person who pays $300,000 in tax, for example, would have to pay an extra $30,000. The Republican substitute would limit itemized deductions available to the 2.2 million couples and individuals with adjusted gross incomes over $100,000. One version would permit a person to write off only 95 percent of otherwise allowable deductions against that portion of income over $100,000. Thus, a person would give up $500 of deductions for each $10,000 that his or her income exceeds $100,000. The limit would not apply to deductions for medical expenses, investment interest or casualty or theft losses. Democrats from populous states, especially California and New York, have criticized the limitation on the ground it discriminates against states with high taxes. The House Ways and Means Committee staff, in an explanation prepared for the Democratic Caucus, said the limitation is based solely on the taxpayer's income - not deductions - and thus would not place an unfair burden on residents of any state. Nevertheless, the proposal is being fought by organized charities and the housing industry on the assumption that limiting deductions would cut incentives for giving and home buying.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Intervenes in Cook County Battle over Third Party
DOC.TEXT: The Nov. 6 election for Cook County offices is in limbo while the U.S. Supreme Court decides whether to allow candidates from the Harold Washington Party to run. ``We ain't running this election anymore,'' Cook County Clerk Stanley Kusper said at a news conference Monday. ``The Supreme Court of the United States is running it, and all we can do is wait until they tell us what to do.'' With just two weeks until the election, Justice John Paul Stevens on Monday halted further printing and distribution of ballots, saying the full court should hear a dispute over candidates from the third-party named for Chicago's first black mayor. Justices may take up the issue Friday. The ballots were being printed without the names of 19 candidates on the Washington Party, representing some blacks disenchanted with the Democratic Party. The county includes Chicago and some suburban areas. The Illinois Supreme Court voted 4-3 on Oct. 12 that the party was not entitled to appear on the ballot because of insufficient nominating petitions. The court majority was made up of Democratic justices. Stevens stayed that Illinois Supreme Court order and allowed election preparations to proceed. But ballots already had been printed without the Washington Party slate. ``Our people tell us if they have to start from scratch doing the ballot it would be impossible to hold the election on Nov. 6,'' said Tom Leach, a spokesman for the Chicago Board of Elections. Election officials from the city and suburban Cook County said they stopped further ballot printing and delivery of voting equipment and suspended absentee voting, which officially began Monday. Jim Hutchinson, the party's vice chairman, said members won't commen on Stevens' order because they haven't discussed it with their lawyers. ``We don't know what all this means, and we don't want to offend the court by saying anything,'' Hutchinson said. The legal action challenging the candidates was begun by five petitioners who Washington Party officials contend were acting for the county Democratic Party. George Leighton, the attorney for that group, said he would seek to have Stevens' stay overturned. Harold Washington, the city's first black mayor, died Nov. 25, 1987, after suffering a heart attack.

DOC.HEAD: Insulted Official who Left in Huff Returns to Get Key to City
DOC.TEXT: A disabled federal official who left in a huff when an ambulance met him at the airport on his last visit to Jacksonville returned to an apology and a key to the city. Evan Kemp, chairman of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, was to speak to a national human rights conference in July but never left the airport. Kemp, who has muscular dystrophy and uses an electric-powered wheelchair to get around, promptly returned to Washington when an ambulance, instead of a wheelchair-accessible van was sent to pick him up. His aides said he didn't want to endure the pain and humiliation of lying in an ambulance for the trip downtown. Monday, on his second trip to Jacksonville, Kemp was the keynote speaker at a conference on disabilities. This time, a van met him at the airport. Once at the conference, he was given apologies and the key to the city by Mayor Tommy Hazouri. Kemp said he found downtown Jacksonville to be ``very, very accessible'' to wheelchairs.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Proposes Mandela-Buthelezi Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7-11 graf, `He blamed...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela angry that Australian radio tried to arrange impromptu Mandela-Buthelezi conversation. Pickup 12th pvs, `The two...'
DOC.TEXT: In a conciliatory move aimed at ending black factional fighting, the African National Congress has proposed a meeting between Nelson Mandela and rival black leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. In its statement Monday, the ANC backed down from months of resistance to a Mandela-Buthelezi meeting. It did not say when the two should meet, only that such a meeting should take place in the ``near future.'' Zulus loyal to Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha Freedom Party have been involved in bloody battles with ANC supporters since the mid-1980s. Buthelezi said he welcomed the invitation for a meeting, which he said Inkatha had been pursuing ``for some time now.'' Mandela, who is visiting Australia, said today he hoped the meeting would ease tensions. Violence between ANC and Inkatha in black townships around Johannesburg has claimed about 800 lives since early August. ``Future meetings are important,'' Mandela told a news conference in Canberra. ``You create a new atmosphere, an atmosphere of hope. The meeting raises the hope of a peaceful resolution.'' Mandela said he had presented evidence of government complicity in the violence to the Australian Cabinet that included affidavits from witnesses. But such evidence has not been shown to his government because people who have spoken out in the past ``have been harassed,'' he said. Later, Mandela became angry when Australian radio attempted to set up a surprise live telephone conversation between him and Buthelezi. Mandela was sitting in the studio after finishing a radio interview when Buthelezi was introduced via a telephone hookup. ``In fairness, you should have told me,'' Mandela said before returning to his hotel. He did not speak to Buthelezi. If a meeting takes place, it would be the first between Mandela and Buthelezi since Mandela's release in February from 27 years in prison. The two were scheduled to meet earlier this year but Mandela canceled under pressure from the ANC, which felt the talks would enhance Buthelezi's stature. The ANC later proposed that Buthelezi attend a meeting with other black homeland leaders, but Buthelezi turned down the invitation because he wanted to attend as the Inkatha leader rather than in his capacity as head of the KwaZulu homeland. The ANC opposes the homeland system, saying it is part of the apartheid system. But Inkatha sees the homeland system as an interim step to black rule in South Africa. Both groups oppose apartheid, but Inkatha disagrees with ANC support of boycotts, strikes and other protests to fight it. Inkatha has also accssed the ANC of trying to speak for all blacks in South Africa. Under apartheid, the black majority has no voice in national affairs. Inkatha and the ANC have held periodic talks, but Mandela and Buthelezi have not attended, and each side has blamed the other for the surge in factional fighting. Until August, the violence had been limited mainly to Natal Province, where about 5,000 blacks have died since 1986. The ANC had accused Buthelezi of orchestrating the latest violence to force a meeting with Mandela and enhance his stature. Almost all Inkatha supporters are Zulus, while the ANC draws support across tribal lines.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa, Nebraska Post Declines in Personal Incomes
DOC.TEXT: Iowa and Nebraska were the only states to post declines in personal incomes in the second quarter of 1990, although income growth slowed throughout the nation, the Commerce Department said today. A study by the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis showed personal income for the nation grew only 1.3 percent, down from 2.1 percent in the first quarter. The slowdown in income growth mirrored the economy as a whole. The department reported earlier the gross national product - the nation's total output of goods and eervices - slowed from 1.7 percent in the first quarter to just 0.4 percent in the second. Personal incomes dropped 2.3 percent in Iowa and 0.4 percent in Nebraska. By region, the Plains states - including both states - posted the slowest growth, just 0.3 percent compared to 1.9 percent in the first quarter. The Far West, Great Lakes and Rocky Mountain regions each recorded 1.6 percent gains. But the Far West growth was down from 3.2 percent in the January-March period; the Great Lakes was unchanged and the Rocky Mountain region up from 1.4 percent. Personal incomes grew 1.3 percent in both the Mideast and the Southwest, both of which had advanced 1.7 percent in the first quarter. They increased 1.2 percent in the Southeast, down from 2.7 percent from January through March. New England's income growth was unchanged at a 0.9 percent. Both declines in construction payrolls and farm incomes contributed to the drop in personal income in the Plains states and slower increases in each of the Southeastern states. The Far West experienced a decline in durables manufacturing and a slowdown in payroll gains in transportation, communications and public utilities. All area states had slowdowns in income growth. In the Southwest, the slower income growth reflected declines in durables manufacturing and farm income. Personal income slowed throughout the region except for New Mexico. In the Mideast, declining payrolls in the construction, transportation, communications and public utilities payrolls contributed to the slower growth. All Mideast states except New Jersey had second-quarter income growth slowdowns.

DOC.HEAD: Former General Accuses KGB of `Legal Gangsterism'
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB general accused the spy agency of ``legal gangsterism'' today as he battled in court to regain his rank and pension, which were stripped after he publicly criticized the KGB. Oleg Kalugin, whose 32-year career with the KGB included 12 years as an agent in the United States, is suing KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov in a landmark case for Soviet citizens aggrieved by government actions. Kalugin's fight has made him a popular hero and helped him win a seat in the national legislature. The three-judge panel in Moscow City Court repeatedl had to call for order as spectators applauded Kalugin's lawyer and heckled a KGB attorney. ``Oh my, we've hurt the KGBs feelings, isn't that too bad,'' an elderly woman called out sarcastically after the KGB lawyer, Victor I. Alexeyev, complained about the crowd. Kalugin's suit contends that Kryuchkov issued secret orders depriving him of his rank and pension in retaliation for his comments in June. In those remarks, Kalugin said the KGB was resisting democratic reforms and continuing to spy on trade unions, clergymen and other possible opponents of the Communist Party. After listening to his arguments today, the judges adjourned the case until Nov. 11. They said they were waiting for answers to questions sent last month to the Council of Ministers, or national Cabinet, and military prosecutor's office. The court had asked the Council of Ministers to provide documents about how, when and why the decision was made to strip Kalugin of his rank, which led to loss of his pension. The military prosecutor was asked to describe the status of a possible criminal lawsuit against Kalugin. Soviet newspapers have said the prosecutor was investigating Kalugin on a potential charge of revealing state secrets. The 55-year-old Kalugin has said he once headed the KGB's section on foreign counterintelligence. He has denied revealing any national secrets. ``I think Kryuchkov's actions represent not only arbitrary rule against me, personally, but also a form of legal gangsterism, and I can't call it anything else,'' Kalugin told the court. The KGB attorney and the head of the agency's financial planning office said at the hearing the decision to deprive Kalugin of his rank was made by the Council of Ministers, and the loss of his pension followed automatically. Kalugin's attorney, Boris A. Kuznetsov, argued that the 13-member Council of Ministers never met to consider Kalugin's case. He said the order was signed by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, at the behest of Kryuchkov. He said documents later were fabricated to make it look as though the full council had approved the decision. Kalugin has filed a related separate suit against Ryzhkov.

DOC.HEAD: Company Denies ABC Cat-Killing Report
DOC.TEXT: A company that supplies animals for scientific research today denied an ABC News report that it inhumanely kills cats. ABC reported Monday that Carolina Biological Supply Co. falsely tells customers it acquires only dead cats from animal shelters. The network said the company actually operates gas chambers in which it kills nearly 200 cats a week. The network aired videotape shot by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals that showed cats being pushed into a gas chamber. The report quoted an employee whose identity was disguised as saying that some cats survive the gas, only to be drowned or to die on an embalming table. ``The allegations made last night on ABC's `World News Tonight' against Carolina Biological Supply Company are unfair distortions of the company's practices in dealing with animal specimens which have been taken out of context to suggest cruel treatment of animals,'' company spokesman Ron Field said. Field said the company in the past allowed licensed animal dealers to use its euthanasia chamber to kill cats it then bought, but the U.S. Department of Agriculture told the company it would have to change its procedures. Carolina Biological Supply no longer allows live animals on its property, he said. The company is one of the world's largest suppliers of animals for scientific research.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Astronauts Had Three Close Calls
DOC.TEXT: NASA astronauts had three close calls while flying jet aircraft since May of 1989 and the National Transportation Safety Board said today the agency should correct problems ``before other dangerous situations are created.'' The NTSB said at a hearing that an astronaut passed close to a Pan Am World Airways airbus flying from Dulles International Airport near Washington in May of 1989. In September of 1989 a NASA T-38 jet passed within 3.1 miles of a small civilian aircraft. And last May another NASA jet passed within three miles of an Eastern Airlines DC-9 near Paducah, Ky. NASA pilots in all three instances were astronauts, but the NTSB did not immediately identify them. In the recommendations, the board stated that ``NASA must implement changes to its T-38 flight program to reduce the potential for human error. NASA should also recognize and correct factors that contribute to the cause of such errors before other dangerous situations are created.'' The board recommended that NASA astronauts fly with an additional crew member aboard the jets when landing or taking off in busy airport areas. The board also recommended that NASA instruct its pilots to write down instructions given by civilian flight controllers. And the board recommended that the equipment on board the jets be modernized to include more safety features.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Orders Court-Martial for State Adjutant General
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Ray Mabus has ordered the Mississippi National Guard to convene a court-martial of its top officer for buying land in the path of a training area expansion. The military trial, the first against a Mississippi National Guard officer, will decide if Adjutant General Arthur Farmer should be disciplined for his participation in the August 1989 purchase of 5 acres of land near Camp Shelby. The governor's office contends Farmer got inside information on expansion plans fo the large National Guard training facility and purchased the land in order to make a profit. The land deal was an ``apparent conflict of interest which should have been avoided'' a military investigator concluded in a just-released report. In a telephone interview Monday from his home in Crystal Springs, Farmer said a hearing could take place as early as this weekend. ``I think I will be cleared if I get a fair trial ... once they see all the evidence,'' he said. ``It's some more harassment. I'm not going to quit. The more they push me in the corner, the more I'm going to buck up.'' Mabus stripped Farmer of day-to-day control of the National Guard in February after reports surfaced that Farmer and two partners purchased the land next to the base south of Hattiesburg. The purchase came eight months after the military proposed to expand Camp Shelby into the DeSoto National Forest. In his 15-page report, military investigator and Gulfport lawyer Wade Baine said Farmer ``took great pains to show that he resold the property to the other co-purchasers at a loss. The loss was $1.'' The investigator's report, based on three summertime hearings, noted the individuals named by Farmer as the co-purchasers were ``subordinates of the adjutant general.'' Farmer's partners were not identified in the report. Farmer, who continues to draw his $50,400 annual salary, said he was served the court-martial document Monday. ``The governor sets the judge, jury and the rules to play by,'' Farmer said. ``My attorney will go down to Camp Shelby ... to meet with the judge, prosecutor and others to see what rules we are going to play by.'' Farmer, 57, said the allegations against him are not covered by specific penalties in the Mississippi Code of Military Justice and ``I have no idea what they are looking at ... a fine or whatever.'' ``I am still the adjutant general and I can be removed only by the Senate. Really, the proper way to have done it is to bring me before the Senate on the charges and I don't think he (Mabus) had anything that would stand up there.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain in the East, Sunshine Elsewhere
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with storms, flooding in Carolinas, picking up 4th graf pvs, `Temperatures were...'
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across parts of the East today, and thunderstorms in North Carolina spawned at least one tornado that overturned a mobile home and uprooted trees. In South Carolina, a man was killed today when his car fell off a collapsed bridge span. The storm system is the same one that brought a foot of snow to the Rockies last week. High wind and heavy rain in South Carolina forced the evacuation of 20 families from a mobile home park, injured at least five people and flooded roads under several feet of water across the state, authorities said. The tornado touched down in a mobile home park in Newport, N.C., officials said. ``Nobody was hurt or anything. They were just shook up,'' said a dispatcher with the Newport police department. Wind damage was reported elsewhere in North Carolina, including a roof blown off a frame house and two mobile homes shifted off their foundations in Hoke County northeast of Raeford, the sheriff's department reported. Heavy rain flooded some low-lying areas. In McAdenville in Gaston County, 4{ inches of rain fell over 18 hours in the Catawba River basin. In Rowan County, several bridges and portions of roads were under water. In Yadkin County, water opened a 4-foot-wide, 20-foot-deep hole in U.S. 421. Twenty-four-hour rainfall totals in South Carolina included 4.85 inches at Chesterfield, 3.53 at Johnston, 3.82 at Lockhart and 3.98 at Sumter, the weather service said. Temperatures were expected to reach the 50s in the northern Plains and Upper Great Lakes; the 60s in the East, Midwest and Pacific Northwest, and the 70s and 80s in the South and Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 93 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla.
