DOC.HEAD: Mayor Cuts His Salary, Other Managers 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins has slashed salaries for the top brass at City Hall by 5 percent because of the city's fiscal crisis and is calling on other elected officials and agency heads to follow suit. The top officials also will no longer be able to count on automatic annual raises. Beginning July 1, managerial-level raises will be tied to individual performance, rather than the rate of inflation or increases granted to city unions. ``It's further evidence of the dire fiscal circumstances in which we find ourselves,'' Dinkins said Monday in announcing the pay cut for himself and nearly 700 other bureaucrats. He is paid $130,000 a year and is taking a $6,500 pay cut. Dinkins expects to save more than $4 million through the cuts and by freezing salaries for 4,000 other managerial employees. The reductions and freeze will remain in effect at least until June 30, the end of the current fiscal year. Falling revenues - mostly lower tax collections blamed on economic recession - created a $1.8 billion gap in the current fiscal year, which started July 1990. The current budget is $28 billion. A $1.4 billion gap looms in the next fiscal year. City Council Speaker Peter Vallone and Council President Andrew Stein said they also will take 5 percent pay cuts. Vallone makes $90,000 annually and Stein makes $105,000. ``In this time of fiscal constraint, it is important that all New Yorkers are willing to accept some sacrifice and to pull together for the good of the city,'' Vallone said. City employees covered by union contracts will not be affected. Dinkins said he also was asking the city's district attorneys, borough presidents, special narcotics prosecutor and mayoral appointees on various boards to impose similar reductions on themselves. Dinkins' reduction would apply to 44 senior level managers in City Hall including the five deputy mayors, the corporation counsel, his press secretary and all other mayoral managerial employees earning at least $70,000. The cuts also would apply to 60 commissioners, 140 deputy commissioners and 202 assistant commissioners.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Raise Long-Distance Rates.
DOC.NOTE: EDs: This is an expanded version of the fourth item in a0467, Washington in Brief
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph is raising its basic night and weekend long-distance telephone rates by 2.2 percent effective Nov. 2. The company said Monday that overall its out-of-state direct-dialed long-distance rates have gone down about 42 percent since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984. An official of the Consumer Federation of America, however, said today that while daytime rates used heavily by businesses have gone down, the night and weekend rates used more often by householders have increased. ``Something is wrong. This is not supposed to happen,'' said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director and telephone analyst for the federation. ``It may be just a couple percent but it shows that the policy is messed up.'' Kimmelman said the consumer group may petition the Federal Communications Commission for review of its relaxed regulatory procedures, adopted 15 months ago, under which approval of the increase is expected. The company said the increase will result in about $39.4 million in increased annual revenue - about five cents on an average $16 monthly long-distance bill. AT&T said the increase applies only to out-of-state, direct-dialed long distance calls made during night and weekend hours. These are after 11 p.m. Sunday through Friday and all weekend until 5 p.m. Sunday. ``This indicates, I think, that the long distance market is not uniformly competitive, at least in this area, and At&T thinks it can raise prices without losing business,'' Kimmelman said. ``Obviously they also think this isn't the most profitable business to have or they wouldn't take a risk of raising prices.'' ``Rather than seeing everybody benefit from relaxed regulation, the consumers are going to be paying the price,'' Kimmelman said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs with 2 grafs to CORRECT that money given to group headed by Kerry, not to Kerry's campaign directly, picks up 12th graf pvs, ``Initiation x x x
DOC.HEAD: Regulators Seeking $30 Million From Former CenTrust Chief
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators are seeking $30.8 million in restitution from the former chairman of the failed CenTrust Bank of Miami, but a lawyer says the executive doesn't have the money and will fight the government's action. Officials of the Office of Thrift Supervision on Monday accused David L. Paul of ``insatiable vanity and greed'' contributing to the collapse of CenTrust, once the biggest savings and loan institution in the Southeast. The failure will cost taxpayers an estimated $1.7 billion. Paul will ``vigorously contest'' the regulators' demand for restitution, his attorney, Aubrey Harwell, said in a telephone interview. ``I would find it hard to believe'' that Paul would be able to put up the money, Harwell said. He said he hadn't yet seen the government's order against Paul. The attorney said Paul is in Israel but he is not there to evade regulatory action and is expected to return soon. ``He will be back and we will respond on his behalf,'' Harwell said. Earlier, at a news conference, the OTS officials said they would go to a federal court in Miami to compel Paul to pay the money if he refused to do so by Nov. 1. Paul used CenTrust depositors' funds for such excesses as $29 million in paintings, a yacht costing $233,000, 24-karat gold leaf ceilings and gold-plated bathroom plumbing, the officials said. Many of the assets were later sold at significant losses by the government, which took over CenTrust last February. The OTS officials said the $30.8 million sought from Paul ranks second only to the government's $40 million case against Charles H. Keating Jr., the former owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. Like Keating, Paul was a heavy contributor to political candidates. He contributed to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee while Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., was its chairman. The contributions have become a key issue in the election race between Kerry and his Republican challenger, Jim Rappaport. A spokesman for Kerry, Michael Meehan, said today that Kerry's campaign has not received any money from Paul directly. ``Initiation of this case represents another milestone in this agency's efforts to bring to justice those believed to have contributed directly through fraud to the failure of S&Ls in this country,'' said OTS Director Timothy Ryan. ``The days of high living at taxpayer expense have ended.'' Ryan and other OTS officials said their order also bars Paul from selling or transferring any assets of more than $5,000. In addition, Paul is required to submit within five days a statement identifying all his assets outside the United States and detailing his net worth. ``Evidence exists that Paul diverted millions of dollars (of CenTrust funds) offshore and that he personally engaged in securities and commodities trading overseas,'' the OTS said. The agency, which is part of the Treasury Department, also is seeking an order that would prohibit Paul from working for any savings and loan. Among the items regulators are seeking in restitution: -$15 million from a fund set up by CenTrust to pay legal fees in lawsuits filed against Paul and other directors. -$4.9 million diverted to a special retirement plan created mainly for Paul. The assets of the plan were transferred out of the country and managed by Edward D.G. Davies, a British financier and former CenTrust director who also is named in the OTS order. -$515,000 in premiums paid by CenTrust on Paul's $6 million life insurance policies. The beneficiary was Paul's wife rather than CenTrust, the beneficiary authorized by CenTrust's board of directors. -$456,900 paid by CenTrust for a security system and guards at Paul's home from January 1987 through February 1990. -A bonus and salary increase of $393,000 paid to Paul in October 1989 following a fiscal year when CenTrust had a $119 million net loss and had been ordered by regulators to stop paying dividends to shareholders. -Design consulting services costing $300,000 and diverted to Paul for the design of his home and $233,000 yacht, the ``Bodacious.'' The government lost $100,000 when it later sold the yacht.

DOC.HEAD: Humphrey the Wrong-Way Whale Stuck on the Rocks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to recast and CORRECT that whale is near rock, not on it, picking up 4th graf pvs. SUBS 11th graf, `Humphrey's troubles...' to CORRECT that not on rock.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HAY1
DOC.TEXT: Humphrey the wandering humpback whale is back, this time stuck in shallows about 200 feet from shore, where rescuers tossed water to keep his skin moist and waited for high tide today to free him. The 40-foot whale, who captured the hearts of millions in 1985 when he spent 25 days lost in the bay and Sacramento Delta before swimming back to the Pacific, beached himself Monday. Scientists recognized him from his tail markings. The whale was still stranded near a rock this morning after rescuers tried for three hours to free him. Volunteers used 12-foot boards and a rope to try to get the whale back into the water. They even used a boat to try to tow him back into chilly San Francisco Bay - all to no avail. Amid whipping wind, volunteers from the Marine Mammal Center worked to keep the wrong-way whale safe. ``He's immobilized,'' said Marc Webber, the center's science administrator. ``We're using pumps, buckets and towels to keep him wet. His body heats up when its out of the water. And there's his great weight. The great mass could crush his bones and organs.'' Denize Springer, a center spokeswoman, said as the tide starting rising early today, ``He still seems to be in very good shape. He made it through the worst time of the night real well.'' But a problem faced by volunteers was that Humphrey was not going along with rescue efforts. ``The fact is the animal didn't help us at all. He's not budging,'' Springer said. Volunteers plan to mount another rescue effort, this time possibly using a crane, at high tide this afternoon, she said. Humphrey's troubles began Monday morning when he blundered onto mud flats near Candlestick Park. Traffic on a highway nearby was snarled for hours as commuters stopped to gawk. Humphrey finally floated off at high tide, only to get stuck again close to a nearby rock. Peigin Barrett, another mammal center spokeswoman, said it didn't appear that Humphrey was injured by the rocks. She said illness might have led the whale to beach himself. Those keeping watch overnight included Sharnel Jackson, 14, who recalled the whale's visit in October 1985. ``We had a big banner in class with Humphrey's name on it,'' she said as she lifted the collar of her jacket against the cold. ``I know Humphrey. I want to see him get free.'' ``I thought the chance of seeing him again in the bay would be real slim,'' said Kenneth Belcomb of the Center for Whale Research in Washington. Belcomb, who was on the scene Monday, has followed Humphrey's exploits since 1985. Scientists speculated that the whale made a wrong turn that year on his annual migration through the bay. Rescuers used everything from underwater explosives to recorded whale sounds to try to get Humphrey to turn around, spending about $50,000 in state and federal money. During that visit, Humphrey was watched by legions of joyful fans. The whale became the subject of songs, poems, books and, of course, a T-shirt. Since then, Humphrey has been spotted in the ocean near San Francisco every August or September.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter's Sex-Abuse Suit Jeopardized by Lawyers Copying Notebook
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a woman suing her parents over alleged physical and sexual abuse during her childhood have admitted copying a notebook containing the defense lawyers' trial strategy. ``The ramifications of this situation are of great proportions and great seriousness,'' Superior Court Justice Herbert T. Silsby II said Monday as he scheduled a hearing next week to determine if the trial should proceed. The trial has consumed three weeks and was expected to last two more. Joanne Goldman, 28, of Brewer, sued for $10 million in damages for alleged physical and sexual abuse by her father, Sol I. Goldman, throughout her childhood and early adulthood at their home in New York City and their vacation home in Eastbrook, Maine. The lawsuit alleges her mother, Gladys L. Goldman, failed to meet her responsibility to stop the alleged abuse. Both parents have denied the allegations. Silsby abruptly halted testimony in the case Friday, but the reason did not become clear until the lawyers returned for a hearing Monday. One of the plaintiff's lawyers, Elizabeth Kelly Ebitz, said she had inadvertently picked up the defense lawyers' notebook after it was left on the plaintiff's table. She admitted copying it. ``We did engage in improper conduct,'' said Ebitz's associate, Judith Thornton. One of the team of attorneys representing the parents, Jules Mogul, said today he plans to call four or five witnesses at the hearing on whether the trial should continue. ``The whole story should come out,'' Mogul said, adding that he was confident the judge would stop the trial. ``I doubt that the case could continue under the circumstances,'' he said. Ebitz did not immediately return a telephone message at her Bangor law office this morning.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Leaders Fight Nationwide Apathy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 23-24 grafs pvs, `Vytautas...Moscow.' with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Vytautus invited by political group, not government. Pickup 25th, `I work...'
DOC.TEXT: Government leaders said today that a deep pessimism has taken hold in Hungary because of economic problems that have overshadowed the democratic reforms the nation has implemented. The leaders spoke at a ceremonial meeting of Parliament commemorating the 34th anniverary of Hungary's 1956 revolution, the bloodiest in the Soviet bloc. Speakers at the session drew parallels between the mood of apathy now and after the uprising was crushed by Soviet tanks. ``We are fighting against a lack of self-confidence,'' said Parliament Speaker Gyoergy Szabad. ``Today, when the country is living through difficult hours, when Hungary is not only suffering from its legacy but new pains and disappointments ... let us remember 1956,'' Prime Minister Jozsef Antall told the assembly. He called on all parties to ``fight poverty and keep the germ of apathy from contaminating our people.'' The revolt was the most violent of several uprisings across Eastern Europe during the four decades of Soviet domination. On Oct. 23, 1956, mass student demonstrations calling for greater democracy, a multiparrawal of Soviet troops quickly escalated into armed clashes with Hungarian secret police and Soviet troops. The revolt ended 12 days later after Soviet tanks rumbled into the Hungarian capital and suppressed the resistance. Official figures put the dead at 5,000 to 6,000, with 12,000 wounded. Western estimates said up to 32,000 people died and 200,000 fled the country. This spring Hungarian voters realized the dreams of the revolutionaries of 1956 and elected a free government that was directed to replace Hungary's Soviet-style command economy with a free-market system. Last year - their spirits lifted with the prospects of approaching democracy - more than 100,000 people held an emotional torchlight rally to mark the uprising. But the optimism that marked that rally appeared to be absent this year. Burdened by a debt of more than $20 billion the highest per capita in the former Soviet bloc - Hungarians see their economy in disarray. Inadequate social services, mounting unemployment, a daunting housing crisis and an infrastructure at least 20 years behind that in Western societies have added to the gloom. Pessimism prevails despite the fulfillment in the last two years of most demands voiced by the 1956 demonstrators. They include: -The withdrawal of all Soviet troops, which is scheduled for completion by June 1991. -Free elections held in March and April. -The right to strike, granted two years ago by reform Communists who engineered the nation's peaceful transformation into a democracy. -Freedom of expression and of the media, which is now guaranteed. -Economic reform, which presently is taking place. -A thorough review of ties with Moscow. Relations with the Soviet Union have been redefined on the basis of equality. Those attending the parliamentary session included Vytautas Landsbergis, president of the independent-minded Soviet republic of Lithuania. He was invited to Hungary by the Federation of Hungarian Political Prisoners. His presence in the legislature was an indirect reminder of the value Budapest places on maintaining some distance to Moscow. ``I work as an accountant, and I can tell you that my firm's situation ... is shaky, indeed almost hopeless,'' Karoly Petrovics told a reporter. ``I just don't know how I am going to keep the family going next year,'' said Petrovics, a 27-year-old father of two. Relatively few people attended wreath-laying ceremonies to fallen revolutionaries at several different venues, in a further indication of the general mood of resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Capsizes, Authorities Fear 50 Drowned
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying about 100 passengers, mostly women and children, capsized over the weekend and authorities fear more than 50 people drowned, Lagos newspapers reported Tuesday. The accident occurred Sunday during a rainstorm in the oil-rich midwestern coastal region, the papers said. Police said they were investigating reports the boat was overloaded. No other details were immediately available. Several similar mishaps have been reported on Nigeria's coast in recent years. Authorities say over-crowding has contributed to most of them.

DOC.HEAD: Bureaucrats Learn to Laugh at Red Tape
DOC.TEXT: Sweden's bureaucrats will start learning to laugh and be happy next month at a course designed to lighten up their lives. ``A bureaucrat works a lot with laws and contracts and is very much controlled, which stops him from really opening up,'' said Ulla-Christin Svensson, whose humor courses will be offered through the Federation of Civil Servants. She said the courses will start in November and several institutions have shown interest, including the National Road Administration and the National Board of Agriculture, where she works as an official. ``We confront problems better by being happy,'' she said in a telephone interview Tuesday from the city of Halmstad on the southwest coast.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Peasants Buried, Believed Dead
DOC.TEXT: Two limestone pits collapsed and buried 10 peasants who were sent inside to retrieve tools, and officials held out little hope Tuesday for their survival after a week underground. The Nanfang Daily newspaper in the southeastern city of Canton said the 195-foot-deep pits collapsed Oct. 16. It said rescuers were unable to help the buried peasants because the collapse triggered a landslide from a nearby hill that was continuing to pile dirt on the site a week later. The newspaper, contacted by telephone, said the pits had been shut down because the owner, Liu Yumin, was operating without a license. However, when he detected that the walls were about to collapse, he hired 10 local peasants to go in and remove the mining tools. Most mines in China are state-owned and operated. Some local governments have tolerated private mining but such operations often are relatively primitive. Thousands of Chinese are killed in accidents at state and private mines each year.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 16 Die In Flooding In Central Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: At least 16 people have died in flooding from rains that devastated areas of central Vietnam, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Tuesday. The provinces of Quang Nam-Danang and Thua Thien-Hue were especially hard hit by tropical storm Lola from Oct. 12-16, said the report, monitored in Bangkok. It said total rainfall reached 31.5 inches in some areas of Quang Nam-Danang, ``where all rivers swelled to the highest levels ever seen in the past 10 years and many areas were submerged.'' Hardest hit was the province's Hoi An town, which was two yards under water. The report said nine people died in Quang Nam-Danang, where damage to property and crops was widespread. It said seven people died in Thua Thien-Hue, where 110,200 houses were submerged.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers End Strike
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of teachers ended a nationwide strike after the state promised to increase their salaries to match galloping inflation, officials said Tuesday. John Mambwe, a district chairman of the 35,000-member Zambia National Union of Teachers, said teachers returned to work Monday, ending a month-long strikeover poor pay and inadequate housing allowances. On Oct. 12, teachers temporarily returned to their classrooms to allow students to take final exams. They threatened to resume their protest if their demands were not met by the end of the year. At least 32 illegal strikes by restive workers have swept Zambia since riots in June, when 27 people where shot while protesting rising living costs.

DOC.HEAD: Bailout Plan Pushes Disputes Into Single Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: Confusion over the wording of last year's thrift industry bailout plan has resulted in a small flood of lawsuits into a single federal court in Washington. The Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act mandated that any lawsuit involving a financially troubled savings and loan firm must be handled in federal court. One paragraph of the law said federal courts - plural - have jurisdiction over those lawsuits. But two paragraphs later, another provision says the Resolution Trust Corp., which handles the thrifts, must move the lawsuits to U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. Michael Tucci, the RTC senior counsel, said a half-dozen federal judges across the country have interpreted the law to say that any time the agency wants to move a case into federal court, it has to go to Washington. So far, 72 lawsuits have been transferred. But there are thousands of suits nationwide involving defunct thrifts. Tucci said the number of cases in the court now ``is pretty small, considering what's coming.'' The additional cases could have a significant impact on the civil court docket, because judges said they already are busy handling a dramatic increase in criminal cases arising from the district's drug problems. ``I'd be a fool to think (judges and litigants) are happy,'' he said. ``But we've been given a law to work with, and we work with it the best way we can.'' Barbara Timmer, general counsel for the House Banking Committee, who helped draft the law, said she was surprised the paragraphs were an issue. The clauses were intended to give RTC lawyers a choice of which federal court to move a case to, not to limit them to federal court in Washington, she said. U.S. District Judge Stanley S. Harris has asked the Administrative Office of the Courts to consider asking the law's sponsors to amend its wording. A spokeswoman for the administrative office, Cathy Ball, said the office was sympathetic, but it was unclear what can be done. Timmer said she knew of no such pending legislation. Tucci said his agency was happy in many instances to have cases heard in federal courts elsewhere, but that the 1989 law requires the agency to move the cases to federal court here before that can be done. In other instances, he said, the RTC would rather try a case here. ``In some cases that's terribly inconvenient, and in some cases it's not,'' he said. ``We look at each one on a case-by-case basis.''

DOC.HEAD: 14 Americans Leave Baghdad For Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saudi diplomat summoned to State Department, says Kuwait calls the shots in the crisis. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen Americans left the Iraqi capital for Jordan today after being freed by Saddam Hussein's government. They departed as Britain worked to gain the release of 50 sick or elderly Britons. ``I was waiting for this moment. I am extremely happy, but sad at the same time because I am leaving many of my friends and colleagues,'' Jack Fraser, one of the freed Americans, told an Associated Press reporter in Baghdad. Fraser, 53, of Santa Ana, Calif., worked for a construction company and had been held in a diplomatic compound in Baghdad. Another freed American, 44-year-old John Thompson, said: ``I was in Iraq for the last four years, working on a Baghdad city master plan.'' Thompson said he was eager to see his 68-year-old mother, Lilo Thompson of Frankfurt, Germany, because she is going blind. ``She had a retinal separation and the stress that I'm stuck in Iraq had caused her a heart attack,'' he said. ``I'm her only child and she wanted to see me badly.'' Also leaving Iraq today aboard a regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight were William Hollingsworth of Huntsville, Ala., and Lloyd Graham of Houston. No list of all 14 Americans was released by officials, and no other names were immediately available. About 1,000 Americans remain trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Salim Mansoor, an Iraqi-American who met with Saddam, said on Monday that 14 ailing or elderly Americans would be freed. Several of the American men who left Iraq today appeared to be very young and two were reportedly dependents of U.S. diplomats. It was not known why Iraq decided to free the younger Americans instead of sick and elderly people. Also today, Saudi Arabia's ambassador was summoned to the State Department in Washington, where he denied the kingdom wants Kuwait to yield territory to Iraq in order to defuse the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Saddam ``should not be under any disillusion,'' Prince Bandar said before meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``This is a decision for the Kuwaitis, not for us. But we don't think aggression should be rewarded.'' There have been indications that the Arab world was softening its hard line in dealing with Iraq - including a statement by Saudi King Fahd that Saddam would not lose face if he were to withdraw his troops. If Iraq took that step and restored the al-Sabah family as Kuwait's rulers, Saudi Arabia and Egypt said there could be talks on the disputes that led to the invasion of the oil-rich emirate. In other developments, former British Prime Minister Edward Heath met with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz today to arrange freedom for 50 or more Britons. There are an estimated 1,400 Britons in Kuwait and Iraq. Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, met in London today with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to discuss the future of his nation. Mrs. Thatcher reportedly stressed that Britain stands behind the United States in demanding that Saddam withdraw all his troops unconditionally. Oil prices dropped by more than $5 a barrel Monday amid reports the Saudis might agree to let Iraq keep some Kuwaiti territory, but recovered somewhat in trading in London today. Since the invasion, when the world oil price was $22 a barrel, oil prices have fluctuated wildly, at one point topping $40 a barrel. A Kuwaiti newspaper in Saudi Arabia reported on Monday that Saddam had dreamed the Prophet Mohammed appeared before him and said Iraq's missiles ``were pointed in the wrong direction.'' The missiles are aimed toward Saudi Arabia, where a U.S.-led multinational force is assembled. Middle East observers said the dream report indicated Saddam could be preparing his people for a withdrawal from Kuwait. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, with President Bush in Burlington, Vt., said today of Saddam's reported dream: ``No comment on dreams. I have enough problem dealing with reality.'' Oil prices plunged Monday following reported remarks made on Sunday by Saudi Arabia's defense minister, Prince Sultan, that Arab nations are willing to grant Iraq ``all its rights.'' That was interpreted as a sign the Saudis are prepared to agree to territorial concessions by Kuwait. The same day, however, Prince Sultan reiterated that ``any solution must provide for an unconditional Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and the return of the rule of the al-Sabah family.'' A reporter who covered the speech for The Associated Press said the prince declared ``rights, whether valid or doubtful'' could always be discussed, but only after Iraqi withdrawal - with no mention of ``all rights.'' King Fahd and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met today in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, and the monarch later said ``we would be thankful'' if Iraq gave up Kuwait. Fahd's statements were distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency. ``It would be nothing to cause anxiety or pain, but to the contrary if President Saddam thought seriously about the matter he will find that it is in the interest of Iraq, in his personal interest, and in the interest of the Arab nation, that he pull out from Kuwait,'' Fahd said. Diplomatic sources said Fahd and Mubarak agreed Iraq's withdrawal could be followed by negotiations on the disputes that preceded the invasion. Iraq had demanded territorial and financial concessions from Kuwait, including the islands of Warba and Bubiyan in the Persian Gulf and the Kuwaiti section of the Rumailah oilfield.

DOC.HEAD: Barber Allegedly Offers Free Haircuts as Bribe
DOC.TEXT: Trying to bribe a police officer is not original but Alfonso Marinello made an offer that was a cut above the rest - free haircuts for life, authorities said. Marinello, 43, was pulled over for alleged drunken driving late Monday after police spotted him driving erratically and gave chase. Police said Marinello first offered each of the officers $2,000. They called their supervisor to the scene and Marinello repeated his monetary offer to her, officials said. When the three refused, Marinello made a last ditch attempt and offered them free haircuts for the rest of their lives, police said. Marinello, who owns a unisex barber shop in Copiague, was charged with first-degree attempted bribery and driving while intoxicated.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Liners Announce New Campaign Against Western Influence
DOC.TEXT: The hard-line leadership on Tuesday dashed expectations it would ease its grip on society, announcing a new campaign against Western influences such as pornography and cracking down on crime. Hundreds of people have been executed in the 6-month-old anti-crime campaign, which has been widely criticized by human rights groups. A front-page announcement in the Communist Party newspaper, the People's Daily, contradicted widespread expectations that the party would relax its tight social controls after the Asian Games ended Oct. 7 in Beijing. Hong Kong newspapers had predicted that more participants in last year's failed democracy movement would be released from jail if the games went off smoothly. But Zhou Chengkui, spokesman for the National People's Congress, said on Monday he had no word of forthcoming releases. Tuesday's announcement indicated that China's hard-line leadership, which has dominated Chinese politics since crushing last year's student protests, has no plans to relax its hold. In speeches carried in the People's Daily, they called for vigilance against alleged anti-party forces. ``At present, our country is politically, economically and socially stable,'' said Qiao Shi, the party official in charge of police matters. ``But we must see clearly that the relatively smooth public order of these few months was achieved through the might of the (anti-crime) struggle. In ideology and in work, we cannot relax one bit.'' More than 720 people were sentenced to death from January to mid-August, including more than 350 in June and July, according to the international human rights group Amnesty International. Most executions in China are carried out within a few days. Thousands of people have been arrested since the anti-crime campaign began in May, with some cities expanding their police forces and even forming civilian patrols. In June 1989, the party launched a six-month anti-pornography campaign that also saw the seizure and destruction of pro-democracy publications. Liu Zhongde, who headed the campaign, said a new drive to last through next spring will clean up remaining ``spiritual pollution and cultural garbage.'' Twelve percent of China's newspapers, 13 percent of its social science periodicals and more than 7 percent of its publishing houses have been closed down since June 1989, Liu said. Thirty-two million books and magazines were destroyed and nearly 80,000 people convicted for involvement in illegal publishing activity, Liu said. ``This is still just a good beginning,'' he said. ``Some obscene publications that have been explicitly banned have reappeared in new form.'' He blamed this on ``the bourgeois liberal tide,'' the party's phrase for Western-style democratic ideas such as free speech and multiparty rule. ``People who support bourgeois liberalism ... advocate complete Westernization,'' he said. ``But complete Westernization necessarily opens the door to corrupt and degenerate capitalist things, and thus obscene things are spread.''

DOC.HEAD: Mich. to Pay $1,000-Per-Day Fine for Delay on Prison Psychiatric Hospital
DOC.TEXT: The state has agreed to pay a $1,000-per-day fine imposed by a federal judge for moving too slowly on plans to build a $50 million psychiatric hospital for prison inmates. The state Department of Corrections will pay the fine on a weekly basis beginning Friday, spokeswoman Gail Light said. On Oct. 12, U.S. District Judge Richard Enslen found the state in contempt of court for delaying the hospital project and ordered the fine to start Monday. The hospital was directed two years ago as part of an ongoing court-monitored agreement between corrections officials and the U.S. Justice Department to improve prison conditions in Michigan. Under the agreement, the Legislature was supposed to provide full funding for the project by last July, construction was to begin next April and the hospital was to be completed by April 1993. ``I don't think there was ever a dispute over whether we needed to build a psychiatric hospital,'' Light said Monday. ``We were just tring to explain to the judge that it's been very difficult because the Legislature hasn't provided funding and because the local communities are very recalcitrant about it being in their areas.'' The hospital is proposed for the Lansing area, so that it could take advantage of Michigan State University medical school programs and personnel. But communities targeted by the department balked at the prospect. To date, the Legislature has authorized only $50,000 to study renovating or expanding existing psychiatric units. State Attorney General Frank Kelley said last week there was no basis for appealing the fine. Enslen also has warned the fine will increase to $10,000 a day if the state does not get back on track with the project by March 15. The Legislature resumes deliberations in mid-November.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Lets 14 American Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 15th, `About 1,000... to UPDATE with Vietnamese reportedly leaving Iraq. Pickup 16th, `Also today...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's government granted exit visas to 14 Americans today, then put them on a flight to Jordan. ``I'm just thrilled that I'm going,'' William Hollingsworth, 64, said at Baghdad's international airport. ``It's a strange coincidence, but I'm leaving the gulf and my son is in Saudi Arabia,'' the Huntsville, Ala., man said, explaining his son is with the U.S. Army. ``I was waiting for this moment. I am extremely happy, but sad at the same time because I am leaving many of my friends and colleagues,'' Jack Fraser, another of the Americans who left the Iraqi capital today. Fraser, 53, of Santa Ana, Calif., like the other Americans, had been unable to leave Iraq since Saddam's troops invaded Kuwait in August. Also freed were John Thompson, 44, an American who lives in Germany, and Lloyd Graham, 48, of Houston. Officials issued no list of the 14 Americans, and the names of the other Americans could not be determined immediately. Several of the Americans appeared to be very young and two were reportedly dependents of U.S. diplomats. Earlier, Salim Mansoor, an Iraqi-American who met with Saddam, said 14 ailing or elderly Americans would be freed today. It was not known why the Iraqi government decided to free other men instead of sick and elderly people. ``President Saddam Hussein, as a gesture of good will, is allowing a certain number of Americans to go home,'' said Mansoor, the head of the U.S.-based American-Iraqi Foundation. Mansoor also said Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz told him that Iraqi officials were willing to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. The United States has said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait before negotiations take place. Mansoor's seven-member delegation arrived in Baghdad on Oct. 14 to attempt to obtain the release of Americans held in Baghdad and Kuwait. Mansoor's U.S.-based foundation claims to represent 150,000 Iraqi-Americans. Also today, former British Prime Minister Edward Heath met with Iraq's foreign minister to arrange freedom for 50 or more Britons. A Virgin Atlantic airline jumbo jet left London's Gatwick Airport today for Baghdad to rescue sick and elderly Britons, airline officials said. It is not known exactly how many Britons will be allowed to return. Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways, said today in London that he had spoken to Heath. Branson said he expected to bring about 50 sick and elderly Britons back to Gatwick. About 1,000 Americans and 1,400 Britons are trapped in Kuwait and Iraq, many held at key installations to deter possible attack by the multinational forces deployed in the region after Saddam's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. A relief official at the United Nations, meanwhile, said 1,000 Vietnamese workers who were stranded in Iraq were leaving today for home. The Vietnamese are the first of 17,000 who were trapped in Iraq, said James Purcell, head of the International Organization for Migration, a 36-nation group helping to repatriate and resettle people uprooted by the gulf crisis. Vietnam has applied for another 5,000 exit visas for more workers, but they have not yet been processed by Baghdad, he said. Also today, five Finnish men who had been trapped in the country since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait flew to Jordan for a connecting flight home. Two opposition Greek politicians left for Baghdad today to win the release of 25 Greeks held hostage there. Carolos Papoulias, a former foreign minister in Greece's 1981-89 socialist administration, and Akis Tsochatzopoulos were accompanied by the chairman of the Committee of Relations of Greeks in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota City Kicks Off GooseFest
DOC.TEXT: What's bad for the goose is good for this northern North Dakota community that has more geese than people, according to organizers of this week's GooseFest. Former Minnesota Vikings football coach Bud Grant will be the first person inducted Wednesday night into the ``Goose Hunters Hall of Fame.' He came to Kenmare last year to hunt and liked it so much he wanted to come back, business leaders said. They're hoping others will do the same. ``If we get too many people for the motel, we've got farmers that'll house them. We'll take all we can get. We'll find places for them,'' Archie Kress promised. Whyagoosefest? Kenmare, with a population of about 1,200, bills itself as the ``Snow Goose Capital of North Dakota.'' Surrounded by three wildlife refuges, it is home to thousands of snow geese for several weeks during the birds' fall migration. `I've talked to people from the refuges last Wednesday and there were about 350,000,'' Kress said Monday. The hunters wait for the geese to wander off refuge land into nearby fields to catch grain stubble left after harvest. State law allows hunters to kill seven geese a day from sunrise until noon. ``It's not that easy to go out there and shoot seven geee,'' Kress said. ``They seem to know when it's noon. We've even thought about trying to sound the noon siren at another time to get them to come out earlier.''

DOC.HEAD: Standard Time Returns Sunday
DOC.TEXT: America's evenings will darken a bit earlier as the nation returns to standard time Sunday. That's when most folks will have an extra hour to sleep, carouse or whatever they like to do in the wee hours of the morning. Of course, this is also the weekend some people will get stuck working an extra hour - factory workers and convenience store clerks, bartenders and police officers among them. For most people, though, the time change simply means remembering to set the clock back an hour - that's right, back - before retiring Saturday night or upon arising Sunday morning. The official changeover will come at 2 a.m. Sunday, ending more than a half-year on daylight-saving time. In the words of the Uniform Time Act, which set up the system of switching between daylight and standard times, clocks are ``retarded'' an hour at 2 a.m. on the last Sunday in October. The swap shifts an hour of sunlight from evening to morning, making life a bit easier for youngsters waiting for school buses and for farmers working their fields. Safety experts are urging Americans to use the time-change weekend as a reminder to put new batteries in their smoke detectors. ``Change Your Clock: Change Your Battery,'' is the slogan of the effort, which aims to make replacing these batteries an annual event. It was during World War I that Americans first tried daylight-saving time, just 35 years after agreeing to a national time system. The summertime shift, begun in 1918, was designed to save fuel by reducing the need for lights in the evening, allowing that energy to be turned to the war effort. Daylight-saving time was again in place in 1919 but was dropped nationally as a deluge of protests demanded that the system be abandoned in peacetime. Some states and localities kept the practice going, however, making the United States a summertime patchwork of daylight and standard time. Congress did away with most of the patchwork with the Uniform Time Act of 1966. Actually, daylight time is still not national, as the law allows states to exempt themselves. Hawaii promptly opted out in 1967, Arizona in 1968 and Indiana in 1972. Indiana isn't a complete exception, though. Parts of the state observe daylight time, parts don't.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman Of the Joint Chiefs Of Staff Sees No Iraqi Pullback
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This story is based on a pool report.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Tuesday he has seen no evidence to support reports of Iraqi troops pulling back from forward positions in Kuwait. Powell, who is on an official visit to confer with top commanders in Operation Desert Shield, said he was aware of recent reports from refugees fleeing the occupied country. ``I have no evidence to substantiate them,'' Powell said. ``The Iraqi forces still remain very solidly in Kuwait in the numbers we have been reporting all along. ``And frankly, I have not seen any evidence of withdrawal.'' U.S. officials say more than 400,000 Iraqi troops are deployed in and near Kuwait, many of them in forward defense positions against possible attack along the Saudi Arabian border and the Persian Gulf coast. Reports by Kuwait refugees recently leaving the country have indicated that some of the forces were being repositioned to the north, closer to Iraq. Powell agreed to talk briefly with reporters in Riyadh following meetings with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander in chief of U.S. Forces in the region. He also visited with some U.S. troops and was to meet in Jiddah with senior Saudi onificant competition for the U.S. Postal Service. Slug BC-Home Delivery. By Business Writer Marc Rice. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 29.
DOC.BYLINE: THE TOKYO TUMBLE: Most Japanese Shrugged Off Stock Plunge
DOC.TEXT: TOKYO - Japan's economy, dizzied by a $2 trillion loss on the Tokyo Stock Exchange over nine months, seems to have landed squarely on its feet. By most accounts, consumers have shrugged off the vanished assets as easy come-easy go. But it has put a strain on some corporations, who have had to cope with a drop in the value of their bonds as well as big paper losses. Slug BC-Japan-Stock Drop. By Michael Hirsh. DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Veto Could Mobilize Blacks on Election Day
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Blacks were a key element in Democratic election victories in the two midterm elections of Ronald Reagan's presidency. Now, President Bush has vetoed a civil rights bill and raised the possibility of another outpouring of black votes this year. ``There are places where if the black turnout is extraordinary, as it was against Reagan in '82, it could make a difference,'' said William Schneider, a political analyst at Boston College. With Election Day only two weeks away, the political question was whether the Bush veto would arouse large numbers of people to go to the polls on Nov. 6. Does the veto boost black turnout in North Carolina, Illinois, Ohio and other key states? How much more motivation do blacks need in North Carolina, where conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms is challenged by former Charlotte mayor Harvey Gantt, who is black? But new motivation could make a difference in Illinois, where Democrat Neil Hartigan and Republican Jim Edgar are battling neck and neck to succeed Jim Thompson as governor. Thompson got the political scare of his life in 1982 when a huge black turnout nearly gave the governorship to Democratic challenger Adlai Stevenson III. Comparable conditions are easy to cite: in that race the economy was in a recession that hit blacks hardest and the Republican president was perceived as anti-civil rights. Most independent polls in Ohio have shown Democrat Anthony Celebrezze trailing Republican George Voinovich in the governor's race. But this is another state where an unusually high black turnout could result in an Election Night surprise. Civil rights is a potent issue in American politics. So are quotas. Bush acknowledged the potential conflict between those two issues in his veto message on Monday. He said the ``temptation to support a bill - any bill - simply because its title includes the words `civil rights' is very strong. ``But when our efforts, however well-intentioned, result in quotas, equal opportunity is not advanced but thwarted.'' ``When the chips are down, the White House is against civil rights,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. He called the action ``tragic and disgraceful.'' On the political battlefields of the final two weeks of the 1990 campaign, Democrats will sound that cry repeatedly. They will tell black voters that Bush is no different than Reagan, a president who never got more than 10 percent support from blacks. By contrast, in the 18 months of his presidency, Bush's approval ratings from blacks have been in the mid 40s. On the other hand, aversion to quotas - a strong strain in the American electorate - is unlikely to send people flocking to the polls to back Republicans as a way of thanking Bush for his veto. That veto appeared certain to stand. Even sponsors of the legislation said there was virtually no chance of getting the two-thirds margins in the House and Senate to override. The measure was the civil rights community's top priority in Congress. It would overturn six job bias decisions handed down by the Supreme Court last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in the most extreme cases of discrimination. The sharpest clashes, however, have come over provisions that would make it easier to win discrimination cases against employers. Bush contended those provisions would force employers to set quotas to avoid lawsuits. But the Washington debate over the details of complex legislation is now a political debate, what Schneider called ``a contest in public relations.'' During the budget negotiations in recent weeks, the president lost the communications contest and was tagged with the perception of wanting to protect the rich from having to pay more taxes. Selling voters, particularly blacks, on the idea that he vetoed a civil rights bill to protect the country from quotas may prove even more difficult.
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: Donald M. Rothberg is the chief political writer
DOC.TEXT: of The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Judges, Prison Guards, Transit Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: Judges left their chambers to march in their robes and prison guards refused to escort inmates Tuesday as Justice Ministry employees staged a nationwide strike for better pay and conditions. In Paris, court clerks said they were short of basic equipment such as telephones and typewriters. In Bordeaux, the chief judge of the children's court said child abuse victims had to wait six weeks for cases to be heard. In an unrelated strike, public transit workers nationwide also walked off the job, disrupting bus, subway, rail and trolley service in several major cities. They were striking for better pay and administrative reform. At several prisons, guards refused to escort prisoners, whether arriving for admission or leaving for transfers or court hearings. In some cases, guards also refused to allow visitors to enter. In Nancy, a police squad was summoned to escort inmates through a picket line of guards. In Bordeaux, where court activity was at a standstill, the chief judge of the juvenile court said insufficient funding had created a crisis. ``A minor who is in danger, who has been raped or physically mistreated, cannot obtain an appointment with a judge for at least a month and a half after the deed,'' said Judge Denis Hubert. ``If tomorrow, a child died, I think the ministry would bear some responsibility.'' In Paris, 1,000 judges, lawyers and court personnel rallied outside the Palace of Justice, then marched to the office of Premier Michel Rocard. Jean-Luc Sauon, leader of a judges' union, said the demonstrators wanted the government to draw up a multiyear plan for the judicial budget. He threatened ``paralysis of the judicial system'' unless Rocard acted. Rocard told leaders of the judicial unions he did not plan to meet them and said they should address their demands to Justice Minister Henri Nallet. The daylong transit walkout was most effective in Bordeaux, where striking drivers halted bus service by blocking the three bus depots. The Atlantic Coast city's normal daily bus ridership is 220,000. Bus service also was disrupted extensively in Lyon. Commuters forced to take their cars encountered huge traffic jams, and even illegal parking places were hard to find. In Paris, the daylong transit disruptions were less severe than anticipated. The morning rush hour passed with few problems, but service on most of the 13 subway lines was cut by at least half during the middle of the day as about 1,500 transit employees joined a protest march. Unions organizing the transit strike were seeking a base salary of $1,300 a month, compared to $1,060.

DOC.HEAD: Explosives Found in Baggage After Arriving at Airport
DOC.TEXT: Grenades, ammunition and a rifle were found in luggage apparently abandoned today in a baggage claim area after arriving aboard a jetliner at Los Angeles International Airport, a spokesman said. The Police Department bomb squad was called to Terminal 7 shortly after 9 a.m. to remove the bag and explosives, said Tom Winfrey of the Department of Airports. There was no explosion or disruption of service, he said. ``There was an unclaimed bag at the United Airlines terminal and when they opened it up they found two live grenades inside and a quantity of .50-caliber ammunition and a disassembled rifle,'' said Winfrey. The type of bag carrying the explosives and weapon, and identification of the flight the bag arrived on wasn't immediately disclosed. Winfrey also had no idea how the explosives apparently passed airport security checks. The baggage claim area on the airport's street level was cordoned off, but Winfrey said ``it isn't affecting our operation.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Opposition Figure Killed
DOC.TEXT: An exiled Iranian opposition leader died in a hail of bullets Tuesday at his home, police said. His supporters accused Iranian agents of carrying out an assasination. Cyrus Elahi, 46, died from several bullets to the head after one or more gunmen opened fire on him in the hallway of his apartment building in the chic 15th arrondissement, police said. The assassins fled and have not been captured. They appeared familiar with Elahi's habits, police said. Elahi was a director of the Flag of Freedom Organization of Iran and a supporter of the late Shah of Iran. The organization is opposed to the Islamic regime that has ruled Iran since 1979. The organization issued a communique accusing ``the terrorists of the Islamic Republic of Iran'' of carrying out the attack. A member of the group, founded in 1986, claimed that other members have been targeted by Iranian assassination squads. He offered no proof. Elahi was a former professor of political sciences at Tehran University before fleeing to France in the wake of the Islamic revolution. The Flag of Freedom Organization of Iran bills itself as the ``sole democratic organization active inside Iran.''

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador Denies Report That Saudis Want Kuwait to Yield Territory
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf pvs, ``We have... to UPDATE with State Dept. comment; picks up 7th graf pvs, Bandar spoke...
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's ambassador denied today that his country wants Kuwait to yield territory to Iraq to settle the Persian Gulf crisis. ``This is a decision for the Kuwaitis, not for us,'' Prince Bandar said. The Saudi ambassador was summoned to the State Department after reports quoting the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, had raised the possibility of giving Iraq some Kuwaiti territory to end its 2{-month occupation. ``Saudi Arabia has not suggested there should be concessions made to anyone,'' Bandar said after meeting for more than an hour with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``You cannot make aggression pay,'' the Saudi envoy said. ``If you make aggression pay, that's the law of the jungle.'' At the same time, Bandar gave a downbeat assessment of the crisis. ``There is nothing encouraging for me,'' he said of various reports that a negotiated way out of Iraq's occupation of Kuwait might be looming. ``We have not heard from anyone that Iraq is willing to withdraw from Kuwait,'' he said. Later, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that Bandar, in his meeting with Baker, confirmed that the Saudis had not changed their policy. During their 85-minute meeting, no more than four minutes were devoted to press reports about a policy shift, she said. The remainder of the meeting, she said, involved a discussion of the overall situation in the gulf. Ms. Tutwiler added that the meeting was not called in response to the reports on Prince Sultan's remarks. Bandar spoke to reporters both before and after his meeting with Baker in an apparent attempt to erase any impression that the Saudi defense minister, who is his father, was proposing Kuwait cut a deal with Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``should not be under any disillusion,'' Bandar said on his arrival at the State Department. ``This is a decision for the Kuwaitis, not for us,'' the ambassador said. ``But we don't think aggression should be rewarded.'' Of Sultan's comments, Bandar said, ``He was not implying Kuwait should do one thing or another. He was talking about what we have doe with other countries, negotiating as friends. Saddam did not choose that route.'' In the past, Saudi Arabia, Iraq and the United Arab Emirates have concluded territorial settlements. Bandar said the defense minister ``was talking about how disputes can be solved not by aggression, which Iraq had committed, but by dialogue, which Iraq did not choose.'' The ambassador, responding to questions before seeing Baker, insisted there had been no softening of Saudi Arabia's position in the 2{-month-old crisis. ``Saudi Arabia has not changed its position at all,'' he said. ``We believe there should be unconditional implementation of the United Nations resolutions.'' The key resolution approved by the Security Council calls on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which it seized Aug. 2 and subsequently incorporated as a province. Baker has publicly ruled out ``partial solutions'' to the crisis and said Saddam should not be permitted to benefit from ``the rape'' of a neighboring nation. More than 200,000 U.S. troops are in Saudi Arabia in case Iraq moves against that nation as well.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-State Incomes-List
Personal Income Growth Slows In Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: U.S. personal income growth slowed during the second quarter, and incomes declined in Iowa and Nebraska, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday. A study by the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis showed national income growth decelerating from 2.1 percent in the first quarter to 1.3 percent from April through June. It weakened in five of the nation's eight regions. The report was a reflection of the sluggish growth of the general economy which dipped from 1.7 percent in the January-March quarter to 0.4 percent in the next. Many economists believe the nation is headed for a recession, if it is not already in one. Personal incomes fell 2.3 percent in Iowa and 0.4 percent in Nebraska. For the Plains region as a whole, income growth dropped from 1.9 percent in the first quarter to just 0.3 percent in the second. Other regions posting slower growth were the Far West, Southeast, Southwest and Mideast. The Rocky Mountain region showed the only improvement, up slightly from 1.4 percent in the first quarter to 1.6 percent in the second. Personal ncomes in both the Great Lakes and New England states were unchanged. The department defines personal income as income received by persons from all sources, less Social Security payments. The slowdown in personal income growth in the Plains region ``reflected declines in farm income and in construction payrolls,'' the report said. ``In addition, the payroll increase in retail trade was smaller in the second quarter than in the first.'' Income growth in the Far West was cut in half, from 3.2 percent in the first quarter to 1.6 percent in the second. Nevertheless, three of the four states - California, Oregon and Nevada - ranked among the top 10 in income growth. ``A decline in durables manufacturing payrolls contributed to the slowdown,'' the department said. ``In addition, payroll increases in the transportation-communication-public utilities group and in wholesale and retail trade were smaller in the second quarter than in the first. In the Southeast, personal income increased 1.2 percent after a 2.7 percent gain in the first quarter. ``Declines in construction payrolls and in farm income contributed to the slowdown,'' the report said. ``Moreover, payroll increases in both durables and non-durables manufacturing and in retail trade were smaller in the second quarter ...'' The slowdown in the Southwest, from 1.7 percent in the first quarter to 1.3 percent in the second, ``reflected declines in durables manufacturing payrolls and in farm incomes.'' the study said. ``In addition, payroll increases in construction and in wholesale and retail trade were smaller ...'' Personal income also dipped from 1.7 to 1.3 percent in the Mideast because of declines in construction payrolls and in the transportation-communication-public utilities group. Alaska and Hawaii, which are not included in a region, ranked among the top 10 states in income growth. Alaska was first with a 2.4 percent increase and Hawaii ninth, with a 1.6 percent gain. Others in the top 10 were Michigan, second, with a 2.2 percent increase; Ohio, third, 2.2 percent; Utah, fourth, 2.0 percent; Colorado, fifth, 1.9 percent; Florida, sixth, 1.8 percent; California, seventh, and Oregon, eighth, both up 1.7 percent, and Nevada, tenth, 1.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Girls Give $1 to Kuwait, But It's Returned
DOC.TEXT: Two grade school girls, touched by the plight of children in Kuwait, sent $1 to the Kuwaiti embassy in Washington, but it was returned with the ambassador's thanks. Melissa Davidson, 7, and her 6-year-old sister, Jessica, sent their dollar to the embassy hoping to help children made refugees by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``I would like to express my profound gratitude for your generous gesture, which I must decline,'' wrote Ambassador Saud Nasir Al-Shabah. Al-Shabah went on to explain he was returning the dollar because ``no fund has been set up for this crisis.'' Nevertheless, he wrote, ``It is your support that strengthens our hope and faith in regaining Kuwait.'' The girls chipped in 50 cents each, Melissa said. Zionsville is in central Indiana, about 10 miles northwest of Indianapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Secession: Staten Islanders Slicing Away?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: recasts 15th graf, `To many ...'
DOC.TEXT: Talk of secession has been in the air on Staten Island ever since it became the Big Apple's smallest borough 92 years ago. On Nov. 6, voters may take a step toward making it reality. Fed up with what they see as inequities in services and a dwindling voice in local government, voters in the city's most bucolic borough will finally get to vent their opinion on seceding from New York City. A yes vote, however, would not send the island and its 350,000 residents floating swiftly toward independence. It would simply authorize a three-year, state-financed study of the fiscal and political ramifications of breaking away. ``This is our chance, our way of saying, `Hey, don't treat us this way.' We're tired of being the Cinderella of New York City,'' said Dennis Papperman, the Secession Party candidate for City Council who would lose his job if Staten Island broke away. ``Nothing would please me more than to lose my job if we secede,'' said the beauty supply store owner. If the referendum passes, a commission of 18 Staten Islanders would be chosen to study secession. In three years a new charter would be submitted to voters, although the Legislature and governor would have final say. Secession talk has been around since 1898 when residents voted - by the slimmest of margins - to join the incorporated city of New York. But for most of the century, talk is all it's been. ``Now it's time to see if people really mean it,'' said Les Trautmann, an island native and editor of the Staten Island Advance, which has held forums and hung billboards urging voters to pass the issue. Many others, led by Borough President Guy Molinari, dismiss the idea as financial suicide. Opponents warn that property taxes would quadruple after secession. Police, fire and sanitation costs would increase and repairing a long-neglected infrastructure would cost taxpayers dearly, they believe. ``If that thing passes, that's it, I'm outta here. There's no way I'll be able to afford living here,'' said John Liotta, an apprentice carpenter. Other residents think the high cost of New York City living makes the proposed study appealing. ``Like we're not paying through the nose for that stuff already,'' Anthony Quinnela said while waiting for the ferry to Manhattan. To many outsiders, Staten Island is the least known of the city's five boroughs. Many know it merely as the turnaround point for the Staten Island ferry, or as home of the world's largest garbage dump, the 2,000 acre, 20-story-high Fresh Kills landfill. But to residents, it's a tree-lined refuge. As recently as the 1960s there were working farms and horse stables. The crime rate remains comparatively low and public schools rank with the city's best. The oft-heard secession cry grew more urgent in 1989 when the U.S. Supreme Court ruled the city's Board of Estimate unconstitutional under the one-man, one-vote rule. The board, which awarded city contracts, was the only corner of government where Staten Islanders enjoyed as much political muscle as the more populated boroughs. With the board's demise, Staten Island was left with just two of 31 City Council seats. A third will be added when the more powerful council expands to 51 members in 1991. ``That's less representation than we have now,'' said Papperman. At first, many joked about Staten Island seceding. The laughing stopped when a bill permitting the referendum passed the Legislature and city attorneys failed to block the referendum vote in court. The question of cost won't be the only consideration for some voters. Michele Troy said she'd simply miss the cachet of a New York City address. ``I like telling people I'm from New York. They think glamour, excitement,'' she said. She tried out the alternative, but wrinkled her nose: ``I'm from Staten Island City. Sorry, it just doesn't sound as good.''

DOC.HEAD: Reward for Finding School Bond Proposition Offered
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of a school bond measure are so worried the initiative has been lost in California's election avalanche that they are offering cash to schools that can find the measure in the voter booklet. A $500 reward will go to four elementary or secondary schools that can name the page number in the 224-page, two-part ballot booklet where the argument in favor of Proposition 146 is located. The four schools will be picked by a drawing of the correct responses received by Nov. 1, with the money coming from the Yes on 146 campaign, said campaign manager Peter Birdsall. With 28 measures on the ballot, the search may not be too easy, he said. ``We are concerned that people are not even aware that the school bond measure is on the ballot,'' Birdsall said. Proposition 146 would raise $800 million for construction and renovation of elementary and secondary schools in California.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis, At A Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Tuesday's developments.
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

Fourteen Americans left the Iraqi capital for Jordan today after being freed by Saddam Hussein's government. They departed as Britain said 33 British hostages would leave Iraq within hours. About 1,000 Americans remain trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. --- Saudi Arabia's ambassador denied on Tuesday that his country wants Kuwait to yield territory to Iraq to settle the Persian Gulf crisis. ``This is a decision for the Kuwaitis, not for us,'' Prince Bandar said. He was summoned to the State Department after reports quoting the Saudi Defense Minister raised the possibility of giving Iraq some Kuwaiti territory to end its occupation. --- The Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Seyassah reported that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told top aides that he dreamed Mohammed appeared before him and told him: ``I see your rockets deployed wrongly.'' The dream could be an attempt to prepare Iraqis psychologically for a pullout from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. --- Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Tuesday he has seen no evidence to support reports of Iraqi troops pulling back from forward positions in Kuwait. Powell is on an official visit to Saudi Arabia to confer with top commanders. On his return to Washington on Thursday, he's expected to recommend whether to extend the U.S. buildup in the region. --- Oil prices were mixed on the futures market Tuesday as uncertain traders tried to figure out which way crude would move after Monday's record drop. --- The Persian Gulf crisis is putting a severe strain on the tiny nations of the Caribbean. Their frail economies and scant natural resources make them highly vulnerable to higher oil prices. The ripple effects in the Caribbean include higher food, utility and transportation costs.
