DOC.HEAD: NASA Prepares, Amid Mistakes, for Tanking Tests
With AM-Astronaut Pilots, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA crews Tuesday prepared for crucial fuel-tank loading tests that will determine if the space shuttles Atlantis and Columbia are leak-free and ready to fly. Work on the shuttles has been marred by mistakes, including two accidents in three days involving metal beams. One beam was left to bang around Atlantis' engine compartment when the shuttle was hoisted to an upright position earlier this month. Another crashed to the floor while being moved by a forklift. ``I hate to say it, but I think some of it has to do with the fact we're not flying and we're not paying as close attention as we should be,'' said Conrad Nagel, who is responsible for Atlantis' prelaunch operations. Discovery's trip this month with a sun-exploring satellite was the first shuttle flight in 5{ months. ``With so many delays, that has a negative affect on the workforce,'' Nagel said. ``When things are moving along, and people are doing their jobs and they're active, it's a little different attitude.'' Getting through Atlantis' fueling test Wednesday, and Columbia's test Monday, should help, Nagel said. Atlantis has been grounded by hydrogen leaks since June, Columbia since May. ``I think we need Atlantis and Columbia back up, is the bottom line, to be back on track,'' said Keith Hudkins, chief of the shuttle orbiter program. Even NASA's astronauts have come under criticism. The National Transportation Board said Tuesday the space agency should take steps to prevent air accidents involving astronauts. Astronauts flying jets have had three close calls with other planes during the past 1{ years, the board said. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration hoped to vindicate at least Atlantis on Wednesday. Shortly before sunrise, NASA was to begin loading liquid hydrogen into Atlantis' external tank at the launch pad. The tank and fuel lines leading to it are new, as are seals in a 17-inch-diameter valve. Liquid oxygen also will be pumped into Atlantis' main propulsion system to make sure there is no damage from the 9-foot-long, 47{-pound beam that was left in the engine compartment. Technicians forgot to remove the aluminum beam after using it for a platform, and the piece crashed into about 25 spots as the orbiter was being raised into an upright position in the assembly building on Oct. 3. A small section of an overboard vent line for liquid oxygen had to be replaced. An investigative team for Lockheed Space Operations Co., NASA's prime contractor for shuttle processing, concluded Friday the accident was the result of human error. Failure to follow procedures was responsible for the Oct. 5 accident involving a beam that is part of a steel sling used to raise the orbiter, Lockheed spokesman J.B. Kump said Tuesday. Workers failed to secure the 60- to 70-foot-long beam to a forklift, and the beam fell about 8 inches to the floor of the assembly building. No injuries or damage were reported. Kump said ``appropriate disciplinary actions'' are being taken against workers in both cases. Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center, said he's ``very unhappy'' about the mishaps. He met with workers in the assembly building last week and urged them to ``be a little bit more aware of what we're doing.'' Columbia's hydrogen leakage, which is much more extensive than that of Atlantis, is at least partly due to worker error. Two seals were crushed when they were installed improperly after the shuttle's last flight in January. Workers have since replaced the damaged seals, part of valves on hydrogen lines leading to the shuttle's main rocket engines. If Atlantis passes Wednesday's test, NASA hopes to send it on a classified Pentagon mission around Nov. 9 or 10. Mission managers will set a launch date following a flight readiness review that begins Monday. The mission originally was scheduled for July, but was delayed when hydrogen leaks were detected during a fueling test in June. NASA officials said they will try to launch Columbia by the end of the year if Monday's fueling test goes well or if any remaining leaks can be corrected quickly. The shuttle's astronomy mission already has endured four postponements.

DOC.HEAD: Syria's Vice President Visits Beirut To Discuss Demilitarization
DOC.TEXT: Syria's vice president made a surprise visit to Lebanon Tuesday to try to boost government efforts to disarm rival militias in battle-torn Beirut, officials said. The visit followed weekend talks in Damascus between President Elias Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad, who renewed a pledge to support efforts to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war and reunify the capital. Government sources said Tuesday's talks dealt specifically with details of the withdrawal of the various militias from the Beirut area. Tens of thousands of fighters belong to a dozen major militias, both Christian and Moslem, which are blamed for most of the 150,000 deaths in the civil war. One source said Vice President Abdul-Halim Khaddam's talk with Lebanese officials was ``a message to all the militias that Syria is serious in supporting government plans to achieve the withdrawal of militias from Beirut and its suburbs.'' The government source said Hrawi wants Beirut and its suburbs free of the militias by Nov. 22 to coincide with the 47th anniversary of Lebanon's independence from France. ``The whole world supports the government decision to disband the militias,'' the source said. ``Greater Beirut will be the first step toward spreading state authority over all of Lebanon.'' Hrawi has been re-establishing his government's authority since Oct. 13, when his army and Syrian troops crushed the mutiny of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. Aoun, who has taken refuge in the French Embassy, had opposed an Arab League-brokered peace pact because it did not guarantee the complete withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops, who have been in Lebanon since 1976. The pact also grants equal rights to the country's Moslems and Christians. On his surprise visit, Khaddam met with Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic; Prime Minister Salim Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, and Parliament Speaker Hussein Husseini, a Shiite Moslem. Hrawi has assigned Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul, a Shiite Moslem, and Defense Minister Albert Mansour, a Greek Catholic, to begin talks with the militia leaders. Involved in the talks would be leaders of the right-wing Christian Lebanese Forces militia; the pro-Iranian Hezbollah; the mainstream Shiite Amal militia; and Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party. The Beirut newspaper An-Nahar said the Syrians also would discuss Hezbollah's control of the south Beirut slums when Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati visits Damascus this week. Hezbollah is the umbrella for pro-Iranian extremists holding most of the 13 missing Westerners, including six Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Gunnery Sergeant Doesn't Want to Miss `Last Hurrah'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Marine Gunnery Sgt. Leroy Ford is sweating it out in the desert by his own choice. He was close enough to retirement to stay back in the States, but he volunteered to stay with his unit. ``This is my last hurrah. I didn't want to miss out,'' he said. ``I didn't want to read about this in the papers and say, `I should have been there.''' Ford, 39, known as ``Gunny'' by his troops, is in the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force stationed in eastern Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield. A 19-year veteran of the Marine Corps, he is due to retire in March. Ford served a year in Da Nang, Vietnam, and was part of the Marine force in Lebanon whose barracks was destroyed by a suicide bomber seven years ago Tuesday. Ford's unit was reassigned from Lebanon to the Philippines two days before the Oct. 23, 1983 bombing by a Shiite Moslem, which killed 241 Americans, mostly Marines. ``When I heard the news, I wanted to go back and get them,'' he said. This is his first assignment to the Middle East since. With his combat experience, he's sort of a father figure for a new breed of Marines preparing for action in the blistering desert. He remembers what it's like to be a scared, 18-year-old private. ``I talk with the guys all the time. I joke with them. They ask me what it's like,'' said Ford, a native of Alexandria, La., who now lives in Camp Pendleton, Calif. Asked about the readiness of today's troops, Ford said: ``They know what a bullet sounds like. I'm not worried.'' But in the next breath, he noted that combat changes fresh-faced volunteers into grizzled veterans in a hurry. ``It makes you grow up faster,'' Ford said. A gunny's job and part of his mystique is making sure his outfit has everything it needs, from chow to spare parts, even if it means bartering with other units or scrounging for gear. His desert-hardened troops enjoy having Ford around. They kid him about his sweat-stained floppy hat. And when he sang ``I'll Be Home for Christmas,'' another Marine needled him. ``You'll have a white Christmas, Gunny. White sand.'' ``It's good to have him around,'' said Navy Corpsman Jeff Pruitt, 24, seeking relief from the relentless desert sun in the shade of an armored vehicle. ``He keeps us loose. He tells us stories.'' Earlier this week, Ford's Alpha Company got its first crack at the practice firing range, zeroing in on targets with its 25mm cannons and M-60 machine guns. ``It gets the blood flowing. You hear that bam-bam-bam,'' said Ford, the father of four children. When Ford retires, he wants to get into hotel management and perhaps open a restaurant back in Louisiana. ``The party's almost over,'' Ford said. ``Like my father said, I'm going to have to get out of the Marine Corps and get a real job.''

DOC.HEAD: Resuscitating Elderly Heart-Attack Victims Worthwhile, Study Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 4 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Infertility Treatment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: CPR by paramedics saves almost as many elderly heart-attack victims as it does younger ones, and should not be abandoned for older people in an effort to eliminate useless procedures, a study concludes. Some previous research of cardiopulmonary resuscitation has suggested the elderly may derive negligible benefit from attempts to revive them after out-of-hospital cardiac arrests. Survival rates in those studies were as low as 1 percent. But a five-year study in Seattle showed that 10 percent of cardiac-arrest patients over age 70 who received CPR from paramedics survived not only long enough to get into the hospital, but also long enough to go home. That compared with a 14 percent survival rate in younger victims. In the study period, which ended in March 1988, paramedics treated 1,407 out-of-hospital cardiac arrests among people age 70 or older, and 27 percent of the victims lived long enough to get admitted to a hospital. During the same period, paramedics treated 1,624 younger patients for out-of-hospital arrests, and the survival rate to admission was 29 percent, said researchers led by Dr. W.T. Longstreth Jr. of Harborview Medical Center in Seattle. A total of 140 elderly patients survived after being released, as did 223 younger patients, the researchers reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Paramedic CPR worked best on heart attacks marked by ventricular fibrillation, a rapid, uncoordinated and ineffective heartbeat caused by haywire electrical impulses in the lower heart chambers, the researchers said. The study's conclusions don't apply to patients who have heart attacks inside hospitals because those patients are much more likely to have other illnesses that reduce survival.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maxene cq in 2nd graf of 3rd item.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Bob Hope has decided after all that he will travel to the Persian Gulf to stage Christmas shows for U.S. troops, but he'll change his act to make it acceptable to Arab censors. ``How am I going to go without the girls? I'd hate to think I was the only pretty face there,'' Hope said Monday night at dedication ceremonies for the downtown Long Beach-Bob Hope USO. For decades, Hope has been accompanied on his Christmas season tours by a platoon of starlets and Hollywood beauty queens. In Saudi Arabia, the 87-year-old comedian will be forced to change the routine. The announcement Monday reversed Hope's earlier position on a performance in the Middle East. Hope wouldn't say Monday why he changed his mind, but he was sharply criticized for saying in August he had no plans to travel to Saudi Arabia. ``Palm Springs is my desert,'' he had said. ``The only way I'm going to the desert is going to Palm Springs.'' During the dedication ceremony, Hope poked fun at military spending and the radar-evading B-2 stealth bomber. ``The U.S. government paid $70 billion for something that fles in, bombs undetected and flies out. I've been doing that for years,'' Hope quipped. --- NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Actor John Goodman has agreed to become the first celebrity Santa Claus in a Christmas parade down Canal Street. ``We hope this will be the beginning of celebrity Santas every year,'' said Mickey Barthelemy, wife of Mayor Sidney Barthelemy and president of Christmas in New Orleans Inc., the non-profit group sponsoring the Dec. 9 parade. The blue-collar husband on the hit sitcom ``Roseanne'' has been in and out of New Orleans since first visiting on a fraternity junket in 1972. He says he hopes to own a home in the city one day. Goodman met his wife, Annabeth, in New Orleans while he was working on the movie ``Everybody's All-American'' in 1987. The couple married there about a year ago. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Two singers and three pianists took turns rendering ``All of Me,'' Gerald Marks' most famous composition, during the composer's 90th birthday party. Maxene Andrews sang first, then Gogi Grant sang a version with lyrics written especially for the party Monday night. Cy Coleman, Marty Napoleon and Billy Taylor each played the song separately before all three took the bench to finish with a six-handed version. When Marks took the stage, he spoke of the foibles and triumphs of his 75-year songwriting career and sang some of his little-known works, including ``North Dakota,'' the first song he ever wrote. Marks also sang a comedy song he claimed lyricist Mitchell Parish wrote during the War of 1812, but Parish actually was born in 1900 - only a couple of months before Marks. --- NEWARK, N.J. (AP) - A chance encounter in a dry cleaning shop landed a starring role in ABC-TV's ``Who's The Boss?'' for a 5-year-old New Jersey boy. ``When I found out I got the role, I was so excited that I could have exploded,'' Jonathan Halyalkar said. Jonathan, from the town of Ramsey, has been filming episodes in Los Angeles since July. He plays Billy, a foster child of TV characters Tony Micelli and Angela Bower, played by Tony Danza and Judith Light. A man married to a Teaneck talent agent discovered Jonathan 1{ years ago. Jonathan's mother, Carolyn, was dropping off clothes at a dry cleaner when her son struck up a conversation with the man, who was impressed and told his wife. Jonathan's character was written into the show after Alyssa Milano - who has played Danza's TV daughter since the show went on the air in 1984 - announced she was leaving at the end of the season. ``Working with Tony Danza is a piece of cake,'' Jonathan said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Offere Compromise That Saved Clean Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: After months of tortured negotiations, a massive rewrite of the nation's clean air laws came down to a dispute over helping coal miners whose jobs might be threatened by the bill. Congressional Democrats were demanding a $250 million plan to give retraining and other benefits to workers who'd lose their jobs because of stringent new environmental regulations. One key lawmaker vowed to use a filibuster to kill any bill that was stripped of the worker benefit plan. But for months the administration was opposed to the addition, claiming it would lead to a costly new program the nation could ill afford. Then, in the pre-dawn hours Monday, the administration floated a compromise that softened key provisions of the plan. It won swift acceptance, clearing the way for final votes this week in the House and Senate and the president's likely approval. The compromise had little to do with the overall bill, which calls for tighter pollution controls on industry, automobiles and utilities to reduce smog, acid rain and toxic chemical releases. But the resolution of this disagreement was like many other tradeoffs that marked months of closed-door bargaining on the 700-page clean-air legislation. ``They were looking to be accommodating,'' said Rep. Robert Wise, D-W.Va., of the White House. Members of Congress were just as eager, not wanting to see months of effort go for nothing. The worker benefit program had been incorporated into the House bill at the urging of Wise, whose district includes both coal mines and large chemical plants. An estimated 5,000 to 15,000 jobs are at risk because the bill calls for sharp reductions in acid rain pollutants, which are likely to cause Midwest utilities to shift away from using high-sulfur coal. But the Bush administration for months has feared the program could easily get out of control and soar in costs. Senior administration officials made clear the president might veto the massive bill - and scuttle the first comprehensive clean air changes in 13 years - if the measure were included. The final break came after midnight Sunday, when all pollution-control issues had been worked out by negotiators for the House and Senate under the watchful eye of the administration. Sources involved in the talks said Roger Porter, the president's domestic policy adviser, floated the a compromise through Sen. John Chafee, R.I. Workers who lose their jobs because of the new clean air requirements would get six months of additional financial assistance after unemployment compensation runs out, similar to Wise's original proposal. But rather than go to all workers, benefits would be restricted to those who could show financial need. This accord met with agreement by Wise and the White House - and eliminated another potential threat to the bill, as well. Sen. Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia had threatened to try and block the bill with a filibuster in the closing days of the congressional session if the worker provision were eliminated. The Byrd threat became more ominous when a group of disgruntled Western senators, including Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, said they were ready to filibuster if the bill imposed new clean air requirements to assure visibility in federal parks. In the end, when Byrd's objections were met, a compromise was worked out to merely study the park visibility issue rather than impose new requirements. Like all compromises, this one permitted both sides to claim victory. White House officials pointed out that with worker assistance no longer an automaticbenefit, costs can be contained. Although yet to endorse the completed bill publicly, White House sources said the program for worker assistance is no longer a problem. That shouldn't be surprising, said a congressional source involved in the discussion. ``They wrote it. We watched them use the typewriter.'' ``We got substantially what we wanted,'' said Wise, noting that the dollar amount remained at $250 million over five years.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Will Support Defense Bill Depite SDI Cut
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will support a $288 billion defense bill despite a wholesale cut in President Bush's 1991 budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative, the Pentagon said Tuesday. ``The secretary did decide last night he would pose no objection'' to the military blueprint crafted by House and Senate negotiators from the two chanbers' differing bills, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. The legislation calls for slashing $1.8 billion from Bush's proposal of $4.7 billion for SDI, commonly known as Star Wars, barely keeping alive the B-2 bomber and sharply reducing spending on land-based, nuclear missiles. Although Cheney was disappointed with the amount of money earmarked for SDI, he believes ``it's a pretty good deal. We got what we wanted in terms of strategic programs, which we felt was essential,'' Williams told reporters. The House and Senate are expected to vote on the legislation within the next three days before sending it to the president for his signature. Shortly after negotiators announced an agreement on the bill last Wednesday, Cheney signaled he would recommend a presidential veto of the legislation that sets spending ceilings for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The Pentagon opposed language restricting the spending on the SDI program, provisions on base closings, a troop cut of 100,000 and a plan to aid defense employees forced out of work by diminishing military budgets. Congressional staff and Pentagon officials worked throughout the weekend to reach a compromise, finally settling on changes that in some cases make minor alterations in language but in others give Cheney more leeway. The reduction in SDI remains the same but language limiting how the money can be spent has been modified. ``It's not as rigid'' in terms of preventing the SDI office from transferring money from one category to another, Willilams said. The legislation provides Cheney with added flexibility on troop cuts. Negotiators agreed on a reduction of 100,000 from the 2.1 million troops worldwide. Added to the bill was authority for the defense secretary to limit the cut to 80,000 based on the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Pentagon officials and congressional staff also changed details in the provision setting up an independent commission to recommend military bases for closing or realignment. The revisions have no impact on the overall concept. The bill makes no change on the issue of the B-2 stealth bomber, providing $4.1 billion for the Air Force program in fiscal 1991. ``There is no restriction in the legislation that would prevent us from pursuing the next aircraft,'' Williams said, referring to the administration's plan to purchase bombers No. 16 and No. 17. While the Pentagon was issuing its interpretation, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was telling lawmakers that schedule delays and cost overruns on the first 15 planes will consume most of the money. ``The fix is in on the B-2,'' Aspin said in an appearance before the House Rules Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Defiant Harvard Professor Imparts Different Lesson to Students
DOC.TEXT: Six months after Harvard Law School's first tenured black professor took an unpaid leave to protest the lack of black women on the faculty, that goal hasn't been realized. But there are other effects of his action. Derrick Bell says he also wanted to show students, many who might be eyeing high-flying careers, that they need to take risks for what they believe in. It's a principle Bell has lived by for years. ``I think it's important that they understand the difference between talking a good game and actually doing something, actually being able to stand up when everyone else is sitting down, to take a stand when everybody else is keeping silent,'' he said. Bell's decision in April to take a leave of absence received great publicity, although he now says he is a bit embarrassed by the attention. This weekend, dozens of Bell's former students returned to Harvard to praise him for his protest. The issue of appointing a black female professor was raised last month at the first faculty meeting of the academic year. Afterward, Law School Dean Robert C. Clark sent a letter to students, saying: ``Diversity is clearly an issue that the faculty takes seriously and it will be one of its central concerns over the course of this year.'' Detlev Vagts, a professor on the appointments committee, said he thought the impact of Bell's protest would be ``marginal.'' ``It keeps us from forgetting the question, but we weren't on the point of forgetting,'' Vagts said. He said the school has a relatively small pool of candidates to choose from in seeking a black female professor, and ``one has to be in the top plateau.'' The law school has 62 tenured professors, including three black males. The school this year also has 18 visiting professors, and one is a black woman. Of the 1,611 students, 183 are black and 106 of those students are women, according to figures from the school. Bell said he sent letters to the dean and other faculty, saying he felt he could not be a role model for black female students. But he saw little action. ``My response to frustration is to do something,'' said Bell, who turns 60 next month. ``It's particularly my response when I'm thwarted by people who say, `I've got the power ... you can't do anything.' '' Bell points out that he has acted this way before. In the late 1950s, Bell had a job with the U.S. Justice Department. But his superiors ordered him to give up his membership in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, claiming there was a conflict of interest. Bell disagreed and quit his job. After working a year for the NAACP in Pittsburgh, Bell was asked by Thurgood Marshall to join the staff of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. Bell says he has been ``rewarded by confronting.'' While Bell has lost his salary, he makes money by accepting invitations to lecture. Bell still holds his tenured position. He continues to work out of his law school office, and he even decided to teach his regular fall seminar on civil rights, although this year the 25 students enrolled are not receiving any credit. Bell will continue his leave until a black woman receives tenure at the law school. And he doesn't appear concerned about the automatic loss of tenure if he remains on leave for two years. ``It's a no loss situation,'' he said. ``I've done what I want to do. If the students get encouraged, fine. If not, at least I tried.''

DOC.HEAD: Former IRS Worker Pleads Guilty to Tax Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former Internal Revenue Service employee has pleaded guilty to tax fraud and theft in a scheme that involved more than $1 million in fraudulent refunds. Patrick Smith, 29, faces up to 15 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. U.S. District Judge Kenneth M. Hoyt scheduled sentencing for Jan. 14. Smith pleaded guilty Monday to two counts of an eight-count indictment returned in May. The other counts were dropped. He was accused of filing five false returns in the names of local taxpayers, each claiming a refund of slightly more than $193,000, said Mike Schofield, an IRS spokesman. Smith pleaded guilty to fraud and theft for cashing another tax refund check valued at $151,784. The original indictment charged Smith established accounts in three cities with a national stock brokerage firm, rented two post office boxes in Houston to receive the refunds and deposited the checks into the brokerage accounts. The government said it recovered nearly all the money.

DOC.HEAD: Territories Sealed After Palestinian Stabs Two Women Soldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with closure of territories, report that an Arab was killed by Jewish civilians, edits to trim and conform
DOC.TEXT: The occupied territories were sealed off today on the orders of Defense Minister Moshe Arens after a rash of revenge attacks by Jews and Arabs left one man dead and at least seven injured. Under Arens' order, the 1.7 million Palestinian residents of the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip will be banned from entering Israel beginning Wednesday morning. The military command said those staying in Israel are ordered to return home immediately. The travel ban will remain in effect for ``several days'' until tensions are reduced, Israel television said. Arens' order came hours after Israeli civilians fired on an Arab car in the southern Negev desert, killing one Palestinian laborer and wounding his three cousins. Doctors at Nasser Hospital in the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis identified the victim as Maher Al Shaher, 30. One of the wounded was in serious condition with a gunshot wound to the back and the others were wounded in their arms and legs, they said. Palestinian reporters said the four were returning from work in Israel when they came under fire from a red U.S.-made jeep in Mivtahim, near Gaza. The Israeli news agency Itim said the injured Palestinians managed to get to an army roadblock and reported the attack to soldiers there. The army confirmed the Palestinians were apparently shot by Jewish civilians firing from a car and said the attack was being investigated by police. Earlier today, a West Bank Palestinian knifed two unarmed women soldiers in Ashkelon and another Arab bludgeoned two Israelis in the head with a hammer in a wave of attacks on Jews in Israel, police said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir assured Israelis that steps were being taken to protect them. ``We are increasing security measures and security forces in all parts of the country,'' Shamir told reporters after a speech in Tel Aviv. Arens accused Palestinian groups of escalating violence in Israel to divert world attention from the Persian Gulf crisis. Police spokesman Yehoshua Butbul said the wounded women soldiers were rushed to Rambam Hospital in the nearby port of Haifa and that the assailant was caught by other soldiers. One of the women was in serious condition with a knife wound in the chest that punctured a lung, said Dr. Albert Suttinger, deputy director of Rambam. The other suffered a superficial back wound, Suttinger said. The victims' names were not immediately released. The attack occurred this morning as the soldiers waited for a ride near the Kiryat Tivon, Butbul said. A truck with blue license plates, indicating ownership by a Palestinian from the occupied West Bank, stopped and the driver got out, Israel radio reported from the scene. ``He took out a knife and started to stab the soldiers,'' the radio said, adding that the women were not armed. Radio reports said civilians assisted in the capture. ``We chased him and then he threw down the knife and we grabbed him,'' one Israeli civilian, Eli Koman, told Israel radio. ``We held him down and shouted at the soldiers to shoot and kill him. They wouldn't. I asked one of them to give me his rifle, he refused.'' An off-duty bus driver identified as Albert Ben-Ezra told army radio he pursued the assailant as he ran towrd farm fields. ``I saw him throw the knife and then I grabbed him,'' the driver said. ``Then I heard shots fired in the air, and the soldiers came and helped me grab him.'' The bus driver, who said he had two daughters serving in the army, said he and the assailant exchanged punches. Israel radio said both were hospitalized with beating wounds. Israel radio said the suspect, who was taken to a hospital for treatment, told police he had driven into Israel with the intent of attacking Jews. The suspect was identified only as a 39-year-old Palestinian from the Jenin area, about 20 miles southeast of the crime scene. In Jenin, a town of 20,000 people surrounded by refugee camps, soldiers shot and killed a 14-year-old Arab youth during stone-throwing protests on Monday. Eight others were wounded. There was no immediate indication of whether the suspect was avenging the teen-ager's death. In Ashkelon, the two victims of the hammer attack were identified as Israelis in their late 40s, army radio said. The Palestinian was apprehended after a brief chase, the radio said. The attacks came as police blocked Arabs from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip from entering Jerusalem for a second day. The ban was aimed at preventing clashes following the stabbing deaths of three Israelis by a Palestinian man in Jerusalem on Sunday. A 19-year-old Arab construction worker was arrested in the Sunday stabbings, which resulted in the deaths of an unarmed woman soldier, a gardener and a policeman. On Monday, an Israeli delivery man was stabbed and slightly wounded by a Palestinian in Jerusalem. Two other stabbing attacks by Palestinians against Israeli soldiers occurred in the Gaza Strip. Neither was fatal. Serious clashes in Jerusalem began Oct. 8, when police fired on Moslems on the sacred Temple Mount after they stoned Jewish worshipers at the nearby Western Wall. At least 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded. The death of the 14-year-old on Monday raised to 763 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 34-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. An additional 284 were slain by fellow Arabs, most for allegedly collaborating with Israel. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Envoy Denies Urging Kuwait Yield Territory To Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's ambassador sought Tuesday to puncture reports that the Persian Gulf crisis is easing or that his government proposes allowing Iraq to hold on to some Kuwaiti territory in exchange for an end to Iraq's occupation. ``There is nothing that is encouraging for me,'' Prince Bandar said after reviewing the situation for 85 minutes with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``We have not heard from anyone that Saddam Hussein is willing to withdraw from Kuwait,'' the envoy said, referring to the Iraq president's Aug. 2 invasion of the oil-rich emirate that prompted President Bush to send more than 200,000 U.S. troops to defend Saudi Arabia. Some of the speculation of a peaceful resolution was based on reports in The New York Times and elsewhere that Prince Sultan, the Saudi defense minister who is Bandar's father, had raised the possibility of allowing Iraq to have some Kuwaiti territory as an outlet to the gulf. But Bandar, in two sessions with reporters in the doorway of the State Department, insisted the reports were off the mark. ``This is a decision for the Kuwaitis, not for us,'' Bandar said. ``Saudi Arabia has not suggested there should be concesions made to anyone,'' the ambassador added. According to the reports, Sultan said: ``We in Saudi Arabia have given parts of our land and parts of our territorial waters willingly. But this came through good will, noble manners and brotherhood.'' He referred apparently to territorial settlements concluded in the past by Saudi Arabia, Iraq and the United Arab Emirates. The Iraqi ambassador, Mohamed al-Mashat, responded on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America that ``this speaks of a readiness to negotiate, which was always the case with us.'' But Bandar ruled out any dividends for Saddam Hussein, a position strongly stressed by Baker in Congressional testimony last week. ``You cannot make aggression pay,'' the Saudi envoy said. ``If you make aggression pay, that's the law of the jungle.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Bandar had confirmed to Baker that the Saudis had not changed their policy. Bandar said Saddam ``should not be under any disillusion.'' The ambassador said his father, the defense minister, ``was not implying Kuwait should do one thing or another. He was talking about what we have done with other countries, negotiating as friends. Saddam did not choose that route.'' Asked if Saudi Arabia, which with Egypt forms the backbone of the Arab alliance against Iraq, had softened its stand, Bandar replied: ``No, absolutely not.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Conditions On Military Aid Seen as Spur to Peace Process
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Senate's decision to slash military aid to El Salvador was a defeat for President Alfredo Cristiani, but some Salvadoran leaders say the vote may get peace talks moving. Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria called Friday's vote to halve the $85 million in previously alloted military aid the result of ``successful incursions by the FMLN in Washington.'' He was referring to the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the leftist rebel army that for 11 years has waged a civil war against a succession of U.S.-backed governments. ``It's not as if we don't need the aid. Because those fighting the system, those in the FMLN, are still waging their battle,'' Santamaria said Monday. But Santamaria, head of the government delegation to peace talks with the rebels, also emphasized that the U.S. move provides an incentive to the FMLN to contribute more to the success of the peace process. According to the aid bill, the slashed $42.5 million would be restored if the guerrillas launch a major offensive or if they fail to demonstrate good faith in the negotiations. All military aid would be cut off if the government withdraws from the peace negotiations. Peace talks have bogged down on the issue of the future role of the armed forces. The rebels demand a drastic purge and reduction of security forces that would culminate in the ``demilitarization'' of Salvadoran society. The government says it is in favor of weeding out negative elements from the army. But it rejects a wholesale purge. Monsignor Gregorio Rosa Chavez, Roman Catholic auxiliary bishop of San Salvador, told a news conference Sunday that the aid cut ``gives rise to signs of hope because it is a recognition that peace cannot be constructed with arms.'' He said the congressional move ``makes the peace process more viable.'' Rebel and government negotiators are scheduled to resume peace talks Nov. 4 in Mexico. Juan Jose Martell, a leader of the leftist Popular Social Christian Movement, said the reduction and conditioning of the aid ``is a positive message to both sides in the conflict. ``The legislators are saying to the government, `If you behave badly, we cut it all' and they're saying to the FMLN, `If you launch an offensive or negotiate in bad faith you'll be contributing to the restoration of all the aid.' This is a way of saying the negotiation must progress and peace must come soon,'' said Martell. But the defense minister, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, said the cut in aid constituted ``a negative signal to everything that represents the country's institutionality and a positive signal to the belligerent adventure planned by the FMLN. It would prolong the conflict.'' He said the cut ``would mean limits on the logistical and operational fields. But the armed forces have been preparing to face this situation for some time.'' More than 70,000 people have been killed in the civil war, and many of the deaths have been blamed on right-wing death squads operating in cooperation with the military. Several military officials have been charged in the murders last year of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. ``People are just fed up with this thing,'' Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said after the Friday vote, referring to the millions of dollars in U.S. aid sent to El Salvador over the past decade.

DOC.HEAD: Trial to Begin Over Love Canal Cleanup Costs
DOC.TEXT: Twelve years after toxic waste bubbling out of the ground forced the evacuation of Love Canal, the government and the company that dumped the waste are going to court Wednesday to begin dividing up the bill. As much as $700 million is at stake for Occidental Chemical Corp. and four levels of government: the city of Niagara Falls, its school board, New York state and the federal government. The two-phase, non-jury trial is expected to last more than two years. After toxic waste began seeping into basements and backyards in the middle-class Niagara Falls neighborhood, Love Canal quickly became a symbol of the nation's hazardous waste problems. President Carter declared a state of emergency in the neighborhood in the summer of 1978, and about 2,500 people left their homes. Nearly 300 houses were bulldozed; hundreds more remain boarded up despite a state agency's efforts to resettle part of the area. Occidental already has been found liable for at least some of the cleanup costs because a company it purchased in 1968, Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Co., created the dump in 1942. Dallas-based Occidental paid $20 million in 1984 to settle a separate lawsuit brought by 1,345 former Love Canal residents. Occidental attorney Thomas H. Truitt said Tuesday the company does not dispute that Hooker dumped 21,800 tons of dioxin, pesticide byproducts and other highly toxic chemicals in an abandoned canal bed dug in the 1890s by an entrepreneur named William Love. Truitt said Occidental expects it will have to pay most of the actual cleanup costs, which the state and federal governments have estimated at $140 million. ``We put the stuff in the canal,'' Truitt said. ``It's our stuff.'' The state is also seeking $310 million for damages to the environment, for creating a public nuisance and for interest, and $250 million in punitive damages for what it claims was Hooker's reckless conduct at the dump. Lawyers for both sides said it is unprecedented for a state to seek punitive damages in a toxic-dumping case. The first two months of the trial are expected to focus on that claim. Occidental argues the dump was well-built by the standards of the 1940s and would not have leaked had the school board and, later, the city and a private developer not dug it up to build roads, houses and an elementary school. A warning about the buried wastes was written into the deed when the company sold the dump to the school board in 1953, and the company says it sent lawyers to a school board meeting in 1957 to repeat the warning when the board first began thinking of selling off part of the property. The state concedes the warnings were made but contends they were innocuously worded compared to what Hooker knew at the time was going on at the dump. ``The deed refers only to `waste products resulting from the manufacturing of chemicals by the grantor at its plants,' which could have meant harmless rubbish,'' Eugene Martin-Leff, the top state lawyer in the case, wrote in a pretrial brief. After deciding the punitive-damage issue, Judge John T. Curtin will take two to four months more to hear Occidental's arguments that the federal, state and city governments and the school board should share the responsibility because they either dumped on the property or owned it after Hooker. Once the judge has ruled who is liable, the trial will recess for about 18 months while the lawyers prepare arguments over how much each party should pay.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Africanist Leader Dies After Long Illness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with where hospitalized, CLARIFIES proximity of families' homes in Soweto. Picks up 4th pvs, `Like Mandela...'
DOC.TEXT: Zephania Mothopeng, who broke away from the African National Congress to help form and lead the militant Pan Africanist Congress, died Tuesday. He was 77. He had been suffering from cancer and pneumonia, and was listed in critical condition the past week by doctors at Johannesburg Hospital. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, another major anti-apartheid figure, visited the PAC president earlier Tuesday. Mothopeng lived his last years a few blocks from the Soweto homes of fellow black nationalists Nelson Mandela and Walter Sisulu, but his militant stance kept him far from the more moderate ANC leaders. Like Mandela and Sisulu, Mothopeng spent years in prison for his political activities. Like his neighbors, the imprisoned Mothopeng became a symbol of the black struggle against the government. His release from Johannesburg's Diepkloof Prison in November 1988 preceded reforms that included freedom for the ANC leaders and government promises to include blacks in a new constitution. In their first public statements after being freed, both Mothopeng and Mandela urged the continuation of the armed struggle against the government. But unlike Mandela and other ANC leaders, Mothopeng opposed talks with the government intended to pave the way for a new constitution. The Pan Africanist Congress refuses to recognize the white-led government and opposes sharing power. Power should be returned to the indigenous Africans, Mothopeng said. ``The question is one of the repossession of our land from foreign colonial oppressors,'' he said in an interview this year. ``Our liberation will be brought about by the Africans themselves, by having to struggle for it. They will not achieve it at the negotiating tables,'' he said. Mothopeng was born Sept. 10, 1913, in South Africa's Orange Free State and became involved in politics in 1940, when he joined the ANC's Youth Wing. In 1959, unhappy with the ANC's contact with activists of other races, Mothopeng and others broke away from the ANC and formed the Pan Africanist Congress. It is a militant group compared to the ANC, urging black self-reliance in the land Mothopeng calls Azania. The PAC contends blacks must struggle for their freedom and find dignity in the process, rather than gaining equality through white concession or compromise. Mothopeng was jailed three times for his political activities, the longest stretch beginning in 1976 after his conviction on terrorism charges. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison and elected president of the Pan Africanist Congress in 1986 while imprisoned. Mothopeng was diagnosed with throat cancer while in prison, and the disease spread to other parts of his body. The government released him after 12 years.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi King, Egyptian President Make Conciliatory Statements
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Jiddah-dated Gulf-Saudi item on digest.
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd said Tuesday that Saddam Hussein would not lose face if he withdrew from Kuwait, and Egypt's Hosni Mubarak expressed hope the Persian Gulf crisis would end without bloodshed. The remarks, taken together with earlier comments by Defense Minister Prince Sultan, appeared to be the most conciliatory messages to the Iraqi leader since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Saudi Arabia also insisted that Prince Sultan had been misquoted, and denied it wants Kuwait to yield territory to Iraq in order to defuse the crisis. Those reports had helped push oil prices down more than $5 a barrel Monday. The Saudis reasserted Tuesday that Saddam must pull out his troops from Kuwait unconditionally. ``The correct reply is to remedy the mistake (of invading Kuwait),'' Fahd told reporters in remarks distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency. ``It would be nothing to cause anxiety or pain, but to the contrary, if President Saddam thought seriously about the matter, he would find that it is in the interest of Iraq, in his personal interest, and in the interest of the Arab nation, that he pull out from Kuwait,'' Fahd said in Jiddah, the Saudi summer capital. In Arab culture, losing face is considered a major dishonor. Arab conflicts traditionally are handed over to a respected mediator trusted by both sides. If his decision is accepted by both sides, ``face'' can be preserved. So far, apart from early efforts by King Hussein of Jordan, no such mediator has emerged. Mubarak, the Egyptian president, visited Saudi Arabia to meet with some of his 14,000 troops deployed at the northeastern region of Hafr al-Batin and told them their presence was meant to ``force him who lost his reason to return to it.'' He also expressed Egypt's hope that the gulf crisis ``end without bloodshed or war.'' Addressing his soldiers, Mubarak warned against any settlement of the Kuwait crisis that does not provide for reinstating the deposed al-Sabah family. ``Only the people (of Kuwait) have the right to choose their government and regime,'' Mubarak said. On Sunday, Prince Sultan, the Saudi defense minister, insisted on an unconditional Iraqi pullout from Kuwait and suggested that after such a withdrawal, negotiations could be held to consider Iraq's long-standing border dispute with Kuwait. Prince Sultan, third in the Saudi leadership after King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah, said that ``rights, whether valid or doubtful'' could always be discussed, but only after Iraqi withdrawal. Some took the prince's remarks as a sign that the Saudis were ready to agree to territorial concessions by Kuwait. This was a factor in a plunge in oil prices on Monday. Prince Sultan subsequently issued a statement ``to clarify ... wrong interpretations'' of his words, reaffirming that ``the kingdom categorically rejects the Iraqi aggression on sister Kuwait.'' In Washington, meanwhile, Prince Bandar, the Saudi ambassador and Prince Sultan's son, also denied his kingdom wants Kuwait to concede territory. Prince Bandar was summoned to the State Department to clarify Saudi policy. He spoke after meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In the Saudi resort town of Taif, a spokesman for the Kuwaiti government in exile stressed that Prince Sultan had been ``misquoted.'' The spokesman, who by custom was not identified by name, said the exiled government's view was ``that there can be no negotiations and no conditions'' regarding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He said the exiled government believed there had been no change in Saudi policy.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Accuses Burmese Military
DOC.TEXT: The State Department accused the Burmese military Tuesday of ``a total disregard for human rights'' in the reported raids on Buddhist monasteries. Troops in the Southeast Asian country arrested 20 monks at one Buddhist monastery Tuesday and surrounded 11 other monasteries in Burma's religious center of Mandalay as part of a crackdown on dissent, according to sources in Rangoon. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Burmese government radio reports said 133 monasteries were raided on Monday. She said department officials could not determine how many monks had been arrested. Burmese monks have been refusing to provide religious services for soldiers or their families, which in the Buddhist religion is the equivalent of excommunication. The monks' actions followed the Aug. 8 suppression of a protest in Mandalay. Western diplomats said two monks and two other people were killed in the confrontation. ``The United States views these raids as one more proof of the regime's total disregard for human rights,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``Its object seems to be the suppression of even token opposition in Burma. We strongly condemn this latest action by the Burmese military.'' Ms. Tutwiler also reiterated the U.S. call for the Burmese military government to transfer power to a civilian government and release all political prisoners. The government of Gen. Saw Maung has refused to turn over power despite the overwhelming victory in May elections of the opposition National League for Democracy. Opposition leaders have been jailed, and human rights groups accuse the military government of widespread abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Loses Parliamentary Majority With Key Defection
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing Hindu party deserted Prime Minister V.P. Singh's coalition Tuesday, depriving the government of a parliamentary majority. But Singh pledged to hang on to power. The walkout was prompted by the arrest Tuesday of the rightist party's leader, who had stirred tension between Hindus and Moslems by campaigning for a new Hindu temple on the site of a Moslem mosque. Singh went on national television to appeal for calm, fearing the political turmoil arising from a conflict between Hindus and Moslems could provoke violence. ``At this moment, and it is a very tense moment, my heart goes out to the innocent children, men, women who today are under tension and under fear,'' he said. Initial reports said scattered violence erupted around the country. United News of India said three people were stabbed to death during rioting in Ahmedabad in western India. At least 80 people died this month in riots between Hindus and Moslems. They usually were set off by minor squabbles, but were attributed to the Hindu temple dispute. Despite the defection, Singh said he was not quitting and will command enough support to maintain his 10-month-old government when Parliament reconvenes. Privately, his aides said it was unlikely the government would complete its four-year term and an early election was probable next year. The legislature is in recess for another three weeks, although President Ramaswamy Venkataraman has the power to convene it early. Venkataraman could let events in Parliament take their course when it begins its session next month. He also could ask the opposition Congress Party, the largest in Parliament, to try to form a new government, or he could call early elections. ``The government has been transferred from intensive care to the terminal ward,'' said V.N. Gadgil, a Congress Party spokesman. His party was ousted in last year's election. Officials in Singh's Janata Dal Party said they believed the Hindu party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, would stop short of voting against the government, since there was no viable alternative. The Hindu party's leaders said they would consider rejoining Singh's coalition if Singh were replaced. Singh's minority National Front government relied on the Hindu party and on the Communist-led Left Front to stay in office. Neither was formally part of the government. The political crisis was prompted by the arrest of the Hindu party's president, Lal Krishna Advani, during his cross-country crusade for building a Hindu temple where a mosque now stands in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. Advani was detained at dawn near the village of Samastipur, 450 miles southeast of New Delhi. Charges against Advani were not published. But up to 20,000 of his supporters were put under preventative arrest to stop what authorities feared could become a bloodbath between the two communities. The Hindu party claimed the figure was closer to 50,000. Hindus say the 16th century mosque was built on the ruins of an earlier temple on the site where the Hindu god Lord Rama was born. A fundamentalist Hindu group says it will begin building a new temple there Oct. 30, defying a court injunction. Thousands of Moslems and Hindus have died in the long history of communal bloodshed in the Indian subcontinent. Violence prompted the partition of colonial India into Moslem Pakistan and predominantly Hindu India when Britain granted independence in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon May Start New Wave of Troop Deployments to Persian Gulf
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is considering a new wave of troop deployments to the Persian Gulf, officials said Tuesday. Such a move would take the gulf buildup beyond the 240,000-troop force now planned. The decision is important because the deployment of more American ground units to Saudi Arabia could transform Operation Desert Shield from a force capable only of defending against a possible Iraqi attack to one tailored to launching an offensive. Officials also said evidence is emerging that U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait are beginning to hamper Iraqi military operations. Pete Williams, a spokesman for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said more than 210,000 U.S. forces now are in and around Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield to defend the desert kingdom against a possible Iraqi attack. That's 10,000 more than the last official count issued by Cheney on Oct. 13. Williams said Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was in Saudi Arabia this week to consult with U.S. and Saudi officials on the possible need to expand Desert Shield deployments, which President Bush ordered Aug. 7. Powell will report his recommendations to Cheney after returning to Washington on Thursday, Williams said. ``Then those decisions will be made on whether additional forces need to be sent or not,'' Williams said. ``So I don't want to ... signal that the deployment is nearly complete - that's a decision that will be made in part this week by Gen. Powell's visit.'' In comments to reporters in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, Powell said Tuesday that he and Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of all U.S. forces in the gulf area, had ``explored all options'' for Desert Shield. Powell declined to comment specifically on additional troop deployments. Williams said it had been planned all along that U.S. troop requirements in the gulf would be reassessed once the initial round of deployments was nearing completion. U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia now include four Army divisions, three Marine Corps expeditionary brigades, an air defense artillery brigade, a mechanized infantry brigade and an armored cavalry regiment. Also in the gulf area are more than 500 aircraft and 55 ships, including aircraft carriers and a battleship. An Army source, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said it was also possible that Powell would recommend reducing the number of American forces in the region, depending on military estimates of Iraq's troop strength and other factors. Bush repeatedly has said he has not ruled out the use of force to push Iraqi troops from occupied Kuwait. Williams said U.S. intelligence estimates put Iraqi troop strength in Kuwait and southern Iraq at 430,000 - unchanged over the last month. He added that American authorities have no evidence to substantiate recent news reports that Iraqi forces are pulling back from the Saudi border to fortify defenses to the north. The Iraqi military remains capable of launching an offensive strike with little warning, Williams said, although its operations are starting to be hurt by the effects of the U.N. sanctions, which have cut off most trade with Iraq. Williams cited Iraq's recent announcement of rationing civilian gasoline supplies as a sign that even the military is threatened by the economic embargo. He said the Iraqi military is short of tires, spare parts and other supplies and has been forced to make ``some adjustments'' in its operations in Kuwait. He did not elaborate, but said of the Iraqis: ``As time goes by, the sanctions continue to have effect. It becomes harder and harder to support that (military) force as the embargo restricts the shipment of spare parts and supplies.''

DOC.HEAD: KGB Renegade Accuses Intelligence Agency of Trying to Silence Him
DOC.TEXT: A deposed KGB general accused his former bosses in court Tuesday of stripping his rank, honors and pension to punish him for publicly criticizing the intelligence agency. If he wins reinstatement, Oleg Kalugin's civil lawsuit against the KGB could become a landmark for Soviet citizens seeking protection for free speech and challenging the secrecy of government decisions. The 55-year-old former general, who was an intelligence agent in the United States from 1958 to 1970, contends in the suit that KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov secretly ordered his demotion in June. Kalugin claims the order was in retaliation for comments he made to the Soviet press and on television that the KGB was resisting reform and continuing to spy on citizens opposed to the Communist Party. ``I think Kryuchkov's actions represent not only arbitrary rule against me, personally, but also a form of legal gangsterism, and I can't call it anything else,'' he told the three-judge panel in Moscow City Court. Kryuchkov has denied the allegations. He did not attend the hearing, the second since the trial opened Oct. 2. The KGB has alleged the orders for Kalugin's dismissal were received from the Council of Ministers, or national Cabinet, and no specific reasons have been given for his firing. Kalugin's fight with the KGB has made him a popular hero and helped him win a seat in the 2,250-member Soviet Congress, representing the southern Russian city of Krasnodar. The judges repeatedly had to call for order as the room full of spectators applauded Kalugin's lawyer and heckled the KGB's attorney. ``Oh my, we've hurt the KGB's feelings, isn't that too bad,'' an elderly woman called out sarcastically after the KGB lawyer, Viktor Alexeyev, complained about the outbursts. Kalugin's attorney, Boris A. Kuznetsov, argued that the 13-member Council of Ministers never met to consider Kalugin's case. He said the order was signed by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, at Kryuchkov's behest, and that documents later were fabricated to make it look as though the full council approved. After listening to both sides, the judges adjourned the case until mid-November. Chief Judge Nikolai Romanenkov said they were waiting for answers to questions they sent last month to the Council of Ministers and military prosecutor's office. The court asked the Council of Ministers to provide documents about how, when and why the decision was made to strip Kalugin of his rank. The military prosecutor was asked to describe the status of a possible criminal lawsuit against Kalugin. Soviet newspapers have said the prosecutor was investigating Kalugin on a potential charge of revealing state secrets. The former general has said he once headed the KGB's section on counterintelligence. He has denied revealing any national secrets. The KGB's efforts to disgrace him ``are illegal, they are not based on any laws of the Soviet state, they contradict common sense, and they violate the human rights of a person who served in the armed forces for more than 30 years,'' Kalugin told the court. At the Oct. 2 hearing, Viktor Alexeyev, chief of the KGB legal department, told the court that the agency revoked Kalugin's military pension after he was demoted, in accordance with a Soviet law. Alexeyev told said the KGB decision was based on an order the Council of Ministers issued June 29. The KGB is considered a branch of the armed forces, responsible for guarding borders, protecting top officials, collecting intelligence abroad and combatting both foreign spies and Soviet criminals. Kalugin's accusations hit the KGB particularly hard last summer, because the agency had just begun a public relations campaign to change its image Through interviews, films and television shows, the agency has sought to convince Soviets it is concerned with counterespionage and fighting corruption, and has given up harassing dissidents and tapping telephones.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Kill 10 Villagers in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels shot and hacked to death 10 Sinhalese villagers in an attack early Tuesday in north-central Sri Lanka, military officials said. The militants crept inside the village of Kadecholai, 60 miles southeast of Jaffna, and killed the villagers as they slept, Brig. Jaliya Nammune said. He said the victims included women and children. Military officials blamed the attack on the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam militia. More than 14,000 people have been killed since the Tamil militia launched the separatist war in 1983. The attack came as the Sinhalese-dominated military pressed on with a week-old campaign to widen perimeters around five key military installations in the Jaffna peninsula, a Tamil stronghold. The 410-square-mile peninsula forms the northern-most part of the island. Jaffna has been a major battleground in the insurrection for a separate homeland for the Tamil minority. The latest round of fighting flared in August, ending a 13-month cease-fire called to negotiate peace. Reporters were flown into Jaffna on Tuesday and taken around areas captured from the rebels. Almost every house had been converted into a bunker, linked to each other with tunnels. Less than a half-mile from Kankesanthurai town, which was captured Sunday night, soldiers fired mortars and automatic weapons at rebels in bunkers. Lt. Gen. Dezil Kobbekaduwa said 119 rebels and 20 soldiers have been killed in the week-old military offensive. The rebels claim they killed 50 soldiers and lost only 15 of their fighters. They had denied losing any village or town. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people and the Sinhalese comprise 75 percent. The Sinhalese control the military and the government. The Tamils complain of discrimation by the Sinhalese in jobs and education.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Scholar Defends Role Of Nancy Reagan In White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 10-15 new with Neustadt comments on other first ladies
DOC.TEXT: Presidential scholar Richard Neustadt, no fan of former President Reagan, emerges as a defender of Reagan's wife, Nancy, in a new edition of his classic study, ``Presidential Power.'' ``Never let your Nancy be immobilized, could be a rule of thumb for future presidents,'' Neustadt writes. The Harvard professor argues that Reagan could have saved himself a lot of trouble if the first lady had been able to advise him on the Iran-Contra affair. She could not, he says, because Reagan relied on the late William J. Casey, the secretive director of the Central Intelligence Agency, ``in such a way as to cut Nancy off'' from knowledge of the arms-for-hostages deal. Neustadt's description of Mrs. Reagan's role as an adviser contrasts with that of fired White House chief of staff Donald T. Regan, who revealed in his memoirs that some of her advice, on matters of the president's schedule, depended on astrology. This, Neustadt concedes, was ``silly, to be sure, though possibly no more so than the whims of staff, or press, or partisans, or family quite traditional in such decisions.'' ``But when it came to people, her reported targets seem well chosen, aim unerring and timing right for someone who must wait for someone else to pull the trigger,'' he writes. Mrs. Reagan was widely reported to have pressed for the removal of Regan, who was dismissed in 1987 after criticism of his handling of the Iran-Contra affair, and Attorney General Edwin Meese III, who resigned in 1988 after a special prosecutor completed an investigation of him without seeking an indictment. ``Nancy Reagan was perhaps that rarity, a disinterested adviser,'' Neustadt says. ``Alternatively, perhaps she was neurotically obsessed, as her detractors hint. Either way, her husband's close associates, however valuable or liked or even loved, were to be sacrificed, in her view, from the moment their continuation on the scene could compromise the president's public relations.'' In a telephone interview, Neustadt said, ``I must say I was offended by some of the attacks on her, which it seemed to me took no account either of her loyalty or the position she was in. But I wasn't trying to cheer or jeer or anything. That's the best I could understand, so that's the way I put it.'' Neustadt said former President Carter's wife, Rosalynn, ``apparently was in her way as close to her husband as Mrs. Reagan seems to have been to Ronald Reagan. But Mrs. Carter, as best I understand it, was ... someone he was interested in consulting about all his affairs, and interested in substance and politics. That's not my impression of Mrs. Reagan. She was interested in him and in his reputation and his place in history.'' The author said the role of President Eisenhower's wife, Mamie, ``was much more that of a conventional wife.'' He said Bess Truman, who had been an assistant in President Truman's office when he was a senator, ``was in her public demeanor totally self-effacing, but in private had felt herself to be a private counselor to her husband on everything.'' In his book, Neustadt writes that President Franklin D. Roosevelt's wife, Eleanor, ``was a substitute for legs, hence eyes and ears, outside her husband's physical confines. She also was an inescapable (and often useful) hairshirt on social issues. But she was not an intimate. Nancy Reagan, on the other hand, specialized in intimacy.'' He describes her as ``the president's closest, perhaps only, friend.'' The author portrays Reagan as inexperienced in foreign affairs and strikingly lacking in intellectual curiosity. ``Personally, I prefer presidents of the other sort, more skeptical than trustful, more curious than committed, more nearly Roosevelts than Reagans,'' he says. ``Still, it may be that his greatest lack was not experience, direct or indirect ... but rather anything to activate the aide in charge of warning him when threats appeared against his public standing or historical appeal. ``That special staff role, of immense importance to someone habitually incurious about detail, had been assigned his wife. More precisely, she had made it hers since Sacramento.'' Reagan began his political career as governor of California. ``Presidential Power'' was first published in 1960 and has been updated several times. The new edition, entitled ``Presidential Power and the Modern Presidents,'' is scheduled for publication Oct. 29 by The Free Press, a division of Macmillan, Inc. Neustadt is a professor emeritus at the John F. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University. Neustadt says the Iran-Contra episode will not dominate the history of the Reagan administration because Reagan recovered from it. Nevertheless, he says, it is a textbook case of a president failing to guard his prospective influence and making himself vulnerable to personal misjudgments and dubious advice. ``The crucial issue of the president's use of prospective influence lies in wait for every incumbent,'' writes Neustadt. ``Bush cannot escape it any more than Reagan could. But possibly to see it with an Iran-Contra sharpness is to see it plainer than before. That might conduce to dealing with it better, better at least than in my judgment Reagan did.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - W. Dale Nelson covered the White House for The Associated Press throughout President Reagan's second term.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers: Toxic Shock Effect on Rise From Strep Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: A bacterial infection that may be as serious as toxic shock syndrome is on the rise and is targeting children as well as adults, researchers reported Tuesday. New research points to significant changes in the pattern of severe streptococcal infections, Dr. Charles Hoge of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control reported Tuesday at an American Society for Microbiology conference. Strep is a common microbe, most frequently thought of as the cause of strep throat. But in rare cases, it can cause extremely serious infections - such as the pneumonia that killed Muppets creator Jim Henson in May. Three years ago, researchers began to talk of toxic shock syndrome caused by streptococcal infections, not the staph bacteria implicated in the much-publicized illness linked to tampon use. Now, researchers from the CDC and in Pima County, Ariz., have studied 128 cases of group-A streptococcal infections in 10 hospitals in the Tucson area to determine the prevalence of the most severe cases. The study involved records between January 1985 and March 1990. Fifty-four cases occurred from 1985 to 1987. None of those met a series of conditions similar to toxic shock syndrome: low blood pressure, rash, peeling skin, multi-organ involvement. But six of the 74 infections studied from 1988 to 1990 did. One of those six patients died, Hoge said. For all the county's severe group-A strep infection patients, the death rate was 20 percent. Laboratory tests on the bacterial isolates from Pima County found a propensity toward production of a specific toxin, and that toxin was present in at least two of the six toxic-shock-like cases. Toxic shock syndrome gets its name from the toxins produced by the bacteria at fault. The exact case definition of ``strep toxic shock'' is yet to be determined. But based on the cluster of symptoms in the Arizona study and the laboratory findings, that toxin may be the culprit, Hoge said. While the study was limited to the one populous county, the pattern is clear, Hoge said: Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome was significantly more likely to occur after 1988. More studies are needed to characterize the exact toxins present in the Arizona cases, which would provide more clues as to the exact nature of the illnesses, Hoge said. But he and his colleagues reported that changes in the strains of the strep bacteria may be responsible for the changing seriousness of strep infections. As in Henson's case, severe strep complications have been seen most frequently in adults. But three of the Arizona cases occurred in children. And other researchers at the conference reported new outbreaks of serious strep infections in children. Doctors at Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., reported that eight of their 29 cases of group-A strep infections between 1971-90 had the pattern of feverish illness, tender skin, multisystem involvement - ``reminiscent of ... toxic shock syndrome.'' One of the eight cases occurred earlier this year, and three more this year have followed the study. ``We have not had four children previously in one year with multisystemic streptococcal syndrome,'' said Dr. Mary Anne Jackson. And doctors at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, reported 16 such cases over a 10-year period. That remains rare, given hundreds of strep cultures a year in a large hospital, said Dr. Scott Halperin, an associate professor at Dalhousie. ``But for 16 kids it's an important issue - tremendously important,'' he said. ``And as a scientific issue, we wonder why the organism has had changes in its pathogenesis over time.'' Neither the Kansas City study nor the Halifax study included specific toxin tests. ``But it certainly is a multisystemic disease,'' Jackson said. ``We're trying to draw the attention of clinicians to this entity ... tell them to think of this.'' When group-A strep infections proceed to the bloodstream, the fatality rate is 20 percent to 30 percent. Strep was once the frequent cause of serious illnesses such as scarlet fever and rheumatic fever, but the most dangerous strains, for the most part, faded from view around the 1940s. Henson was the most famous recent victim of streptococcal illness; he died of a severe and rapidly spreading pneumonia.

DOC.HEAD: Nevis Leader Urges Secession from St. Kitts
DOC.TEXT: The premier of the Caribbean island of Nevis has urged secession from its larger neighbor St. Kitts through a change in the tiny nation's constitution. But Simeon Daniel did not elaborate on what steps are being taken toward independence for Nevis, which has about 20 percent of the twin-island nation's 43,700 residents. Daniel, who made the comments Monday during an assembly of his Nevis Reformation Party, predicted secession could come before the next local elections in Nevis in December 1992. St. Kitts and Nevis, one of the world's smallest nations, became independent from Britain in 1983. St. Kitts is 68 square miles, and Nevis is 36 square miles. Under the 1983 constitution, Nevis has extensive local powers as well as its own premier and assembly. But Daniel has complained of neglect by the central government in Basseterre. The convention was held in Charlestown on Nevis, about 200 miles southeast of Puerto Rico. The two islands are two miles apart. Daniel's party has a coalition with the ruling People's Action Movement led by Prime Minister Kennedy Simmonds.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Tests Encouraging On Killer Cotton Plants
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary tests of cotton plants genetically engineered to kill bugs themselves have been encouraging, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The department's Agricultural Research Service this summer conducted the first field tests of the cotton plants developed by Monsanto Co. of St. Louis, Mo. Test plants, called transgenic, were inserted with a gene from a different organism, Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bt, a commercially available natural bacterium. The gene enables Bt to make a protein toxic to many caterpillar species. And the transgenic plants make a similar protein. Department scientists said the transgenic plants caused caterpillars to have ``a fatal case of indigestion, often after eating only a bite or two'' of the leaves or bolls. The engineered cotton plants still must undergo extensive testing, but officials said the new technology could help reduce the use of chemical pesticides, reducing production costs for cotton farmers.

DOC.HEAD: Psychological Report Says Rocky Flats Workers Hit Hard By Changes
DOC.TEXT: Employee morale at Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has fallen because of the plant's chronic problems, and now many workers have an indifferent attitude that jeopardizes safety, a psychological report says. A Rocky Flats spokesman said plant officials disagreed with some of the report's conclusions, but acknowledged that there has been turmoil among the work force because of a large number of recently hired employees. The report said continuing criticism from the media, community groups and friends have made employees ``fearful of declaring that they work here. Many have reported feeling embarrassed to mention to people that they are employed at Rocky Flats.'' The Aug. 30 report is from J.N. Thistel, administrator of the employee assistance program, to F.J. Furman, director of the plant's occupational health department. Thistel wrote that sweeping changes have had an intense impact on employees and that the problems are causing employees severe stress at home and on the job. Sources at the plant provided copies of the report to The Associated Press on condition they not be identified. Thistel said the problems have taken a toll on employees, and interviews with the plant psychologist have ``skyrocketed from a low of 22 face-to-face interviews for the month of March to a high of 145 in August.'' ``Particularly in the last three years, change at the plant has been prolonged, arduous and capricious,'' Thistel warned. ``Consequently, employee morale has suffered because individuals no longer know what is expected of them, why the changes are occurring, and are unable to have the time to recuperate before another crisis confronts them,'' he wrote. ``This eventually causes employees to simply wear out and go into a survival mode by adopting an indifferent attitude,'' he added. The report helps show that serious problems continue to plague the Denver-area plant, which makes plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. A consulting firm, Cermak Fletcher Associates Inc. of Gaithersburg, Md., has done a study for EG&G Inc., the plant contractor, citing serious management problems at the plant during the last five months. That report, released Monday by plant officials, said EG&G relied too heavily on the U.S. Department of Energy to identify problems at the plant. It also said upper management failed to develop a comprehensive plan for restarting the plant. Operations at the plant have been suspended since November 1989 because of safety and environmental concerns. In June 1989, FBI and Environmental Protection Agency investigators raided the plant, looking for evidence of improper disposal of hazardous wastes. A federal grand jury was convened in August 1989 to investigate, but has not issued any indictments. Thistel acknowledges that workers' attitudes pose potential safety problems. He said employees are getting mixed messages to restore the plant to safe operating conditions and to complete work quickly so the plant can resume operations. ``This has been reported to have placed many supervisors at odds with employees, with the supervisors pushing workers to meet deadlines and the workers complaining that they are being asked to perform operations that aren't safe,'' Thistel wrote. Francis Allhoff, assistant general manager for administration and planning, said EG&G's top management disagreed with some of Thistel's conclusions, especially that workers are being pushed to resume operations at the cost of safety. ``Any push we have has to do with safety improvements, not towards resumption,'' he said. But he said management is having a problem conveying that idea to workers.
