The report said staff members are suffering from burnout because of overuse and underuse of personnel. ``While on one hand we have people working massive amounts of overtime, many without adequate compensation, on the other, we have highly qualified people that have nothing to do. The latter is closely akin to a prison environment, where individuals are punished by sensory deprivation,'' he wrote. Allhoff acknowledged that there were some delays in getting workers to their assigned jobs because it could take up to a year for new employees to get security clearances. He said more than 1,100 employees have been hired during the past year. He said other jobs are being found for people to do in the meantime, and any delays in putting them to work are temporary.

DOC.HEAD: Caretaker Government Attempts to Stem Sympathy Wave
DOC.TEXT: The army-backed caretaker government made a last-ditch attempt Tuesday to stem the sympathy wave that many feel puts Benazir Bhutto within striking distance of returning to power. As the ballot boxes were being readied, the caretaker government filed a seventh corruption charge against the 37-year-old former prime minister before a special one-judge tribunal in the eastern city of Lahore. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan used his constitutional powers on Aug. 6 to oust Ms. Bhutto and install a hand-picked caretaker government comprised of her most outspoken critics. The latest charge alleges Ms. Bhutto abused her power by making illegal appointments in some 10,000 government jobs. A hearing was set for Nov. 5. Later Tuesday, the president issued a blistering speech on nationwide TV and radio in which he recounted the charges against Ms. Bhutto and her former administration. He urged the estimated 50 million eligible voters not re-elect her party when they vote Wednesday. ``You need not fear anyone but God Almighty for his fear alone will give you courage to make the right decision,'' said the 73-year-old bureaucrat and stalwart of Pakistan's last military dictator, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. Ishaq Khan was once considered the standardbearer of Pakistan's infant democracy. But that image has been largely tarnished by the special tribunals set up to try Ms. Bhutto and her government. More than 100,000 soldiers in full combat gear fanned out across the country Tuesday to prevent what many have predicted will be Pakistan's most violent election. At stake in Wednesday's poll are 217 seats in the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament that will choose Pakistan's next prime minister. Polls open at 8:00 a.m. local time (11 p.m. EDT) and close at 5:00 p.m. (8:00 a.m. EDT) Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party and three smaller allied parties are pitted against the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 parties with little in common but contempt for Ms. Bhutto. Most analysts say the election is too close to call, but her opponents insist the People's Party will win no more than 75 seats, far from an outright majority. Despite a host of economic and social problems, Wednesday's poll is seen as a referendum on the dismissal of Ms. Bhutto's popularly elected government after only 20 months in power, and on the future course of a democracy struggling to emerge for the past 43 years. Even before the first votes were cast, Ms. Bhutto's loyalists were accusing the caretaker government of cheating. They said the tactics included moving polling stations, impounding vehicles designated to take Ms. Bhutto's ssupporters to vote and buying identity cards from the poor, her support base. ``The allegations being made are not unique,'' said Ken Wollack, executive vice president of the Washington-based National Democratic Institute. The group sent 40 international poll watchers from 18 countries to monitor the election. Their assessment could determine whether Pakistan continues to receive hundreds of millions of dollars in crucial economic and military assistance. Nawaz Sharif, Ms. Bhutto's chief nemesis and leader of the Islamic Democratic Alliance, dismissed the allegations. ``She's trying to project the idea of rigged elections because she is preparing the ground for defeat,'' said Sharif, considered the leading contender for prime minister if the alliance forms the next government. When Ishaq Khan fired Ms. Bhutto, he alleged her largely inexperienced government had plundered the national treasury and used government funds to buy political favors. He said it had handed out government jobs to friends and their families and failed to curb lawlessness and ethnic violence in Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sindh. Ms. Bhutto has insisted her government was clean and competent. In an effort to politically destroy Ms. Bhutto, the caretaker government dragged her and a half-dozen former Cabinet ministers before special tribunals dismissed across the board as ``kangaroo courts.'' But instead of discrediting her left-leaning party, the caretaker government only helped unify the leadership and rank-and-file, and halt Ms. Bhutto's declining popularity. The caretaker government then arrested her flamboyant and controversial husband, Asif Ali Zardari, a 38-year-old Karachi businessman blamed for much of Ms. Bhutto's troubles. Zardari was arrested Oct. 10 and held without bail in the April kidnapping of a Pakistani-born British citizen and extortion of $800,000. Zardari has used his arrest as a badge of honor and portrayed himself in newspaper advertisements as a martyr for democracy. He also is a candidate for two seats in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves More Money for S&L Probe, Drug War
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Tuesday to spend $19.3 billion this fiscal year to operate the Commerce, Justice and State departments, including more money for savings and loan prosecutions and the drug war. The legislation, approved 377-40, contains provisions agreed to in negotiations with the Senate to comply with deficit-reduction requirements and to compromise differences between the two chambers' versions of the bill. Before sending the measure to the Senate, however, the House discarded Senate language, accepted by House negotiators, that would have required the U.S. trade representative to wait five years after leaving the government before accepting a private sector job representing a foreign country. Opponents of that provision said it was inappropriate in an appropriations bill. The total spending in the bill is $529 million less than the amount appropriated for the three departments last year and $681 million less than requested by President Bush. The bill calls for $8.5 billion for the Justice Department, including $105 million in various divisions for savings and loan investigations. Money specifically for activities related to S&L crimes includes: -$47 million in the FBI budget. -$45 million in the budget for U.S. attorneys. -$6 million in the budget for the Justice Department's criminal division. -$5 million in the budget for the civil division. -$3 million in the budget for the tax division. The bill appropriates $694 million for the Drug Enforcement Administration, $146 million more than last year but $6 million less than requested by the president. It also earmarks $328 million for interagency law enforcement efforts against organized drug crime, an increase of $113 million over last year but $2 million less than requested by Bush. Japanese-Americans who were put in prison camps in the United States during World War II would get $500 million. Nearly 50 years after the internment, Congress voted last year to make the payments. The State Department section of the bill includes $788 million to cover overdue U.S. payments for membership in the United Nations and its affiliate international organizations. The appropriation reflects Bush's plan to bring the United States up to date in dues payments in recognition of the United Nations' work in gathering international support for action against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. The United States is five years behind in payments. The appropriation in the bill covers full 1991 membership in the organizations and 20 percent of the back payments. Another provision in the bill prohibits export licenses to ship supercomputers to any country helping Iraq improve its warfare capabilities or whose nationals are helping Iraq improve its military operations.

DOC.HEAD: International Doctors Group Plans Peace Mission to Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A multinational group of doctors hoping to prevent a war in the Middle East wants to sail a hospital ship into the region to provide free medical care, a spokesman said Tuesday. ``We're writing to world leaders in hopes that the ancient responsibility we have as physicians to prevent war could be realized,'' said Edward G. Toomey, an internist at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. ``We're just hoping that something will come of it.'' The Baltimore-based physician's group, Life International, has also planned a meeting in Geneva on Nov. 2 to show solidarity against a possible war in the Persian Gulf. The organization first had planned to use the former Navy ship, the Sanctuary, as a roaming medical facility for Third World nations, but Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 changed its priorities. ``We plan to go to one place and stay long enough to make a major difference in the way medical care is delivered and affect the quality of life of people,'' said Bob Mead, Life International's executive director. ``Ideally we'd like to have (the ship) be in some place for a year and a half or two years and do some medical training as well.'' Two Navy hospital ships are already in the Persian Gulf, Toomey said. The Sanctuary first sailed after World War II when it brought American war prisoners home from Japan. It was also used in the Korean and Vietnam wars. Life International tried for two decades to buy the ship and finally succeeded in 1988 when Congress sold it for $10. It is now being renovated in Baltimore Harbor by volunteers. About 150 doctors from Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, India, Pakistan, Egypt, the Soviet Union, Great Britain and the United States have said they would attend the Geneva meeting, Toomey said. The group plans a resolution to urge President Bush, Iraqi president Saddam Hussein and other players in the Persian Gulf crisis to avoid war at all costs.

DOC.HEAD: High School Senior Named Tournament of Roses Queen
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: A high school senior on Tuesday had a chance to display her poise immediately after she was named the 1991 Tournament of Roses queen, when a member of her court fainted in her arms. Cara Payton Rullman, 17, stumbled when her classmate fainted, but she quickly regained her composure and stepped forward to accept the crown and a bouquet of roses from 1990 Queen Yasmine Delawari. ``I was really shocked. I did trip a little bit. I guess I'm human,'' Rullman said after the ceremony. Rullman said the excitement of the announcement was too much for Tisha Mei-Ling Kong, with whom she attends San Marino High School. Kong was quickly revived, said Julie Sakamoto, a tournament spokeswoman. The queen and her six attendants were chosen from about 700 applicants, based on their public speaking ability, poise, academic achievement and personality. Rullman is a varsity cheerleader and a member of National Charity League. She said she plans to attend college and someday work with children suffering from Down's syndrome. The queen and her court will make about 100 appearances to promote the annual Tournament of Roses parade and Rose Bowl football game, held on New Year's Day. Actor Bob Newhart will serve as the 1991 parade's grand marshal.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Claims Captive Iranian Ex-Oil Minister Committed Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Tuesday that a former oil minister of Iran who was captured by Iraqi forces early in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war committed suicide two years later. The official Iraqi News Agency said its information came from an ``official source'' who was commenting on press reports that Iraq was still holding former Cabinet member Mohammad Javad Tondguyan. INA, monitored in Nicosia, did not say exactly when or how he died. The agency said President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, then prime minister, sought to gain Tondguyan's release on March 22, 1986, during a visit to Baghdad, and that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told him Tondguyan had committed suicide. On Monday, Iran accused Iraq of holding Tondguyan in a ``secret prison'' and demanded his immediate release. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Iran had ``live and documented evidence'' Tondguyan was alive and that Iraq should show good will by releasing him at once. Tondguyan was captured while on a tour of the fronts in October 1980, a month after the Iran-Iraq war broke out. A cease-fire ended hostilities in August 1988. Saddam recently agreed to Iran's terms for a formal peace settlement of their border dispute as he tried to break out of the international isolation that followed his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Saddam subsequently withdrew his troops from sections of Iranian territory occupied during the conflict. The two Persian Gulf neighbors also have exchanged tens of thousands of prisoners of war. The Iraqi agency said Iraq formally informed Iran of Tondguyan's suicide through the International Committee of the Red Cross. It said Iraq also handed over to Iran all papers related to the investigation, a medical report and a death certificate in accordance with provisions of the 1949 Geneva Convention.

DOC.HEAD: Another Courtroom Victory Makes Dees Two for Two Against Racists
DOC.TEXT: Attorney Morris Dees is two for two in multimillion-dollar court battles against racists, making him enemy No. 1 of violent white supremacists in the United States. ``I'm sure, for the time being, anyway, that these guys see me as the problem. They ought to be looking at themselves,'' Dees, 52, said Tuesday. A state jury late Monday awarded $12.5 million to relatives of a black man beaten to death by racist ``skinheads,'' giving Dees a big victory over White Aryan Resistance leader Tom Metzger. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million verdict against the United Klans of America after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. ``I think this verdict is much more important than the one against the United Klan for the lynching of Michael Donald, because that Klan group was on the decline,'' said Dees, head of the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala. ``This is an ascending group. It's gaining membership, gaining power, dealing with the young, aggressive, violent-prone segment of society, the skinheads.'' Dees said steps will be taken immediately to attach the assets of Metzger, a 52-year-old television repairman from Fallbrook, Calif. Defendants in the latest case included Metzger, his son John, Kenneth Mieske and Kyle Brewster. Mieske and Brewster are Portland skinheads who pleaded guilty to criminal charges in the death of Mulugeta Seraw, 27, an Ethiopian man who was attacked with a baseball bat in November 1988. The Portland jury agreed 11-1 that the Metzgers sent agents to the city to organize skinheads and incite them to commit violence against minorities. Metzger, who represented himself in court, contended that his activities were protected by free speech provisions of the Constitution. An attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union, Michael Simon, said his group had no problem with the verdict. ``In light of the findings that there was an intentional incitement, which is not protected by the First Amendment, there is no threat to First Amendment liberties by holding a defendant liable for the consequence of his actions,'' Simon said. The Rev. Richard Butler, pastor of the Church of Jesus Christ-Christian Aryan Nations in Hayden Lake, Idaho, said the monetary verdict will help the white supremacist movement by serving as a wake-up call. ``I think it's terrible,'' he said. ``It's theft. It's actually the theft of his property, the theft of his business and everything else. They're going to steal all the property they can of every white man.'' Metzger said after the verdict he was prepared to do whatever was necessary for the white racist cause. ``My wife and I made a pact in 1971, when we went against the Vietnam War and quit paying taxes, that if we had to leave our home in Fallbrook, California, with only the clothes on our back, so be it,'' Metzger said. The judgment assessed Metzger $5 million, the White Aryan Resistance $3 million, John Metzger $1 million and Mieske and Brewster $500,000 apiece. Jurors also awarded $2 million in non-economic damages and $500,000 for loss of income, to be divided equally among the five defendants. Elden Rosenthal, a Portland attorney who had Jewish relatives die in German concentration camps, helped represent the Seraw family. He praised the work of Ancer Haggerty, the black Multnomah County circuit judge who presided over the civil trial. ``He called this right down the middle,'' Rosenthal said. ``He did not let his personal biases influence the way he handled himself in this courtroom.'' Dees, who has an autobiography, ``A Season For Justice,'' coming out in April, said he has no other big cases looming. But he doesn't think the country has heard the last from Metzger. ``I don't think there's any question that Metzger has been driven up against the wall,'' Dees said. ``I think he sincerely believes the things that his paranoid mind tells him about how the Aryan race is doomed to be consumed by the `mud people,' as he calls them, and that he sees some Holy Grail purpose to stop this from happening. ``If a man is willing to die for his race, what else would he be willing to do for his race?''

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Party Group Invited to Iraq to Discuss Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Right-wing leader Jean-Marie Le Pen said Tuesday his party has been invited to Iraq to discuss hostages and he would personally accompany French citizens home if they are freed under a plan by Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi National Assembly earlier Tuesday overwhelmingly endorsed the Iraqi president's proposal to release all French nationals held in Iraq and Kuwait. Le Pen, who has urged expulsion of Moslem immigrants in France, has been highly critical of France's role in the multinational force amassed following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He began private contacts with Baghdad to seek a peaceful solution to the conflict. There have been no reports of when or if French hostages could be released. About 330 French citizens are held in Iraq or Kuwait, including 67 at strategic sites as a deterrent against military attack, according to the French Foreign Ministry. Saddam made the proposal to free French hostages Monday ``in appreciation to liberal French people's rejection'' of U.S. policies toward Iraq, and in support of President Francois Mitterrand's desire for a peaceful resolution to the gulf crisis, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. A statement from Le Pen's National Front party indicated a high-level party delegation would shortly leave for Iraq ``at the invitation of Iraqi authorities.'' ``A National Front delegation ... will occupy itself first of all with the fate of the French who find themselves there as well as the other Europeans,'' Le Pen told the French television network La Cinq. But Le Pen said he will only go to Iraq if all the hostages are freed. Iraqi's French Ambassador Abdul Razzak Rachid al-Hachimi refused to confirm whether the delegation would take home hostages. ``We prefer and we hope that a French government official will go to Baghdad to bring the French nationals back, that's for sure,'' al-Hachimi said in a La Cinq interview. Hubert Vedrine, a spokesman for Mitterrand, declined comment on the Iraqi decision. The Iraqi assembly endorsed Saddam's hostage-release proposal in a 248-2 vote, Iraqi officials said. Earlier Tuesday, Premier Michel Rocard and some legislators held a meeting dedicated to the French hostages. Bernard Stasi, a centrist member of the National Assembly, quoted Rocard as saying the release would be ``a unilateral decision taken by Iraq.'' ``The taking of hostages is odious,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a communique. ``Their release is no more than an atonement for an unacceptable act. France cannot accept any sort of negotiation on the subject.'' But the ministry said France would take measures to repatriate the hostages if they are freed. Saddam's proposal has been viewed as an attempt to split the West's anti-Iraq alliance by creating the impression that France was negotiating its own deal. France, with 13,000 troops deployed in the gulf region, represents the second largest Western military force after the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Recalls Bloody 1956 Uprising
DOC.TEXT: On the anniversary of the East bloc's bloodiest uprising, Hungary's leaders on Tuesday urged their countrymen to fight fear of the future in the spirit of their battle against Soviet tanks 34 years ago. Commemorations of the 1956 revolt were modest compared to last year, when they were combined with other events marking Hungary's transition to democracy. Economic worries and political disenchantment have spread since then. Budapest wreath-laying ceremonies that attracted thousands last year drww hundreds Tuesday. Speakers at a ceremonial meeting of Parliament drew parallels between disenchantment now and that which followed crushing of the uprising by Soviet armor. ``Today, when the country is living through difficult hours, when Hungary is not only suffering from its legacy but new pains and disappointments . . .. let us remember 1956,'' Prime Minister Jozsef Antall told the assembly. He asked all parties to ``fight poverty and keep the germ of apathy from contaminating our people.'' Antall and other dignitaries later placed wreaths at the grave site of revolutionary Premier Imre Nagy and associates executed after the failed uprising. Vytautas Landsbergis, president of the independence-minded Soviet republic of Lithuania and a guest of Hungarian Federation of Political Prisoners, suggested Lithuanians emulate the 1956 struggle. He said it served as an example to his republic as it seeks to break away from the Soviet Union. ``Fifty-six served as a very good example for our cause,'' he told state radio. ``If we want to be free we have to do the same as what you did in `56.'' It was not clear what Landsbergis meant by the statement, which was carried in voiced-over Hungarian translation on the radio. Lithuania's attempt to regain its independence has been almost totally peaceful. In later comments, he emphasized that Lithuania was using only nonviolent means. Daylong commemorative rallies were arranged, as well as a march retracing the steps of the 200,000 demonstrators who gathered 34 years ago. The revolt began on Oct. 23, 1956, with student demonstrations calling for greater democracy, a multiparty system and withdrawal of Soviet troops. Protests grew into armed clashes with Hungarian secret police and Soviet troops before Soviet tanks suppressed all resistance 12 days later. Official figures put the dead at 5,000 to 6,000, with 12,000 wounded. Western estimates said up to 32,000 people died and 200,000 fled the country. Last year, their spirits lifted with the prospects of approaching democracy, more than 100,000 people marked the uprising with an emotional torchlight rally. Less than six months later Hungarians elected a free government that pledged to replace the Soviet-style centralized economy with a free market system. In the last two years most demands voiced by the 1956 demonstrators have been fulfilled, including withdrawal of all Soviet troops, now in progress; free elections; freedom of expression, and economic reforms. But spirits this year were dampened by worrisome economic indicators that include a debt of more than $20 billion and mounting unemployment. ``I work as an accountant, and I can tell you that my firm's situation . . . is shaky, indeed almost hopeless,'' Karoly Petrovics, a 27-year-old father of two, told a reporter. ``I just don't know how I am going to keep the family going next year.'' Still, the anniversary evoked strong emotions from some people. A ceremony outside the national radio building, the site of 1956 fighting, was briefly disrupted when about 20 men forced their way into the lobby. They demanded removal of a black marble plaque set up by the former Communist government in memory of secret police officers who died defending the station against revolutionaries. The men withdrew after a cloth was placed over the plaque.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0596, BC-House-Budget-Roll Call transmitted Oct. 6 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Oct. 6 that three California Republicans did not vote when the House tried unsuccessfully to override President Bush's veto of a bill that would have funded the government for one week and reopened closed agencies. The three, Reps. Dana Rohrabacher, Norman Shumway and William Thomas, voted no.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty: Rise in Death Squad Killings Reported in El Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed until 8:01 p.m. EDT Tuesday. Time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Wednesday reported a significant upsurge in the number of killings by army-supported death squads this year in El Salvador. The London-based human rights group reported more people were killed in the first seven months of 1990 than in all of last year. Between January and early August, 45 people had reportedly been killed by death squads. Forty were reportedly killed by death squads in 1989, it said. Amnesty said killings, torture and ``disappearances'' have continued despite a U.N. Agreement on Human Rights signed July 26 by the government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the guerrilla group Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN). ``Bodies of victims have been found mutilated, some with their faces completely destroyed and others with signs of having been brutally tortured. Victims have been shot dead on the streets or in their homes,'' the Amnesty report said. The Nobel Peace Prize-winning group detailed several killings, including an agricultural cooperative member slain Aug. 1 at work, and a union member who was taken from his home by two men in civilian clothes July 23. His body was found the following day. Amnesty said its information on the death squad killings came from former members of the security forces, among other sources. Amnesty said its sources and other information ``including testimonies by former members of the military, suggests that those responsible for these actions (death squad killings) are linked to the armed forces.'' It said four apparent death squad killings that occurred in the days following the U.N. accord ``suggest that those responsible are continuing to operate with the confidence that they will not be punished.'' Amnesty said Cristiani's government had acknowledged reforms were needed and that the security forces sometimes committed ``excesses.'' But the government has denied involvement. ``However, the extent and nature of the abuses and the fact that human rights violations have been committed with almost total impunity under this and previous government has left little doubt of official complicity,'' Amnesty said. The rights organization said it was also concerned about reports of rights abuses linked to the FMLN. The report on El Salvador is based on findings by Amnesty delegates who visited the country in April. The report contains 34 recommendations, including making full investigations into violations; strengthening the office of the Attorney General and ensuring its independence, and protection for judges and witnesses involved in human rights cases. About 72,000 people have been killed in the 11-year-old civil war between the government and the FMLN. The two sides began cease-fire talks in May and are scheduled to meet Nov. 4 in Mexico. After the U.N. agreement, the government spoke out publicly against torture and established rights training courses, Amnesty said. The government revised detention guidelines and established a 24-hour office to provide information on detainees, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Legislator Norman Buchan Dead at 67
DOC.TEXT: Norman Buchan, an outspoken Scottish legislator and writer of folk songs, died after a long illness, his family announced Tuesday. He was 67. Nature of his illness was not announced. Buchan represented the Scottish constituency of Paisley South for the opposition Labor Party. Two byelections are now pending in Paisley, near Glasgow. Allen Adams, 44, the Labor representative for Paisley North, died Sept. 5. Born in Helmsdale in northeastern Scotland on Oct. 27, 1922, Buchan was educated at Glasgow University and served with the Royal Tank Regiment in North Africa and Italy in World War II. After the war he took up teaching. Buchan was first elected to Parliament in 1964. From 1967 to 1970 Buchan served in the Scottish Office, which runs Scotland's affairs from Westminster. He was an agriculture minister for seven months in 1974. Always on the left of the Labor Party, Buchan was a vociferous member of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, which favors unilateral disarmament by Britain, and a staunch supporter of state ownership of enterprise. Buchan was also one of Scotland's best-known folk songwriters and edited a book of songs. He is survived by his wife Janey, a member of the European Parliament, and their son. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Rain In East, With Floods And Tornadoes In Carolinas
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the Atlantic states Tuesday, and thunderstorms in the Carolinas caused flooding and spun off tornadoes. In South Carolina, strong wind and heavy rain forced the evacuation of 20 families from a mobile home park, injured at least five people and flooded some roads under several feet of water, authorities said. North Carolina had at least two tornadoes and record amounts of rain that swelled rivers to flood stage. The tornadoes caused no injuries but one man was killed when his car went off a bridge that was knocked out by a train derailed by flood-damaged track. Flooding also was reported at Dover, Pa., where Conewago Creek was out of its banks, the National Weather Service said. Six roads were closed by flooding in Carroll County, Md., and local flooding was reported in Washington. In addition to the Atlantic states, rain and occasional thunderstorms also spread over the upper Ohio Valley and the northern and central Appalachians. Light rain was scattered across south-central Iowa, northwest Missouri, southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.78 inches at Cape Hatteras, N.C.; 1.30 inches at Williamsport, Pa.; 1.28 inches at Virginia Beach, Va.; and 1.24 inches at New Bern, N.C. Miami warmed to a record high of 90. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 2 p.m. EDT ranged from 36 at both Sheridan, Wyo., and Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 91 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Bureau Briefly Seized by Relatives of Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of political prisoners briefly occupied a United Pres International office Tuesday demanding transmission of a communique drawing attention to their plight. The three men and four women were unarmed and carried a statement criticizing the civilian government for failing to free all leftists imprisoned under the former military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Oton Gutierrez, who heads the news agency's bureau in the Chilean capital, said the group ``left the office peacefully after talking to me and to police.'' He said full text of the group's statement was not transmitted by the Washington-based news agency, though a report on the incident would move on the wire. The group initially insisted they would not leave the office unless their communique was moved in full on UPI's international wire and the agency's Chilean news service. After succeeding Pinochet last March, President Patricio Aylwin pardoned a number of prisoners who had not committed violent crimes. But he has refused to free those charged with violence or terrorism, and is legally prohibited from pardoning suspects whose trials are in progress. An estimated 260 prisoners jailed for political reasons remain behind bars in Chile.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Drafts Mild Reform of Election Law
DOC.TEXT: Albania published a draft election law Tuesday that for the first time permits secret ballots and multiple candidacies. But Albania, the lone defender of Stalinism in Europe, would remain a one-party state. The Communist-controlled legislature will discuss the measure in November. The draft allows several candidates to contest each of Parliament's 250 seats and permits a broader range of official organizations to propose candidates than in the past. Besides the ruling Albanian Labor Party (Communist Party), the Communist-run Democratic Front, the youth organization and trade unions also could field candidates. No date for elections has been set. The draft, which appeared on the front page Tuesday of the party daily Zeri I Popullit, was publicly outlined Oct. 9. Its publication seemed timed to coincide with the arrival of journalists and diplomats for a meeting of Balkan foreign ministers, the first such high-level international here in decades. Following East Europe's anti-Communist revolutions, Albania has been taking steps this year to modify its hard-line Communist system and has emerged from its self-imposed international isolation. Coupled with a lack of freedom, Albania's 3 million citizens endure the lowest living standards in Europe. Last July, discontent led an estimated 4,000 Albanians to besiege embassies in Tirana before being allowed to emigrate. The public show of unrest was unprecedented, but President Ramiz Alia has kept to his line of cautious reform, opening up the economy for the first time to foreign investment and allowing some Albanians to travel abroad. A legal expert who met with journalists Tuesday made clear, however, that Albania's Communist hierarchy is not considering following other East European leaders in abandoning one-party rule. ``There won't be any party pluralism,'' said Aleks Luarasi, deputy dean of Tirana University's political science faculty. ``There will be pluralism of opinion. The people are free to express their opinions in the mass organizations, in the party and in other ways. But there won't be any party pluralism.'' Luarasi said Parliament will appoint a committee to oversee reform of the constitution, and that he expected further legal changes. One such change will concern religious practice, outlawed under Communist Albania's founder Enver Hoxha, who ruled from 1944 until his death in 1985. Religious matter was dropped last May from a list of activities deemed anti-state propaganda. Luarasi said Albanians now can gather undisturbed at holy places. However, churches and mosques have not been reopened. Traditionally, roughly 70 percent of Albanians were Moslems, 20 percent Orthodox and 10 percent Roman Catholic. Luarasi noted that laws guaranteeing free operation of religious institutions in addition to freedom of belief probably would have to be passed if Albania wants to realize its goal of joining the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Albania was the only European nation that did not sign the 1975 Helsinki Accord, also known as the Final Act, that launched the Conference as a body stipulating and monitoring human rights in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Court Reverses Decision Allowing AT&T Discounts For Corporations
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Tuesday invalidated a Federal Communications Commission decision that allows American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to discount long-distance packages for large corporations. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here held that the FCC did not fully examine whether the customized long-distance services AT&T offers its larger corporate clients violated the Communications Act. The appellate court ordered the FCC to review its 1989 decision on the so-called Tariff 12 services offered by AT&T, whose long-distance operations are subject to government regulation. AT&T started offering the long-distance packages to companies such as General Electric Co., Ford Motor Co. and DuPont in 1988. The service packages enable large companies to hire AT&T to set up an integrated long-distance network to transmit voice, data and visual communications and manage the system. The tariffs filed with the FCC for each service contain the specifications that AT&T provided the customer during contract negotiations. Several of AT&T's long-distance competitors, including MCI Telecommunications Inc., and US Sprint, argued that these tariffs violated the Communications Act because they were so narrowly tailored that the services were not generally available to all potential customers. The three-judge appellate panel held that the FCC used impermissible criteria in determining whether a package of services offered to one large corporate customer was different from an aggregate of the same long-distance options sold individually to other customers. The FCC must also determine if there is a ``neutral, rational basis'' for the price differences between the two sets of services, the court said. The FCC's 1989 order ``gives us no confidence that this analysis has yet been done,'' the court said in an opinion by Circuit Judge Laurence Silberman that was joined by Judges Abner Mikva and Harry Edwards. ``We have the impression that there is a certain air of unreality about this case,'' Silberman wrote. ``The FCC (one way or another) will undoubtedly permit AT&T to compete effectively against its competitors in the large user market if that is what is really involved here.'' ``But we are obliged to insist that it do so by turning square corners of administrative law,'' Silberman wrote. MCI spokesman John Houser said the court's ruling put ``in legal limbo'' Tariff 12 arrangements that the company contends are ``anti-competitive and unlawful.'' But AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said the telecommunications giant was ``confident that issues raised by the court's opinion can be easily remedied by the FCC.'' ``The decision today doesn't in any measure pull the plug on customers that AT&T is now servicing and we are confident that the concerns raised by the court can be easily remedied by the commission,'' Linnen said. ``We will continue to offer these services to existing and prospective customers.'' FCC general counsel Robert L. Pettit said in a statement that the FCC would carefully study the ruling and consider AT&T Tariff 12 filings now pending ``in light of the court's opinion.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi-Egyptian Meeting Sends Conciliatory Signal to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd on Tuesday said Saddam Hussein would not lose face if Iraq withdrew from Kuwait, and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak expressed hope the Persian Gulf crisis would end without bloodshed. The remarks, taken together with earlier comments by Defense Minister Prince Sultan, appeared to be the most conciliatory message to the Iraqi president since his troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But Saudi Arabia also said Prince Sultan was misquoted and denied it wants Kuwait to yield territory to Iraq to defuse the crisis. Those reports helped push oil prices down more than $5 a barrel Monday. The Saudis said again Tuesday that Saddam must withdraw his troops from Kuwait unconditionally. ``I do not see that if a blunder were committed that we correct the mistake with another mistake. The correct reply is to remedy the mistake,'' Fahd told reporters in remarks distributed by the official Saudi Press Agency. ``It would be nothing to cause anxiety or pain, but to the contrary if President Saddam thought seriously about the matter he would find that it is in the interest of Iraq, in his personal interest, and in the interest of the Arab nation, that he pull out from Kuwait.'' Losing face is considered a major dishonor in Arab culture. Arab conflicts traditionally are handed over to a mediator trusted by both sides. If both sides accept his decision, face can be preserved. Apart from early efforts by King Hussein of Jordan, no such mediator has emerged so far. Mubarak visited Saudi Arabia to meet with some of his 14,000 troops deployed at the northeastern region of Hafr al-Batin and told them their presence was meant to ``force him who lost his reason to return to it.'' He expressed Egypt's hope the crisis ``end without bloodshed or war.'' Mubarak then traveled to the United Arab Emirates to meet with officials there and check on a 2,000-strong Egyptian force based 185 miles from Abu Dhabi, the Emirates' capital. Addressing his soldiers, Mubarak cautioned against a settlement that does not provide for reinstating Kuwait's deposed Al-Sabah family. Emirates President Sheik Zayed Bin Sultan Al-Nahyan, who accompanied Mubarak, said he hoped the issue would be settled soon ``either by peace or by war.'' Rejecting conciliatory statements, Zayed said the emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, must be reinstated. ``Is it our duty to save an aggressor's face?'' Zayed said. ``No. He put himself in an awkward situation and he must get out of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Triumphant, Colorful Ungaro, New Softness All Over
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Emanuel Ungaro carried the day Tuesday with a sumptuous festival of color in summer ready-to-wear. The show marked a triumph of all Ungaro stands for among his fans: fabulous mixes of silk prints and leather - even patent leather - clothes both tailored and feminine. As Ungaro has eased up on skintight silhouettes, the most welcome innovation is in his new, flowing smock tops of silk in beautiful shades like pink, yellow and raspberry, often over narrow skirts. One could call his blouson dresses sacks. But whether one or two piece, they flow gently around the body in a medley of flower prints or solid, bright crepe de chines, sometimes sashed at a low hip above a narrow hem. Add to this floaty new shirt-jackets, flounced babydoll and trapeze dresses in airy fabrics, full-sleeved V-necked print or silk crepe blouses cut like gypsy shirts. Even the fitted suits or dresses with easy jackets look softer. The luscious pastel plaid jackets paired with flowered outfits underneath are great fun, as are belted blouse and skirt outfits. Lame print dresses with low waists and flounced hems, flowered shifts under multicolored striped blazers, flared evening dresses with full tulle crinolines peeping underneath and sensational fringed taffeta stoles complete the festive Ungaro line. The fashion words elsewhere were also easy and soft. Guy Douvier's offering for Guy Laroche embodied wisdom itself. Like Ungaro, Douvier did a version of the blouson dress with bold jacquard pastille dots, flowers or striped prints. The wearable classics included short and boxy coats or long shirt-jackets, cashmere trench coats in navy or hot pink, and double-breasted coat dresses in soft poplin wool. Some good bicolor poplin shirtwaist dresses with drawstrings at hemlines or hips in shades like poppy and grey or khaki green were typical of the casual dressing advocated at Laroche. Casual beachwear included bright ethnic prints, long white wrapped skirts and plenty of shorts. One striking outfit was topped by a large black-and-white diamond-printed silk twill shirt-jacket. Best in the dressier line here were a couple of sequined minis topped by a draped bustier top and raw silk shirt-jacket in hot shades of gold, fuchsia and rust or combinations of blue and green. Philip Wagon, the new English-born ready-to-wear designer for Nina Ricci, showed a line sometimes so soft it almost went limp. There were plenty of long and floaty shirt jackets, slim pants and shirtdresses, often in white or ivory fluid fabrics and pique. Wagon also opted for his version of the flowery blouson look. It was all in good taste, from the bicolored navy-and-white crepe dress cut to look like a white blouse with a dark apron to the flounced crepe de chine, the sacks, tent dresses and shifts. A typical simple shift in deep turquoise had slightly puffy, cuffed long sleeves, big buttoned-down patch pockets and was worn with a flowing carnation red chiffon scarf. As a saddlemaker, Hermes trotted out a jockey line featuring bicolored leather jackets looking like jockey silks over white stretch riding pants. The wide rider's raincoat in off-white was a handsome look, along with blazers and stretch jodphurs. The design team headed by Claude Brouet, a fashion specialist and former editor of the magazine Marie-Claire, turned out some dashing new silks, also a specialty of the famed saddlemaker.

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Names as Army Boss Ex-Guerrilla Chief Accused of Torture
DOC.TEXT: Namibia named as its army chief Tuesday a former SWAPO guerrilla commander accused of torturing suspected spies and dissidents. The Defense Forces announced in a one-line statement that Maj. Gen. Solomon Dumeni Hawala was appointed army commander, effective immediately. The position had been vacant since Namibia, formerly South-West Africa, became independent on March 21. An opposition party, the Namibian Patriotic Front, condemned Tuesday's appointment. Hawala was a fighter in the South-West Africa People's Organization, or SWAPO, which waged a 23-year battle for independence against South Africa. Hawala, commonly called Jesus Hawala, also has been called the Butcher of Lubango, a town in southern Angola where SWAPO had a camp during the war. People formerly held in SWAPO camps in Angola on suspicion of being spies or dissidents have accused Hawala of supervising widespread torture. The Namibian Society for Human Rights, a private group, accuses SWAPO of failing to account for an estimated 1,500 people detained during the war. A U.N. commmission of inquiry last year put the figure at just over 300. SWAPO official Theo-Ben Gurirab, who became Namibian foreign minister after independence, acknowledged in August 1989 that some detainees were tortured, but said all were released. Under an independence plan, Namibia wrote a constitution and held democratic elections last year that were won by SWAPO. SWAPO President Sam Nujoma became Namibia's first president. Namibia's infant democracy has been widely praised for its fairness and moves toward reconciliation, but Hawala's appointment could reopen old wounds. The SWAPO Youth League has demanded removal of opposition members of Parliament it accuses of being puppets for South Africa. SWAPO party leader Moses Garoeb has attacked the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, the largest opposition party, as disrupting national unity.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Closes Off Territories After Wave of Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 25 grafs to UPDATE with past closures of occupied territories, name of woman injured in Tuesday attack, quote from civilian claiming he beat attacker. Picks up 22nd graf pvs, `Off-duty bus...'
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Tuesday barred Palestinians in the occupied territories from traveling to Israel following a series of revenge attacks by Jews and Arabs. Under Arens' order, the 1.7 million Palestinian residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip will be banned from entering Israel beginning Wednesday morning, the military command said. Those staying in Israel, where many work, were ordered to return home. Israel television said the travel ban will remain in effect for ``several days'' until tensions are reduced. The army usually erects barriers on main roads leading to the territories to enforce such orders. The last closure of the occupied areas in response to violence was after the May 20 slaying of seven Arabs by a Jewish civilian near Tel Aviv. The territories also have been blocked in recent years during the Jewish Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, holiday. Arens' order was issued hours after Israeli civilians fired on an Arab car in the southern Negev desert, killing one Palestinian laborer and wounding his three cousins. Doctors at Nasser Hospital in the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis identified the victim as Maher Al Shaher, 30. One of the ounded was in serious condition with a gunshot to the back, they said. Palestinian reporters said the four were returning from work in Israel when they came under fire from a red Jeep in the area of Mivtahim, near Gaza. The army confirmed the Palestinians were apparently shot by Jewish civilians and said the attack was being investigated. Earlier Tuesday, a West Bank Palestinian knifed two unarmed women soldiers and another Arab bludgeoned two Israelis with a hammer. The knife-wielding Arab was chased and captured by soldiers and civilians, police said. There were reports he was beaten, and hospital officials said he was in critical condition with head injuries. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the recent wave of attacks on Israelis, which began Sunday with three stabbing deaths in Jerusalem, resulted from ``unusual hysterical incitement'' of Arabs. Tension has risen since Oct. 8, when police fired on stone-throwing Palestinians at Jerusalem's hallowed Temple Mount, killing at least 19 Arabs. Clandestine leaflets have urged Arabs to step up attacks on Jews, and the violence since Sunday's killings raised fears that the 34-month Palestinian uprising may be entering a more dangerous phase. A leaflet distributed Tuesday by Hamas, a Moslem fundamentalist group, praised as a ``hero'' the Palestinian laborer who killed an unarmed woman soldier, a gardener and an off-duty policeman Sunday in Jerusalem. It said the laborer had killed ``three enemy soldiers'' and added: ``This is only the beginning.'' The daily Yedioth Ahronoth reported a rush by Israelis on gun shops, and reporters pressed Shamir to say what his government was doing to protect the public. Shamir said security was being increased ``in all parts of the country,'' but he insisted the violence would die down in a matter of days. Tuesday's trouble began at about 9:30 a.m. when an Arab shouting ``Allahu Akbar!'' (God is great) stabbed two women soldiers hitchhiking near Kiryat Tivon in northern Israel. Naama Yekutiel, a youth instructor, was in serious condition with a punctured lung, said Dr. Albert Suttinger, deputy director of Rambam Hospital in Haifa. The other, Cpl. Limor Ben-Shaul, suffered a superficial back wound, Suttinger said. Radio reports said several citizens helped capture the assailant. ``We chased him and then he threw down the knife and we grabbed him,'' civilian Eli Koman told Israel radio. ``We held him down and shouted at the soldiers to shoot and kill him. They wouldn't. I asked one of them to give me his rifle. He refused.'' An unidentified civilian speaking on Israel television said he participated in a beating of the alleged attacker. ``He shouted `Ai, ai!' and we began beating him. We kicked him. We tried to beat him as hard as possible,'' said the man. Off-duty bus driver Albert Ben-Ezra told army radio that he pursued the assailant and exchanged punches with him. ``I saw him throw the knife and then I grabbed him. Then I heard shots fired in the air, and the soldiers came and helped me,'' said the bus driver, who added that he has two daughters in the army. The suspect was identified as a 39-year-old Palestinian from the West bank town of Jenin, where a 14-year-old boy was killed and eight other people injured in a clash with soldiers Monday. He was taken to Afula Hospital in central Israel, and then to Rambam, where Suttinger said he was in critical condition. Later Tuesday, in the southern coastal city of Ashkelon, an Arab wielding an 11-pound hammer battered two Israelis in their 40s as they worked in a machine shop, police said. Both were hospitalized, and details of their conition were not immediately available. The 23-year-old Arab, who worked at the shop, was arrested, police said. They said he claimed to be avenging a friend who was killed in Gaza. The attacks came as police blocked Arabs from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip from entering Jerusalem for a second day in an effort to prevent violence between Arabs and Jews. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said tension in his city was decreasing, but would not disappear ``until negotiations begin on peace. ... When no progress is seen, or any small light at the end of the tunnel, there is despair.'' Also Tuesday, two Palestinian men were found dead in the Gaza Strip town of Rafah after being shot by fellow Arabs for allegedly collaborating with Israel, Arab reports said. Police were investigating the deaths. Internal feuding has killed 286 Palestinians since the uprising began in December 1987. Most were accused of collaboration. At least 763 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 51 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Wandering Whale's Out of the Mud, but Not Out of the Woods
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Humphrey the wandering whale, freed from one spot in the mudflats of San Francisco Bay, spent most of Tuesday stuck in another spot before he began wandering again. Five years after the 40-foot humpback's much publicized voyage through the bay to the Sacramento River, he drew a crowd of thousands to a cove near Candlestick Park, where he lay beached by rocks bearing a ``No Trespassing'' sign. A team of marine biologists, veterinarians and the Coast Guard nudged the 45-ton whale with their hands, splashed him with buckets of water, towed him with a harness and used an air compressor to suck mud from below him. ``Essentially we were trying to tease him off that mud rock,'' Frank Griffith of the California Marine Mammal Center said during the effort. ``There's no amount of human beings that you could put out there to push him off like you'd push a car down the street. If he's stuck on the bottom by mud suction, you couldn't move him unless he puts some effort into moving himself.'' As afternoon high tide rolled in, Humphrey budged a bit from the mud at 2:20 p.m., flipping his fins, raising his tail and blowing water through his spout. The crowd cheered. A short while later, Humphrey got stuck again, but with more work he freed himself and swam out into the bay while volunteers banged pipes to direct him away from land. Once Humphrey reached deep water a quarter to a half mile away, rescuers hoped to used recorded whale sounds to lure him out under the Golden Gate Bridge to the ocean where he belongs. ``I think the guy likes attention. I think he likes people,'' said Frank Boyd of San Francisco, who was in the crowd watching Humphrey. Humphrey became something of an aquatic celebrity in the fall of 1985, when he spent 25 days swimming in San Francisco Bay and the Sacramento River Delta before being guided and cajoled back to the Pacific. His legions of fans heralded him with songs, poems, books and, of course, a T-shirt. The state and federal governments spent $50,000 on the effort to coax him out to sea. Biologists recognize Humphrey through tail markings with a unique pattern, like a fingerprint. They've spotted him in the ocean near San Francisco every year since in August or September. Nearly 200 children from five grades in the nearby Bret Harte Elementary School walked out to the edge of the bay Tuesday to watch Humphrey. ``We are studying about whales,'' said Mrs. Swaraj Gujral, a fifth-grade teacher. ``The children are very worried. They wonder how he can survive. They said we should all get together and push him. I think he likes it here. He went away but he left his heart in San Francisco.'' Efforts to move him using boards and a tow rope during the early morning high tide failed. For most of the day, Humphrey's white-striped dorsal hump poked only about three feet above the surface while his head and tail remained under water. ``The fact is the animal didn't help us at all,'' said Denize Springer, spokeswoman for the Marine Mammal Center. ``In 1985 when he was stuck, then he helped us.'' Humphrey beached himself twice Monday - the first time blundering onto mud flats near Candlestick Park, snarling traffic for hours as commuters slowed to gawk. The mammal finally floated off on a rising tide but then worked himself into a real jam when he became stranded again north of the stadium. He was completely out of the water as the tide went out Monday night and again after sunrise. Volunteers from the Marine Mammal Center then worked to keep him from becoming dehydrated. Another fear, Springer said, was that the whale's weight would crush vital organs. ``He's literally lying on his lungs,'' she said. Springer said a blood test taken Monday and completed early this morning showed nothing abnormal about Humphrey's condition ``other than he has been under stress and hadn't eaten.'' Although humpback whales aren't known to attack humans, the volunteers trying to help the stranded mammal face the danger of being hit by the whale's strong fluke, or tail, which could cause serious injury or death. Those keeping watch included Sharnel Jackson, 14, who recalled the whale's first visit. ``We had a big banner in class with Humphrey's name on it,'' she said as she lifted the collar of her jacket to ward off the cold. ``I know Humphrey. I want to see him get free.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Shoot to Death First Cousin of Drug Cartel Leader
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday shot to death the first cousin of cocaine baron Pablo Escobar. A police report said the cousin was Luis Gaviria, also a drug trafficker. He was the second close relative of Escobar's to be fatally shot by police in three months. Authorities did not reveal Gaviria's role with the cartel. Police said Gaviria died in an armed confrontation with security forces in a suburb of Medellin, Colombia's second largest city and home base to the cartel. In August, police killed Gustavo de Jesus Gaviria, another Escobar cousin. That cousin reportedly had taken over the cartel's daily operations since Escobar was forced into hiding because of a government crackdown. Officials blame the Medellin gang for killing about 550 Colombians in attacks since August 1989, when the government and drug traffickers declared war on each other. Meanwhile, the cartel's second in command said in a letter published Tuesday that he is willing to help gain the release of seven journalists recently kidnapped by drug traffickers if the government grants him the right to move about the country. In the last two months, officials say the Medellin cartel has abducted seven journalists, including Diana Turbay, the daughter of a former president, and Francisco Santos, news editor of Colombia's leading newspaper, El Tiempo. Also kidnapped is Marina Montoya, sister of Colombia's ambassador to Canada, German Montoya. Montoya's son was kidnapped by the cartel earlier this year but was freed after church leaders appealed for his release. Jorge Luis Ochoa's letter was a response to an appeal by Ramiro Andrade, former Colombian ambassador to Spain. Andrade, who helped Ochoa avoid extradition from Spain to the United States in 1986, asked Ochoa to mediate in the kidnapping crisis. Observers say the cartel abducted the journalists to pressure the government to grant drug traffickers a pardon.

DOC.HEAD: UNESCO `Silk Road' Expedition Sets Sail from Venice
DOC.TEXT: An international expedition set sail Tuesday to commemorate the travels of the 13th century explorer Marco Polo. Seventy scholars were aboard the private yacht of the Sultan of Oman as it left Venice's Grand Canal on a voyage retracing the maritime route from Venice to Osaka, Japan. The 51-day expedition will stop at 29 ports in 17 countries. The project is sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) and is part of a 10-year study entitled ``Study of the Silk Roads: Roads of Dialogue.'' During a ceremony at the Ducal Palace, the Director General of UNESCO, Federico Mayor, said the project was of ``both scientific and cultural significance with the international goal of increased dialogue among different cultures and civilizations.''

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact Meeting Postponed
DOC.TEXT: A Warsaw Pact summit scheduled for November to plan the future of the disintegrating Soviet-led military alliance has been postponed, according to reports Tuesday. A Hungarian diplomat said the three-day meeting, scheduled to begin Nov. 3 ``will likely be held later this year,'' but that no firm date had been set. Hungarian radio also reported the meeting would be held later. In Moscow, the Foreign Ministry said it had no information on a postponement. The Hungarian diplomat suggested the meeting had been moved back to await the results of a Nov. 19 summit in Paris of heads of state of the 34 nations participating in the European security process. At that summit, a key East-West arms reduction agreement on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe is to be signed by the leaders of the 16 NATO and six Warsaw Pact nations. Negotiators in Vienna from the 22 nations participating in the conventional arms talks are under pressure to finalize the agreement before the Paris summit. Washington has repeatedly said President Bush would not go to Paris if the treaty were not ready. A main barrier in Vienna is disagreeent on how many tanks and other weapons each East European pact member may maintain within overall East-West ceiling already agreed on. Pact experts are to hold a fourth meeting in Prague, Czechoslovakia, this weekend to try and solve the deadlock.

DOC.HEAD: Government Presents New Electoral Bill to Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The government presented a Parliament reform bill Tuesday that makes it easier for parties to achieve a majority of seats but presents obstacles for small political groups. Under the proposal, parties must secure at least 3 percent of the vote in national elections to be represented in 300-member single-chamber Parliament. Advocates say the minimum requirement would force small groups to unite under one banner. The plan would also reduce the requirement to form a government to 43 percent of the vote. Presently, a party needs at least 47 percent for a majority. The proposal, presented to Parliament on Tuesday, is expected to be hotly debated before it comes up for a vote Nov. 8. The present proportional representation law was adopted prior to the June 1989 general elections by the then-ruling Panhellenic Socialist Movement. Greeks have gone to the polls three times the past 16 months for national elections after parties failed to achieve the 47 percent majority. In April, the conservative New Democracy party won 46.88 percent of the vote, but it gained a one-seat majority after it was joined by a deputy from a small conservative party.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Gunmen Ambush Taxi Driver in Belfast
DOC.TEXT: IRA gunmen ambushed a taxi driver Tuesday outside a hospital in Belfast, fatally shooting him before escaping into the traffic of a busy road, police said. The victim, William Aiken, 33, of Templepatrick, had just dropped off a passenger at the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children. He underwent emergency surgery for head wounds suffered when he was shot at point-blank range but died a short time later, according to a hospital spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. Witnesses gave police descriptions of the gunmen, who fled from the hospital grounds to an adjacent road. The shooting took place in a fiercely republican area of Belfast. The victim worked for a taxi company based in the Protestant part of the city, police said. The slaying was claimed by the mainly Catholic Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to end British rule in the mainly Protestant province and unite it with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic. The taxi driver was the fifth person to die the past eight days as a result of sectarian strife in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Becomes Longest Living Kidney Transplant Survivor
DOC.TEXT: Retired store clerk Milburn McKenzie passed an extraordinary anniversary this month. The 65-year-old from Miniota, Manitoba, received a life-saving kidney transplant 25 years ago. According to an international transplant registry at the University of California, that makes McKenzie the longest living single-kidney transplant recipient in the world. ``I think I have been very lucky,'' McKenzie said. ``But I never celebrate (the anniversary) or anything. This year, I think I was helping my son build his deck.'' McKenzie received his transplant at Saskatoon's Royal University Hospital in 1965, when the procedure was still in its infancy. McKenzie was born with a hereditary condition that caused tumors to grow on the kidneys, ultimately destroying them. When he was 21, one kidney was removed. Twenty years later, the other deteriorated and also had to be taken out. He was on dialysis for about six weeks before a donor kidney became available.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Guerrillas Kill TV Journalist in Northern Highlands
DOC.TEXT: Hooded Maoist Shining Path guerrillas shot to death a Peruvian television reporter in a northern Andean city, police said Tuesday. Police said three guerrillas wearing hoods shot and killed Pedro Macedo Figueroa late Monday in the doorway of his home in Huaraz, a city 175 miles north of Lima. Macedo, 53, was a reporter for the Lima television station America Television. He was well-known in the Huaraz region for waging a campaign against the guerrilla movement in local newspapers and on radio, a local journalist said. Violence in the Huaraz region, an area popular with mountain climbers and trekkers, has increased steadily since the Shining Path killed a British tourist in the region in May 1989. More than 20,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980. The majority of the victims were civilians, according to human rights groups.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Hatfield Trailing in Oregon
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield trails Democratic challenger Harry Lonsdale in the latest poll on Oregon's U.S. Senate race. Fifty percent of those surveyed said they favored Lonsdale and 44 percent backed Hatfield, according to the poll for KATU-TV in Portland. Six percent were undecided. The poll surveyed 608 registered voters statewide Oct. 17 through Sunday and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Hatfield, whose environmental record has been repeatedly attacked, said he's ``depending on the common sense of the people.'' ``I think they'll find as they become acquainted with the Lonsdale record that he is neither a friend of the working people nor of the environment.'' Dan Walters, a spokesman for Lonsdale, said the poll shows that ``Hatfield's negative campaign tactics have backfired.'' Hatfield recently accused Lonsdale's company, Bend Research, of dumping toxic chemicals into the ground at the plant site near Bend. Lonsdale says the company has handled all chemicals properly and the state has found no problems at the plant.
DOC.HEAD: No Live Televising Of Florida Governor's Debate On One Station
DOC.TEXT: Miami's CBS affiliate reversed itself Tuesday and agreed to show the only scheduled gubernatorial debate live, but a station in the capital refused despite a plea from Democrat Lawton Chiles. Polls have shown the contest a dead heat, giving added importance to the candidates' face-to-face confrontation. WCIX-TV in Miami had initially said it was sticking with Dan Rather's CBS Evening News at 7 p.m. on Oct. 30, while WCTV-TV in Tallahassee opted for ``Wheel of Fortune'' and ``Jeopardy'' instead of the debate between Chiles and Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. Both stations planned to show the hour-long debate on tape-delay: Miami at 11:30 p.m., Tallahassee at midnight. The Miami station initially indicated it had too many contractual obligations to create time for the debate, but Tuesday afternoon announced it would show Chiles-Martinez after all. ``It is clear from viewer feedback we're getting today that there is a heightened interest in seeing the debate live,'' said Jerry Birdwell, director of broadcast operations at WCIX. ``We will air the debate.'' The CBS Evening News will simply be shifted to 6:30 p.m. on Oct. 30, he said. But the Tallahassee station was sticking by its decision to delay the debate and air the game shows instead, prompting an angry complaint from Chiles in a telephone call to WCTV General Manager Jim Caruthers. Chiles, in a tight race and with less money than Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, has been pressing for more debates. The Martinez campaign says one is enough.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Must Vote For Husband, Boss Or Cousin On Election Day
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Rinehart knows about being caught in the middle. Her husband is running for Bibb County sheriff - against her boss. And the third candidate in the race is her first cousin. ``That's not unusual; that's just Bibb County,'' said Jack Farmer, a state Alcoholic Beverage Control Board enforcement agent who frequently works in Bibb County. The sheriff's candidates are incumbent Sheriff James Fondren, Brent Police Chief R.W. ``Bob'' Rinehart and painting contractor Wayne Hobson. Fondren is a Republican, Rinehart is a Democrat, and Hobson is an independent. Mrs. Rinehart, who is the sheriff's department secretary, said the situation gets ``touchy at times.'' ``There's friction sometimes, but there's friction sometimes on all jobs,'' she said. ``We have a very cordial relationship.'' Her husband was a police officer in Brent while Fondren was police chief.
DOC.HEAD: Group issues Voter `Self-Defense' Manual
DOC.TEXT: A free telephone information service and a voters' self-defense manual are two ways a non-partisan group is trying to counter what it calls ``the issueless mudslinging'' of modern political campaigns. Richard Kimball, board president of the Center for National Independence in Politics, said members of Congress are ``the hired help of our democracy'' and voters need factual information in order to hire wisely. He said the center has come up with a few ways for voters ``to break through the hype and glitz'' and get facts unvarnished by campaigns or interest groups: -The Voter's Self-Defense Manual, ``practical suggestions and unfiltered information'' about candidates in each state. It is available in all 50 states by calling 1-900-820-CNIP (2647). The call costs $3. The money covers the , a manual for the caller and another one for a library or school in the state. -A National Political Awareness Test involving written and telephone interviews with Senacost of the callte and House candidates. Available in 19 states and scheduled to expand nationwide by 1992, the test allows voters to compare their positions with those of the candidates. -``1-800 Voter Information Service'' telephone lines, operating this year in North Carolina and Nebraska. Kimball said thousands of calls have come in and the service will be available to voters in all 50 states by 1992. The toll-free lines provide information about the lives, campaign contrthin three hours after a terrorist incident.
