DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously identified the director of the Naval Investigative Service as Rear Adm. Thomas Brooks in an Oct. 22 story on the conduct of NIS agents investigating sex crimes. It was Rear Adm. William L. Schachte Jr. who, as commander of the investigative service, said in an August letter that his office would try to arrange additional sensitivity training for the agents. Brooks is head of Naval Intelligence.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Slaps Duties on Goods from Two Other Yugoslav Republics
DOC.TEXT: Communist-ruled Serbia, largest of the nation's six republics, all but abolished Yugoslavia's internal common market Tuesday by imposing duties on goods from reform-minded Slovenia and Croatia. Measures approved by Serbia's Parliament undermined the liberal economic reforms of federal Prime Minister Ante Markovic and appeared to push the troubled Balkan nation one step closer to political disintegration. Prime Minister Stanko Radmilovic said his 15-point economic program would protect Serbia's economy from ``disloyal domestic and foreign competition'' and from Markovic's ``destructive policies.'' It imposes duties on Serbia's foreign imports and on goods from the western republics of Slovenia and Croatia, where center-right governments replaced Communists after free elections this year. Radmilovic said Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's most developed regions, could no longer ``count on free access to the Serbian market.'' Goods from the two republics are more expensive but generally of higher quality than Serbian-made goods. Deputies passed seven points of the program Tuesday, including the one imposing import tariffs. The other points will be voted on later. No details were available on the size of the duties. Croatia and Slovenia seek greater independence by transforming Yugoslavia into a loose confederation and applying for European Community membership. They would keep the common Yugoslav market, however, where most of their products are sold. Serbia remains Communist, with elections set for December. Its government wants power to remain in Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital. Under Radmilovic's program, Serbia no longer will sell raw materials and electricity at subsidized prices to Slovenia and Croatia. Serbia also would ban or impose heavy taxes on many foreign goods, to protect its own producers. Serbia has refused to eliminate some key price controls and close down money-losing enterprises. Serbian Parliament spokesman Ivan Cumic said Tuesday's vote was ``virtually unanimous,'' but refused to give specifics. Markovic, a Croatian technocrat, has opened Yugoslavia's borders to cheap foreign goods, hoping to force home firms to lower their prices and raise productivity to compete. Radmilovic slammed Markovic's privatization plans and tight-money policies, saying they harmed Serbia's economy. He acknowledged some of his program conflicted with federal laws, but said that was justified, to keep Serbia on par with Slovenia and Croatia. Markovic, prime minister since March 1988, introduced reforms last December that have throttled runaway inflation and pulled Yugoslavia from the brink of bankruptcy. The reforms won praise from Western creditors, but side-effects include a sharp drop in industrial production and closure of many unprofitable firms. That threatens to push up unemployment, already a hefty 19 percent. Initial optimism that Markovic's popularity could overcome the growing political crisis evaporated in the face of continued feuding between politicians and ethnic groups.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Portray Calculating Killer in Rampage that Killed 7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores prosecutor's first name in 5th graf, `Bumerts disputed ...' Picks up 7th graf ``Here is ...'; ADDS one graf with defense arguing for lesser charge.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors Tuesday portrayed Ramon Salcido as a calculating killer who stepped over the bodies of his mother-in-law and her daughters to find a bandage for a finger he cut during a wine country rampage that left seven dead. In closing arguments, defense attorney Marteen Miller conceded that Salcido killed the seven, including his wife and two children, but claimed Salcido was crazed and incapable of planning the murders. If convicted of first-degree murder, Salcido faces the death penalty. The jury was scheduled to begin deliberations Wednesday. The trial began Sept. 14. Salcido, 29, is being tried in San Mateo Superior Court for the April 14, 1989, murder of his wife, Angela, two of his daughters, his mother-in-law and her two daughters and a co-worker at the Grand Cru winery. He also faces three counts of attempted murder for attacks on a third daughter, another co-worker and the co-worker's wife. Prosecutor Peter Bumerts disputed the defense contention that anger and drugs sparked the rage and that Salcido was suicidal. ``Here is a man who wants to kill himself, stepping over dead bodies to get to a bandage to bandage his finger... which he cut while killing people,'' Bumerts said. Investigators say a trail of blood from Salcido's cut finger indicated he stepped over the bodies of his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, and her daughters, Ruth, 12, and Marie, 8, after fatally slashing them. Blood was found on a box of bandages in the Richards house and Salcido was wearing a bandage on his finger when he was arrested in his native Mexico four days after the slayings in Sonoma County, the prosecution said. The trial was moved here because of extensive pre-trial media coverage. Bumerts maintained Salcido was lucid when he earlier killed his wife and slashed the throats of his daughters at a dump, and said he then pondered killing more of his family. ``Before he even leaves the dump, he's thinking about his next victims,'' Bumerts said. He produced a photo of the dump, saying, ``That is hell. That is not heaven.'' The prosecution said that while being returned to California, Salcido said in a taped statement that he was angry with his wife because she had married him while pregnant with another man's child. He said he was angry at his mother-in-law for not telling him about the child's parentage and angry at his supervisor because he thought the man tried to have him fired. Miller said Salcido showed up at the Richards home with no intention of killing the woman and her two girls. ``He went there with no idea in the world to do anything to those children,'' Miller said. Miller suggested that someone can be psychotic and kill in an organized fashion. ``Someone can be crazy as a toad, negotiate their way into a courtroom... wait for the judge and kill him,'' Miller said. He said Salcido was an atypical Mexican immigrant who did not socialize much with other Mexicans, was ``at odds with himself'' and was overwhelmed by financial and legal problems. Jurors, he said, should put aside their fears of being called ``baby killers at cocktail parties'' and ignore what he described as people whispering ``you should've sent him to the gas chamber.'' Miller asked jurors to convict Salcido of less than first-degree murder. Second-degree murder carries a basic penalty of 15 years to life, while terms for manslaughter can range from two to 11 years.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Leader Says Prague Spring Paid Off in the End
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak leader Alexander Dubcek said his appearance Tuesday before the Swedish parliament proved the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' revolt succeeded in the end. Although he was isolated and harassed for the next 21 years, Dubcek said he believed Czechs were right to use passive resistance against the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact tanks in 1968. ``They told us we'd lost, but we didn't lose. The proof is that I now stand here,'' said Dubcek, now the country's assembly leader. ``We decided then not to use weapons. If we had resisted, maybe the peace in all Europe would have been threatened.'' Dubcek is one of only a handful of foreigners to address the Riksdag, Sweden's parliament. The chamber was not full, but Dubcek received two standing ovations from those who attended. After the speech, he flew to Norway, where he was to meet Wednesday with the king and government leaders. In the speech and at a news conference, Dubcek said he favors a strong federation in Czechoslovakia and believes the country's ethnic problems can be resolved through democratic principles. ``It will be hard work,'' he said. He also said the only way for Czechoslovakia to proceed with development and economic reform was through a market system that includes privatizing most of the state sector, and open the economy to foreign investment and joint ventures.

DOC.HEAD: President Raises Funds, Congressman Raises Differences
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf to update with appearances on behalf of Franks, Rowland after 14th graf, On a
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A president who shows up at a fund-raiser for a freshman congressman usually hears his praises sung in accolades that would do justice to a canonization. But when Rep. Peter Smith brought on President Bush Tuesday as the guest of honor after the $125-a-plate apple pancakes, the lawmaker took pains to emphasize his ``specific disagreements'' with Bush on civil rights and deficit reduction. It may have been the most halfhearted introduction Bush has heard in 21 months as president, and it dramatized the discomfort many Republicans feel with the tax-raising, deficit-lowering deal Bush hopes to nail down with the leaders of Congress. Something unusual also happened at Bush's next campaign stop in Manchester, N.H., for another GOP congressman named Smith - Bo Smith - who is running for the Senate. Bob Smith skipped his own fund-raising event, sending his wife Mary Jo instead to introduce the president. She said her husband stayed in Washington because of key votes pending in the House. Back in Washington, an aide said Smith prides himself on his near-perfect attendance record and wanted to be on hand to support the president in any attempt to override his controversial veto of the civil rights bill. The aide asked not to be identified. Peter Smith is a former college president trying to hang onto his seat against a tough challenge from independent Bernard Sanders, the iconoclastic, socialist ex-mayor of Burlington. ``He is a man of independent mind. I wish he'd stop reminding me that we do have a few differences out there,'' remarked Bush. ``But, hey, listen: nobody is going to do it exactly my way. ... There are 435 of these people in the United States Congress.'' Smith, unlike most Republicans, voted for the original, controversial budget deal that Bush and the leaders struck last month, then turned around and voted with the House Democrats on an alternative raising taxes steeply on the rich. Sanders has skewered him for both. ``My specific disagreements with this administration are a matter of record - most recently on the civil rights bill, but (also) some of the elements of our deficit reduction,'' said Smith. ``Let me just tell you, Mr. President, I think the people of Vermont are ready and willing to support higher taxes on the wealthy as an important part of any package to get this country out of deficit,'' said Smith. Smith said Bush ``had run on and won on'' a pledge not to raise taxes, but agreed to do it ``because he understood that the good of this country had to come first.'' Bush has seen his own personal popularity rating plummet amid his turnaround on taxes and the budget stalemate of the past month. With two weeks until election day, Republicans are worried that Bush's problems could jeopardize their chances. On a rainy, dismal day, Bush also was campaigning in Waterbury, Conn., for Gary Franks, a black Republican congressional candidate, and in Stamford, Conn., for the party's gubernatorial candidate, Rep. John Rowland. The fund-raiser for Franks was closed. At a $500 a plate dinner for Rowland, Bush drew applause when he noted the Republican's promise not to impose a state income tax on Connecticut residents. Although the president seemed put out by the lukewarm introduction in Burlington, he praised Peter Smith as a congressman who ``votes his conscience'' and ``puts the good of the country first.'' ``When he voted for the early compromise it wasn't an easy vote,'' said Bush. ``He knew he was going to get sniped at from people way on the right or way on the left. ... I, perhaps in a different perspective, had to do exactly the same thing.'' ``We're hanging tough for a good agreement,'' Bush assured the crowd of 700 Vermont Republicans, some of whom paid up to $500 to have their pictures taken with the president. The event was expected to net $40,000 to $50,000 for Smith's campaign. ``The days of tax and spend and damn the deficit must come to an end,'' declared Bush. He also made a spirited defense of his stand in the Persian Gulf against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Seventy-five anti-war demonstrators stood in the rain outside the conference hall in Burlington to decry Bush's policies with banners reading ``Talks Not Troops'' and ``No War for Natural Resources.'' ``I saw some signs coming in here today: `no war for oil.' I can understand the sentiment by some of those young people,'' he said. But he said the United Staes and its allies were standing up for morality against Saddam Hussein, whom he likened to Hitler. ``The holding of hostages, innocent men and women .... goes against the conscience of the entire world,'' said Bush. ``The starving of embassies - good God! This is 1990. ... These are crimes against humanity. There can never be compromise, any compromise, with this kind of aggression. ``It isn't oil that we are concerned about, it is aggression and this aggression is not going to stand,'' declared Bush. It was Peter Smith who led the crowd then in giving Bush a standing ovation.
