DOC.HEAD: EN HOUSE FARM BILL ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Third Party Ballot Challenge Makes For Election Confusion
DOC.TEXT: Preparations for local elections were at a standstill Tuesday after the U.S. Supreme Court intervened in a third-party ballot dispute in the hotly contested gubernatorial contest. At issue was whether the all-black slate of county candidates from the Harold Washington Party, named for the city's first black mayor, should be included on the ballot. Washington died in 1987. Justice John Paul Stevens on Monday halted further printing and distribution of ballots in Cook County, saying the full Supreme Court should hear the dispute. Most of the ballots already have been printed, without the Washington Party candidates. The Supreme Court was expected to consider Stevens' action Friday and possibly hear the Washington Party's challenge to an Illinois Supreme Court ruling keeping its candidates off the ballot. The Illinois Supreme Court ruled Oct. 12 that Washington Party candidates weren't entitled to appear on the ballot because they didn't have enough nominating petitions. The legal challenge was filed by five petitioners, who Washington Party officials contend acted for the county Democratic Party. It was not immediately clear if county or state elections would be postponed if the high court rules in the Washington Party's favor. City and county election officials said it would be nearly impossible to retool election ballots and computers to include the third party's slate of 19 county candidates within two weeks. Cook County Republican Party Chairman Richard Seibel, said ``the urgency of the election is in question. (Voters) don't know if it's going to be November 6 or December 6 at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: Soviet Immigrants Have Buried Jews' Demographic Fears
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Tuesday the influx of Soviet Jews means Israel no longer needs to fear being submerged by a growing Arab population. In a speech to Latin American immigrants, Shamir said the debate in the Jewish state over the demographic issue, ``which was very widespread and disturbed many people,'' had vanished in recent months. ``Many among us took masochistic pleasure in playing with the comparative numbers of Jews and Arabs, and searched the statistics for the date on which the number of Arabs would equal and perhaps exceed the number of Jews,'' he said. ``And wonder of wonders: lately this sport is disappearing. No one will miss it.'' ``In a few years we will not recognize the land of Israel. Everything will have changed - society, the economy, the culture,'' he said. ``Our people will grow, it will fill our little country with Jews, and thus the country will be bigger in content, human strength, potential.'' Speaking from a prepared text, Shamir was careful not to suggest his government might violate its undertakings to friendly governments and send the Soviet Jews to live in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. But Shamir boasted the Soviet influx had handed his nationalist doctrine a victory over those who have argued that both for the sake of peace and for demographic reasons, Israel should give up the occupied territories with their 1.7 million Arab inhabitants. ``I remember the days, not long ago, when arguments such as these were heard in public debate: `If I knew that the gates of Russia would open and hundreds of thousands of Jews would come out, I would think differently about the problem of the borders of the land of Israel','' he said. ``And now the gates have opened and the immigration flows and those voices and those arguments are no longer heard.'' Israeli officials say they expect 1 million Soviet Jews to come here by 1992. The country's population is 4.7 million, of whom 3.9 million are Jewish and 800,000 are Arab. Shamir added that the Soviet exodus used to be ``the most talked about issue in the Arab political world.'' Today, he said, ``You hardly hear any of them talk about it. They have realized that they cannot persuade their great ally, the Soviet Union, to shut the gates. Russia won't shut the gates, and they (the Arabs) have accepted... that that is the way the world goes.'' Shamir said the Soviet Union was no longer the Arabs' major military backer. ``We are grateful to the nations of the Soviet Union and their leaders for this turning point,'' he said. ``We won't forget it.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out at Main Omaha Post Office
DOC.TEXT: A propane tank exploded on the roof of the main post office building south of downtown Tuesday, sparking a blaze that prompted the evacuation of about 300 people, fire officials said. No injuries were reported fire that began when the tank exploded and tar being applied for a new roof burst into flames, said the fire officials. The cause was under investigation. Some of the estimated 300 people who were inside the three-story brick building when the blaze broke out were allowed back in later, said post office spokesman Dave Failor. No delay or interruption in the mail delivery was expected, he said. About 60 firefighters brought the blaze under control within a half hour, said Assistant Fire Chief Denver Schmadeke. The fire was confined to the roof.

DOC.HEAD: Patient Dies After Blood Type Mix-Up
DOC.TEXT: A hospital has appointed a committee to investigate the death of a heart-transplant patient whose blood type was listed incorrectly in a transplant matching computer. ``We aren't pointing a finger at anyone,'' Dr. Robert Emery, director of heart transplantation for Abbot Northwestern Hospital and the Minneapolis Heart Institute, said Monday. The 47-year-old patient, who had type O blood, received a heart from a type A donor because his blood type was erroneously listed as type A. He died when his body rejected the heart. The survival rate is more than 60 percent when hearts from type A donors are transplanted into type O patients. That survival rate jumps almost to 100 percent when hearts from type O donors are transplanted into type O patients, Emery said. The patient, whose name was withheld, suffered from cardiomyopathy - deterioration of the heart muscle - and from lung and kidney problems. The blood-type mix-up was discovered shortly after the transplant. Doctors controlled the mismatch with anti-rejection drugs for about seven days before the patient's body rejected the heart, Emery said. Abbott Northwestern officials rechecked the blood type classifications for all patients on its transplant waiting list and no other errors were found, Emery said.

DOC.HEAD: BP Oil Fined $2.3 Million For Polluting Delaware River
DOC.TEXT: BP Oil Corp. agreed Tuesday to pay $2.3 million for dumping waste from its Marcus Hook refinery into the Delaware River, federal authorities said. The fine, part of a legal settlement, was the second largest the government has ever assessed for water pollution, federal officials said. U.S. Steel was fined $2.9 million in 1977 for pollution from its plant in Gary, Ind. ``I think you'll see a trend toward increases in the size of fines for water pollution'' predicted Cynthia Giles, an assistant regional counsel for the Environmental Protection Agency. The government sued BP Oil under the Clean Water Act in 1986, prompting the company to replace its wastewater treatment plant with a new $25 million plant, which began operating last year. BP Oil's old plant was discharging excess oil and grease, ammonia, solids, sulfides and various chemicals that reduced the amount of oxygen in the water, changed its acidity and sickened and killed fish, authorities said. The company violated its wastewater discharge permit 6,500 times from 1979 until the present, said the EPA. All the charges concerned the old plant. Discharges from the BP Oil plant were ``a major contributor to the pollution problem in the river,'' the EPA said. The refinery is on the river about 2 miles north of the Delaware state border. It produces gasoline, jet fuel, diesel oil and other petroleum products. Joann Elser, BP Oil's human resources manager, said the new plant was operating at 99.6 percent efficiency. ``We've been here a long time, we're firmly entrenched in the community,'' she said. ``We're concerned about the quality of water going into the river.'' The settlement includes the $109,000 BP oil already has paid the state of Pennsylvania to settle a separate suit by the Department of Environmental Resources.

DOC.HEAD: Admiral Defends Base Actions on Sex Crimes
DOC.TEXT: Young women are as safe from sexual assault at the nation's only training center for female Navy recruits as they are anywhere in society, the base commander said Tuesday. ``We have nothing to hide,'' Rear Admiral Louise C. Wilmot said at a news conference. She was responding to news reports about 24 allegations of rape, sexual assault and fraternization at the Naval Training Center in Orlando over the past 18 months. The sex crimes and fraternization problems at the base had been previously reported, but Navy officials in Washington recently made copies of internal investigative records available to reporters. The Navy's inspector general suggested that Navy investigators of sex crimes are inadequately trained. He indicated that more female investigators should be assigned to the Orlando training center. The report said base officials had failed to seek appropriate punishment for offenders. ``We just reject that out of hand ...,'' Wilmot said. ``There is a lot of misinformation out about that (inspector general's) report. We helped write that report.'' Six rape cases never went to trial because of insufficient evidence, Wilmot told reporters, but 13 cases of fraternization and five of sexual assault were prosecuted and the offenders punished. The six reported rape cases aren't a large percentage in a command where 15,000 women were trained during that time, the admiral sad. ``We can assure young women and their parents that they have nothing to fear'' at this base, she said. Three of the alleged rapes were reported on the base and three outside, she said, ``and none involved instructors or officers.'' Each case was investigated but none was prosecuted, for lack of sufficient evidence. The admiral said that in some cases there were problems with the credibility of the witnesses, in others excessive alcohol was involved, and ``we have had cases where people have made false accusations of rape.'' She personally reviewed all the decisions against bringing cases to trial, and they were then reviewed by higher authorities in Washington, ``and no one disagrees with us,'' the admiral said. In the wake of the report, the base is creating a centralized computer list of all such allegations and crimes, expanding a rape-awareness course for recruits, conducting seminars and strengthening other counseling and assistance programs for women, she said. The training center has seven major commands, each headed by a captain. ``If anything, they're very protective about the female members of their command,'' the admiral said. ``I stand for equal treatment for men and women.'' The Navy has strict fraternization rules, and the base prohibits any social contact between training-company commanders, who are usually noncommissioned officers, and female students. This applies even when the recruits finish training and are transferred. Violators are subject to non-judicial punishment and are usually fined, removed from their positions and transferred out of Orlando. With some 18,000 Navy and civilian employees, the training center is the Orlando area's second largest employer, next to Walt Disney World. It has an annual payroll of $300 million.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Ready to Reconvene Congress
DOC.TEXT: Democratic congressional leaders said Tuesday they will reserve the right to call lawmakers back into session if needed for any emergency in the Persian Gulf. The leaders also are establishing a smaller group that will be available to consult with President Bush on the Middle East as a way of maintaining the role Congress claims in the exercise of war powers. A joint statement by House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, noted that ``presidential consultation with Congress is required by law under certain circumstances. ``We believe that regular consultation is necessary and useful, particularly given recent developments in the Persian Gulf.'' Normally, once Congress adjourns for the year it can be recalled only by the president. But this year's adjournment resolution - expected later this week - will provide that power to the top Democrat in each chamber as well, in consultation with the House and Senate Republican leaders. The smaller consultative group will include from the House, Foley; Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.; Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee and senior committee Republican William Broomfield of Michigan; Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee and top GOP member William Dickinson of Alabama; and Intelligence Committee Chairman Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., and ranking Republican Henry Hyde of Illinois. From the Senate, the group will include Mitchell; Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan.; Foreign Relations Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and ranking GOP member Jesse Helms of North Carolina; Armed Services Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and John Warner, R-Va., the ranking minority member; and Intelligence Chairman David Boren, D-Okla., and senior GOP member William Cohen of Maine. The Constitution of the United States makes the president commander-in-chief of the armed forces but in Article 1, Section 8 says: ``The Congress shall have power ... to declare war.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III has testified to Congress the administration would try to consult Congress on activity in the Persian Gulf, but he refused to commit the administration to consultation or to a request for a declaration of war.

DOC.HEAD: Company Says it Doesn't Kill Cats, Disputes ABC Report
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Alamance district attorney are investigating animal cruelty allegations involving a biological supply firm, officials said Tuesday. ABC News reported Monday that Carolina Biological Supply Co. has been killing nearly 200 cats a week with poison gas to be sold for science education or research. The report said customers were told that all of the cats had been killed at animal shelters. The investigations were prompted by complaints by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and began prior to the ABC report, officials said. Cats have been killed at the company's gas chamber, but not by Carolina Biological, company spokesman Ron Field said Tuesday. Licensed animal dealers were allowed to use Carolina Biological's chamber to kill animals in the past, but Field said that practice was recently halted. ``For a number of years the company has openly permitted federally licensed animal collectors to use the company's euthanasia chamber, understanding that the practice was approved by the USDA. Animals were put to sleep by collectors and purchased by the company only after the animals were sacrificed,'' Field said. District Attorney Steve Balog said his investigation should be completed in a week or so. USDA Regional Animal Care Division Supervisor Joe Walker, contacted at his office in Tampa, Fla., told the Burlington Times-News that inspectors on his staff began an investigation of Carolina Biological Supply Co. earlier this year. ``We won't have any comment on the investigation until it is completed,'' Walker said. Carolina Biological is one of the world's largest suppliers of animals for scientific research. ``Just recently the USDA said that if we wish to allow live cats on our property in the future we would have to modify these procedures,'' he added. ``Instead, we decided not to allow dealers to use our facilities any longer and as a consequence now permit only euthanized cats on its property.'' Field said Carolina Biological Supply has never bought live cats. ``The allegations made last night on ABC's World News Tonight against Carolina Biological Supply Co. are unfair distortions of the company's practices in dealing with animal specimens which have been taken out of context to suggest cruel treatment of animals,'' Field said. The ABC report included videotape shot by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals showing live cats being pushed into a gas chamber and an unidentified former employee saying overcrowding in the chambers sometimes meant some cats did not die immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Church Tells General to Stop Roiling Guatemala's Political Waters
DOC.TEXT: A church leader on Tuesday urged former dictator Jose Efrain Rios Montt, banned from running in the presidential race, to retract accusations the government plans to cheat in the Nov. 11 national elections. Otherwise, Archbishop Prospero Penados del Barrio warned at a news conference, this could destabilize Guatemala and lead to a military coup against outgoing President Vinicio Cerezo. Cerezo's government denied Rios Montt's allegations, as did a representative for the military. ``In the name of peace ... I ask that Gen. Efrain Rios desist from his attitude which is polarizing our people and causing confrontation, and this can lead to destabilization and a coup,'' Penados said. Rios Montt has been resisting a constitutional provision barring him as a candidate because he became president through a military coup 7{ years ago. Speaking at a political rally last weekend in Chiquimula, 104 miles east of Guatemala City, Rios Montt accused Cerezo of planning to fix the elections in favor Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the presidential nominee of Cerezo's centrist Christian Democrats. Rios Montt also urged his supporters to fight the ban by writing in his name on ballots ``to show that it is you who want me in power.'' By law, this would automatically invalidate the ballot, and enough invalid ballots could scuttle the elections. ``This could cause confrontations, because his call for resistance is not as passive as it seems,'' Penados said. ``He is being pigheaded. He has run the legal course - from the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court - with negative results for his aspirations.'' A born-again Protestant, Rios Montt claims he was robbed of victory when he ran for president on the Christian Democratic ticket in 1974, with the election fixed to put conservative Gen. Eugenio Kjell Laugerud in power. In March 1983, he headed a junta of three officers that overthrew Laugerud's successor, President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia, an elected army general. But three months later, he forced out the other two generals and stayed on as president. While in power, Rios Montt built up his image as an administrator who was equally tough on common criminals and leftist guerrillas. He had more than a dozen suspected rebel leaders summarily executed by firing squads, ignoring an appeal from Pope John Paul II to spare their lives. Rios Montt was overthrown in 1983 by a military coup led by Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores, who then had an elected convention reform the constitution and called elections, which Cerezo won in 1984. Cerezo completes his five-year term Jan. 14, the first civilian elected president in 17 years, in a country convulsed by a three-decade-old leftist guerrilla insurrection. All the rest have been military men. ``He (Rios Montt) has been dead politically since Aug. 8, 1983, when I relieved him (of power) on the decision of the army high command,'' Mejia Victores told reporters Tuesday. Rios Montt, who broke with the Christian Democrats, has been trying to run at the head of a ticket by a three-party conservative coalition. In public opinion polls, he was leading 12 other candidates on a law-and-order platform that was appealing to Guatemalans tired of a three-year crime wave. Presidential spokesman Carlos Anleu reiterated government promises that the ``elections will be free and clean.'' On Nov. 11, Guatemalans will also vote for a new legislature, municipal authorities representatives to a Central American parliament that will soon be formed by Guatemala, Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador, and Nicaragua. If none of the candidates get a majority of half-plus one of the votes cast for president, the two top contenders will go into a runoff.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Fish Net Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House passed and sent to President Bush a bill that would ban the use of large-scale drift nets in U.S. waters up to 200 miles offshore and their use by American fishing fleets anywhere in the world. On a voice vote, the House dropped its own version of the legislation and agreed to adopt a bill approved earlier this month by the Senate that also would require Bush to seek an international ban on drift-net fishing. The nets, which can extend up to 40 miles around, have been blamed for the deaths of thousands of dolphins, other sea mammals and birds caught in their paths as they are dragged through the water to trap commercial fish. The bill expands the 1976 Magnuson Fishery and Conservation Act to include previously exempted tuna in government controls over commercial and sport fishing within 200 miles of the U.S. coastline. The legislation also requires the government to develop standards that tuna canners would have to adopt in order to label their product ``dolphin safe.'' Some companies, according to lawmakers, have adopted the ``dolphin safe'' label in response to boycotts by environmentalists even though they continue to purchase tuna known to have been caught in nets responsible for dolphin deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Afflicted Long Island Boy Gets Wish; Meets Bush in Connecticut
DOC.TEXT: An 8-year-old New York boy afflicted with brain tumors got his wish Thursday: he finally met President Bush. Jimmy Kilanowski of Lake Ronkonkoma on New York's Long Island was in the front row of the audience with his parents at a Republican fundraiser where Bush was speaking. Bush had invited the family after reading news accounts that Jimmy's hopes of meeting him had been frustrated by a bureacratic snarl at the White House. After Bush's speech for Connecticut GOP gubernatorial candidate John Rowland, Bush hugged the boy, who put his arms around the president's neck and whispered something to him. When the president left, the boy turned to his parents and said, ``He still cares.'' The White House invited the Kilanowski family to come to the event because it was relatively close to their New York home. Jimmy was given a year and a half to live in April 1989 because of the brain tumors. He had expressed his desire to meet Bush through a local organization which grants wishes to terminally ill children. However, the White House initially denied the request, apparently on the grounds that the request had not been made through the proper channels. Bush himself decided to see the boy after reading a news account in the New York Post suggesting that he was too busy to see the ill child, said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Guccione, Penthouse to Pay Former Model $4 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 10th graf, `Guccione testified ...' to UPDATE with comments from Guccione. Picks up 11th graf, `The judge ...' Contents may be objectionable to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday ordered Penthouse magazine and its publisher Robert Guccione to pay $4.06 million to a former Pet of the Year who charged that he used her as a virtual sex slave. State Judge Elliott Wilk ruled that Guccione made sexual demands on Marjorie Thoreson as a condition of employment at Penthouse, where she worked from 1973 to 1980. ``Sexual slavery was not part of her job description,'' Wilk said. Guccione's ``cold and calculating ... use of sexual coercion forced her to safeguard her employment by sacrificing her body,'' which is a violation of state law, Wilk said. Thoreson, now 37, sued Guccione for $10 million, alleging breach of contract, sexual harassment and fraud. She testified during the March 1989 trial that Guccione forced her to perform hard-core sex acts in a pornographic movie and used her sexual favors as partial payment to furnish a hotel-casino he owned in Atlantic City. She said Guccione also ordered her to carry on a sex affair with his financial adviser so he would move from England to the United States. She said she severed the relationship because it appeared the adviser was going to leave his wife and four children. Her attorney, Murray Schwartz, said the ruling is ``for all the women like her who may have suffered at the hands of Guccione. He has finally been held accountable.'' Penthouse lawyer Jeffrey Daichman labeled Thoreson a liar and said an appeal was expected. The ruling ``read more like a political manifesto about the women's movement than an objective analysis of the evidence,'' he said. Guccione said in a statement that Penthouse presented evidence to the judge showing that Thoreson ``was a former prostitute, drug-abuser and three-time felon who had violated her probation.'' He said Thoresen allegedly began an affair with the financial adviser ``at a time when she was not even employed by Penthouse.'' At the trial, Guccione testified that Thoreson was a potential Marilyn Monroe whom he had rescued from a life of crime. The judge, who heard the case with no jury, said Guccione's only evidence to contradict Thoreson was his word, and added, ``I do not believe him.'' Wilk awarded Thoreson $4 million in punitive damages and $60,000 in compensatory damages. The amounts were based on Guccione's $150 million personal worth and Penthouse's market value of about $200 million, he said. Thoreson, a native of St. Paul, Minn., was working as a topless dancer and a cocktail waitress in California in 1973 when she sent Guccione nude photos and asked if he could help her become an actress. Guccione began by signing her to a personal management contract and changing her name to Anika di Lorenzo. He made her Penthouse Pet of the Year in 1975 and invited her to move into his New York townhouse, which she did. In 1976, Guccione cast her in his sexually explicit movie ``Caligula,'' which Thoreson now says was a pornographic film that ruined her career. For her role, Guccione paid for surgery to have her breasts enlarged. Guccione testified during the trial that he cast her in Caligula because she was sexually ``and perfect for the part.'' ``I thought it was a leg-up on prostitution in Las Vegas, stealing cars, writing bum checks, and building up a life of crime,'' he said, referring to her checkered past. Thoreson sued Guccione after he fired her in 1980 because she refused to accompany him on a trip to the Far East. She said she feared he would pass her around to the businessmen he was meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Yeshiva Task Force Formed After Flier Threat
DOC.TEXT: Fliers threatening the lives of Jewish children here in retaliation for the slayings of Palestinians have been turned up in Brooklyn and police are trying to calm worried parents. Investigators are unsure if the threat is in earnest, and of how many of the fliers actually were distributed. ``In light of what's been happening in Jerusalem, we have to take this seriously,'' said Deputy Police Chief Kenneth Gussman, a ranking police commander in the borough of Brooklyn. A 25-officer task force will focus on six precincts with sizeable Jewish populations in Brooklyn, Gussman said, and ``visit every yeshiva (Jewish school), ask them if they have received a copy of the flier, alert them to the fact the flier had been found and assure them of increased police attention to ally their fears.'' The investigators also are seeking the writer of the flier, which is signed, ``Moslem from New York'' and bears a photo of a wounded Palestinian shot by Israeli troops in Jerusalem on Temple Mount earlier this month. Nineteen Palestinians were killed in a melee that Jews said began when Palestinians threw stones on them. The flier says the writer will kill Jewish children, beginning Monday. ``I think it's a prank,'' said Rabbi Bernard Freilich, director of the Council of Jewish Organizations of Boro Park. ``This does not look professional, but there's a lot of concern due to what's going on in the Middle East.'' The flier was found on a sidewalk on Oct. 17 by a woman who gave it to a rabbi, Frelich said. Copies of the flier reportedly appeared in different sections of Brooklyn, but police and Frelich said it was not clear whether the copies were being circulated by alarmed members of the Jewish community or by others. Sixty Jewish religious leaders and school administrators met with police officials on Monday to discuss the situation.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Frees 14 Americans, To Free Nearly 1,000 French, Bulgarians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with like French, Bulgarian release, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM1,3,5
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein allowed a trickle of foreigners - including 14 Americans - to leave Iraq on Tuesday, and Iraqi authorities said all 930 French and Bulgarians held in Iraq and occupied Kuwait will likely soon be released. Many have been held as part of the ``human shield'' strategy employed by Saddam to protect against attack from multinational forces massed in the Persian Gulf since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. More than 1,000 Americans and thousands of other foreigners still are denied permission to leave Iraq or occupied Kuwait. Said President Bush, ``I'm always pleased when Americans might be released, or if anybody's released. But it just reminds me of the brutality of the policy, the total brutality, holding people against their will and parceling them out as though to look generous. It is brutal and it is unacceptable.'' The 14 Americans who arrived Tuesday night in Amman, Jordan, on a regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad included two employees of the besieged U.S. Embassy in occupied Kuwait and two sons of diplomats stranded there. The 14 were taken to a VIP lounge at Queen Alia airport, then were escorted by embassy officials to an Amman hotel to spend the night before flying Wednesday morning to Frankfurt, Germany, en route to the United States. A U.S. Embassy spokesman at Amman's airport said the group included ``officials who worked with U.S. government offices in Iraq and Kuwait.'' The spokesman, Jonathan Owens, refused to elaborate on their roles. When asked if the officials were diplomats from the embassy in Kuwait, he said: ``No, they're not.'' A member of the American-Iraqi Foundation that assisted in the release told reporters the group included ``two U.S. embassy staffers who worked at the embassy in Kuwait, but were released because they are sick.'' Hussaini Arabo refused to elaborate on their ailment or disclose their names and exact functions at the embassy. Arabo also said Iraq will free all Western hostages in return for international assurances that the country will not be attacked by U.S.-led forces assembled in Saudi Arabia. ``President Saddam will release all hostages in one hour if he gets guarantees from the U.S. or from any other member of the (U.N.) Security Council that there would be no offensive against Iraq,'' Arabo said. Salim Mansour, head of the foundation, said: ``When we met with Saddam, we had the impression he genuinely wanted peace. He wants a peaceful solution to the crisis.'' Mansour gave no date of their meeting with Saddam. Five Finnish men also left Iraq on for home, and 33 ailing or elderly Britons were scheduled to depart with former British Prime Minister Edward Heath. In Stockholm, Sweden, Iraq's charge d'affaires, Mohammed Said Hani, announced Tuesday night Iraq will release five Swedes it holds hostage. He said more would have been freed if Sweden had sent a higher-ranking official than a Foreign Ministry department chief to Baghdad last week to try to secure freedom for the 90 Swedes still there. Also Tuesday, the Iraqi parliament endorsed Saddam's proposal to allow all 330 French citizens to leave Iraq. Saddam's move was seen in Paris as an attempt to divide the West's anti-Iraqi alliance, and the French government called on Iraq to free all foreign hostages. The official Iraqi News Agency said Saddam also wants to free all 600 Bulgarians in Iraq and Kuwait. It said he told Parliament to vote on this issue after a meeting Tuesday with visiting Bulgarian Vice President Atanas Semerdzhiev. In Washington, meanwhile, the Saudi ambassador denied his kingdom wants Kuwait to concede territory to bring about a peaceful settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``You cannot make aggression pay,'' Prince Bandar said. ``If you make aggression pay, that's the law of the jungle.'' He was summoned to the State Department after reports quoting the Saudi defense minister, Prince Sultan, had raised the possibility Iraq might gain territory in return for ending its occupation. Prince Sultan is Prince Bandar's father. Bush, speaking in Waterbury, Conn., said he adamantly opposed any ``territorial compromise'' and said he felt assured that was the position of the Saudi government. ``There is no give on it. If you reward the man with one iota of territory, you've rewarded aggression. And that is not the position of the United States nor of our coalition.'' None of the Americans who left Iraq Tuesday had been part of Saddam's ``human shield'' against attack. ``I'm just thrilled that I'm going,'' William Hollingsworth, 64, said in Baghdad before boarding the Iraqi Airways flight. ``It's a strange coincidence, but I'm leaving the gulf and my son is in Saudi Arabia,'' said Hollingsworth, of Huntsville, Ala. He explained that his son is with the multinational force assembled after Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``I was waiting for this moment. I am extremely happy, but sad at the same time because I am leaving many of my friends and colleagues,'' said 53-year-old Jack Fraser of Santa Ana, Calif. Another American, 44-year-old John Thompson, said he was eager to see his 68-year-old mother in Germany because she is going blind. ``I'm her only child and she wanted to see me badly,'' he said. Also leaving Iraq was Lloyd Graham, 48, who said he was going home to his wife, three daughters and son in Houston. One evacuee identified himself as Gerald Scognn. He said he is the son of an American diplomat holed up at the embassy in Kuwait. ``I don't know if I will see him again,'' Scognn, 21, of Fairfax, Va., said of his father. ``I am very pleased to be free but I am sad to leave behind a lot of very good friends,'' he said. ``I know why I was freed, but I'd better not discuss that,'' Scognn said in response to a question, adding, ``I want to return to Fairfax, Virginia, and see my mum and my girlfriend who are very worried about me.'' Craig Turlay, 21, of Phoenix, said the situation in Iraq was ``pretty monotonous.'' ``We just stayed at the embassy headquarters and carried on as best as we could,'' Turlay said. Turlay was moved several weeks ago to Iraq from Kuwait, where his dad also worked at the embassy. He, too, left his father behind. Neither of the evacuees would identify his father by name or give other details. No other identities of the freed Americans were immediately available. The Americans left Baghdad with a seven-member delegation from the American-Iraqi Foundation. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of the release of the 14 Americans: ``We always hope that there will be more, and the history is that when it suits him (Saddam) he lets people go.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that of the 14 Americans, six are ailing, two have critically ill relatives and six are students. She said 63 Americans with health problems have not been allowed to leave. Prince Bandar, the Saudi envoy, spoke in Washington after meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``Saudi Arabia has not suggested there should be concessions made to anyone,'' Bandar said. His remarks were an apparent attempt to erase any impression that the Saudi defense minister was proposing that Kuwait make a deal with Iraq. Of his father's comments, Bandar said, ``He was not implying Kuwait should do one thing or another. He was talking about what we have done with other countries, negotiating as friends. Saddam did not choose that route.'' In other developments, Saudi King Fahd met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. The monarch later said ``we would be thankful'' if Iraq withdrew from Kuwait. Diplomatic sources said Fahd and Mubarak agreed that Iraq's withdrawal could be followed by negotiations on Iraq's demand for territorial and financial concessions from Kuwait, including the islands of Warba and Bubiyan in the gulf and the Kuwaiti section of the Rumailah oilfield.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Burn Buses, Two Workers Slain in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Militants burned six buses early Wednesday and two workers were slain as unions launched a nationwide general strike to demand a $1.50 raise in the daily minimum wage. One policeman was also wounded during violence that erupted in the early hours of the strike called by the leftist May First Movement. The 150,000-member military went on high alert for the strike. Public transport appeared to be significantly affected by the walkout, and the military said soldiers would be used as drivers to prevent a breakdown in service. President Corazon Aquino had urged workers against joining the strike, saying the nation's fragile economy could not afford the wage increase. Unidentified attackers burned buses in the Manila districts of Santa Mesa and Marikina and in the provinces of Tarlac, Batangas and two in Cavite. In one of the Cavite incidents, the driver and conductor were stabbed to death after five men boarded the bus, ordered passengers to disembark and set the vehicle on fire. Police arrested eight people in Manila's Marikina district after authorities found explosives in their shanty. Many bus and passenger jeepney drivers refused to ply their routes out of fear of attacks. Brig. Gen. Emiliano Templo, a military spokesman, said armed troops were riding in the few buses still operating. Few jeepneys, the main mode of transport, were seen operating during the morning rush hour in Manila. Schools and colleges in Manila and surrounding provinces were closed. In the capital's Kalookan district, strikers burned tires in the streets and fled, firing pistols in the air as police approached. One policeman was wounded, officials said. There were no arrests. Bus service north of Manila was virtually paralyzed as strikers commandeered three buses and barricaded them on a narrow bridge in Tarlac, home province of Mrs. Aquino. In Angeles City, 50 miles north of Manila, the military said Communist rebels threatened to bomb at least 10 gas stations if they opened Wednesday. Angeles is home to the U.S.-run Clark Air Base, one of the largest American military facilities overseas. Additional military checkpoints were set up Wednesday in streets near the sprawling American base. Sen. Ernesto Maceda, chairman of the Senate defense committee, said the bus attacks appeared to have been carried out by Communist rebels who endorsed the strike. The Cabinet security committee met early Wednesday to assess the strike but there was no report on any decisions. On the eve of the strike, suspected Communist rebels bombed the headquarters of Shell Philippines and Caltex oil companies and set fire to a bus near the capital. No casualties were reported in any of the attacks, police said.

DOC.HEAD: `Gonza the Lancer,' A Japanese Play, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Imagine a mixture of ``Father Knows Best,'' ``The Seven Samurai'' and a bit of ``Blue Velvet'' and you may have some idea of what director David Greenspan has done in ``Gonza the Lancer.'' The early 18th-century play, which opened Tuesday at the New York Shakespeare Festival, was written by Chikamatsu Monzaemon who is often called ``the Japanese Shakespeare.'' But Chikamatsu might have a hard time recognizing his bloody tale of domestic tragedy transposed to a 1950s never-never land where the characters dress like Ozzie and Harriet but engage in enough sex and violence to put David Lynch to shame. Greenspan is one of three young directors given producer Joseph Papp's blessing this year at the Public Theater. They have been allowed to create their own seasons of plays, and Greenspan has started with this rarely produced work. The evening starts on a wildly self-indulgent note when the director himself steps forward to babble a prologue he wrote in 1982 called ``The Long Flat Plane.'' Greenspan loses a good deal of the audience with this existential hooey about the meaning of life and where we are in relationship to it. Once it's out of the way, the play can begin. There's a narrator, here played by two different actors, one for each act. Greenspan borrows freely - and often to good effect - from story theater as well as Charles Ludlum's Ridiculous Theater Company. When Gonza gets on a horse to ride, actor Koji Okamura mounts a metal stool. When the heroine's little children appear, they are doll-like puppets carried by other performers. And there is some gender-bending in the casting, with several male actors playing female characters and women cast in men's roles. Actor Tim Perez - looking uncomfortably like Harvey Fierstein in drag - dons a babushka, a floral print blouse and purple slacks to play a governess. Actress Fanni Green sports a mustache to portray a warlord. On a mostly bare stage, Greenspan gets most of his laughs out of his props. There are some amusing 1950s artifacts - a pink vacuum sweeper being among the more interesting. The acting is rudimentary, but at least Mary Shultz, who projects a Marilyn Monroe sultriness, manages to convey some emotion as the doomed Osai. The rest of the cast seem like stick figures. The production's oddness doesn't necessarily make the evening any more interesting. In fact, that's all you remember. This version of ``Gonza the Lancer'' sticks in the memory more for its weirdness than anything Greenspan and company have to say about the play.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Goes on Trial for Credit Card Misuse
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas' attorney general cheated the taxpayers out of more than $8,000 for his own use while serving as the state's top legal officer, a prosecutor alleged Tuesday at his theft trial. A defense attorney responded that the state gave Attorney General Steve Clark authority to use his state-issued Visa credit card any way he pleased and so he cannot be convicted of misusing it. The 43-year-old Democrat is charged with one count of felony theft by deception. If convicted, he could be sentenced to 20 years in prison and could be fined $15,000. In opening arguments, prosecutor Chris Piazza accused Clark of improperly billing taxpayers at least $8,448.27 on his credit card for meals 56 times from 1986 to 1989 with family, friends and political supporters. ``You'll see a transformation. You'll see a side you didn't know existed, a transformation much like that of Jekyll and Hyde,'' Piazza said, referring to author Robert Louis Stevenson's double-sided character. ``When you're finished with this evidence - I hate to tell you this - you'll see a transformation from attorney general of the state of Arkansas to a convicted felon,'' Piazza told the jury, which was seated Monday on the opening day of the trial. After the allegations arose in February, Clark reimbursed the state $3,951.29. He blamed poor record-keeping and said records of his meetings were reconstructed from notes, his calendar, receipts or memory every two to three months. The allegations also forced Clark to give up his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor, improving Gov. Bill Clinton's re-election chances. Dozens of people Clark listed on his expense account as dinner guests either say they didn't eat with him or they didn't discuss state business. Defense attorney Bill Bristow maintained that Clark ``can use that credit card from the state of Arkansas anyway he wants to. If he wants to, he can buy a car with it. A house with it. He is not forbidden by law from doing that.'' ``You may say to Steve, `You were sloppy, you were vain, you used bad judgment, you ruined your political career, but, Steve, you didn't commit a crime,''' Bristow said. Bristow said Clark is not the only elected official who spends state money for personal use. ``You know who spent money on entertainment? Spent money for postage and spent money for laundry? The governor,'' Bristow said. Clinton gets an allowance for the governor's mansion, which pays for food and entertainment. The state receipts for $25,960 in mansion expenses in 1989 come under the heading ``Food,'' Bristow said. Clark, in office since 1979, earns $26,500 a year. His salary is among the lowest among state attorneys general.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selected for Another PTL Trial
DOC.TEXT: A jury was seated Tuesday to decide a $757 million lawsuit that accuses PTL founder Jim Bakker and others working for the TV ministry of diverting contributors' money to their own use. Opening arguments in the civil action filed by thousands of former followers of the former TV evangelist were scheduled for Wednesday morning. Bakker, 50, is in a Minnesota prison, serving a 45-year sentence for his conviction last October on charges of fraud and conspiracy in connection with PTL. He is appealing the conviction. The lawsuit was filed in 1987 on behalf of 145,000 so-called ``lifetime partners,'' several months after Bakker resigned from the PTL in the wake of a sex and money scandal. Most of Bakker's ``lifetime partners'' sent him $1,000 in exchange for lodging at the Heritage U.S.A., a Christian retreat south of Charlotte that once was connected to the PTL. The lawsuit alleges that Bakker and other PTL officials, accountants and others, conspired to fraudulently raise million of dollars for the ministry, then launder it so Bakker and his top aides could spend it on themselves. The jury in the civil action was chosen from about 120 potential jurors over four days. The eight primary jurors were selected on Monday. Attorneys negotiated more than nine hours on Tuesday before agreeing to go to trial with four alternate jurors instead of six.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Fishermen File Class Action Against Hanford Contractors
DOC.TEXT: Indian fishermen on Tuesday sued private contractors who ran the Hanford nuclear reservation for nearly five decades, alleging that radioactive contamination from the complex damaged their livelihood. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court is the third class action that claims plutonium and uranium processing at Hanford damaged local residents' health or ability to make a living. Two similar suits were filed this summer on behalf of potentially thousands of people living or working downwind from Hanford. The legal actions followed a government panel's conclusion that emissions from Hanford during the 1940s and 1950s were large enough to cause illness to nearby residents. A study by The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta is underway to determine past effects of Hanford emissions on those living nearby. The latest case filed in U.S. District Court case seeks unspecified amounts for lost income and earning capacity, diminished property values and property damage. It also asks that further releases of radioactivity and toxic chemicals be barred and that exising radioactive and other contamination be cleaned up. The seven Yakima Indians filing the lawsuit claim radioactivy and other contamination has damaged the Columbia River fishery since the 560-square-mile reservation was established during World War II. The suit said the class eventually could include more than 700 Indians who fish along the river. The Indians' attorney, Fred Sayre of Santa Monica, Calif., said the Yakimas do not fish some river areas because they fear radioactive contamination. Lawyers for the current main contractor, Westinghouse Hanford Co., would not comment on the lawsuit, said spokesman Bill Klink. Also named as defendants were several major corporations and their Hanford subsidiaries, which were hired to run reactors, chemical plants and waste storage operations on the federal reservation over the past 50 years. Telephone calls placed after hours to the offices of the following former contractors went unanswered on Tuesday: E.I. du Pont de Nemours, of Wilmington, Del., which built Hanford during the Manhattan Project and operated it until 1946; General Electric Co., of Fairfield, Conn.; Atlantic Richfield Co., of Los Angeles; and Rockwell International Co., of El Segundo, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Factions in Liberian Civil War Hold Talks
DOC.TEXT: Liberia's three warring factions met together for the first time in months Tuesday to discuss a cease-fire plan for the troubled West African nation. At the session, a general in a five-nation force in Liberia said it was safe for a caretaker government to move into the capital city of Monrovia. Rebel leader Charles Taylor has for months refused to send a representative to the talks, called by a West African regional mediation group. Taylor said his aides were in Banjul only to listen and report back, but some officials said their presence suggested Taylor has not completely rejected negotiations. The last attempt at a cease-fire broke down in late September. The West African military force sent to oversee the truce later began attacking Taylor's men when they resisted relinquishing control of Monrovia. Taylor is opposed by remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's forces, who still hold the executive mansion in Monrovia, and a splinter rebel group led by Prince Johnson. Johnson's troops on Sept. 9 captured and killed Doe, who was visiting the headquarters of the 6,000-member West African force. Troops for Johnson and Doe have been cooperating with the multinational force from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia. At least 5,000 civilians have died in the civil war since Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Christmas Eve. The regional force has driven Taylor's soldiers from Morovia's suburbs and field commander Gen. Joshua Dongonyaro of Nigeria told the meeting the interim government could take power. The government, headed by political scientist Amos Sawyer, was created by the five West African nations to rule until elections can be held. Taylor has opposed creation of the government, saying his men control the majority of the country and he should be president. Taylor has set up headquarters in the central city of Gbargna, which he has declared is the country's new capital. He said he plans to hold elections within the year. Representatives of Doe's remaining forces accused the regional force's former field commander of being responsible for the president's death. They claimed Ghanaian Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo ordered Doe's security guards disarmed when they arrived at the headquarters, but let Johnson's men keep their weapons. Johnson's soldiers slaughtered Doe's men, said Gen. Hezekiah Bowen, who represented Doe's forces at Tuesday's meetings. Quainoo has denied any responsibility for Doe's capture and death, saying his men could not have intervened without breaking their pledge of neutrality. He was replaced as field commander shortly after Doe's death. Meanwhile, Sierra Leone is reviewing its position on welcoming Liberian refugees because of a disagreement about how many there are in the country. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees estimates there are 60,000, but the government in Sierra Leone says the number is more than three times higher.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Wants U.S. Officers on Illegal Extradition Charges
DOC.TEXT: Mexico is demanding extradition of two Texas lawmen on charges of illegally bringing two Mexican men to the United States to face murder charges, the attorney general's office announced Tuesday. It said prosecution against the two has already begun in their absence. The allegations are similar to those of an April case that damaged U.S.-Mexican relations: Mexico charged U.S. officials with arranging the kidnapping of a Mexican doctor accused of helping murder a U.S. drug agent. A news release said the former chief of Coahuila state judicial police, Angel Joaquin Lugo Castaneda, was arrested Saturday in the case and was jailed, and that two lower-ranking Mexican police were charged. The news release Tuesday said the Foreign Ministry ``is seeking the immediate extradition of the U.S. policemen,'' identified as Mitch Woods and Frank Collazo of Beaumont, Texas. Woods is an investigator with the Jefferson County district attorney's office and Collazo is a policeman in Port Arthur. Contacted Tuesday, Collazo said he is involved in the case, but his first name is not Frank; it is Luis. Efforts to reach Woods for comment were unavailing. The news release said murder suspects Hector Javier Morales Villa and Omar Ayala Mendoza were arrested by Coahuila state policemen Hector Galindo Lopez and Federico Rivera Balderas ``and turned over to the U.S. police in the middle of International Bridge between Piedras Negras and Eagle Pass, Texas.'' Piedras Negras is in Coahuila state, across the border from Eagle Pass. The Mexico City daily Excelsior said the two are charged with killing an elderly woman. It gave Morales' age as 24 and Ayala's as 21. Excelsior said Galindo and Rivera were being sought. The Mexico City daily El Universal said the parents of the two murder suspects accused Lugo of accepting $80,000 from U.S. police to hand the two over. Both suspects lived in Palau, 85 miles southwest of the Eagle Pass border crossing. The newspaper said officials failed to act on the parents' complaint until they appealed to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. It said state officials fired Lugo on his incentive. A spokeswoman for the attorney general's office said she could not elaborate on details of the case, and was unsure of the penalty for illegal extradition because Mexico is in the process of revising criminal penalties. Excelsior ran a front-page story Tuesday accusing the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration of protecting two of the six Mexicans accused in Mexico of kidnapping Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain in April and spiriting him across the border. U.S. officials are trying to prosecute Alvarez Machain on charges of aiding in the 1985 torture-murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena. They are appealing a court decision that his arrest was illegal. Mexico has demanded the extradition of Antonio Garate Bustamante and Hector Berrellez.

DOC.HEAD: Stormy Weather In Carolinas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 5th graf, `One man...,' to CORRECT that two autos fell through bridge sted four and that two people were injured sted four. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Elsewhere...
DOC.TEXT: Floodwaters caused a strange chain-reaction accident Tuesday in South Carolina when water washed out railroad tracks, causing a train to derail and knock down a highway overpass. Two automobiles fell into the gap left by the overpass, and one motorist was killed. The accident was among several caused by thunderstorms that doused the Carolinas and spun off tornadoes. Rain fell through much of the Atlantic states. The railroad accident took place near St. Matthews in central South Carolina. Flooding washed out supports under railroad tracks, causing a freight train loaded with coal to derail, said Sam McCuen, a state Highway Department spokesman. The train hit an overpass carrying U.S. Highway 176, collapsing the span and sending automobiles plunging through the open space, he said. One man was killed and two others were injured, authorities said. Elsewhere in South Carolina, strong wind and heavy rain forced the evacuation of 20 families from a mobile home park, injured at least five people and flooded roads under several feet of water across the state, authorities said. North Carolina had at least two tornadoes and record amounts of rain that swelled rivers to flood stage, the National Weather Service said. ``Nobody was hurt or anything. They were just shook up,'' said a dispatcher with the Newport police department after a twister touched down in a mobile home park in the eastern Carteret County town. In Alamance County, N.C., a state Department of Transportation worker's car was swept down a flooded roadway while the man was checking flooding near the Graham waste treatment plant. ``The water just swept me down the bank and pretty soon the car was completely submerged,'' said 47-year-old Sammy Barnes. ``I rolled the window down, but the water was coming in so fast I didn't think I would ever get out.'' Barnes climbed out of the car and clung to a low-lying branch for more than an hour before a fellow transportation worker saw the lights of his car and pulled him to safety. He was not injured. The storm nearly doubled the record amount of rain in the Wilmington area for Tuesday's date. According to the National Weather Service, 4.23 inches of rain fell in about six hours. The previous high for the date was 2.23 inches in 1914. The old record for any day in October was 4.2 inches on Oct. 11, 1882.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Actor's Son's Murder Trial to Proceed Without Sister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 6th graf to CORRECT that Cheyenne Brando is Dag Drollet's lover sted wife. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `We are...
DOC.TEXT: The murder trial of Marlon Brando's son can begin even if Brando's daughter, who is the victim's lover and a potential witness, can't be brought back from Tahiti, prosecutors indicated Tuesday. The daughter, Cheyenne Brando, was at the actor's mansion May 16 when her brother, Christian, allegedly shot and killed her Tahitian lover. Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas ordered 255 prospective jurors to court Nov. 5 for the start of Christian Brando's trial. Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop said he is continuing to negotiate with French authorities for the return of Miss Brando from Tahiti, where she took refuge shortly after the shooting. But the approaching trial date makes it unlikely that the complicated legal agreement can be reached, he said. The assistant prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney William Clark, said the State Department has been contacted about the case and has requested documents from the prosecution for use in negotiations with French authorities. The authorities have been preventing Miss Brando's departure from the French colony. Miss Brando, 20, has been charged in Tahiti as an accessory to the murder of her lover, Dag Drollet, 26. Although he died in the United States, the French consider his death a crime against one of their citizens. ``We are not optimistic,'' Clark said of the prospects of Miss Brando's return. ``The French are telling her she is not free to leave.'' Miss Brando went to Tahiti in June and recently gave birth to Drollet's child there. The prosecution has a strong case even without Miss Brando's testimony, Clark said. ``We're pretty sure we know what happened that night ... But when it comes to murder, that's always the hardest to prove,'' Clark said. ``We would like to have Cheyenne. She's one of the most important witnesses.'' Clark said the key issue will be whether Christian Brando is guilty of murder or the lesser charge of manslaughter. The defendant claims the shooting was accidental. Clark said he anticipates calling other witnesses to describe the events of the murder night, adding he hoped the defendant would take the stand. Asked whether the prosecution would call Marlon Brando as a witness or leave that to the defense, Clark said, ``We're sure he's going to take the stand. Who calls him first is part of the gamesmanship.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Thinks Israel Will Allow U.N. Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council on Tuesday postponed for 24 hours a vote on a resolution criticizing Israel for not cooperating with a U.N. probe of the killing of 19 Palestinians. The council thinks Israel will change its mind. U.S., British, Arab and non-aligned nation diplomats all said later they thought Israel may release its own inquest into the Oct. 8 killings on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem and allow a U.N. envoy to visit the scene. At least 19 Palestinians died when Israeli security forces fired on protesters throwing rocks on Jews praying at the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall. Israel has said letting in a U.N. investigating commission would infringe on its sovereignty over Jerusalem, which it has annexed. Yemeni Ambassador Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal said the United States would be trying to persuade Israel to cooperate before the vote is taken on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Raids, Arrests Seek to Curb Looting on Tense Atlantic Coast
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 21 people Tuesday and recovered food and aid items believed looted by former Indian Contra rebels and others upset over worsening conditions on Nicaragua's isolated Atlantic Coast. Three people were wounded in a spate of looting last week in Puerto Cabezas, where friction remains strong between ex-Contra rebels and Sandinista loyalists on the police force. The tension is also seen as a reflection of increasingly hard times in Nicaragua's economy. Flooding this year destroyed many crops in the region and an austerity program by President Violeta Chamorro has meant less money and jobs for the Atlantic Coast. Ms. Chamorro defeated Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega in February elections. Samuel Cepeda, a Miskito Indian who allegedly led the looting, accused government officials of stealing donations intended for the Indians. Cepeda is a leader of Kisan For Peace, an umbrella group of three Indian organizations that signed peace accords with the former Sandinista government in 1988. Kisan seeks assistance similar to the aid given about 2,300 Yatama Indian rebels that demobilized last June. The Yatama and other former Contras got offers of land and other help. Both Kisan and Yatama are made up of Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians who generally opposed the leftist Sandinista government. Cepeda said Leonel Panting, head of the regional government, assured Kisan it would receive part of a boatload of donations from Managua that arrived in Puerto Cabezas Oct. 12. ``They promised us a third of the cargo, but we could see them at night stealing from the warehouses,'' Cepeda said. About 300 Kisan members and relatives raided a warehouse belonging to the Moravian Church on Oct. 18 as goods were being loaded onto trucks. The looters took tools, cooking oil, rice, flour and powdered milk. Five police guards fired into the air, witnesses said. Two officers and a civilian were wounded by ricocheting bullets, police said. A day later, a smaller group looted a government warehouse containing donated clothes. Police were not present at the incident. Puerto Cabezas police chief Dean Dixon said the items recovered in the raids are a small part of what was stolen. Briceno Ortega, 37, one of those arrested in the pre-dawn raids, admitted he stole food but claimed Indians sought to divert aid for themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rwandan Rebels Agree to Truce
DOC.TEXT: Rebels seeking to overthrow the government of Rwanda are prepared to accept a cease-fire, Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni said. Museveni made the announcement following a second round of talks with Belgium's Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and Defense Minister Guy Coeme. ``I have just received word from them which indicated that they were ready to observe a cease-fire,'' said Museveni's statement on Monday. Rebel officials, however, could not immediately be reached for comment. Martens initiated efforts last week to negotiate an end to the fighting between government troops and a Tutsi rebel force comprised mostly of Rwandese refugees. The rebels, which invaded Sept. 30 from Uganda, accuse Rwanda's Hutu-dominated government of corruption, human rights abuses and failing to repatriate refugees. Many of the rebels are former Ugandan army troops. As many as 10,000 Tutsis were massacred and hundreds of thousands driven into exile in the 1960s. Rwanda's President Juvenal Habyarimana agreed to a cease-fire and a condition for peace talks during a meeting in Tanzania last week with Museveni and Tanzania's President Ali Hassan Mwinyi. A large number of Rwandan refugees also live in Tanzania. The leaders also agreed that neutral troops acceptable to both sides should monitor the truce in the former Belgian colony in south-central Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Who Left Child in Car Trunk Loses Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up penalties, RECAST lead to include that police said she had been locking child in trunk for a month.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who told police she locked her child in the trunk of a car every weekend for a month while she was at work has been charged with criminal restraint. Chante Fernandez, 24, of Elizabeth, told police and reporters she did it out of desperation. She said she'd been abandoned by her husband and was unable to find any one responsible to care for her 5-year-old daughter while Ms. Fernendez worked weekends at a shopping mall. Her arrest Saturday has focused attention on day care options as legislators and some state welfare officials criticized the system for failing poor families. If convicted of criminal restraint, Ms. Fernandez faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and $7,500 fine. According to police, Ms. Fernandez said she had kept the child in the car during weekends for the past month while she worked as a salesclerk in the Fortunoff store in the Woodbridge Center mall. Ms. Fernendez reportedly told police she kept the child in the car after firing three babysitters because they had stolen her food, invited guests to her home and left her daughter unattended. Roberta Francis, director of the division on women for the state Department of Community Affairs said she disapproved of the action, but noted Ms. Fernendez felt she had little choice. The mother ``had no other option but to do that,'' Ms. Francis said. ``It was a Catch-22. Society shouldn't put people into a Catch-22 situation and our reaction should not be to completely blame the mother for what she did.'' Ms. Fernandez, who is free on $5,000 bail, was arrested Saturday after police found the pajama-clad child in the trunk of a 1987 Toyota Celica in the mall parking lot. The child, who was in good condition, was taken into custody by the state Division of Youth and Family Services pending an investigation into the charges. In a telephone interview, Ms. Fernandez said she was notified Tuesday that she was fired from her $300-a-week secretarial job at the Central Lumber Management Co. in Elizabeth. A woman who answered the company's telephone Tuesday refused to discuss the case or refer the call to someone who would. Ms. Fernandez said she earned $160 on weekends as a saleswoman at the Fortunoff store at the mall. Fortunoff officials on Tuesday confirmed that she had worked at the store but refused to say whether she remained with the company. Ms. Fernandez said her husband abandoned her, her father died in January and her house had been robbed three times. ``I don't have anything now,'' Ms. Fernandez said. ``I've lost everything.'' Legislators and social service officials say the case demonstrates the lack of child care for poor working families. A bill that would provide $75,000 in grants toward the construction and expansion of child-care centers was introduced in 1988, said state Sen. Wynona Lipman, D-Essex, the bill's sponsor. The legislation is pending. ``We realize that facilities are lacking,'' said Ms. Lipman. ``I think we're working hard to correct that, but still, low-income children are rapidly being left on the landing and their mothers have no child care because they can't afford it. It's hard to correct the issue.'' She said there are 300,000 children under the age of six competing for about 100,000 day-care slots across the state. However, Linda Moroses of the Community Coordinated Child Care of Union County said there is day care for those who seek it. The agency is a day-care referral service. ``If a person were really looking, they would find us,'' she said. ``Yu can find our number in advertising in the paper, flyers in the public school systems, word of mouth, in corporate buildings, in the phone book.''

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff's Deputy Shot Over Campaign Signs
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff's deputy was shot and critically wounded Tuesday while hanging up campaign posters for the Democratic opponent of Cook County Sheriff James O'Grady, police said. Sheriff's Deputy Irving Bell and at least three other people were posting signs for Alderman Michael Sheahan when another sheriff's deputy who apparently supports the Republican incumbent emerged from a nearby bar and shouted at them to remove the signs, said police Cmdr Ronnie Watson. The deputy then called inside the bar for about 10 acquaintances to help him and ordered one of them to kill the Sheahan supporters, Watson alleged. A man pulled out a gun and fired at Bell, hitting him in the back, the stomach and the buttocks, he said. Bell, 34, was in critical condition Tuesday night at Christ Hospital and Medical Center, said hospital spokeswoman Jan Barnett. His colleagues escaped unharmed. The 3 a.m. shooting on the South Side left both candidates in the sheriff's race accusing each other of allowing thugs to work on the campaign. O'Grady contended that the wounded deputy was not putting up Sheahan posters but was instead pulling down O'Grady posters. Police were questioning an O'Grady campaign worker about the shooting, the Chicago Sun-Times reported in its early Wednesday editions. Watson said two men were being questioned but that no charges had been filed. ``For something like this to happen to one of our workers is absolutely shocking,'' Sheahan said. ``I'm interested in winning this election, but I'm not interested in anyone getting hurt.'' ``I'm asking Mr. O'Grady to call off these people, these thugs and goons. This is the worst thing I've ever seen in politics.'' O'Grady said Sheahan workers had provoked the confrontation by tearing down his campaign signs and vandalizing his campaign office. ``This incident is the unfortunate outgrowth of a rising tide of street-level hooliganism, vandalism, and intimidation directed against our campaign by the Sheahan campaign,'' O'Grady said in a statement. O'Grady said the Sheahan supporters outside the bar are part of an ``ongoing night crew'' assigned to steal or damage his campaign's property. O'Grady said Bell has been suspended from the sheriff's office while unrelated allegations are investigated.

Carrying a child does not make a woman a parent, a judge ruled in awarding a test-tube baby to the boy's genetic parents instead of the surrogate they hired for $10,000. Civil rights advocates and ethicists charged that the ruling Monday by Superior Court Judge Richard Parslow ignores the law and creates a ``breeder class'' of women. ``The judge is saying gestation doesn't count, it counts for nothing, and I think that is a very disturbing outcome,'' said Susan M. Wolf, an associate for law at the Hastings Center, an ethics research institute in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. In giving custody of the 5-week-old boy to Mark and Crispina Calvert instead of surrogate mother Anna Johnson, the judge said, ``A surrogate carrying a genetic child for a couple does not acquire parental rights.'' ---= PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) - A white supremacist says a $12.5 million verdict against himself and his followers over the slaying of a black man will leave him broke - but free to preach violence without fear of being sued again. A jury Monday found that Tom Metzger, a former grand dragon of the Ku Klux Klan, and his White Aryan Resistance incited the slaying by skinhead toughs. The jury ordered Metzger and his followers to pay the family of Mulugeta Seraw the entire $12.5 million sought on its behalf by the Southern Poverty Law Center of Montgomery, Ala. ``Back home, we say it cleans his plow,'' said Morris Dees, an attorney for the law center. ``The first thing we're going to do is send a moving van to his house so we can take it over.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The House ethics committee is opening an urgent investigation of whether Rep. Donald E. Lukens, R-Ohio, made improper sexual advances toward a Capitol employee. Lukens, convicted in Ohio last year of a misdemeanor sex offense, was ordered to testify under oath today about the new allegation. ``The committee has received additional evidence indicating that Rep. Lukens may have made unwanted and unsolicited sexual advances to a congressional employee,'' the committee said in a statement issued Monday evening. Sources close to the case said Lukens recently fondled and propositioned a young elevator operator in the Capitol, and gave her his business card. She reported the incident to her supervisors, and one source said there was a witness to corroborate her story. ---= NICOSIA, Cyprus (AP) - Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani is intensifying his purge of anti-Western radical rivals in a power struggle that looks to be heating up against the backdrop of the Persian Gulf crisis. The outcome, at this stage, does not seem to be in doubt: Rafsanjani is gradually consolidating his power. But he needs to force the pace to maintain the momentum of his effort to liberalize Iran's economy and society after the June 1989 death of revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Rafsanjani, leader of the so-called pragmatists, is seeking to improve the quality of life for Iran's 55 million people to cement his popularity. He also seeks to rebuild bridges with the West and the Arabs. ---= ST. PAUL, Minn. (AP) - Minnesota's Republican auditor has jumped into the governor's race, taking advantage of allegations the regular GOP nominee invited teen-age girls to take a nude dip with him nine years ago. Auditor Arne Carlson announced a write-in campaign Monday against Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich and Perpich's embattled Republican challenger, business executive John Grunseth. Two women have charged in sworn statements that Grunseth encouraged them to join him in a nude swim in 1981, when they were 13 and 14. Grunseth, 44, denied the allegation but has been under increasing pressure from his party to quit the race. An internal GOP poll last week indicated that five Republicans, including Carlson, could beat Perpich in the Nov. 6 election but that Grunseth could not.
