DOC.HEAD: Nome Merchants Take Rubles But Can't Dish 'Em Out
DOC.TEXT: A sign posted on the doors of a half-dozen Nome businesses depicts a handshake and reads, in English and Russian, ``We accept many rubles.'' The problem so far has been getting rid of them. ``There's been no monetary benefit so far - it's like Monopoly money,'' said Nome Liquor and Grocery owner Greg Higashi, who has accepted more than 5,000 rubles in about nine months from visitors from across the Bering Strait. ``But we did it for good will, not profits. And we're hoping that maybe when it does open up in Russia that we can exchange them for merchandise or whatever.'' Soviet officials have said the ruble could become convertible on the international market within a couple of years as part of the nation's transition to a market economy. But for many Nome merchants, the pace of Soviet reform has been frustratingly slow. In the first nine months of their neighborly grass-roots experiment in monetary exchange, Nome merchants have sold thousands of dollars in goods and services to Soviet visitors. In return, they have gotten 30,000 virtually worthless rubles they can neither spend nor invest. Some shopkeepers have found only one use for the Soviet bills: They sell them to American tourists as souvenirs. The merchants hope that by accepting rubles they will encourage freer trade and travel across the Bering Strait, forming new friendships and eventually new markets for Alaskans. ``The whole intent of the project was a goodwill public relations campaign to convince the Soviets to make the ruble convertible or allow us to use it,'' said Nome city manager Jim Stimpfle. The Soviet government sets the ruble's value artificially, apart from the market fluctuations that determine other currencies' values. It is illegal in most cases to take rubles out of the Soviet Union. But many Soviet travelers to Nome do bring rubles with them, merchants say. Since the ``ice curtain'' between Alaska and the Soviet Far East began thawing in the late 1980s, Nome has seen an influx of Soviet visitors on cultural, scientific and other exchanges. Soviet Eskimos are allowed to visit their Alaska counterparts without visas. Many Nome residents likewise have visited Soviet cities like Magadan, Anadyr and the closest city, Provideniya, about 230 miles west of Nome. A year ago, Nome-based Bering Air began allowing Soviet citizens to pay for trips to Alaska with rubles, and the Nome Chamber of Commerce followed suit early this year, urging businesses to accept the Soviet money. Bering Air has an average of two charter flights weekly between Provideniya and Nome, resulting in a fairly steady stream of Soviet visitors. Stimpfle said he has visited the Soviet Far East seven times and sees many opportunities for trade. ``We can make it work if they'll let us use their currency. We can start a market system much faster, and we don't have to wait for a convertible ruble,'' he said. ``But the Soviets just want dollars - dollars, dollars, dollars.'' Bering Air President Jim Rowe is paid in rubles by customers in Provideniya, and puts the rubles in a Soviet bank. But Soviet authorities require that he use dollars - or even barter items like calculators and typewriters - to pay landing fees, so he has nothing to spend the rubles on. In January, he gave 80,000 rubles to Soviet schools and hospitals rather then let them be taxed in the bank, said Chris Rowe, his wife and the company's vice president. The carrier, which also flies to 25 northwest Alaska villages, is able to cover its expenses but isn't profiting from the Provideniya runs, she said. ``It's not fair,'' she said. ``If they want to pay us in rubles, they'll have to come up with something we can do with them.'' But Rowe also said Nome residents are investing in the future and making it more affordable for ordinary Soviet citizens to visit the United States. Bering Air offers an exchange rate of one ruble to one dollar - compared to the official Soviet rate for tourists of about six rubles to the dollar. Nome businesses offer varying exchange rates. Nome Checker Cab offers one-to-one, charging four rubles for the $4 ride from the airport to town, said owner Gary Hart. Hart even has ``Checker'' written in Russian letters on his cabs. ``We're all willing to take this gamble in hopes we'll encourage national leaders to maybe look at one little northwest Alaska community that's willing to develop international trade,'' Hart said. Marty James, owner of Maruskiya's of Nome gift shop, said he has collected about 1,000 rubles, mainly selling T-shirts and souvenir pins. He wants to buy more products from the Soviet Far East eventually, particularly Eskimo crafts. On a recent trip to Provideniya, James' family met a Soviet family who later sent gifts. ``They make very lovely things there - lead crystal, cups and saucers, a silver ring they sent my wife,'' he said. ``They're great people - they're our neighbors. I'd like someday to be able to travel over there like you would do here and go to a co-op or some kind of organization that would have goods available. ``Everything cannot go through governments. That's a lesson they have to learn and have not learned yet. If we're part of that in a small way, I'd be happy.''

CBS' `WIOU' Brings Television Newsroom to Television
DOC.TEXT: Imagine the newsroom of ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' seduced by the dark side of The Force, and you have ``WIOU.'' It's the same people in different bodies, acting out a premise gone wrong. At its best, tonight's premiere is a bleak, black comedy of television manners, rich with the irony that what happens in front of the camera rarely corresponds with what goes on behind it. At its worst, it strains to introduce a raft of characters, establish their relationships and tell a story. A fine cast, horribly wasted, is under orders to create caricatures instead of characters. They struggle heroically to create dramatic tension out of a fundamentally flawed script. ``WIOU'' is WNDY, a financially ailing Chicago TV station at the bottom of the ratings. John Shea plays Hank Zaret, newly named the station's third news director inside a year. Exiled from New York by network brass over a career-threatening screwup, his mandate is to turn the station around. This displeases his immediate subordinate, executive producer Liz McVay (Mariette Hartley), who's been passed over for his job. And it re-introduces him to an old flame, Kelby Robinson (Helen Shaver), an ambitious reporter angling for a shot at anchoring the news. Shea, Hartley and Shaver give ``WIOU'' its only semblance of rational adult behavior and professionalism. Otherwise, it's a newsroom filled with outlandish characters conforming to our worst expectations of stereotypes: Harris Yulin (who has moments of magnificence) plays the reptilian, sexist, Pompous Anchor who's pulling down a million-three and can't keep his hands to himself; Dick Van Patten, portraying a Shameless Ham of a Weatherman, can expect a bill for royalties from Willard Scott; Joe Grifasi plays the Cynical Flack, a P.R. hustler obsessed with ratings; Phil Morris plays the shallow, shameless, Nakedly Ambitious Reporter out to make a name for himself; Jayne Brook plays the Earnest Young Producer getting her shot as a reporter; and Wallace Langham is the Eager Young Intern who worships her. As the show's publicity says: ``The personal and professional lives of these men and women in front of the cameras and behind the scenes are brought sharply into focus as they confront the harrowing deadlines, newsroom politics, ratings battles and ethical dilemmas which are literally all in a day's work.'' 'Nuff said? Nah. Here's a taste of what's to come: The Shameless, Nakedly Ambitious Reporter arrives at the scene of the fire: ``If this is a two-alarm fire, I'm Mrs. O'Leary's cow!'' quoth he. Then the Earnest Young Producer interviews a fire victim, the father of a missing child. Agonized, she cuts off the Pompous Anchor's really dreadful questions when they intrude on the father's grief. She stops the interview but lets the cameraman continue his tight shot on the weeping man's face for about five minutes. Sensitive, eh? What's genuinely incredible about this program is that two of its executive producers, its co-creators and the pilot's co-writers, John Eisendrath and Kathryn Pratt, actually worked at Chicago's WBBM-TV, owned and operated by CBS. Given the opportunity to say something about their former craft, its horrors, absurdities and the vast majority of hard-working news professionals, they give us cliches. --- Elsewhere in television ... YOU MIGHT OTHERWISE NOT NOTICE ... DEPT.: ``Art of Indonesia: Tales from the Shadow World,'' airing tonight on PBS, uses ancient Javanese poetry andssacred tests to show viewers the myths and symbols at the center of Indonesia's thousand-year-old culture. CIVIL WAR II: PBS says at least 38.9 million people saw at least part of one episode of the five-night, 11-hour documentary series ``The Civil War.'' While about 10 percent of a typical PBS audience uses a videocassette recorder during a given program, ``The Civil War'' was recorded by between 16 percent to 22 percent of its audience. PBS will air ``The Civil War'' again in January and July 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Yes, Homeowner, There is A Future to Housing
DOC.TEXT: When housing prices are falling and investment analysts are frothing about a collapse of the real estate market, there still is no safer place for your money than the home in which you live. The truth of the statement lies in the historical evidence. It shows that while price declines do occur they are rare and relatively short-lived, and that housing prices recover with the economy and often grow faster than it. Still, you would have to be hard of hearing not to detect the shrieking of the sirens, the screeching of the alarmists, the blare of the headlines. Houses unsold after 12 months on the market! Sellers cutting prices $50,000! So what? Homeowners know that no matter what the market analysts say, they do not lose money on their houses until they choose to sell or have to sell. Some of the bearish comments come from academe, some from writers seeking to cash in on homeowner fears, some from brokerage house analysts who tend to view a house solely as an investment rather than a place in which to live. This week a brokerage house analyst commented sagely that thousands of people who purchased houses three years ago have a loss on their investment, a statement that bears little resemblance to facts or reality. Most of the people who live in those homes would, in fact, be surprised and mystified to hear that they had lost money, since nowhere in their checking accounts or tax records is there any evidence of such losses. The tendency to view housing solely as an investment, and to measure its value by the month and year rather than by the decade, is reflective more of a Wall Street trader's mentality than that of a homeowner. Traders constantly price their portfolios, homeowners do not. Traders live day to day, homeowners live for long-term goals. Traders can do little to improve the value of their shares, homeowners constantly make improvements. Moreover, homeowners are constantly paying down the mortgage, obtaining tax benefits and enjoying the kind of physical protection for one's head that no stock, bond or other security can provide. After examining the claims of housing doomsayers, Harvard University's Joint Center for Housing Studies, an impartial assessor, offered this reassurance: ``Contrary to popular reports about the impending home price crash, today's homeowners have little reason to worry.'' They backed it with statistics showing that except for brief periods, housing keeps pace with the economy. ``While it may be necessary to ride out a short-term down cycle, over time home prices tend to rise at or above the general rate of inflation, making housing a solid investment and key component in the financial security of the current and future generations of elderly Americans.'' They offered the hypothetical example of a household that in 1974 bought a typical single-family home in Boston for $89,144 (1989 dollars). Assuming the buyers had a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage and sill owned the home in 1989, the paydown of the mortgage principal and appreciation in prices would have boosted equity in the home by $140,192. At that price they would have had an inflation-adjusted compound annual growth rate of 15.1 percent. Had they purchased the house in 1980, paying a higher price but enjoying greater inflation during the 1980s, real equity would have grown at 24.6 percent annually. And even if the house had been purchased in 1986, when the explosive Boston market was near its peak, the homeowner would have realized equity gains of 16.9 percent in each of the following three years. Let the doomsayers shout, let them denounce housing as an investment, let them try to frighten you with predictions of doom. Safe in your own home, you can ride out the storm, knowing better times lie ahead.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Lead United States in Action on Global Warming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Suggested for side-by-side use with AM-Global Warming-US
DOC.TEXT: European countries preparing for a U.N. conference on global warming have forged a consensus on the need for action, breaking with the go-slow policy of the United States. The U.S. policy, however, may threaten the outcome of the 10-day Second World Climate Conference, which begins Monday in Geneva. Optimists had hoped it would set an agenda for hard negotiations on details of a climate convention. Now it seems the United States will block any move to set targets for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide, a key ``greenhouse'' gas. Global warming from the ``greenhouse effect'' occurs when carbon dioxide, methane and other pollutants build up in the atmosphere, trapping the sun's heat like a greenhouse. Of 100 nations attending the conference, only Egypt, oil-producer Saudi Arabia and perhaps the Soviet Union, which fears the economic consequences of a treaty, are likely to support the U.S. position. In April, at a global warming conference in Washington, Environment Minister Hans Topfer of West Germany disputed President Bush's claim that more research was needed ``to sort out the science.'' Speaking for near Chrysalis House, a residential substance abuse program in Maryland. ``The first is you're an addict. The second strike is you're a female. If a female addict happens to be pregnant, in the eyes of most of the country, you're at the bottom of the heap.'' In fact, some prosecutors, citing concerns for the children, have charged pregnant drug users with crimes, sometimes jailing them. Since 1987, more than 50 criminal cases have been filed against women for drug abuse during pregnancy, about 80 percent of them minorities, the American Civil Liberties Union says. Civil libertarians argue that this drives addicts away from prenatal care. ``Prosecutors are telling them to get clean or be arrested and they'll take away their kids,'' said the ACLU's Isabelle Pinzler. ``There aren't the places for drug treatment and the places that exist frequently won't take them.'' ``It forces them to make a Sophie's choice - either getting healthy or abandoning the child in foster care or a dysfunctional family from which they themselves came,'' said her colleague, Lynn Paltrow. More than 5 million women of childbearing age use illegal drugs, including more than 1 million who take cocaine, the National Institute on Drug Abuse said in 1988. Up to 375,000 babies may be exposed to drugs annually, according to the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education. While those numbers indicate the scope of a problem exacerbated by the crack epidemic, others suggest glaring inadequacies in treatment. Consider: -Some 280,000 pregnant women nationwide needed drug treatment, yet less than 30,000 received care, according to a 1990 survey by the National Association of State Alcohol and Drug Abuse Directors. -Two-thirds of 18 big-city hospitals surveyed last year by a U.S. House committee had no place to send pregnant women for drug treatment. -A New York study found 54 percent of treatment programs excluded expectant women; 87 percent rejected pregnant Medicaid recipients addicted to crack. ``They think there will be a terrible malpractice problem,'' because of potential pregnancy complications, speculates Dr. Wendy Chavkin, the author and an associate professor at the Columbia School of Public Health. All of this is especially frustrating, experts say, because pregnancy often motivates women to seek help. ``If they don't find a program out there, chances are we've lost them,'' Mrs. Hudicek said. ``Some die. Some end up in hospital emergency rooms giving birth to crack-addicted babies.'' ``Part of the American way is motherhood and apple pie,'' she added. ``The stigma that women face ... admitting they're addicted to drugs is incredible.'' Cynthia, a Chrysalis House resident and new mother, knows the feeling. ``You already have low self-esteem,'' said the recovering cocaine-heroin addict, who asked that her last name not be used. ``Finally you do humble yourself to say ... `I have a problem,' and there's a bunch of excuses. ... They say, `We can't help you now. Come back in 30 days.' You may die, you may get incarcerated.'' Or you may get sick. Cocaine, doctors say, increases the risk of premature delivery and life-threatening hemorrhages and can cause physical and neurological damage to babies. Pregnant addicts often ignore their health. One Michigan woman said it was easier to walk four houses to buy crack than take a bus four miles for prenatal care. Others sell furniture, food stamps, even themselves for drugs. About 180 addicts are in Hutzel's 21-year-old program; about half are pregnant and 50 percent of those women take methadone to prevent miscarriages. Hutzel provides counseling, child care, lunch, transportation and prenatal care. The residential recovery program houses women and their young children in a former convent. Many have long histories of addiction. Wanda Kaigler, now 37, says her drug use began at age 16. She nearly died six years ago from bad heroin, and though she survived and even quit once, her habit has stripped her bare. ``It makes you lose your friends, your family, your furniture, your home, your respect for yourself,'' she said. ``You feel terrible afterwards. As long as you do it, you feel good.'' A widow for three years, Miss Kaigler also lost her six children, ages 2 to 17, when they were removed by authorities. She wants them back, proudly noting two are honors students. ``I love my kids,'' she said. ``They don't think so. Sometimes, I don't think so.'' Kelly Barrington's concern for her baby, coupled with the threat of losing her 9-year-old daughter, led her to Hutzel. ``God knew the only way I was going to stop is if I got pregnant,'' said Miss Barrington, a drug abuser for 15 of her 31 years who switched to crack from heroin after her veins collapsed. ``I couldn't live with the fact that I hurt an innocent baby.'' She, too, had hit bottom. She was jailed briefly, lost everything and was so desperate she'd drag her daughter to dope houses, explaining she was sick and ``that was the medicine I needed.'' Her daughter responded by repeatedly breaking her crack pipes. ``I try to forgive myself and say I was a sick person,'' said Miss Barrington, her purse adorned with badges for every month she has been drug-free. ``I feel great that God gave me another chance to turn things around.''

DOC.TEXT: Eighty percent to 85 percent of the women complete Hutzel's pregnancy program, which serves about 250 females a year. About a quarter continue in recovery, but more than half of those who inquire never show up. Some fear prosecutions will deter even more. A Massachusetts judge this month threw out an indictment charging a 24-year-old mother with drug distribution for cocaine found in her infant son. ``By imposing criminal sanctions, a woman may turn away from seeking prenatal care for fear of being discovered, thereby undermining the state's asserted interests,'' Boston Superior Court Judge Suzanne V. DelVecchio said in her ruling. But some prosecutors say they must help the children - even if means charging and jailing pregnant women. ``Innocent children are horribly damaged by the use of cocaine. If that's not child abuse, I don't know what is,'' said Charles Condon, a South Carolina solicitor who helps run a program in which pregnant users must enroll in treatment or risk arrest. ``We don't want them to be prosecuted,'' he said, but ``you really have to give them consequences for their behavior.'' At Hutzel, Wanda Kaigler knows all about consequences. But she plans to stay clean and dreams of living with her kids ``away from drugs.'' ``Anything you have faith in and believe in,'' she said, ``you can have.''

DOC.HEAD: Is a Pregnant Addict Guilty of a Crime?
With AM-Surviving Year One II
DOC.TEXT: When Traci Jackson gave birth to a stillborn child, Texas authorities say, she had with her a deadly weapon. It wasn't a gun or a knife, but cocaine - in her body. That's what Houston prosecutors will argue when the 20-year-old woman faces trial Nov. 12 on a cocaine possession charge that could send her to prison for up to 20 years. The trial is among more than 50 cases in 20 states and the District of Columbia in which pregnant drug abusers have been charged with crimes ranging from child abuse or neglect to drug delivery, homicide and assault with a deadly weapon. In Alaska, a woman pleaded no contest in 1989 to criminally negligent homicide in the death of her 2-week-old son, which was tied to maternal cocaine use before birth. In Florida, a woman was convicted last year of delivering drugs through the umbilical cord and sentenced to 15 years probation. And in Kentucky, a 33-year-old mother addicted to drugs and pills for half her life was sentenced this spring to five years in prison for child abuse. These actions ``are all illegal extensions of the state statutes by prosecutors who want to get their names in the paper,'' argues Lynn Paltrow, an ACLU attorney in New York. Some courts, too, have been troubled by this approach. A Boston judge this month dismissed a drug charge against a woman whose baby was born with cocaine in its system. ``There is no familiar bond more intimate and more fundamental than that between the mother and the fetus she carries in her woman,'' Judge Suzanne DelVecchio wrote. ``This court will not permit the destruction of this relationship by the prosecution.'' But prosecutors say the threat of legal action is a strong incentive to seek treatment and an appropriate way to protect children. ``It's about time we notified those who would use cocaine while pregnant that they'd better stop it,'' said Casey O'Brien, a Houston prosecutor in the Jackson case. ``It's just not fair to others. It's not fair to their children. It's not fair to society that ... (takes on the responsibility) for their children who survive or are damaged irreparably by cocaine.'' In the Houston case, the state claims Miss Jackson - her attorney says her real name is Beverly Amos - entered a bathroom in an apartment and shortly thereafter gave birth to a stillborn baby, later found inside a plastic bag in a closet. The government says Miss Jackson used crack that day; an autopsy found the baby had large quantities of cocaine in its liver. Prosecutors say DNA testing provides circumstantial evidence she was the infant's mother. Defense attorney Alex Bunin doesn't acknowledge the woman had a child and says the charge violates equal protection. ``A man cannot be prosecuted for that crime,'' he said. Bunin also says the state is unfairly attempting to punish the woman twice - for possession and for the use of cocaine as a deadly weapon. O'Brien said prosecutors don't have to prove the deadly weapon kills, only that the manner in which it was used was capable of causing serious bodily injury or death. ``The baby never had a chance,'' O'Brien said. ``The cocaine killed it in the womb. Whether it killed it legally or practically, the result is the same.''

DOC.HEAD: Surviving Year One
PART III: Born Too Soon and Too Small: The Legacy of Poor Prenatal Care
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The cost of America's failure to ensure that pregnant women receive proper care can be calculated in the millions of dollars. But it also can be measured in the tortured body of an infant born too soon and too small, as Mitchell Landsberg finds in the last of a three-part series, ``Surviving Year One.'' ---

Eric could almost fit in his father's hand, if his father were there to hold him. He is so small, so weak, so sick - a little boy pushed into the world far before his time. He is kept alive by machines. Machines make Eric breathe, and machines keep Eric warm. Machines feed him and machines record his heartbeat, his pulse rate, his temperature. He lives in a sterile glass crib, surrounded by banks of blinking lights, tangled in a webbing of tubes and splints and bandages. His eyes and his mouth open and shut, and he writhes gently. For all the machinery, it is human suffering that contorts his face and a human will that keeps his tiny heart beating. It shouldn't have been this way. Eric was born six months into his mother's pregnancy, without benefit of meaningful prenatal care or decent nutrition, and most likely with the damaging effects of drugs. Now Eric, like his sister before him, is in the neonatal intensive care unit at the Children's Hospital of New Jersey. Here, in the corroded core of one of America's poorest cities, doctors and nurses struggle daily to save babies who enter life too soon, too sick and too small. ``This is so typical,'' says social worker Debbie Beacher, who has just finished listening to Eric's mother recite her story of drug abuse and homelessness. ``An unwed mother, young, a drug abuser, has a baby born prematurely that ends up in this unit.'' It is like this around the nation, in cities big and small, in places like the Hospital for Sick Children in Washington, D.C., and Valley Children's Hospital in Fresno, Calif. ``We're seeing a growing need for our kind of hospital in just the past few years,'' said Dr. Edna Leung, a pediatrician at the Hospital for Sick Children. ``It's sad. We enjoy what we do ... but we just wish we could make some of these problems go away.'' The problems won't go away, and their legacy is children like Eric. Society pays, and the costs are enormous. It costs about $600 to administer prenatal care to a woman during the nine months of a normal pregnancy. Drug treatment for a crack addict costs about $5,000. Without prenatal care, without drug treatment, the risks of a woman delivering a premature, low birthweight child increase dramatically. And so do the costs. It costs an average of about $25,000 to treat a low birthweight infant - one under 5.5 pounds. For extremely low birthweight babies, under 1.65 pounds, the average is more than $100,000. That's an average. Some cost far more. Once, the point would have been moot - such tiny babies would have died at birth. But medicine has made tremendous strides in saving them. Between 1980 and 1987, the infant mortality rate in the United States dropped by about 20 percent. During the same period, the percentage of infants born to mothers who had no early prenatal care scarcely changed, and the percentage of low birthweight infants actually increased. Since birthweight is the single most important indicator of infant health, the meaning is clear: Children are being born sicker than ever, and medicine is using superior technology to keep them alive. In Fresno, Dr. Nadarasa Visveshwara has been treating a baby that weighed exactly 1 pound at birth. The child's mother, who is on Medicaid, had received very little prenatal care. The baby is now six months old. The medical bills have topped $750,000 and probably will be around $1 million by the time the child is released from the hospital. The prospects for the child ever enjoying a productive life, Visveshwara said, ``are very poor.'' Does he ever ask, is it wise to save such children? ``Almost all the time,'' he said, ``because we hesitate to produce an infant who will be a burden to the parents and to society, and who won't be able to lead a productive life. ... But the baby always gets the benefit of the doubt.'' Eric, whose real name is being kept confidential, weighed slightly more than 2 pounds at birth. In 1960, his odds of surviving infancy would have been about one in 10. Today, they are better than 50-50. His medical bills are around $100,000 and climbing, and his parents have no ability to pay. His birth was costly, but not in financial terms alone. There is an incalculable cost in pain and suffering, in emotional distress and social disruption. These are statistics for extremely low birthweight infants, those somewhat smaller than Eric: -90 percent will suffer respiratory problems. -70 percent will have brain hemorrhages. -80 percent will have heart problems. -50 percent will have liver problems. -5 percent to 10 percent will be blind. -2 percent to 3 percent will die of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Of those who survive, 40 percent will be mildly handicapped, 40 percent will be severely handicapped and 20 percent will be normal. There's more. Premature infants are much more likely than other children to have cerebral palsy. They are much more likely to have learning disabilities later in life. And children who spend their infancy in a hospital will have difficulty bonding with their families, a trait also widely attributed to children exposed to drugs in the womb. The longterm emotional costs are yet unknown. ``There's just not that closeness, and these kids have more difficulty when we get them home,'' said Dr. John H. Niles Jr., president of the Medical Society of the District of Columbia. ``They're just not the joy that a baby should be.'' ``It's like a Vietnam kind of thing,'' Niles added. ``These kids have been in a battle, and there are going to be some scars. And society is going to pay for those scars.'' The easiest way to avoid the scars, most people believe, is to make prenatal care widely available and do whatever it takes to get women to take advantage of it. The most commonly repeated statistic about prenatal care is that every $1 spent on it will save $3.30 in future medical costs. Dr. Shyan Sun, director of neonatology at the Children's Hospital of New Jersey, is a skeptic. He shuffles through a file drawer to pull out a list of everything his patients have going against them. They are poor, they are young, they are unmarried, uneducated; they abuse drugs, they drink, they smoke. ``One cannot naively believe that prenatal care alone will solve the problem,'' Sun insisted. ``I am not optimistic that we will make a difference in the near future. We still have to take care of all these social problems.''

Two House Agriculture subcommittee chairmen are opposing a Chicago Board of Trade plan to double the number of grain and soybean futures contracts available to speculators. Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said Monday that such changes should not be made until the effects of the 1990 farm bill are known. The bill, which establishes new planting options as part of government budget cutting, will dramatically change the commodities market, said Glickman, chairman of the wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee. He and Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., whose subcommittee oversees the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, have asked the CFTC to withhold approval of the Chicago Board of Trade plan until next year. The farm bill has been approved by a House-Senate conference committee, but awaits final votes in both chambers and the president's signature. In a letter to CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm, the chairmen said the Chicago Board of Trade plan appears to be response to pressure from big commodity trading fund managers. The funds ``have little interest in the price discovery or legitimate hedging functions of these markets and view them simply as another speculative venture to market to their customers,'' the lawmakers wrote. ``We do not believe the commission should approve the proposal until its proponents can verify with certainty that it will enhance the performance of these markets and allay fears that it will simply subject grain producers, marketers, and users to unnecessary, damaging price fluctuations,'' they added.

DOC.HEAD: Getting Help From a Reluctant State
With AM-Surviving Year One III
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Kelly Crockett snuggled next to his mother, too young to do much of anything except eat, sleep and cry. Too young to know that he is starting life a step behind most other babies. Despite city-wide efforts to improve health care services and lower Indianapolis' sky-high infant mortality rate, Joseph's mother struggled to get caseworkers at the Marion County Welfare Department to extend Medicaid to her fourth child. ``They don't care, or they don't want to care,'' said Lisa Carter, 24. ``It's too much of a headache for them. It's almost as if you're asking them for $20 out of their pocket.'' Joseph was born prematurely; he was delivered at 36 weeks by emergency Caesarian, and weighed 5 pounds. And it took seven weeks before Joseph was added to the welfare rolls, before he could receive Medicaid, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps. In the interim, the pediatrician and hospital didn't press for payment, but Miss Carter had to pay for his food and transportation to the doctor herself. Joseph's father tried to help, but judging from the support he gave Lisa during her pregnancy, she knows she couldn't count on him. Nor could she count on the welfare department. The conscientious caseworker who handled her file for two years recently quit. With her departure returned the threats that the family's Medicaid and Aid to Families With Dependent Children would be cut off because of improper paperwork. But then, Miss Carter says her Medicaid coverage has been taken away twice -both times unjustly, she believes. Miss Carter was 5 when her mother was murdered, but she overcame that to become an A student in school. At 16, her first child, Taron Smith, was born, but she overcame that to graduate from high school. Two years later, she was working toward an associate's degree in secretarial sciences when her grandmother became ill. She quit school to care for her and never returned. At 19, her daughter Shenika was born, weighing just 4 pounds, 12 ounces. Miss Carter had become a single, teen-age mother with two young children, and she couldn't find a way out. ``I'm not stupid, but I have had plenty of tragic situations in my life,'' she said. ``But I can't use that as a crutch.'' In Indiana, a family of four must be living below 32.7 percent of the federal poverty level, bringing in less than $385 a month, to be eligible for Medicaid and AFDC. Only Alabama, Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, North Carolina, Texas and West Virginia have stricter standards. For pregnant women and children under 6 years old, the picture is brighter because of federal mandates. In April, Congress required all states to provide Medicaid coverage to pregnant women and young children with family incomes below 133 percent of the federal poverty level, $1,972 per month for a family of four. Miss Carter feeds, clothes and shelters her family on child support she receives from the children's fathers and on her $405 in monthly AFDC payments, the state's maximum payment for a family of five. Thirty-six states have higher payments. Even a part-time job at minumum wage would boost her income above the state's limits. She and her oldest child would be ineligible for Medicaid and the whole family would lose its AFDC and food stamps. Still, Miss Carter has goals. She's looking for a job that pays enough to take care of her four children. She wants to return to school. ``My situation is not something that's good for my baby or my other three babies,'' she said. ``I want to help myself, but I need support. And I don't have any.''

DOC.HEAD: Surviving Year One
Part I: Health Workers Reach Out To Keep Babies Alive
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphotos, AP Graphics, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The world's wealthiest nation has a monumental infant mortality rate. Behind that wretched statistic are 40,000 tragedies - the number of American children under the age of 1 who die each year, many victimized by their mothers' poverty, ignorance or drug use. In the first of a three-part series, ``Surviving Year One,'' National Writer Lisa Levitt Ryckman visits Indianapolis - once the city where a newborn was least likely to reach its first birthday, now a town that is fighting back. ---

Carol Sanders' baby was born in an infant mortality disaster area, a neighborhood where community health workers measure success in newborn ounces and weeks in the womb. In this urban death zone, Tyrone Lamont Payton survives with a vengeance. He arrived in triumph two days shy of his due date, a strapping 8 pounds, 14 ounces. Nineteen-year-old Carol's fourth child, he was the first who wasn't born too soon and too small. More babies die each year in Carol Sanders' impoverished neighborhood than any other in Indianapolis. Until recently, black babies died at a higher rate in Indianapolis than any big city in America. And more babies die in America than any other Western industrialized nation. Babies born in Hungary or Poland had a better chance of celebrating their first birthdays than any baby Carol Sanders carried. Enter Wafiyyah Harrison, a mountain of a woman with enough compassion, wit and strength of purpose to wring a little happiness from the hopelessness in the violent inner-city neighborhood nicknamed ``Little Detroit.'' Harrison helped Sanders help herself, and the result was the vigorous good health of Tyrone Lamont Payton. ``I tell them, `You've got to meet me halfway. It comes down to, do you want a healthy baby or do you not?' '' said Harrison, one of four community health workers with the Maternity Outreach Mobile Project care coordination team. ``If you're below the poverty line, you cannot afford to have a special-needs baby. So you need to do what it is you need to do.'' Across the nation, health workers haunt inner-city housing projects and rural shacks, staging a frontal assault on the forces that feed infant mortality statistics. The savings in lives and money recently persuaded the General Accounting Office to recommend that Congress fund home-visiting through Medicaid. ``Myself, I didn't have the best life coming up,'' Sanders said, hugging her youngest daughter against a swollen belly just before Tyrone's birth. ``But I'm going to give them the best that I can.'' Not all women who need help having healthy babies are as ready to cooperate as Sanders; a hand offered is not always accepted, the outreach workers have been dismayed to learn. Carol Sanders' sister was five months pregnant with her second child and already in pre-term labor when Harrison began visiting. Unhappy about her pregnancy, the 18-year-old ignored most of the health worker's advice about rest and diet. The result was 2-pound, 5-ounce Antonette, born at 28 weeks and lingering in the hospital intensive care nursery weeks after her full-term cousin had gone home with his mother. ``There's one group that all we need to do is get them hooked up with prenatal care, improve their nutrition, teach them basic parenting,'' MOM Project Director Joanne Martin said. ``But there's another reservoir of people for whom that's not enough. They have a lot of problems in their lives, and being pregnant is only one of them. For that group, we need to be more creative and not throw up our hands in despair.'' Despair runs deep in Indianapolis' inner-city neighborhoods, where toddlers play in dirt shiny with broken glass and houses sag and rot behind boarded windows. In the worst of these areas, where the Sanders sisters live, 37 of every 1,000 babies die before age 1. But city officials were unaware of the deaths in the shadows of their new downtown skyscrapers and sports facilities until the fact was splashed across the front pages of local papers. The news was bleak. In 1986 and 1987, more black infants died in Indianapolis than any other major city in America, at a rate of more than 23 per thousand. Stunned city leaders hastily did their own calculations. There was no mistake. ``It's a shock when you see these headlines and wonder who's not doing their job,'' said Dave Arland, spokesman for Mayor William Hudnut. ``But it's been a situation of not addressing it, not addressing it, not addressing it over the years, and then we wind up at the top of the heap.'' A city-county commission that studied the problem discovered a horribly overburdened health care system. Clinics didn't exist in the neighborhoods with the highest infant death rates, and a woman could wait weeks for an appointment at existing facilities. And the seemingly simple task of riding a bus to the hospital or clinic was arduous and time-consuming. Indianapolis' problems are endemic to big-city - and rural - America, and are reflected by the dismal U.S. infant mortality rate. Improvement in the rate stalled in 1985 for the first time in 20 years. That same year, there were increases in the number of babies born with a low birthweight and born prematurely, under 5{ pounds and before 37 weeks gestation. Low birthweight babies are 40 times more likely to die during the first month of life. A very low birthweight baby like Antonette, who weighs less than 3\ pounds, is 200 times more likely to die in her first month of life than her normal weight cousin, Tyrone. About 40,000 babies younger than 12 months die annually in the United States, two-thirds of those in the first 28 days of life. Two black infants die for every white one, the worst racial disparity in 50 years. Health officials say infant death hits the black community disproportionately because black women and their babies suffer more from the ravages of poverty: lack of education, inadequate prenatal care, lower maternal age, a high number of previous and unwanted births, poor nutrition, smoking and substance abuse. Alter those factors and save lives, said the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, which called in 1988 for universal access to health care for pregnant women and their infants as a crucial first step. ``There is an answer,'' said commission Executive Director Rae Grad, adding that half of all U.S. infant deaths are preventable. ``It's basic, boring, straightforward. It's feeding women, making sure they have health care. Making sure their babies have health care. This isn't glamorous stuff that makes the cover of Time magazine. But it works. It saves money. And it saves lives.''

DOC.HEAD: INDIANAPOLIS: saves lives.''
DOC.TEXT: Indianapolis officials reached the same conclusion. Since then, four new clinics have opened in the city. A computer netork helps track patients when they move from one clinic to another. A motor coach equipped with a state-of-the-art ultrasound machine, part of the March of Dimes-funded MOM Project, travels to different county clinic sites to serve those patients. This fall, four care-coordination teams are fanning out across the city. The black infant mortality rate is falling; the rate for 1988, the most recent year available, is 20.3 per 1,000, down from 23.7 in 1987. So far, the MOM Project team has taken 270 referrals and opened 183 cases. Sixty-eight babies have been born, only five of them under 5{ pounds, a low birthweight rate half that of the area they serve. The infant mortality commission estimates that every low-birthweight birth the workers avert represents an instant savings of $14,000 to $30,000. At most, the team has only to prevent 14 such births to equal its own annual operating costs. The four MOM Project health workers try to spend at least eight hours a week doing outreach, haunting Medicaid lines and welfare offices, jumping out of cars to talk to women on city streets. ``Are you pregnant?'' they ask. ``Do you know anyone who is?'' That's how Harrison found Tracy Kersey, 17 and already the mother of one, who settled her bulk uncomfortably in a chair and proudly announced she no longer smokes. Harrison's support made it possible. ``You feel like it's somebody there for you when you don't have nobody there,'' Kersey said. ``She's someone you can talk to when you're down and have troubles.'' Food and housing are scarce, but trouble is something these women have in abundance. Among the project's client list are an anorexic chain-smoker in hiding from an abusive partner, a 13-year-old girl with an alcoholic mother, and a woman who boasted of getting drunk every weekend during her pregnancy. Now her fetal alcohol syndrome baby is on their rounds, too. ``Being a mother yourself, you feel all mothers want the best for their babies,'' MOM outreach worker Claudia Thompson said. ``Then you'll run into situations where you begin to wonder, `Now, are they concerned at all about this child?' But I understand it, because they've got all these other problems.'' The MOM Project workers deal in basics first, assessing each woman's health and educating about nutrition, pre-term labor and other problems. They provide referrals for food, housing, Medicaid and WIC, the federal supplemental food program that provides free food, nutrition education, prenatal care and counseling to mothers and children. Visits continue until the baby turns 1. Less than half of women and children entitled to Medicaid and WIC are actually enrolled in the programs in the United States; many women don't realize they are eligible. Some simply don't know what resources are available, and they make no effort to find out, the health workers say. ``A lot of these people are in denial. They deny they have five or six babies and are on welfare. I look at pregnant women who don't want to do anything for themselves as people who are in denial,'' Harrison said. ``Until you accept that you have a problem, there's nothing I can do. And that's the way I look at it. You have to accept you have a problem, whether it's poverty, no food, pregnancy. ``Then there's always something we can do.''

DOC.HEAD: Home Visitors Have Been Around 100 Years
With BC-Surviving Year One I
DOC.TEXT: Reed Tuckson remembers his mother, the nurse, donning her hat and climbing into a little blue car to visit poor families in their homes and teach other mothers how to plan their pregnancies and care for their babies. By the time Tuckson became Washington, D.C., health commissioner decades later, the system that had supported visiting nurses like his mother had collapsed under budget constraints and desperate nursing shortages. In 1989, Tuckson had just eight community health nurses for the entire city. Such nurses remain in short supply, but home visitation programs using lay workers have begun to proliferate as government officials recognize the health benefits and cost-effectiveness. Basic prenatal care can cost as little as $500; the lifetime costs of caring for a low-birthweight baby can hit $500,000. About 4,500 home visiting programs exist nationwide, although fewer than one-third address the problems of pregnant women and their babies. At least 10 European countries, all of which have lower infant mortality rates than the United States, use home visiting to some extent, and some programs are universal. Virtually every British and Danish newborn is seen by a home visitor who is a nurse or midwife. American programs, which date back 100 years, usually target disadvantaged families, and home visitors are likely to be women from the community who have overcome the same problems their clients face. ``In many home visiting programs, it's not uncommon to find households with no plumbing, no cooking facilities, households overrun by vermin, substantial family dysfunction with drug use and violence. Many families lack the basics for survival,'' said Dr. David Olds, who began a home-visiting program in 1978 in Elmira, N.Y. Olds' program tracked babies until they were 2, and found that they were heavier at birth and less likely to be abused or neglected. Four years later, the home-visited mothers had more months of employment and fewer subsequent pregnancies and were more likely to have postponed the birth of a second child. In Norfolk, Va., the Resource Mothers Program targets pregnant teen-agers by linking them with trained community workers who help them get prenatal care and educate them about health during pregnancy. Since the program began in 1985, the low birthweight rate for home-visited teen mothers has dropped to 6 percent, compared with 9.4 percent for teen-agers nationwide. The General Accounting Office in July recommended that Congress extend Medicaid coverage to home visitation programs, although it also recommended more research to determine exactly which kinds of programs work best. Congress recently approved but failed to fund a network of home healthcare workers.

DOC.HEAD: Coupon Books, Lotteries Draw Women to Prenatal Care
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT ``Columbia Clinic'' to ``a Columbia clinic''
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Surviving Year One I
DOC.TEXT: Women who might otherwise never see a doctor are being drawn into prenatal care by coupon books good for pickles, college courses and lotteries that pay cash for seeking medical treatment early in pregnancy. South Carolina's coupon program, called ``Caring for Tomorrow's Children,'' is one of a number of such giveaways nationwide aimed at reducing low birthweight and infant mortality. Free coupon books like South Carolina's are offered in Chicago and Washington, D.C., and several states and health plans are in the process of organizing their own, including Blue Cross of California, the Hawaii Medical Service Association, New Hampshire, New Jersey and the New York cities of Rochester and Syracuse. In Pawtucket, R.I., Memorial Hospital and two other health centers that make up the Blackstone Valley Perinatal Network run a Healthy Baby Lottery, funded by the March of Dimes. It awards six monthly prizes from $25 to $100 for women who seek prenatal care in their first 12 weeks of pregnancy, plus a $50 bonus for women who come in before their 10th week. Every six months, a $500 drawing is held for women who complete their doctor's recommended prenatal care. In the six months before the lottery began in February, 73 percent of the women who came to the centers had delayed prenatal care until their second trimester. Since the lottery began, however, that figure has dropped to less than 59 percent, said network director Noreen Mattis. Mattis said Broward County, Fla., has begun its own lottery based on the Rhode Island program, and other states have expressed interest. ``If we prevent one low birthweight baby, or one handicapped child, which I think it is likely to do, then I think it's worth it,'' said Dr. Larry Culpepper of Memorial's department of family medicine. Coupons in South Carolina's book, worth more than $550, include free pickles, a ride on a Medicaid van to a prenatal check-up, and a free personal interest course at a state technical college. The 400-page book also provides women with health tips and a guide through the social service maze. To encourage women to get medical attention, each coupon in their book must be stamped by a doctor before it can be redeemed. About 44 percent of pregnant women in South Carolina received inadequate prenatal care in 1988. In 1987, South Carolina had a higher percentage of low birthweight babies - those weighing less than 5{ pounds - than all other states except Louisiana and Mississippi. The state's infant mortality rate was among the nation's lowest, 12.2 per 1,000 lives births in 1988, compared with a national average of 9.9. Catherine Bagnal, high-risk maternity coordinator at a Columbia clinic, said many young pregnant woman have the attitude, ```My mother had 13 children and she stayed at home and she didn't go to the doctor. Why do I need to go?' And that was kind of hard to come up against.''

DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices plunged a record $5.41 a barrel in heavy trading on a combination of Middle East peace hopes, technical trading factors and a report of an apparition appearing to Saddam Hussein in his sleep. Monday's drop in the November contract for light, sweet crude oil to $28.38 per barrel marked the biggest single-day drop since futures contracts began trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange in 1983. The previous record was a $4-a-barrel decline on Aug. 17. But the sudden erosion of the so-called ``war premium'' may not show up at the gas pump anytime soon. Analysts said it would take anywhere from three to 14 days for price movements to be passed along to consumers. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - House and Senate negotiators approved a clean-air bill expected to eventually cost the economy $22 billion a year and affect most of American society by toughening pollution controls on automobiles, factories and power plants. The bargainers worked out the final details before dawn Monday, ending more than a year of bargaining between the two chambers. Late in the afternoon, the conference committee gave the measure formal endorsement, with only Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., opposing it. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - The long-delayed sale of MGM-UA Communications Co. neared completion Monday when Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. delivered the $967 million balance of the purchase price. MGM-UA's board of directors scheduled a meeting Tuesday regarding the $1.3 billion sale of the historic studio, the two companies said in a statement. Pathe, a Beverly Hills-based entertainment conglomerate, said if the board gives its approval, Pathe anticipates closing the deal Friday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Resolution Trust Corp., faced with a limited pool of outside talent to help clean up the savings and loan mess, has bent its ethics rules to do business with some companies. The RTC, the federal agency responsible for disposing of hundreds of collapsed S&Ls, is signing on about 1,000 new contractors a week and could soon rival the Defense Department as a lucrative source of government contracts. At the same time, there is a limited number of outside companies, such as accounting firms, with the expertise the RTC needs. Because the $500 billion savings and loan scandal is so far-reaching, many of the companies with the know-how needed to resolve it have been touched by it in some way. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Office of Thrift Supervision said it will seek $30.8 million in restitution from David L. DOC.TEXT: The stock market settled for a mixed showing after last week's rally ran into some resistance despite a continued slide in oil futures prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which climbed 122.77 points last week, slipped 4.70 Monday to 2,516.09. The dollar strengthened against all major currencies in worldwide trading. Gold prices declined in sympathy with the drop in oil. Bond prices closed little changed. On other markets, livestock and meat futures also fell, and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Plans Strategy Change To Battle Slumping Market
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. has joined the move toward ``open'' computer standards, planning an announcment for later this week about modifications to its flagship line. The world's second-largest computer maker plans will announce Thursday that it is changing its VAX computers so they can run software designed for the popular Unix operating system. That means companies equipped with both VAX and Unix-based computers could run the same software on all, saving the cost of buying or writing a second version of the software. Analysts said Digital was pushed into the change by a slumping market for its proprietary machines, which cannot easily be connected with computers made by other companies or operate software designed for those machines. An operating system is the base layer of software than controls a computer's internal housekeeping functions. Applications software, such as word processing programs, provide specific functions for the computers and run on top of an operating system. Digital said it will release a new version of its VAX operating system next year that will adhere to an open-system standard called Posix. Posix, in turn, is compatible with Unix. Digital also said it intends to have the operating system certified by an international group called X-Open Ltd., which promotes open-system computing. Analysts said Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., needs to make its VAX computer line more attractive. ``There is clearly a slowdown in orders for VAX,'' said Jay Stevens, who follows the computer industry for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Part of that sluggishness is due to the desire for open systems, but it also is due to a delay by customers in ordering new Digital computers while they await promised new models, analysts said. One such model, also to be announced Thursday, is a new top-end version of the VAX 6000 midrange computer line. The VAX 6000 model 500 will offer 85 percent more processing power than the current top-end 6000, but only cost 18 percent more, said Stephen Blanchette, the line's marketing manager. Digital officials admit the move to open systems is driven by the marketplace. ``It is apparent that open-systems computing is the way of the future and Digital intends to address that market,'' said Phil Auberg, marketing manager for the VAX software line. While Digital's move is important for a company that has relentlessly promoted a proprietary computer line, it isn't unique. NCR Corp. made perhaps the most dramatic move into open systems of any old-line computer maker with an announcement last month that it will replace the company's entire product range with open-system machines. Digital also will announce Thursday that it will phase into the VAX line over the next two to three years a more powerful processor based on reduced-instruction set computing, or RISC, Auberg said. RISC technology speeds up computers by reducing the number of instructions they must complete to perform a task. RISC chips are used in speedy computer workstations, including those made by Digital, that offer performance approaching levels of the largest mainframes at a fraction of the price. The VAX announcements follow Digital's unveiling last week of a computer system aimed at small and midsize businesses. The computers, based on industry-standard Intel Corp. microprocessors, have been praised by analysts as a strong move into a market where Digital has not put much effort in recent years. Digital hopes the flurry of announcements will give a kick to sales, which have suffered in the past few quarters. Last week, Digital reported both revenue and profit fell in the quarter ended Sept. 30 compared with the same period last year. Digital earned $26.2 million, down sharply from $150.8 million a year earlier, while revenue slipped to $3.09 billion, from $3.13 billion. But the results were a vast improvement over the second quarter, when it reported a loss of $256 million, its first ever. The red ink resulted from a $400 million charge to pay for a major scaleback that included the elimination of thousands of jobs and plant consolidations to contend with the computer industry slowdown.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the major provisions of the clean air legislation approved by House and Senate negotiators.
DOC.HEAD: Urban Smog
DOC.TEXT: -Smog-causing pollution would have to be cut by 15 percent within six years and 3 percent annually after that until federal air quality standards are met. About 100 cities would have to achieve federal standards within five to 15 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area would be given 20 years. -Factories and businesses would have to install new pollution-control equipment to cut smog-causing emissions. Large factories and small polluters such as dry cleaners, gas stations and paint refinishers would be affected in cities with significant smog. -New pollution control requirements would be established for offshore oil rigs, although rigs off the Gulf Coast would be exempt.
DOC.HEAD: Motor Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: -Automobilettailpipe emissions would have to be reduced by 30 percent to 60 percent by 1998. On-board canisters would be required to capture fuel vapors. A second round of tailpipe controls would be required if the Environmental Protection Agency considers them necessary after 2003. -Alternative-fuel vehicles would have to be phased in for taxi and other fleets and a pilot program would be created in California to introduce up to 300,000 alternative-fuel cars for private use by 1999. -The bill would require the sale of cleaner gasoline blends in nine cities with the worst smog problems. Compliance likely would come through ethanol blends or other ``reformulated'' gasoline. The cities are Los Angeles, Houston, New York, Milwaukee, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Hartford, Conn., San Diego and Chicago.
DOC.HEAD: Toxic Pollution
DOC.TEXT: -Factories would have to install ``maximum achievable control technology'' to reduce the release of 189 toxic chemicals, many of them carcinogens, by 90 percent by 2000. -Additional emission controls may be required by the EPA to ensure ``an ample margin of safety'' from exposure to cancer-causing industrial emissions. The EPA would develop an urban air toxic chemicals program to reduce cancer risks by 75 percent over five years. -Requirements would be established for industry including new monitoring and response requirements for chemical accidents. Also would set up a chemical safety board to investigate accidents.
DOC.HEAD: Acid Rain
DOC.TEXT: -Electric utilities would be required to reduce annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons in two stages by the year 2000; emissions would be capped after that. Releases of nitrogen oxides, also a precursor of acid rain, would be cut by 4 million tons. -Utilities would be allowed to buy and sell ``pollution credits'' to reduce the cost of emission controls at dirty plants. Utilities that already operate clean plants could use the credits for emissions in new plants to allow for growth.
DOC.HEAD: Estimated Costs
DOC.TEXT: -The White House estimates the measure's cost at $11 billion a year by 1995 and $22 billion to $25 billion a year by 2005. -Industry estimates $35 billion to $50 billion a year by 2005, when all pollution controls would go into effect. -The American Lung Association puts cost benefits from healthier air at $50 billion a year in reduced health care expenses. -The EPA estimates the cost of current pollution controls to the economy at $32 billion a year.
DOC.HEAD: Jobs
DOC.TEXT: -Provides a five-year, $250 million program to help workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. Funds require worker to be in a retraining program to become eligible.

DOC.HEAD: Unusual Defense Wins Traders More Time, At Least
DOC.TEXT: Two commodity traders who contend trading rules were broken routinely at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have won more time, at least, with their unusual defense against federal fraud charges. Ray Pace's lawyer thinks it will be late spring before Pace and Sam A. Cali return to court after U.S. District Judge William T. Hart ruled they should be tried separately from 12 other Japanese yen futures traders. The decision Monday came about six weeks into the yen traders' trial. Hart did not set a date for the separate trial of Cali and Pace. Hart said evidence presented by Cali and Pace might prejudice the jury against the other defendants, who have denied breaking rules. All 14 defendants had sought to have Cali and Pace severed from the trial. Cali's lawyer, Thomas Durkin, said he was ``tremendously encouraged'' by Hart's decision. ``I read his opinion as a validation of the defense,'' Durkin said. ``We intend to vigorously pursue it when we get the opportunity.'' Pace's lawyer, Steve Rosenberg, was less enthusiastic. ``I think the decision is a fair one, but how this all ends up remains to be seen,'' he said. Durkin and Rosenberg suggested in their opening arguments last month that almost every trader at the Merc violates trading rules almost daily and that exchange officials are aware of the problem. The Merc has denied that its officials knew about or condoned rule violations. Durkin and Rosenberg contend any rule violations their clients may have committed do not constitute fraud or racketeering, the crimes with which they are charged. Hart denied motions for a mistrial by several defendants who contended the opening statement already had prejudiced the jury against them. The case resulted from an FBI investigation of corruption at the Merc and the larger Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two biggest commodity exchanges. The defendants are accused of cheating customers by executing their orders outside the trading pit or at less-than-optimal prices. A similar trial involving 10 soybean futures traders from the Chicago Board of Trade is continuing. In the first of the three scheduled trials, one Swiss franc futures trader from the Merc was acquitted and two others were convicted July 9 of minor trading violations, leaving the jury deadlocked on fraud and racketeering charges. A retrial on the unresolved charges from that trial is to begin March 5.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Moves Toward Buyout of MGM-UA
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. has the money it needs to finish its $1.3 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co., the studio behind the Oscar-winning ``Rain Man'' and the James Bond and Rocky films. Pathe and MGM-UA announced Monday that the Beverly Hills-based entertainment conglomerate had delivered the $967 million balance of the purchase price. MGM-UA's board of directors scheduled a meeting for today on a sale of the historic studio. Pathe, headed by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, said it hopes to close the deal by week's end. Combined with previous installments totalling $353 million, the payments fulfill the purchase price of $1.3 billion. Of the additional $967 million, Pathe said almost $600 million was raised through a private placement of stock in the new company. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said details of the offering would be revealed in Securities and Exchange Commission filings later this week. He did not identify the new investors, but said Pathe would maintain a majority interest in the new company. MGM-UA executives declined to comment further on Monday's announcement. Over the last two years, production at the studio has slowed to a crawl as MGM-UA has gone through a variety of aborted takeovers. Pathe on Sunday sold English-language television rights for nearly 1,000 MGM-UA films to Turner Broadcasting System Inc. as part of a deal under which MGM-UA will help finance its own purchase. That transaction was valued at a reported $200 million. The MGM-UA-Pathe deal has been delayed by Parretti's financial difficulties and an acrimonious split between Pathe and Time Warner Inc. Time Warner was to have contributed $650 million toward the purchase price in exchange for a lien on the valuable United Artists film library and extensive distribution rights to Pathe and UA movies. Time Warner dropped out of the deal and sued Pathe for $100 million, claiming Pathe double-sold some distribution rights. Ever since Kirk Kerkorian placed MGM-UA on the blocks in April 1988, the sale has been a spectacular odyssey of failed financing, lawsuits and juicy gossip. Kerkorian, who owns 80 percent of the company, has been approached by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., Australia's Qintex Entertainment Inc., PolyGram N.V., MCA Inc., Japan's C. Itoh and Co., Barris Industries Inc., several unidentified foreign investors and the Walt Disney Co. A 1989 deal with Qintex appeared to be one of the most likely to be completed. But the $1.5 billion transaction fell apart when Qintex was unable to raise the money. Parretti is an elusive figure. The son of an olive merchant, he made his fortune, he says, by buying, restructuring and selling troubled European companies. He has predicted that one day he will preside over ``the biggest film group in the world.'' Parretti bought the financially strapped Cannon Group movie studio, purveyors of exploitation titles like ``River of Death,'' in 1988 for $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Union Near Agreement with Chrysler; Bode Well for UAW?
DOC.TEXT: Labor analysts say a move by Chrysler Corp. toward a contract with the Canadian Auto Workers may bode well for talks with the United Auto Workers union in the United States. Canadian union President Bob White on Monday received a new economic proposal from Chrysler Canada Ltd. and called it ``a great relief.'' ``It's clear that we're not going to have to fight to get a basic economic agreement,'' he said. ``They've clearly indicated that they're ready to meet the pattern.'' White said dozens of issues remained unresolved, but he was confident a contract could be reached by the midnight Thursday deadline the union has set. The UAW and the Canadian union are pressing Chrysler to accept pattern agreements reached with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. UAW workers at Ford plants in the United States ratified by a 4-to-1 vote a new national agreement mirroring the GM-UAW agreement, the union said Monday. UAW and Ford executives are to sign the new contract Friday. Before the Canadian union received Chrysler Canada's economic proposal, there had been speculation that bargaining with the smallest of the Big Three automakers on both sides of the border would be tough. But after White's comments, analysts said that may not be the case. Since the UAW and Chrysler began bargaining in the United States in mid-July, company officials have said Chrysler faced severe economic problems. After the UAW pattern agreement was reached, Chrysler said the deal was too expensive. ``It indicates that the negotiations could very well proceed more smoothly in the United States despite Chrysler's rhetoric to date,'' said Harley Shaiken, a labor professor at the University of California in San Diego. There was no immediate comment from UAW officials bargaining at Chrysler headquarters in Highland Park. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said Monday he couldn't comment on the Canadian talks or their significance on talks with the UAW. ``It's two separate sets of negotiations,'' he said. Despite that, Shaiken and Harry Katz, a labor professor at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., said it was likely Chrysler would accept the pattern agreement with the UAW. ``I all along have thought that Chrysler was going to have to conform to the pattern because the union was not about to give them a major exception,'' Katz said. There are differences between the UAW and the Canadian union pattern contracts. The UAW contract calls for a 3 percent wage increase in the first year and lump-sum payments of 3 percent in each of the next two years. The Canadian union contract calls for wage increases of 7.5 percent in the first year, 6.7 percent in the second and 4.8 percent in the third. Before wage increases in the new contracts, UAW workers were getting about $15.70 an hour, including cost-of-living allowances. Canadian union workers received about $15.50 hourly. One of the big differences is health care. The UAW agreement calls for no change in the system for providing health care to GM and Ford employees. The Big Three spent about $4.5 billion for health care last year, $684 million of that by Chrysler. A national health-care system in Canada covers much of the health-care cost for Canadian workers.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Reserves Decision on Pension Obligation
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has reserved judgement on whether the LTV Corp. must reassume liability for more than $2 billion in employee pension plans it stopped funding in 1987. U.S. District Judge Robert Sweet of Manhattan heard arguments Monday on a request by the Federal Pension Guaranty Corp. to make the Dallas steel, aerospace and energy concern take back responsibility for the pension plans. FPGC general counsel Carol Connor Flowe said Sweet had to shift liability in light of a recent Supreme Court ruling. The high court's June ruling upheld the federal pension agency's decision to force LTV's Cleveland-based steel unit, LTV Steel Corp., to reassume pension obligations for three underfunded plans, which were to provide for more than 60,000 LTV retirees and active employees. ``It's time now to enter judgement and to let the workers and retirees in these pension funds get their benefits,'' Flowe said. But LTV attorney Lewis B. Kaden said the high court had decided only legal issues and had not taken into account the company's current financial situation. ``The issue that has to be decided is the legality of the order here today, not three years ago,'' Kaden said. He said LTV, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, would not have assets to fund the pension plans. Kaden, however, said Sweet had authority to consider certain legal issues, among them whether LTV could be compelled to make contributions into the pension plans and whether plans that had no assets could be restored. ``You can't engage in a futile act,'' he said. Flowe claimed LTV was merely arguing positions already rejected by the Supreme Court. The judge indicated that he thought the issues raised by Kaden could be resolved in bankruptcy court. ``I really intuitively adopt Miss Flowe's thought on the changed circumstance argument that this is not the place for that to be worked out,'' he told Kaden. At a later point, Sweet said, ``The question is how much of this poison dish am I going to be able to pass on.'' Lawyers for LTV's various creditors also urged the judge against returning liability to the company, arguing that the move could disrupt LTV's attempts to reorganize. LTV filed for protection from its creditors in July 1986. The litigation stems back to 1987 when LTV stopped funding the pension plans and the FPGC assumed liability. A few months later, a new LTV labor contract with the United Steelworkers of America restored some retirement benefits similar to those in the terminated plans. The FPGC claimed that the company was taking unfair advantage of federal funds to cut costs and ordered LTV to reassume liability for the three terminated plans. When LTV challenged the order, FPGC went to court. In June 1988, Sweet ruled that the agency improperly ordered LTV to reassume the plans' operations. A year later, a federal appeals court agreed that FPGC had exceeded its legal authority. But the Supreme Court reversed the lower courts and sided with the FPGC in its June ruling, which said LTV had to take back liability for the plans.

DOC.HEAD: News Corp. Boss Says Earnings Will Rise
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch, chief executive of News Corp. Ltd., said Tuesday that he expects his debt-laden international media company will increase earnings this fiscal year. Murdoch told the annual meeting of shareholders that despite uncertainties in some of the company's major markets, he expects News Corp. to ``trade on ahead of last year.'' He did not estimate earnings and would not comment on the company's short-term debt problems that helped depress News Corp.'s stock price in recent weeks. News Corp.'s short-term debt soared last fiscal year to $2.30 billion from $396 million. Total debt rose to $8.21 billion from $6.13 billion. News Corp. stock closed Tuesday up about 50 cents to $4.75 in Australian stock market trading. In an interview Monday, Murdoch said his empire will increasingly concentrate on film and electronic media, rather than the newspapers and magazines with which he built News Corp. Newspapers and magazines now account for about 70 percent of News Corp. profits. His international holdings include interests in the Fox Television network in the United States and a 51 percent holding in the Suth China Morning Post in Hong Kong. In the last fiscal year ended June 30, News Corp. reported earnings that earnings dropped 75.5 percent to $267 million, largely because of losses at Murdoch's Sky-TV satellite broadcasting business in Britain and a pilots strike at the half-owned Ansett Australia airline. Shareholders approved Tuesday a resolution allowing directors to issue limited-voting shares. Murdoch wants to be able to issue such shares so the company can raise funds without diluting his 45 percent stake in the company. On Oct. 3, Murdoch merged four of his Australian newspapers into two around-the-clock productions, a move that reflected increasingly tough times in the Australian media business. The morning Melbourne Sun and afternoon Herald became the Herald-Sun on Oct. 8, the same day that the Daily Telegraph-Mirror was formed from the merger of the morning Sydney Daily Telegraph and the afternoon Mirror.

DOC.HEAD: GM Plans Shutdown of Truck & Bus Plants
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is planning to shut down its Truck & Bus Group full-size pickup assembly plants in Pontiac and Fort Wayne, Ind., for two weeks next month due to slow sales, an official said today. Kari Hulsey said the plants will be closed for two weeks beginning Nov. 5, affecting about 3,200 Pontiac East employees and about 2,700 Fort Wayne workers. She also said the company has told the United Auto Workers union that it is thinking about closing the plants for the weeks of Dec. 10 and 17, extending the usual one-week Christmas vacation to three weeks.
