DOC.HEAD: Say Disney Getting $600 Million From Japanese Investors to Make Movies
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. is close to arranging a film-production financing package worth at least $600 million backed largely by Japanese investors, the Wall Street Journal reported today. The financing would pay for nearly all of Disney's motion picture output for part of 1991 and at least part of 1992, and would mark the largest infusion yet of Japanese money into a major Hollwywood studio short of acquisition, the Journal account said. It quoted some industry observers as saying the transaction would be the largest single such financing in Hollywood history and that the final figure could be closer to $1 billion. The Journal said financing would be backed by two Japanese banks, the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. and Fuji Bank Ltd, and two U.S. banking companies, Citicorp and Manufacturers Hanover Corp. Officials from Disney and the banks declined to comment on the Journal account, which apparently was based on industry sources. The reported transaction reflects the allure of Hollywood investments for the Japanese. Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. in 1989 for $5 billion, and MCA Inc. has been talking with Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. about a possible acquisition worth as much as $8.6 billion. The newspaper said the Japanese financing package for Disney would replace the Silver Screen limited partnerships that have financed the company's film-making efforts over the past five years with more than $1 billion. It said Disney and Silver Screen have been far apart in recent talks about extending their relationship, and that was one reason that Disney sought alternative financing from Japanese investors. Disney has three separate film labels - Disney, Touchstone and Hollywood Pictures, which plan to produce about 25 films a year. The average film costs about $25 millin to produce and nearly that much to promote and distribute.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola, NFL Sign Worldwide Promotional Deal
DOC.TEXT: The National Football League has signed a new three-year agreement giving the Coca-Cola Co. exclusive soft drink marketing and promotional rights through March 1993. Coca-Cola has been the NFL's official soft drink since 1984. The terms of the new agreement were not announced. The agreement gives Coca-Cola exclusive worldwide rights to use the NFL name and symbols in soft drink advertising, including rights to the Super Bowl and Pro Bowl. For the first time, it specifies that Atlanta-based Coca-Cola may market its NFL association internationally. ``As the NFL continues to gain momentum outside the United States, it is only natural for us to expand our partnership with Coca-Cola and its international network,'' NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Harvest Pressures Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as the advancing corn and soybean harvest pressured the markets. A weekly Agriculture Department report released late Monday showed the corn harvest was 47 percent complete and the soybean harvest 57 percent complete as of Sunday. The corn harvest remains far behind the average pace of 58 percent for that date, although soybean producers have nearly caught up to the norm after planting the crop late due to heavy spring rains. Harvest progress could speed up considerably next week if a National Weather Service forecast for warm, dry weather in the Midwest pans out, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures prices were { cent to } cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62{ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.29{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower across the board with December at $1.24 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 2\ cents lower with November at $6.08{ a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed while pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange following USDA reports Monday that showed more cattle on feedlots and fewer pork bellies in commercial freezers than traders had expected. Live cattle futures were .15 cent lower to .05 cent higher with December at 76.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .25 cent lower with October at 86.80 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .52 cent higher with December at 54.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.15 cents to 1.28 cents higher with February at 66.95 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled lower on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: UPS Takes On Federal Express, Guarantees Morning Delivery
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service has announced it will match the delivery and pickup times of overnight delivery competitor Federal Express Corp. UPS has pushed back its guaranteed overnight delivery time to 10:30 a.m. and is offering same-day pickup. The company used to guarantee delivery by noon, and would pick u packages the day after a customer called. Both features have helped Federal Express dominate the $8 billion overnight delivery market and limit UPS's customer reach. ``We knew that this is what we needed to compete in this market,'' said UPS spokesman Alan Caminiti. Now, Caminiti said, the Greenwich-based package delivery company can compete with Federal Express in both service and price. ``We think when somebody's making a decision and they look at all of these factors ... it's going to make the decision for UPS clear,'' Caminiti said. UPS, the world's largest package delivery company, sends more than 700,000 packages a day by air, both overnight and second-day delivery, he said. Paul Schlesinger, a transportation analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said UPS's announcement could take the competitive edge away from Federal Express. ``Federal will either see an erosion in their volume or may have to do something on price - or both,'' Schlesinger said. UPS charges $11 for a same-day, overnight letter pickup to non-regular customers, Caminiti said. Regular customers who receive UPS's $4.50-per-week daily pickup service pay $9 for overnight delivery, and customers who drop off their overnight letters pay $8.50. Federal Express, based in Memphis, Tenn., charges $13 for drop-off service and a $2.50 surcharge for pickups. A Federal Express spokeswoman, Shirlee Finley, downplayed the threat, saying the announcment was ``another question of them playing catch-up.''

DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with New York prices; ADDS byline; PRECEDE London
DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mixed in Confused Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices were mixed on the futures market this morning as uncertain traders tried to figure out which way crude would move after Monday's record drop. ``We're having a little bit of confusion down there today,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken N.J. ``They're not exactly sure where they want to take the market.'' Light sweet crude oil for December delivery was down 81 cents to $29.60 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange in early trading. January and February delivery contracts were also lower, but later months were higher. Today's mixed prices appeared to put at least a temporary halt to oil's recent rapid decline, which resulted in a record fall of $5.41 per barrel on Monday. The big drop came as November contracts were traded for the last time and pushed those contracts to $28.38 at the close. December contracts had not fallen that far on Monday because of trading limits imposed by the exchange, so the spot price of oil was actually higher this morning. The big falls have come as traders determined a peaceful solution in the Persian Gulf seemed more likely than war. They have stripped away more than half of the ``war premium'' that sharply pushed up prices to the $40-per-barrel range in the weeks following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Refined petroleum products were also moving in different directions today amid the confused trading. Home heating oil was up 3.37 cents to 79.35 cents per gallon on November contracts. Winter and early spring delivery contracts were all lower, while late spring and summer contracts were higher. Unleaded gasoline was up 4.20 cents to 80.70 cents per gallon on November contracts. Winter and spring delivery contracts were trading lower, while contracts for next fall were moving up. Earlier today, oil prices had moved up more than $1 per barrel in London, where European traders said some doubts had arisen about the market's perception on Monday that a negotiated peaceful solution was close in the Gulf crisis. The London market's rebound appeared to be a combination of a correction from drop on Monday of more than $5 a barrel and a reassessment of how likely the Gulf crisis is to be resolved peacefully. ``Prices just went down too fast'' over the past couple of trading sessions, one London trader said. Traders said that comments by Saudi Arabian government officials, including King Fahd, suggesting that the kingdom hasn't abandoned its hard-line position against Iraq helped turn the market around. Oil's big plunge on Monday was largely attributed to comments from another ranking Saudi official that were seen as an indication Iraq might be able to keep some Kuwaiti territory in a negotiated settlement. Traders in New York said that despite the later Saudi statements, it would likely take a renewed threat of war to push prices up very far.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak To Unveil Systems To Bring Color Photos to Desktop Publishing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to update with announcement today; picks up 10th graf, Establishing a ...
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. is bringing its new photographic compact disc to desktop computer publishing with hopes the new technology will catch on with those who want to produce splashy documents with full color pictures and graphics. Kodak announced today a line of products and standards that will tie the CDs to the desktop publishing systems that have mushroomed in popularity in recent years. The announcement came a month after Kodak unveiled a system that stores photographs electronically on CDs and displays them on television screens. Kodak said it is teaming with a number of leading computer and software companies, including International Business Machines Corp., Apple Computer Inc. and Adobe Systems Inc., to help popularize the system. Kodak also announced a $1,500 color printer to be used to make paper copies of the photographs and text from IBM and Apple computers and compatible models. ``We see desktop color imaging to be a whole new industry,'' said John P. White, an executive at the Rochester-based company who is in charge of the new products. White said Monday the new desktop publishing system is the commercial version of the photo CD system announced in September. In that, amateur photographers would have their film developed and the images put on CDs by professional photo finishers. The photo CD system won't be available until 1992. Kodak apparently wanted to announce the software and other aspects of the commercial system in advance to get the computer industry prepared for the technology, said David Nelson, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Kodak also announced it has developed a standard for how colors are represented in digital form, or the ones and zeros of computer language. That is how photos and other data are stored on CDs and in computer memory. The standard is a mathematical representation of the colors. Establishing a standard is necessary step to ensure that an electronically stored photograph will have the same colors no matter what printer is used or on what computer screen it is displayed, experts say. ``It's something that's technical, but having the right colors is very, very important,'' Nelson said. With current technology, color reproduction varies so greatly from printer to printer that what appears as yellow on one machine could look more like brown on another, said John Warnock, chairman and chief executive of Adobe. ``This has been a huge problem,'' said Warnock, whose company's PostScript software established an industry standard for how printers print out pages of documents. By providing a standard for how colors are represented electronically, Kodak should help lower costs in the electronic use of color photographs, Nelson said. ``And lower cost attracts new products and new software, which makes color publishing easier to perform,'' he said. Kodak said the standard, along with software it will offer called color management tools, also will ensure that the color shown on a computer screen will be identical to the one printed out on a printer. Under today's technology that is not always the case. Kodak said its color-standard system is the first such specification for high-resolution color than spans the computer, broadcast and print media. Digitized color photographs require vast amounts of computer storage space. By putting this digital data on CDs, which have a large storage capacity, Kodak says it has eliminated another roadblock to greater use of color photos in computer software. In addition, it says, the photo CD technology provides higher-resolution images than traditional scanning devices used to change photographs into computer code. Kodak developed the photo CD technology in conjunction with N.V. Philips, the Dutch electronics giant. Kodak estimates the market for desktop color imaging will reach $5 billion by 1995, including hardware and software products.

DOC.HEAD: Senate in Long-Shot Bid to Override Bush Civil Rights Veto
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 6th graf to say vote not likely today. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Senate sponsors are launching a long-shot effort to override President Bush's veto of a major civil rights bill, which he says would encourage hiring quotas. But the bill's House sponsor, Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., acknowledged Monday that a new push for civil rights legislation likely will have to wait until next year. ``When the chips are down, the White House is against civil rights,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said following the veto. He called the action ``tragic and disgraceful.'' ``I deeply regret having to take this action,'' Bush said in his veto message. However, he said the measure would leave employers so vulnerable to discrimination suits they would hire by quota in self-defense. ``We think we'll win an override vote,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today. He said he hoped Congress would consider Bush's alternate civil rights proposal. ``If not, we'll do it next session,'' he said. Senate sponsors were shooting for a vote as early as Wednesday to override the president's veto and pass the bill over his objections. The timing of the vote still was uncertain. Hawkins said he would not seek a House override vote unless he was certain it would succeed. ``I'm just not going to waste any more time,'' he said, noting, ``I've been assured the bill will be introduced as soon as Congress meets next year.'' The bill was passed by the Senate, 62-34, and by the House, 273-154 - strong majorities, but not reaching the two-thirds required to override a veto. The measure, the civil rights community's top priority in Congress, would overturn six job bias decisions handed down by the Supreme Court last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in the most extreme cases of discrimination. The sharpest clashes, however, have come over provisions that would make it easier to win discrimination cases against employers. Bush said the ``temptation to support a bill - any bill - simply because its title includes the words `civil rights' is very strong. ``But when our efforts, however well-intentioned, result in quotas, equal opportunity is not advanced but thwarted,'' he said in his veto message. ``The very commitment to justice and equality that is offered as the reason why this bill should be signed requires me to veto it.'' The president said the ``bill actually employs a maze of highly legalistic language to introduce the destructive force of quotas into our nation's employment system.'' Under the measure, he said, ``employers will be driven to adopt quotas in order to avoid liability.'' Civil rights supporters scoffed at that argument. ``It's pure poppycock,'' said Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. ``The bill has nothing to do with quotas.'' ``The president's veto ... and his repeated efforts to pin the false label of quotas on this legislation are part of a disreputable tactic to appeal to public resentment and prejudice,'' Neas said. Bush called on lawmakers to enact his version of the measure before they quit for the year, probably later this week. However, that appeared unlikely, as Bush's critics said his proposal would weaken current law. Civil rights advocates denounced the president's proposal as a sham for permitting challenged hiring practices to stand if they could be justified on such grounds as ``customer relations.'' Such justifications, they said, were used to support the separate-but-equal ``Jim Crow'' laws of the first half of the 20th century that kept blacks in segregation. The White House plan would cap at $150,000 the total damages an employee could win in a job discrimination suit. As passed, the bill would allow unlimited compensatory damages in some cases and cap punitive damages at $150,000 or the total of compensatory damages plus back pay, whichever is greater. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said, ``The president's decision is disturbing and difficult to understand.'' He added that during negotiations on the measure, ``we often got the impression the White House staff was looking for excuses not to support this bill, rather than for ways to achieve a fair bill and a meaningful bill. Today that impression is all the stronger.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Auto Giant To Lay Off 70,000 Workers For a Week
DOC.TEXT: Italy's auto giant Fiat, faced with a sales slump, will lay off 70,000 workers for a week in late November, twice the number originally planned, the company said Tuesday. A spokesman for the Turin-based group said the temporary layoffs were designed to cut car production by 90,000 units by the end of 1990. Auto sales in Italy dropped 7.5 percent in September from a year earlier. But Fiat sources indicated that despite a recent slowdown in the domestic market, 1990 is expected to be a positive year for Fiat, with more than 2 million cars produced. The layoffs were announced for the plants at Mirafiori, Atese, Termini Imerese, Chivasso, Pomigliano D'Arco and Cassino. The highly automated Cassino plant produces the Tipo and Tempra models. Workers laid off will get about 90 percent of their salaries through a special state fund. Despite the announcement, Fiat shares closed higher on the Milan market, at 6,609 lire Tuesday from 6,544 the previous day. Some brokers speculated that the strength was mostly due to expectations that a long-expected announcement of a joint venture or commercial agreement with the U.S. group Chrysler may be coming soon.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used f0301, AM-S&Ls-Paul, 1st Ld-Writethru, sent Oct. 22 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on Oct. 22 that Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., received campaign contributions from David L. Paul, former chairman of the failed CenTrust Bank of Miami. Paul contributed to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee while Kerry was its chairman. A spokesman for Kerry, Michael Meehan, said Tuesday that Kerry's campaign has not received any money from Paul.

DOC.HEAD: GATT Chief, Chiding EC, Calls For Deep Farm Trade Reform
DOC.TEXT: The only satisfactory outcome of world trade-liberalizing talks is major cuts in government farm supports, the official overseeing the crisis-ridden talks said on Tuesday. Arthur Dunkel, director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, told a German audience that pressures for reform ``are growing from all sides and will not be held back by fine-tuning current policies or by tinkering at the margins of the problem.'' Dunkel urged ``a comprehensive reform program, extended over a reasonable period of time,'' including cuts in border restrictions and in domestic supports and export subsidies. His speech seemed designed to put pressure on the European Community, the only major group failing to meet an Oct. 15 deadline for offering farm support cuts in GATT, and on Germany, which most strongly opposes concessions. Divided European ministers have failed several times to agree on a proposed common position, and the rift over agriculture supports is threatening to derail the wide-ranging 4-year-old talks. Ministers from some 100 nations are scheduled to sign a package deal cutting trade barriers in 15 areas in early December. Dunkel, at a gathering of the Uebersee-Club in Hamburg, appealed to newly unified Germany to shoulder ``its responsibilities,'' saying its economic power depends on an open world trade system. Also Monday, a U.S. negotiator reiterated Washington's stand that only substantial farm trade reform can save the entire GATT talks from collapse. Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz said on a satellite interview program with European journalists that the farm talks are stalled and ``we have not yet had one serious day of negotiations on agriculture.''

Stock prices were mixed today as gains in the broader market outpaced blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had slipped about 20 points in the early going, was down 10.89 to 2,505.20 at midafternoon. The broader market continued to show resilience. Advancing issues were ahead of losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock going into this, I would definitely recommend they go to DeVoe's school,'' Tonkin said. DeVoe took his buy here-pay here concept a step further last year when he created J. D. Byrider Systems, a national buy here-pay here company with 20 dealer franchises from Wilmington, Del. to Greeley, Colo. Franchisees pay a $29,000 fee, a 3 percent royalty fee and 2 percent for advertising. ``With our experience in the business, many of the dealers could use more support, more training, field men, marketing programs done for them, etter operations manuals, and so we feel like there's a big potential in franchising,'' DeVoe said.

DOC.HEAD: Martin Marietta Net Income Up 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta Corp. on Tuesday reported a 25 percent gain in net income for the third quarter, with higher sales and earnings in every division but one. Third-quarter net income totaled $108.8 million, or $2.16 per share, up from $87.3 million or $1.65 in the same quarter last year. The per-share earnings reflect a reduction of 2.7 million outstanding shares as a result of a buyback program. Net sales rose 5 percent, from $1.42 billion to $1.49 billion. Martin Marietta said each of its operating groups had higher sales and income except the Electronic and Missiles division, whose projects include the Copperhead anti-tank projectile program and the Hellfire anti-armor missile. The company also said its quarterly income included one-time gains on the sale of Florida real estate, as well as a favorable court ruling involving the 1989 sale of a cement plant. Those gains amounted to 25 cents per share. For the year to date, net income rose 16 percent to $270 million, or $5.33 per share, compared to $233 million and $4.41 per share last year. Net sales for the nine-month period totaled $4.57 billion, up from $4.17 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Joseph Testified Against Former Junk Bond Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with morning testimony; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. chief Frederick Joseph testified against Michael Milken for the first time today and said a key 1985 investment by the junk-bond executive may have violated Drexel policies. Joseph took the stand as a government witness in Milken's pre-sentencing hearing on charges that the financier repeatedly broke the law as head of Drexel's high-yield bond department. The testimony focused on the $2.5 billion Drexel-financed leveraged buyout of Storer Communications Inc. by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. in late 1985. Prosecutors claim Milken misappropriated valuable Storer equity warrants, or rights to purchase Storer stock, and used them to bribe clients. According to the government, five Drexel-affiliated investment partnerships acquired 82 percent of the Storer warrants without legally disclosing the interests. A large block of preferred stock and warrants was repurchased by Drexel from a customer, Atlantic Capital, shortly after the Storer deal was completed. The block was, in turn, sold to one of the Drexel-formed investment partnerships. The partnership consisted of important Drexel clients, money fund managers, Drexel employees and a trust in the name ose-Winners, 2nd Add,400

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Cutting Flights from Twin Cities, Detroit, Memphis
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines will cut 28 of its 1,380 daily departures beginning Nov. 1 as part of an effort to offset the increase in jet fuel prices, the nation's fourth-largest carrier said Tuesday. The airline will eliminate its flight from Memphis to San Diego, spokesman Bob Gibbons said. The rest of the changes will reduce the number of flights between two locations. Northwest will cut flights from Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport to Memphis, Chicago's Midway Airport, Omaha, Neb, Fargo, N.D., and Louisville, Ky. The airline will also reduce flights from Detroit Metropolitan Airport to Milwaukee, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Boston, San Diego, Seattle, Kalamazoo and Lansing, Mich., and Columbus, Ohio. A number of airlines are cutting employees and services to reduce costs in the wake of increased jet fuel prices. Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi has said there will be layoffs at the Eagan-based carrier because of the fuel hikes, but no layoffs have been announced.

DOC.HEAD: ConAgra Plans to Acquire Elders IXL Assets
DOC.TEXT: ConAgra, Inc. said Tuesday that it has signed a letter of intent with Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia to acquire assets of several Elders companies. ConAgra said it plans to acquire assets of Elders Brewing Materials and Elders International Wool Division, as well as a 50 percent interest in Elders Meat Division. Elders IXL, based in Melbourne, Australia, is an international agribusiness and brewing company. ConAgra, an international food company with annual sales of $20 billion, said it plans to invest $175 million in the transaction. The deal is subject to reaching of a definitive agreement, approval by the ConAgra and Elders IXL boards of directors and government review, ConAgra said. Elders Meat is a major Australian beef processor. Elders Brewing Materials makes malt for brewers in Australia and international markets. Elders International Wool is a trader and processor of wool in Australia and New Zealand, and is a leading exporter of Australian wool. Combined sales of the three businesses total about $1 billion, ConAgra said.

The stock market was mixed today despite losses among selected blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had slipped about 20 points in the early going, was down 8.17 to 2,507.92 an hour before the closing bell. The broader market showed significant resilience even while blue chips were fading. Advancing issues were ahead of losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues by about 7 to 5, with 865 up, 614 down and 455 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 118.24 million shares as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. As expected, the market opened on a soft note. ``You're bound to get a little profit-taking'' after such a sharp runup, said Alfred E. Goldman, a vice president with A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. ``A day of consolidation is natural after the big jump up last week,'' he said referring to the 120-point advance in the Dow for the week ended Friday. Crude oil prices, which lost more than $5 a barrel on Monday, were mixed to lower today, but the decline had limited impact on equities even though cheaper energy prices signal an easing of inflationary pressures. Oil prices ``are still higher than four months ago,'' Goldman noted. Among actively traded Big Board issues, Citicorp was down { at 12{; Philip Morris was off ] at 48[; General Electric was up } at 54{, and Boeing was down 1 at 47{. Disney, which said it will receive $600 million in Japanese-backed financing, jumped 1} to 97|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped 0.16 to 171.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 293.38, up 1.15.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Net Drops 40 Percent With Sale Of Fisher-Price
DOC.TEXT: The Quaker Oats Co. on Tuesday reported a 40 percent drop in net income for the first quarter of its fiscal year, noting the costs of spinning off its Fisher-Price toy division. Quaker's net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 fell to $33.2 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $55.7 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Quaker is in the process of spinning Fisher Price off to shareholders. Fisher-Price accounted for $16.1 million of Quaker's net income in the first quarter of 1989. Excluding fiscal 1989 earnings from the toy company, Quaker's net income fell about 16 percent. The company blamed the weaker performance on lower sales in Brazil and increased spending for international marketing of its Gatorade drink. First-quarter sales rose 9 percent to $1.33 billion from $1.21 billion, the Chicago-based company said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Rally, Lifting Grain Futures
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late, technically inspired rally that helped boost corn prices. Wheat futures finished narrowly mixed. Soybean futures bounced back after the November contract failed to penetrate a three-week low of $6.05 a bushel. ``The fact that it held there spurred short-covering toward the end of the day and that's what rallied us into the close,'' said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Short-covering occurs when traders buy back contracts that they previously sold on expectations the market would fall. Corn futures drew additional support from indications the Soviet Union is preparing to buy more foreign grain. Analysts said harvest pressure on the corn and soybean markets is beginning to ease now that the harvest has passed the halfway point. At the close, wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.63\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.31{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1} cents lower with December at $1.24\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 6{ cents higher with November at $6.14{ a bushel.
