DOC.HEAD: Most Japanese Shrug Off Stock Plunge, But Corporate Strains Surface
DOC.TEXT: Japan's economy, dizzied by a $2 trillion loss on the Tokyo Stock Exchange over nine months, seems to have landed squarely on its feet. By most accounts, consumers have shrugged off the vanished assets as easy come-easy go. A leading think tank's Gross National Product projection for fiscal 1990 actually was revised upward earlier this month, to 4.8 percent economic growth from 4.6 percent. Retail sales in Septembr rose from a year ago, with luxury purchases leading the list. And Tokyo's notoriously high land prices, the bellwether most look to for recessionary signs, show little slippage. ``The average Japanese family has over 11 million yen (about $85,000) in the bank,'' said Mark Yim, senior analyst at Baring Securities. ``They have so much wealth anyway, the decline doesn't matter that much.'' However, the selling spree that nearly halved the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average from a peak of 38,915.87 in December to above 25,000 this fall has put a strain on some corporations, who have had to cope with big paper losses. Most of the market's stock is held by large Japanese corporations and banks. Businesses with huge cash surpluses had fed the five-year stock boom preceding the fall. But higher interest rates, the primary cause of the slump, and corporate paper losses is putting a crimp in investment. Some economic slowdown is expected, although not a recession. By early last week, the Nikkei index stood at around 25,300 points following several consecutive gains. Some analysts, however, have said it could sink as low as 16,000 before the growth ``bubble'' swelled by Japan's liquid wealth finally deflates completely. Whatever the bottom, the slump's suddenness has helped mark Tokyo's rite of passage from a clubby, protected market designed to engineer Japan's postwar regrowth to more of a Western-style financial free-for-all, analysts say. One sign has been a fraying of the tight corporate ties and rigid government control that as recently as a decade ago made Japan's financial markets nearly impenetrable to foreigners. The Tokyo stock market was once considered stable partly because a majority of stocks were never traded. Corporate shares were ``cross-held'' by large institutional investors such as banks, whose stocks in turn sat in the permanent accounts of other huge corporations. All had an unspoken agreement to weather the volatilities of the market. But banks, battered by high interest rates, were forced to sell corporate stock to maintain income levels. The companies reciprocated by dumping the bank stock. As a result, since the beginning of the year, the share prices of Japan's top 21 regional banks have fallen by more than 50 percent, according to Paul Heaton, senior research analyst at W. I. Carr. ``It's a case of enough is enough,'' Heaton said. ``You don't mind holding stock if it falls 15 percent . . . but if other companies with which you've maintained a business relationship sell your stock you're going to wonder what's the purpose of holding theirs, especially in an era when bonds are better.'' Many such relationships, nurtured in postwar years when capital was scarce, had become inefficient and unprofitable anyway, analysts say. ``This kind of slump gives banks and large companies a convenient excuse to really go for globalization,'' said Kuniko Inoguchi, a political economist at Sophia University. ``Now they can try what they have had in mind for the last two years or so, to go beyond the traditional structure of cross-shareholding and closed business practices.'' With the growth of Japan into the world's premier banking nation, ``there's greater opportunity abroad than in traditional commitments,'' she said. ``And they've discovered they can win the global competition.'' Encouraging these changes have been the twin levers of financial deregulation and foreign participation. Since the mid-1980s, new instruments such as futures trading in government bonds and stock indexes, as well as a loosening of notoriously low, uniform interest rates on some deposits and money funds, have helped pry oen the black box of Japanese finance. The number of foreign members on the exchange has grown to more than 20 since 1986, when they were first allowed. ``The Tokyo stock market has grown transparent,'' said Warwick Jones, a vice president at Merrill Lynch Japan. ``In the future it may look a lot more like other markets.'' Analysts say deregulation, particularly in interest rates, was largely responsible for the unprecedented price fluctuations seen during the market slide. The recent drop in U.S. stock prices had been precipitated by panic selling, spurred by daily reports of the Persian Gulf crisis or economic worries. Higher interest rates tend to make bonds and money market instruments more attractive, triggering a flight from stocks. The rate increases are themselves a symptom of Japan's continuing economic expansion - now in its fourth year - and the government's need to tamp down the resulting inflationary pressures. The Bank of Japan has raised its benchmark discount rate, or the interest charged to member banks, five times since last May to the current 6 percent. That touched off higher market rates already aggravated by a worldwide capital shortage stemming from investment demand in Eastern Europe and the U.S. budget deficit. ``It's quite rational,'' said Toshio Suzuki, a top executive at Nomura Research Institute. The Ministry of Finance, traditionally as protective of the market as a finicky mother hen, plans no further stablization measures beyond several that produced a record one-day surge Oct. 2, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``What we see at the moment is a gradual stabilization,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday, Oct. 29

DOC.HEAD: UPS Heats Up Competition on Overnight Deliveries
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service said Tuesday it's moving head-first into the overnight delivery market, bringing heavy competition to overnight leader Federal Express Corp. UPS, the world's largest package delivery company, announced this week two services that match Federal Express - guaranteed 10:30 a.m. delivery of overnight packages and same-day pickup. With both companies touting their reliability and delivery expertise, the big difference appears to be price. The average shipper pays $11 for UPS to pick up and deliver an overnight envelope; Federal Express charges $15.50 for the same service. If a customer drops off the envelope a UPS facility, it costs $8.50 for overnight delivery; at Federal Express, it's $13. The UPS move is aimed directly at those customers who took their overnight business to Federal Express because it was faster, said Alan Caminiti, a spokesman for the Greenwich, Conn.-based company. UPS used to offer delivery by noon and couldn't pick up a package until the day after a customer called. ``We knew that this is what we needed to compete in this market,'' Caminiti said. So far, Federal Express is unfazed. ``They're basically playing catch-up,'' said spokeswoman Shirlee Finley, whose Memphis, Tenn.-based company opened the doors to overnight delivery in 1979 and added 10:30 a.m. delivery in 1983. ``We founded the market and pretty well set the industry standards,'' she said. ``It's not surprising that once again our competitors have followed the lead.'' Federal Express doesn't plan to lower its prices, she said, and isn't worried about losing customers to UPS. But analysts said that might just be wishful thinking. ``Federal will either see an erosion in their volume or may have to do something on price - or both,'' said Paul Schlesinger, a transportation analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. ``Any competition will have some impact on Federal Express' results,'' said John E. Hilton, an analyst with Argus Research Corp. ``While at this point the impact is not quantifiable, we do expect it to crimp Federal Express' earnings growth rate slightly.'' Finley said Federal Express, which delivers about 1.5 million packages a day, commands 40 percent to 50 percent of the $8 billion overnight delivery market. UPS, which began overnight delivery service in 1982, delivers about half that number of parcels through air delivery, Caminiti said. Caminiti said UPS has hired hundreds of part-time drivers to handle the extra load from the 10:30 a.m. deliveries. The company's shaky contract talks with the Teamster's union in August centered on the issue of hiring the extra part-time drivers for the new service, he said.

DOC.HEAD: GE Transportation Gets Locomotive Contract
DOC.TEXT: GE Transportation Systems of Erie has received a three-year, $200 million contract from CSX Transportation Inc. to build 150 locomotives, officials said Tuesday. The agreement calls for the delivery of 50 locomotives each year from 1991 to 1993, said Jerry R. Davis, president of CSX Rail Transport, the operating arm of CSX Transportation. The order is for GE's newest 4,000 horsepower, six-axle Dash 8-40C locomotive. The new units, expected to haul general merchandise and coal, will be added to the railroad's fleet of 147 GE Dash 8 locomotives. CSX Transportation already has the largest fleet of GE locomotives operating in the United States. CSX Transportation provides rail transportation and distribution services over a 19,200-mile rail network in 20 states, the District of Columbia and Ontario.

DOC.HEAD: Disney to Get $600 Million From Japanese Investors to Make Movies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix garble in 7th graf
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. said Tuesday it formed a film production financing partnership worth at least $600 million, backed largely by Japanese investors. For five years, Disney has limited its filmmaking risk - along with its potential profits - by raising about $1 billion through limited partnerships mainly with U.S. investors. The last of those, Silver Screen IV, will conclude as planned, Disney said. Then the new partnership, Touchwood Pacific Partners I, will become the main source of finance for all live-action films at Disney's three studios, Disney, Touchstone and Hollywood Pictures. ``The whole film business has been becoming more global,'' said Disney spokesman Erwin Okun. ``And, frankly, the Japanese provided better terms.'' The deal is another example of Hollywood's allure for the Japanese. Last year, Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. for $3.4 billion and Victor Co. of Japan agreed to invest $100 million in Largo Entertainment, a film company headed by former 20th Century Fox President Lawrence Gordon. Recently, MCA Inc. has been talking with Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. about a buyout worth as much as $8.6 billion. And just last month, Disney reached an agreement for a unit of Nomura Securities to provide up to $200 million in financing over four years for movies made for Disney by Interscope, an independent production company. The latest Disney deal marks the largest infusion yet of Japanese money into a major Hollywood studio short of acquisition. Touchwood Pacific is a U.S. partnership. Its $600 million financing, however, will be based on $180 million raised from Japanese investors who buy limited partnerships through an affiliate of Yamaichi Securities, a leading Japanese securities firm. In addition to that equity, another $420 million will take the form of a line of credit from a consortium of banks led by Citicorp's Citibank. Banks involved include The Fuji Bank Ltd., The Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Disney, Touchstone and Hollywood Pictures together plan to produce about 25 films a year. The average film costs about $25 million to produce and nearly that much to promote and distribute. The Wall Street Journal, in a report on the financing Tuesday, quoted some industry observers as saying the transaction would be the largest single such financing in Hollywood history and that the final figure could be closer to $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: East Europe And Third World Battered By Oil Price Hike From Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. official Tuesday proposed a moratorium on debt ollection from those countries hit hardest by the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Prospects for the developing countries as a whole are worsening because of the slowdown in the growth of industrial countries' economies, the increase in interest rates and the rise in the price of oil,'' said Bettino Craxi, the former Italian premier and U.N. special representative on debt. The Gulf conflict, he told the General Assembly's Second Committee, which deals with economics, ``is likely to produce increased poverty and environmental degradation.'' The rise in oil prices caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will cripple the weak economies of Eastern Europe and the non-oil-producing Third World countries, according to a U.N. study. Craxi said the oil price hike will cause a stagnating or negative growth rate for many African countries, and will produce major new debtors among low-income South Asian nations, which so far have escaped serious debt problems. Eastern European nations will suffer severe balance-of-payment problems, and foreign aid will be reduced to highly indebted countries that export oil, such as Mexico and Nigeria. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar appointed Craxi last December as his special representative on the debt problem, which is retarding development in almost half the countries of the world. ``It is estimated that if prices vary between $30 and $40 a barrel in 1991, the oil-importing developing countries will be facing an oil import bill ranging between $45 billion to $60 billion,'' said Rafeeuddin Ahmed, the undersecretary-general for international economic and social affairs. ``For many of these countries, this will be an unbearable additional burden,'' he said. Some developing countries - those that produce oil - will reap additional billions from the price hikes, Ahmed's report says. Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, excluding Iraq and Kuwait, which are under a U.N. economic embargo, will gain $88 billion in windfall revenues if the price stays at $30 per barrel. The OPEC winners are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela. Iran alone would gain $9.8 billion in additional revenues. Non-OPEC oil-exporting countries would gain $14.6 billion. Those countries are Angola, Brunei, China, Colombia, Egypt, Malaysia, Mexico, Oman, Syria, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Yemen, and a handful of minor exporters. The poor Third World countries without oil resources hoped the oil producers would share some of their wealth, but so far no formal steps toward that goal have been taken. Kuwait's government-in-exile and Egypt, however, are considering asking the General Assembly to urge wealthy nations to share their windfall with the impoverished countries. Sub-Saharan Africa will be one of the regions ``devastated'' by the oil price hike, U.N. officials say. Consumption of oil in the region is expected to fall by about 30 percent, smashing an economy that is 70 percent dependent on oil for its productive output. The oil cutbacks will cause power stations, factories and mines to close, slowing growth and further eroding living standards. Eastern Europe once depended on cheap oil from the Soviet Union, but with the breakup of the Eastern Bloc, the Soviets now sell their oil at market prices, even to their former client states. U.S. President George Bush has said he will push the World Bank to arrange loans worth $5 billion to assist Eastern Europe. But several nations there have already appealed to the Security Council's sanctions committee for relief, citing cumulative losses that nerly equal that amount. Most Latin American nations, already burdened by a crushing foreign debt, will also see their economies staggered by the oil price shock. Among the South American countries with significant extra costs are Brazil and Chile.

DOC.HEAD: Comptroller Delivers Harsh Message to Bankers
DOC.TEXT: In a break with the dogged optimism of the American Bankers Association convention, Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke Tuesday chastised the industry fr bringing upon itself a decline in public confidence. Clarke, the nation's top bank regulator, told the ABA the industry's reputation is at its lowest level in 50 years. ``Bankers don't have a reservoir of public goodwill from which to draw,'' Clarke said. ``This is a harsh assessment ... but this is not a time to be kidding ourselves.'' The ABA meeting is taking place as the industry grapples with a slumping economy, anxiety over loan losses and political fallout from the savings and loan crisis. But banking leaders have maintained that the industry overall is strong and able to withstand the current downslide. Clarke suggested the industry will have further difficulties if it does not shore up its standing with the general public and legislators. ``Your public image is likely to determine the outcome of legislative debates next year on the future of banking,'' he said. Clarke said many bankers have lost sight of basics such as sound lending practices, diversification of risks and long-term vision. ``Recent experience has again brought home the lesson that there is no substitute for following the fundamentals,'' Clarke said. ``But, as banking's current reputation proves, profound damage occurs from the failure to follow it.'' Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman, who followed Clarke on the ABA agenda, gave the convention a somewhat more hopeful view. But Seidman told reporters later he agreed with Clarke. ``I think everything Mr. Clarke said was true,'' Seidman said. ``I cannot erase from my mind President Carter's `malaise' speech. The question to me is whether too much emphasis on the down side doesn't tend to depress us all. But I don't disagree with anything he said.'' In his speech, Seidman said the federal deposit insurance fund is capable now of covering any forseeable bank losses and remaining solvent. But further erosion of the economy could change that, he said. ``Your bank insurance fund is under stress and unfortunately I cannot report that any improvement is likely in the near future,'' said Seidman, who is in the final year of his term as FDIC chairman. ``You may think that we at the FDIC have the most pressing interest in seeing the insurance fund remain sound, but that's not true. It is you, the good bankers who will pay if we can't succeed in dealing with our losses,'' Seidman said. The Bush administration has predicted that bank failures will reduce the FDIC's commercial bank fund by more than $6 billion over the next three years. Clarke said banking is at a crucial crossroads, and is dealing from a position of weakness. He said there are those in Washington who feel there is nothing sacred about banking and would not hesitate to let the industry fall by the wayside. That element, Clarke said, argues that with the exception of federal deposit insurance, other financial institutions now offer every service that once was the exclusive province of banking. To maintain the existing banking system, he said, the industry needs a combination of legislation making it more competitive and regulations that provide less opportunity for banks to get into trouble.

DOC.HEAD: General Cinema To Scale Back Operations
DOC.TEXT: General Cinema Corp., one of the nation's largest movie theater chains, announced plans Tuesday to scale back its operations. The company will sell or close about 20 theaters, consolidate several field offices and eliminate 85 jobs, a company official said. General Cinema estimates the theater division will lose $11 million in the fiscal year ending Oct. 31, said Peter Farwell, vice president for corporate relations. ``Our goal with this program is to return it to profitability by 1991,'' Farwell said. He said no decision has been made as to which theaters will be sold or closed, but most would be in the South. General Cinema operates 1,498 movie screens at 313 locations in 32 states. Its payroll includes 2,500 full-time employees, including 200 at its headquarters in the Boston suburb of Chestnut Hill. General Cinema also owns 60 percent of The Neiman Marcus Group, whose specialty retail holdings include the Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman department stores, as well as Contempo Casuals. Restructuring in the theater division will not affect those operations, company officials said. Earlier this month, General Cinema sold its investment in Cadbury Schweppes, resulting in an after-tax gain of more than $80 million, or $1.10 per share, in its fourth quarter. With the restructuring and the sale of the Cadbury Schweppes shares, General Cinema expects to report net fourth-quarter earnings of more than $50 million, or about 70 cents per share. For the fourth quarter of fiscal 1989, General Cinema had earnings of $7.9 million, or 10 cents per share.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Profit at $248 Million in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. reported a third-quarter profit of $248 million or $6.46 a share on Tuesday, with nearly all of it due to a one-time $234 million gain from a pension-fund change. The company also reversed all of its earnings on the C-17 transport aircraft program, which resulted in a one-time charge of $93 million to cover the elimination of previously reported earnings dating back to 1985. McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest defense contractor, now estimates it won't make any money on the $6 billion C-17 project, which is scheduled for a first flight in June of next year and completion in 1994. ``Backing out the unusual items, these earnings were surprisingly stronger than expected,'' said Howard Rubel, a stock analyst for C.J. Lawrence in New York. ``The C-17 is a disappointment, but hopefully this is a clear-the-decks approach and let's go from here.'' The big gain involving the pension fund came after McDonnell Douglas executives decided to dissolve the company's plan covering 14,000 retired salaried employees and replace it with an annuity sold by Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Without the two unusual items, the company would have reported a profit of $72 million, or $1.87 a share, in the quarter. In last year's third quarter, McDonnell Douglas had a profit of $38 million, or 98 cents a share. Sales in the quarter were $4.17 billion, up 12 percent from $3.70 billion for the same period a year ago. McDonnell Douglas, headquartered in St. Louis, makes aircraft for the Air Force, the Navy and the Marines, as well as missiles and space systems. The company is also the second-biggest maker of commercial aircraft. ``There was continued improvement in the operation of all of our businesses,'' said John McDonnell, chairman and chief executive officer. ``For most of them, the third quarter was better than the second and the second was better than the first. And our results to date this year are far better than last year.'' All of the company's businesses had improved profits during the quarter ended Sept. 30, except the transport aircraft division based in Long Beach, Calif., which is still racking up losses. Last year, the transport division underwent a major reorganization, but still ended up with a loss of $222 million for the year. In the most recent quarter, the transport segment had a loss of $98 million. For the first nine months, McDonnell Douglas had a profit of $307 million, or $8.00 a share, compared with $159 million, or $4.16 a share, for the same period in 1989. Sales were $12.12 billion vs. $10.29 billion for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Seeks to Force Polly Peck Into Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: A bank has moved to force the troubled British congomerate Polly Peck International PLC into bankruptcy proceedings, the bankruptcy court said Tuesday. The National Bank of Canada filed a petition with the London court on Monday against the food and electronics conglomerate, which has been suffering a severe liquidity freeze, the court said. The petition effectively asked the court to place the company in receivership so that its assets can be liquidated to meet debt payments. A hearing was scheduled for Dec. 12. Bankers speculated that the National Bank of Canada's move was designed to set out its claims against Polly Peck in the event of a rush by creditors. The hearing falls more than a month after a debt-payment standstill agreement between Polly Peck and its key lenders expires Nov. 9. A Polly Peck spokesman declined to comment on the filing, and officials at National Bank of Canada's London branch office weren't immediately available to comment. Polly Peck needs about 100 million pounds, the equivalent of $194 million, in short-term financing to get it through its liquidity squeeze, sources have said. Asil Nadir, Polly Peck's chairman and chief executive, has been visiting Turkey and northern Cyprus in search of financial support. Polly Peck's troubles began Sept. 20 when it suspended trading in its shares on London's Stock Exchange after the collapse of its stock price. The collapse followed news of a British fraud office raid of a company associated with Nadir. British press reports have said the office is investigating allegations of a share support scheme in Polly Peck stock.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Company Seeking Permission For Iraqi Oil
DOC.TEXT: Coastal Corp. has received permission from the U.S. government to import as much as 2.6 million barrels of Iraqi crude oil. But the company must obtain permission from the Saudi Arabian government to bring the light-grade oil to Corpus Christi, said company spokesman Jim Bailey. The Saudi government opposes the release of the oil, worth about $75 million, and is hesitant to make exceptions to the United Nations embargo, which prohibits trade with Iraq and Kuwait, Bailey said Monday. Coastal claims it should be allowed to purchase the oil because it was exported from Iraq to Saudi Arabia through a pipeline in July, before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The company must reach an agreement with the Saudis by the end of the month because the Treasury Department permit requires the oil to be delivered to the United States by Dec. 15 and oil shipments from the Middle East take about 45 days to reach the Gulf Coast. The company would pay for the oil through an escrow account that would allow access by the U.S. government but not the Iraqis, Bailey said. ``None of (the money) would go to the Iraqis,'' he said. ``It is in the best interest of the United States because we could use the crude.'' The light crude would allow his company to make fuel for the military, Bailey said. ``It is really in the best interest of Saudi Arabia as well,'' he added. The U.S. Customs Service seized a shipload of Iraqi crude at the Port of Corpus Christi only two days after the Aug. 2 invasion. The 479,000 barrels were to be refined at Coastal's refinery here. Customs officials released the oil the next day after determining it was bought before the embargo was implemented. Britain has granted Coastal a waiver to import the oil because Coastal's trading subsidiary is headquartered in Bermuda, a British colony, Bailey said.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Earnings Up for Northern Telecom
DOC.TEXT: Northern Telecom reported an increase in third-quarter net earnings Tuesday and predicted continued strong growth for the rest of 1990. The telecommunications company said net earnings rose to $97.7 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to $80.1 million in the 1989 period. Earnings per share rose to 38 cents, up 23 percent from 31 cents in the same period last year. Third-quarter revenues increased 14 percent to $1.62 billion vs. $1.41 billion reported for the same three months of 1989. Northern Telecom Inc. is the Nashville-based U.S. subsidiary of Northern Telecom Limited, which is headquartered in Toronto. The company said revenues from all geographic areas increased in both the quarter and first nine months, with international revenues continuing to lead in year-over-year percentage gains. Central office switching remained Northern Telecom's most profitable product line, and revenues from transmission products showed the largest percentage increase overall. ``The strong results for the third quarter and first nine months lead us to remain optimistic that 1990 will be a year of record performance for Northern Telecom,'' said Paul G. Stern, company chairman, president and chief executive officer. Net earnings for the first nine months were $272.5 million or $1.05 per share, up from $208 million or 80 cents per share in the 1989 period. Revenues for the first nine months were $4.89 billion, up 13 percent from $4.32 billion last year. Northern Telecom sells digital telecommunications systems and provides products and services to telephone operating companies and other institutions. It has more than 49,000 employees worldwide.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market lost ground Tuesday after struggling to hold onto spotty gains for most of the session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 22.03 points to close at 2,494.06. Advancing issues narrowly outnumbered losers by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 821 up, 695 down and 455 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 146.30 million shares, down from 152.65 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 177.02 million shares. As expected, the market opened on a soft note as traders continued to take selective profits following the 122-point runup in the Dow late last week. The key index flirted with postive territory before taking a decisive move lower in the final half hour of trading. Continued haggling over the federal budget continued to weigh on the market. Shortly before the market closed, New Mexico Sen. Pete Domenici, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, said that an ``understanding'' on a deficit-reduction package appeared lost. Other lawmakers also commented that much remains to be resolved on the tax portion of the bill. Without a budget agreement, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to lower interest rates. The stock market generally benefits when the Fed eases credit because costs for businesses are reduced. Separately, investors were uninspired by a further decline in the price of crude oil. The December contract for light, sweet crude lost more than $1 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, settling at $29.37. But analysts said that since the Middle East crisis remains unresolved, market players are keenly aware that prices could spike higher at a moment's notice. Among investors, there is a ``recalcitrance, a tentativeness because they just want to feel more comfortable that we've gotten some of these problems behind us,'' said Hugh Johnson, a senior vice president at First Albany Corp. He said that ``any move upward in (stock) prices will be very labored as long as these problems are not resolved.'' Among atively traded Big Board issues, Citicorp was down ] at 12| a day after the banking concern had difficulty selling an issue of preferred stock. Also in the financial sector, C&S Sovran plummeted 2] to 16\; an investment firm downgraded the stock and lowered its earnings estimates for the concern. Elsewhere, Philip Morris was down { at 48; Bristol-Myers Squibb was off [ at 62|; MCA was up 1| at 58~, and IBM was down 1 at 106}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $10.99 billion, or 0.38 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.03 to 170.50. Standard & Poor's industrial index lost 2.70 to 367.19, and S&P's 500-stock composite index closed at 312.36, down 2.40. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 0.03 to 341.09. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 292.97, up 0.74.

DOC.HEAD: Equitable Names New President
DOC.TEXT: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States on Tuesday named Joseph J. Melone, president of Prudential Insurance Co., as its new president and chief operating oficer. Melone, 59, will start Nov. 5, said Richard H. Jenrette, Equitable's chairman and chief executive officer. Jenrette had held the title of president before the announcement. Melone joined Prudential in 1968 as executive director of marketing, and has been its president since 1984. Prudential is the largest insurance company in the United States. Equitable is the third-largest U.S. life insurance company, with total assets of $135 billion.

DOC.HEAD: GD, Westinghouse Picked to Make Magnets for Supercollider
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp. and Westinghouse Electric Corp. have been chosen to compete for a $200 million contract to design and manufacture magnets for the superconducting super collider. Roy F. Schwitters, director of the Super Collider Laboratory, said the General Dynamics' Space Systems Division in San Diego, Calif., has been chosen as the leader for the project. Also chosen was Westinghouse's Collider Dipole Division of Orlando, Fla., Schwitters said in a statement released Tuesday. General Dynamics will produce prototype magnets for test and evaluation. Each firm will then produce 35 preproduction magnets, which the Super Collider Laboratory will start testing and evaluating in 1993. Both companies will later produce 251 magnets each to be installed in the super collider's particle accelerator. The firms will then compete for a production order for the remaining 8,200 superconducting magnets, each of which will be about 52 feet long and weigh about 25,000 pounds. The magnets will guide beams of high energy protons around the accelerator's rings at the speed of light and bring them into collisions where detectors will record the results, enabling scientists to learn more about the nature of energy and matter. The super collider is to be built 30 miles south of Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Stop Falling as Market Regroups
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices stabilized Tuesday after a record drop the day before took futures prices below $30 per barrel. Light sweet crude for December delivery settled at $29.37 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down $1.04 from the previous day's December bid. But that price was about $1 higher than the mark set by the expired November contract, which plummeted a record $5.41 to $28.38 on its last day of trading Monday. December contracts did not fall as far as November on Monday because of daily limits imposed by the exchange on contracts beyond the near month. The December contract was pressured lower Tuesday to narrow that gap, butanalysts were not sure whether to characterize the move as an increase or a decrease. ``It's tricky,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Stabilization is the best word.'' January and February crude contracts fell along with December, but later contract months were higher. ``We're having a little bit of confusion,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``They're not exactly sure where they want to take the market.'' Those following crude prices said the market was definitely viewing peace in the Persian Gulf as more likely than war. Crude's record fall Monday occurred as traders responded to news of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein having a dream in which a prophet told him his rockets were pointed in the wrong direction. Prices also had fallen on statements from a ranking Saudi official that were construed as indicating Iraq might be able to keep some Kuwaiti territory in a negotiated settlement to the crisis. Refined petroleum products recovered some ground from Monday's plunge, moving higher for next month delivery, with later months mixed. Home heating oil was 5.08 cents higher at 81.06 cents per gallon for November delivery. Contracts for subsequent months were mixed. Unleaded gasoline was 3.40 cents higher at 79.90 cents per gallon for November delivery, with later months trading mostly lower. Natural gas prices were higher Tuesday, rising 1.5 cents to $2.52 per 1,000 cubic feet for December delivery. Other contract months moved up as well.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Strengthens
DOC.TEXT: The dollar traded mostly higher against other major currencies Tuesday, rising most strongly against the Japanese yen after the Federal Reserve sold yen to buy dollars, traders said. Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold climbed $1.60 to close at $371.20 an ounce. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold at $371.25 an ounce, up $1.75, at 4 p.m. EDT. Traders said the Fed sold an undetermined amount of yen for dollars, apparently at the request of a customer such as another central bank. Traders said the sale was not believed to be an attempt by the Fed to affect the value of the dollar against the yen. However, Greg Scarola, a trader with PaineWebber International Ltd., said the sale apparently contributed to the dollar's strong showing against the Japanese currency. But John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said the dollar had firmed against the yen in overseas trading before the New York market opened, and the Fed's purchase of dollars with yen might have had little effect on the market. To boost the value of the dollar the Fed often buys the currency with other currencies in order to decrease the amount of dollars in circulation. The dollar rose against several other major currencies as well. McCarthy said the dollar managed to shrug off what otherwise might have been bad news for the currency, including growing signs of a peaceful resolution to the Iraqi standoff. He said the dollar was boosted by technical factors. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 127.13 Japanese yen from 126.25 yen Monday. Later, in London, it rose to 127.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.15 yen, up from 126.02 late Monday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9461 from $1.9495 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9435, cheaper than $1.9455 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Monday, included: 1.5180 German marks, down from 1.5182; 1.2817 Swiss francs, down from 1.2835; 5.0820 French francs, up from 5.0815; 1,137.25 Italian lire, up from 1,137.00; and 1.1721 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17605. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: 1.5175 German marks, up from 1.5135; 1.2810 Swiss francs, up from 1.2800; 5.0700 French francs, up from 5.0662; 1.7098 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7060; 1,136.50 Italian lire, up from 1,134.25; 1.1708 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1725. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $371.75 troy ounce, up from $367.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $371.40, from $369.00 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, it was up 23 cents to $371.59. Silver bullion settled at $4.219 a troy ounce on the Comex, up from $4.194 late Monday. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid price of $4.24 a troy ounce, from $4.21.

DOC.HEAD: RJR Nabisco Results Improve in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Inc. reported improved third-quarter results Tuesday showing reduced losses following the food and tobacco conglomerate's $25 billion leveraged buyout. RJR Nabisco recorded a loss of $86 million, down 81 percent from a $447 million loss in the same period a year earlier. The company said its operating income rose 56 percent to $706 million from $452 million in the third quarter of 1989, while its revenue rose to $3.53 billion from nearly $3 billion the previous year. The firm also reported its cash flow - the key figure for companies paying down high debt levels - at $886 million for the quarter. The company's interest expenses fell to $845 million from $983 million. RJR Nabisco went private in early 1989 in the largest debt-financed buyout and corporate acquisition ever. Since then, the company, like other firms saddled with billions of dollars in liabilities, has been watched closely to see whether it could generate enough earnings to pay down its debts. Analysts said Tuesday they were pleased with the company's performance, although some of the numbers were skewed by several one-time items. For instance, the company's results in the latest quarter were boosted by a $108 million gain from RJR Nabisco's purchase of junk bonds. The buyback is part of a recapitalization announced earlier this year. RJR Nabisco's tobacco operating income rose more than 51 percent to $683 million from $451 million in the third quarter of 1989. The gain was due in part to an inventory reduction program that depressed third-quarter 1989 tobacco sales. Tobacco revenue rose to $2.11 billion in the latest quarter from $1.55 billion in the 1989 period. Despite such extraordinary items, RJR Nabisco's results were very good and slightly better than expected, said Becky Barfield, an analyst with First Boston Corp. who described RJR Nabisco as ``on track to slightly ahead'' of itsggoals. Jack Maxwell, an analyst with Wheat, First Securities Inc. in Richmond, Va., called RJR Nabisco's results excellent and said of its cash flow for the quarter, ``That's really fantastic.'' RJR Nabisco said earnings from its food business rose nearly 6 percent to $197 million from $186 million a year earlier. Food revenue fell to $1.42 billion from $1.45 billion in third-quarter 1989. The year-earlier results included sales from RJR Nabisco's Baby Ruth and Butterfinger candy business and its Chun King oriental foods business, which were later sold. For the first nine months of the year, RJR Nabisco reported a loss of $416 million, down from $1.01 billion in the same period of 1989. Operating income during the period was up 46 percent to $2.04 billion from $1.40 billion, and revenue rose to $10.19 billion from $9.23 billion. Under the recapitalization announced last summer, RJR Nabisco is retiring a large part of the $6 billion in junk bonds used to take the firm private. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., which arranged the buyout, gave the food and tobacco a $1.7 billion equity infusion and negotiated bank loans to pay for the repurchase of the bonds. By lowering its debt, RJR Nabisco is reducing its interest expenses and making itself less vulnerable to the problems that have handicapped other highly-leveraged firms in recent years. RJR Nabisco's tobacco brands, produced by its R.J. Reynolds Tobacco units, include Winston, Salem and Camel. Its food products are manufactured by Nabisco Brands Inc. and Planters LifeSavers Co. and include Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers and Planters nuts.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Surge on Reduced Recession Fears
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices surged Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange in a powerful rally ignited by fading recession fears and fanned by computer-generated buying. On other commodity markets, platinum led the precious metals higher; oil futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Copper futures settled 3.55 cents to 5.2 cents higher with the contract for spot delivery at $1.322 a pound. The rally marked copper's fourth straight daily advance after the spot price touched a three-month low of $1.2315 last Wednesday. Analysts said the recent decline reflected pessimism about the economy and perceptions that industrial demand for copper would slacken in a recession. But recession fears have eased as oil prices have fallen, and many speculators who sold copper futures in anticipation of a further decline bought back those contracts Tuesday after signs of trade buying surfaced, analysts said. ``People started thinking the slowdown might not be as bad as formerly thought and demand for copper might not be as adversely impacted,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. Analysts said buying interest also was fueled by the London Metal Exchange's weekly report on warehouse stocks of copper, which showed an unexpectedly large decline of 5,075 metric tons to 192,424. The rise in prices triggered large-scale buying by speculative funds whose trading decisions are based on computerized analysis of price charts and other market information, analysts said. Platinum futures rose sharply for the fifth straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Like copper, platinum prices fell dramatically when recession fears were on the rise. In addition to a letup in recession worries, ``some people are thinking that with oil prices breaking like they have recently, we could see some moderation of interest rates, which might be supportive,'' said William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch. Platinum settled $9.90 to $10.10 higher with October at $422.40 a troy ounce. On the Commodity Exchange, gold futures ended $1.50 to $1.60 higher with October at $371.20 a troy ounce; silver was 2.4 cents to 2.5 cents higher with October at $4.219 a troy ounce. Near-term crude oil futures remained below $30 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The selling was prompted in part by the release of 14 Americans in Iraq, prompting further speculation that a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis is near. Futures prices of refined products finished broadly mixed with near-term deliveries up sharply after Monday's dramatic plunge in gasoline and heating oil. Light sweet crude oil futures settled $1.04 lower to 72 cents higher with December at $29.37 a barrel; heating oil was 3.83 cents lower to 5.08 cents higher with November at 81.06 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3.13 cents lower to 3.4 cents higher with November at 79.90 cents a gallon. Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late, technicaly inspired rally that helped boost corn prices. Wheat futures finished narrowly mixed. Soybean futures bounced back after the November contract failed to penetrate a three-week low of $6.05 a bushel. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with December at $2.63 a bushel; corn was } cent to 1{ cents higher with December at $2.31{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1} cents lower with December at $1.24 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 8 cents higher with November at $6.14 a bushel. Strong cash markets took precedence over Monday's bearish government cattle-on-feed report to lift most cattle futures prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The buying interest spilled over into pork complex, which also drew support from a bullish government report on frozen pork-belly stocks. Live cattle futures settled .10 cent lower to .57 cent higher with December at 77.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .43 cent higher with October at 87.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .45 cent higher with December at 54.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .85 cent to 1.23 cents higher with February at 66.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Holds Administration Bailout on Short Leash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf: ``Rep. Frank,'' to CORRECT spelling Annunzio sted Annuzio. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House Banking Committee voted Tuesday to trim the Bush administration's request for as much as $57 billion more for the savings and loan bailout to $10 billion. Both Democrats and Republicans on the panel suggested that Congress should deny more money for the bailout in view of President Bush's assertion a year ago that ``never again'' would taxpayers be tapped for it and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's refusal to testify why that has changed. But warned by regulators the bailout's total costs might swell another $250 million to $300 million in the next three months without the funds, the committee approved just enough money to keep the program going through February. The approval, by voice vote, sets a spending ceiling for money that must be provided in a separate appropriations bill. Administration officials had warned for months the $50 billion that Bush sought and got from Congress a year ago would not be enough, and Brady suggested over the summer another $40 billion to $80 billion might be needed. However, the administration never submitted a formal request for the money until Brady wrote the chthe 11th hour subjected to the old squeeze play.'' The committee's chairman, Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, said further money to keep the bailout going beyond February will not occur ``until Secretary Brady and other officials of the administration appear in full-dress oversight hearings.'' Gonzalez said he had a commitment from House leaders to speed the short-term bill to the House floor, where it was expected to pass with little debate. Congressional and administration sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said they do not expect the Senate Banking Committee's bill to ever get a vote. Instead, they said, the Senate is expected to attach the House version to another bill, possibly one toughening penalties for S&L fraud, through a parliamentary maneuver that would allow senators to avoid a recorded roll-call vote on the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Infotechnology Inc. Sued by Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: Infotechnology Inc., which owns 47 percent of Financial News Network, was sued Tuesday by shareholders, who claimed executives issued false and misleading information about the companies' finances. The suit filed in Manhattan's federal court represents all persons and entities who bought Infotech stock between Sept. 28, 1989, and Oct. 1, when both FNN and Infotech announced they were unable to meet a deadline for completing financial statements for the fiscal year that ended June 30. The lawsuit said the price of Infotech stock fell to $3 on Oct. 1 from its previous close of $5.75. ``Had plaintiff and the members of the class known of the materially adverse information not disclosed by defendants, they would not have purchased Infotech common stock at the artificially inflated prices that were paid,'' the lawsuit said. In its Oct. 1 announcement, FNN said it was seeking an extension for filing a financial statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission because of a dispute with auditors involving the company's investment in FNN:PRO, a video news and information market service for professional investors. FNN said the dispute could lead to a bank loan default and a ``very substantial non-cash loss'' for the fourth quarter, according to the lawsuit. Infotech announced it also was seeking an extension because it needed FNN's completed statement to complete its own. The company also said was considering restructuring $20 million in loans, which were secured by its shares in FNN. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Employees Gain Majority Ownership in Textile Company
DOC.TEXT: The 26,000 employees and managers of Burlington Industries have acquired a majority ownership and voting control of the textile giant, the company said Tuesday. ``Burlington is now the largest manufacturing company in the United States controlled by its employees and management,'' said Frank S. Greenberg, Burlington's chairman and chief executive officer. The company established an employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP, last year. The transaction announced Tuesday gave employees and management all of the voting stock and 51 percent of the company's common equity. The transaction changes the ownership status of the financial investors that helped Burlington repel a hostile takeover attempt in 1987 by Asher Edelman and Dominion Textile of Canada. The investors were The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and its affiliates, Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Bankers Trust New York Corporation. Morgan Stanley and Bankers Trust, which purchased 62 percent of Burlington's common equity in 1987, reduced their ownership to 43 percent when the Burlington ESOP was created last year. They have further reduced their common equity stake to 13 percent. Equitable has retained its original investment, and its common equity has increased proportionately to 36 percent from 24 percent as a result of the transaction, the company said. Equitable also continues to hold a significant amount of Burlington's subordinated debt. As part of the change, Burlington's board of directors will be enlarged. Representatives of Burlington management will comprise a majority of the board to reflect the increased ownership of management and employees. Burlington is one of the world's largest makers of textiles for apparel, home furnishings and industrial products. It has 51 manufacturing plants in nine states, Canada and Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Industry Consortium Unveils ``Open'' Software
DOC.TEXT: A consortium of leading computer companies oncluding IBM and Digital Equipment Corp. unveiled a computer software system Tuesday they say will make it vastly easier to connect various brands of computers. The group, called the Open Software Foundation, announced the release of its first operating system, or the base layer of software that controls a computer's internal functions. By agreeing to offer the same operating system on some or all of their computers, the OSF members hope to answer pleas from computer users that different brands and types of computers work together more easily. The computer industry is overburdened with operating systems, some unique to one brand of computer, others tied to specific computer chips. But there is no single operating system that can be used on every computer in the market. That means applications software, such as a word-processing program, designed for one type of computer usually cannot be used on another type of computer. This often forces computer users to buy or write different programs for each type of machine they own. ``Many of our customers have told us that open systems is what they want and what they expect,'' said Jack Kuehler, president of International Business Machines Corp. Kuehler, as well as executives of Digital, Hewlett-Packard Co., France's Groupe Bull, Simens-Nixdorf Information Systems of Germany and Japan's Hitachi Ltd., said at an OSF news conference that their companies would offer the consortium's operating system as an option on a number of models. But however noble the OSF's goals, its formation was sparked by a less magnanimous reason - an industry battle over control of Unix, a popular operating system that is the core of OSF's new software. Unix was developed 21 years ago by American Telephone & Telegraph Co., but other companies later devised incompatible versions of it. OSF, a non-profit group based in Cambridge, Mass., was founded two years ago by a group of AT&T competitors after they became concerned that the phone and computer company was trying to retain control of Unix development rather than allow it to evolve into industry standard. In response to OSF, AT&T formed a rival industry group called Unix International Inc., which includes the nation's third-largest computer maker, Unisys Corp., as well as Data General Corp. and Sun Microsystems Inc., which is 20 percent owned by AT&T. The split over Unix obscures the future of OSF's operating system. OSF and AT&T's Unix operations said last November they were discussing a merger to end their division. But the talks broke off in April after the two sides apparently could not agree on a plan to make Unix development independent of any manufacturer.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Returns to Profitability, But Earnings Fall at Control Data, Tandy
DOC.TEXT: Wang Laboratories Inc. said Tuesday it returned to profitability in its most-recent quarter, but two other computer makers, Control Data Corp. and Tandy Corp., said their earnings slipped. Wang said it earned $2.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $62.1 million, or 38 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue in the period, which is Wang's first fiscal quarter, totaled $571.5 million, down from $604.8 million a year earlier. ``Given an extremely difficult industry situation and an adverse economic environment, we are pleased with these results as further evidence that our turnaround programs are working,'' said Richard W. Miller, chairman and chief executive officer of the Lowell, Mass.-based company. Wang has been attempting to pull out of a slump that has caused it to report a string of quarterly losses. ``During the (most recent) quarter, the company achieved another important milestone by totally eliminating debt to its bank group,'' he said. ``This debt was $575 million in August 1989, and it is zero today.'' Wang said it recorded a gain of $11.8 million during the quarter from the transfer of an interest in a real estate subsidiary in Brussels, Belgium. Control Data Corp. said it earned $8.5 million, or 20 cents a share, in the third quarter, down 13.2 percent from $9.8 million, or 23 cents a share, in 1989's third quarter. Revenue fell 43 percent to $434.1 million, from $763 million. Last year's third-quarter results included revenue and earnings from Imprimis, a disk drive subsidiary that since has been sold, and a pre-tax restructuring gain of $8.5 million, the company said. The Bloomington, Minn.-based company will take ``decisive steps'' in the fourth quarter to deal with problems at its energy management and automated wagering operations, according to a statement from Lawrence Perlman, president and chief executive officer. Empros, the energy management division, is faced with cost overruns on fixed-priced contracts, said Nancy Foltz, a company spokeswoman. The automated wagering unit is considering a write-off in connection with the suspension in the United Kingdom of a betting game operated by one of its customers, Foltz said. Control Data did not estimate the size of a potential write-off or say how much the overruns at Empros will cost. The effects ``could be substantial in relation to earnings generated by the rest of the company's operations,'' the company said. For the first nine months of the year, Control Data said it earned $26.5 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with a loss of $484 million, or $11.51 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue totaled $1.26 billion, down from $2.41 billion. Tandy said it earned $52.2 million, or 65 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $62.8 million, or 73 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue at the Fort Worth, Texas, company totaled $1.09 billion, up 11 percent over $986 million in the same period last year, which is Tandy's first fiscal quarter. Tandy, a computer manufacturer and operator of the Radio Shack electronics stores, blamed the lower earnings on price cuts of its products. ``Given the uncertain retail environment in the wake of the Middle East crisis, we began to clear Radio Shack's inventories of certain discontinued consumer items and computer models prior to the holiday selling season,'' said John V. Roach, chairman and chief executive. ``Clearance sales of these discontinued items were strong and negatively influenced gross margin and earnings,'' he said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Reports Record Revenues
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. on Tuesday reported record sales, revenue and net income for the 102nd consecutive quarter, citing sound business fundamentals amid a slackening economy. For the third quarter ended Sept. 30, net income was $242.2 million, or 67 cents a share, compared to $217.9 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. Systemwide sales were $4.99 billion, compared to $4.6 billion a year ago, while total revenues were $1.8 billion, compared to $1.6 billion a year ago. Michael R. Quinlan, chairman and chief executive officer of McDonald's, said 1990 will be another good year for the company despite a weakening U.S. economy. ``The fundamentals of our business remain sound and we will meet investor expectations for this quarter and for the year,'' he said. During the third quarter, McDonald's passed the 3,000 restaurant milestone in international growth, said James R. Cantalupo, president and chief operating officer. ``With new opportunities in Eastern Europe and the USSR, and the acceleration of profitability in other markets, Europe has become important to the growth strategy of McDonald's,'' he said. A total of 317 outlets were added in the first nine months of 1990, including 159 outside the United States. An additional 342 restaurants were under construction as of Sept. 30, including 163 outside the United States. For the first nine months of 1990, McDonald's had net income of $616.1 million or $1.69 a share, up from $555.6 million or $1.49 a share in the 1989 period. Revenues increased to $5.05 billion vs. $4.56 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: AAA Reports Smallest Gas Price Increase In Four Weeks
With AM-Gulf-Gasoline Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The average price of a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded gas went up a tenth of a cent in the last week, the smallest increase in four weeks, the American Automobile Association reported Tuesday. A gallon of regular unleaded went for an average of $1.38, up from $1.379 last week. AAA's record price is $1.388, logged the weekend before Easter 1981. Since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the average price of gas nationwide has gone up 30.5 cents per gallon, according to AAA. The largest price increase was in New England. Largest decreases came in the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic regions.

DOC.HEAD: Salomon, Morgan Stanley Post Lower Third Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Lower revenues from investment banking cut into profits at Salomon Inc. and Morgan Stanley Group Inc., which reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings Tuesday.

Salomon's profit fell 55.4 percent to $79 million, or 55 cents a share, on revenues of 2.57 billion. That compares to a profit in the same period a year ago of $177 million, or $1.28 a share, on revenues of $2.62 billion. Salomon's results include a $200 million pre-tax charge for reducing the size of its Philipp Brothers commodities unit. Without the special charge, the company would have earned $201 million, or $1.62 a share, for the quarter. Salomon's investment banking revenue fell $44 million to $114 million in the third quarter. For the nine months that ended Sept. 30, Salomon's net income declined 21 percent to $318 million, or $2.32 a share. That compares with $402 million, or $2.82 a share, in 1989. The company's nine-month revenue was up 8 percent to $7.01 billion from $6.49 billion last year.

Morgan Stanley's third quarter earnings dropped 28.8 percent to $71.9 million, or $1.82 per share, on revenues of $1.54 billion. The company earned $101.1 million, or $2.54 a share, on revenues of 1.48 billion in 1989. Morgan Stanley's investment banking revenue fell to $176 million from $192 million in the third quarter of 1989. Over the nine months, Morgan Stanley's net income fell 28 percent to $212 million, or $5.33 a share, compared to $294 million, or $7.40 a share, in the same period last year. The company's nine-month revenues increased 4 percent to $4.39 billion from $4.24 billion. In 1989, Morgan Stanley had a pre-tax gain of $56.2 million from the restructuring of Burlington Holdings Inc. during the third quarter. In addition, its nine-month 1989 earnings were boosted by a $51.5 gain from the restructuring of investments in Essex Group Inc. and the Silgan Corporation.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Walloped Some in Third Quarter, Helped Others
DOC.TEXT: Three of the largest oil companies blamed Persian Gulf turmoil Tuesday for depressing third-quarter earnings, while another said the resulting oil-price jump gave it mixed results and two more said profits rose five-fold. The decreased earnings reported by Mobil Corp., Shell Oil Co. and Sun Co. and the mixed performance by Texaco Inc. contradicted what they called the popular belief that big oil companies have cynically exploited the spectacular jump in crude prices stemming from Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``It is ironic that at the time the public perceived the oil industry was profiteering and price gouging, our oil products business lost $64 million in net income in the two months following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait,'' said Shell President Frank H. Richardson. Conversely, Amerada Hess Corp. profited immensely from trading in oil-price futures, and Diamond Shamrock Inc. benefited from a major revaluation of its crude oil and refined product inventories, which rose enormously in value because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Oil prices went from about $21 a barrel before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait to as high as $41 on a U.S.-led embargo of Iraqi crude and fears that a war would disrupt supplies from a crucial production region. At the same time, prices for gasoline and other refined products shot up, but not nearly as much as crude. This means companies primarily involved in extracting petroleum or speculating in petroleum have done well. But companies heavily reliant on the ``downstream'' refining end of the business have been hurt because they've had to absorb some of the higher crude costs without passing them on to consumers.

Mobil earned $379 million or 89 cents a share in the three months ended Sept. 30, down 29 percent from the $532 million or $1.30 a share earned a year earlier. Third-quarter revenue totaled $16.31 billion vs. $13.46 billion, a 21.2 percent increase. ``During the third quarter of 1990, results in our marketing and refining operations declined substantially, reflecting our inability to recover the rapid run-up in crude oil and purchased product costs,'' Mobil Chairman Allen E. Murray said. The company, based in Fairfax, Va., said it earned $5 million on marketing and refining operations in the third quarter, vs. $366 million a year earlier. In the United States, marketing and refining operations ended the quarter with a $22 million loss. For the nine month period, Mobil earned $1.28 billion or $3.02 a share, down 5.8 percent from the $1.36 billion or $3.32 a share earned in the comparable 1989 period. Nine-month revenues totaled $45.16 billion vs. $41.52 billion, an 8.8 percent increase.
DOC.HEAD: Texaco Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Texaco, based in suburban White Plains, N.Y., said it earned $381 million or $1.38 a share in the third quarter, up 25 percent from $305 million or $1.10 a share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $10.95 billion vs. $8.36 billion, up 31 percent. James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive, said the results showed that Texaco's exploration and drilling businesses did well from the oil-price jump but much of that gain was blunted by lower profit margins on refined gasoline and petrochemical products. For the nine months, Texaco earned $1.06 billion or $3.78 a share, down from $2.13 billion or $8.19 a share a year earlier when earnings were inflated by a large one-time gain from the sale of its Canadian subsidiary. Nine-month revenues totaled $28.83 billion vs. $26.41 billion, up 9.2 percent.

Shell, based in Houston and one of the largest gasoline marketers in the United States, earned $227 million in the third quarter, down 33 percent from $340 million a year earlier. The company is the U.S. affiliate of Royal Dutch Shell Group and does not report per-share results. Third-quarter revenues totaled $6.21 billion vs. $5.40 billion, up 17 percent. For the nine months, Shell earned $590 million, down 48 percent from $1.14 billion a year earlier. Nine-month revenues totaled $17.13 billion vs. $16.44 billion, up 4.2 percent.

Sun, based in Radnor, Pa., earned $25 million or 24 cents a share in the third quarter, down 71 percent from $85 million or 80 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $3.35 billion vs. $2.73 billion, up 23 percent. For the nine months, Sun earned $211 million or $1.97 a share on revenues of $106.98 billion, vs. earnings of 271 million or $2.54 a share on revenues of $106.84 billion a year earlier.

New York-based Amerada Hess earned $280 million or $3.46 a share in the third quarter, vs. $51.8 million or 64 cents a share a year earlier, with much of the gain coming from petroleum futures trading. Third-quarter revenues totaled $1.75 billion vs. $1.18 billion. For the nine months, Amerada earned $247.50 million or $3.06 a share, down from $405.50 million or $4.99 a share a year earlier. Nine-month revenues totaled $4.65 billion vs.$4.14 billion.

San Antonio-based Diamond Shamrock said it earned $53.2 million or $2.15 a share in the third quarter, vs. $10.1 million or 35 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $725 million vs. $517 million. For the nine months, Diamond Shamrock earned $69.7 million or $2.72 a share, vs. $51.9 million or $1.93 a share a year earlier. Revenues totaled $1.88 billion vs. $1.53 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Sells Video Rights to Time Warner Arm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after second graf pvs, The deal . . ., to UPDATE with MGM board extending deadline to Friday; PICKUP third graf pvs, In buying . . .
DOC.TEXT: Warner Bros. will pay $125 million for video rights to many MGM-UA films, with the money helping to fund Pathe Communications Corp.'s buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co., the companies announced Tuesday. The deal puts into place another piece of the complex sale of MGM-UA to Pathe, headed by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. The MGM-UA board voted on Tuesday to extend the deadline for the sale's closing to Friday. ``There are no snags and no problems,'' company spokeswoman Mary Hardy said. Included in the Warner Bros. purchase are more than 1,000 United Artists titles, 650 Cannon releases, about 40 MGM films made after 1986 and about a dozen Pathe films. In buying the video rights, Warner Bros., an arm of Time Warner Inc., said it will drop a $100 million lawsuit it had filed against Pathe June 29 following an attempt by Warner Bros. to help finance Pathe's purchase of MGM-UA. On Monday, Pathe and MGM-UA announced that Pathe had delivered the $967 million balance of the $1.3 billion purchase price. The new enterprise already sold English-language television rights for nearly 1,000 MGM-UA films to Turner Broadcasting System Inc. on Sunday. That transaction was valued at a reported $200 million. Beverly Hills-based Pathe is a film producer with a variety of movie-related holdings in Europe. As part of the transaction, MGM-UA will buy for $700 million the bulk of Pathe's assets. That $700 million is being raised in part through the Warner Bros. and Turner transactions. Of the remaining $1.3 billion purchase price, $600 million came from a private sale of stock in the new company, mostly from European concerns affiliated with Giancarlo Parretti, Pathe's majority owner. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said details of the stock sale would be revealed in Securities and Exchange Commission filings later this week. He did not identify the new investors, but said Pathe would maintain a majority interest in the new company. It remains unclear what will be left of MGM-UA when Pathe takes control of the historic studio as early as Friday. Over the last two decades, MGM-UA majority owner Kirk Kerkorian has parceled off many of the company's assets, including almost all rights to older MGM movie titles and the MGM studio real estate itself. At the very least, Pathe will still control domestic theatrical rights to the combined studios' films and MGM-UA's television arm, which makes ``thirtysomething'' and other shows. Wall Street analysts have said it will take at least $500 million in capital expenditures over several years to revive MGM-UA. In Tuesday's 12{-year deal with Warner Bros., the companies said Time Warner will receive worldwide video rights to the libraries of MGM, UA, Pathe and Cannon. Cannon was bought by Pathe last year. In addition, Warner Bros.' home video arm will have worldwide rights to 11 current and upcoming Pathe releases. They include ``Quigley Down Under,'' ``The Russia House,'' ``Shattered,'' ``Not Without My Daughter'' and ``Thelma and Louise,'' among others.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson & Johnson Reports 18.5 Percent Increase In Third Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Johnson & Johnson's earnings for the third quarter rose 18.5 percent, in part because of the weaker dollar, the pharmaceutical company said Tuesday. For the third quarter, earnings were $314 million, or 94 cents per share, up from $265 million, or 80 cents per share during the same period in 1989. Sales for the quarter increased 17.1 percent to $2.87 billion from $2.45 billion last year. More than half of the pharmaceutical and health care giant's revenues are generated abroad, with international sales accounting for $1.47 billion of total worldwide sales, said Ralph S. Larson, chairman and chief executive officer. International sales, from which Johnson & Johnson generates more than 50 percent of its revenues, increased 22.1 percent during the third quarter. The weaker dollar increased third quarter sales by 5.3 percent, the company said. Earnings for the first nine months of 1990 rose 3.6 percent to $911, or $2.73 per share, compared with $879 million, or $2.64 per share, in the same period in 1989. Sales for the first three quarters of 1990 were $8.53 billion, a 17.1 percent increase from 1989 figure of $7.29 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Food Parent's Net Up 88 Pct
DOC.TEXT: Castle & Cooke Inc., Dole Food Co.'s parent company, said Tuesday that earnings rose 88 percent, with the opening of markets in Eastern Europe increasing demand for fresh fruit and vegetables. ``Our food business is reporting record profits,'' Chief Executive David H. Murdock said in a statement. ``As a low-cost producer, we are well positioned to take advantage of the increased worldwide demand for fresh produce.'' Castle & Cooke is in the process of trying to sell Dole, which dominates the worldwide production and distribution of fresh produce, to concentrate on its other business, real estate. Several big international food companies are reported to have considered buying Dole. Castle & Cooke said its third-quarter profits were $44 million, or 74 cents per share, on revenue of $879 million. That compares with the 1989 third quarter's profit of $23.4 million, or 39 cents per share, on revenue of $762 million. Profits would have been higher except for a $12.6 million after-tax charge from Dole giving up on pineapple production on the Hawaiian island of Lanai. Castle & Cooke said in September it would switch to more diversified agriculture and begin developing resort hotels on the island. The first part of that development is a 102-room English country manor-styled hotel, The Lodge at Koele.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Lawyers Prepared Chapter 11 Filing For Continental, Board Split
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with report that company considered Chapter 11, transition; PICKUP second graf pvs, The board . . .
DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE HOUSTON
DOC.TEXT: A team of lawyers spent the weekend preparing a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing for Continental Airlines, but the carrier's board is split on how to deal with its financial troubles, according to a published report. In its early Wednesday edition, The New York Times quotes an attorney, who spoke on condition of anonymity, as saying the papers were ready to be filed in bankruptcy court Monday morning. The airline denied the report. ``The company has no intention of filing for bankruptcy protection,'' said Art Kent, a spokesman for Continental. Continental suffered losses during the normally busy summer travel season and has been hurt by higher fuel prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the newspaper said. Frank Lorenzo, who recently stepped down as chairman of Continental but remains on the board, opposes a Chapter 11 filing by the airline, the Times said. Also, Jan Carlzon, chairman of Scandavian Airlines System, which owns 16.8 percent of Continental stock, opposes filing for bankruptcy, the newspaper quoted the lawyer as saying. A filing would reduce the value of SAS's holdings. The newspaper said it was not clear which board members support filing for bankruptcy protection. On Tuesday, Continental said it has moved to cut costs by restructuring its senior management team, cutting five top executives. The board of directors for the Houston-based airline approved the restructuring plan on Monday. ``With radically higher fuel costs, Continental must become a stronger competitor in the global marketplace,'' said Hollis Harris, Continental's chairman and chief executive officer. ``We have reaffirmed our intention to become a preferred airline among frequent travelers around the world.'' Harris was given the additional role of president, replacing Mickey Foret, who is leaving the company to pursue other interests, officials said. Also leaving the carrier will be Neal Neehan, senior vice president-customer services; Clark Omstad, senior vice president-properties and government affairs; Jim Arpey, senior vice president-aircraft programs; and Elliott Seiden, vice president and associate general counsel for Continental Airlines Holdings, Inc. Continental named Thomas Kalil senior vice president-customer service and announced Lewis Jordan, executive vice president and system general manager, was given the additional responsibility for managing the company's international division. ``These actions position Continental with a lean and efficient management structure that reflects the realities of operating during this fuel crisis,'' Harris said.
